All the challenge in this game is anti-fun. A great example is how they don't tell you the name or effects of an item before you pick it up, meaning you are forced to play at a massive disadvantage until you spam-play this game enough to know what everything does. Add in the "challenge" is 99.99% item stat checks, and this game struggles to find an identity since it requires the knowledge and time investment of a serious competitive game while offering the control and mechanics of a casual mobile game. Overall, not worth the time.

It's very easy to pick up, but provides a decent challenge to master. There are a lot of items, and you can memorize most of their effects if you want (which I did) but if that's not your thing, the game provides a short description whenever you pick one up (that doesn't interrupt gameplay). The quantity of items does provide a fair amount of freshness to each run, but it can get pretty stale after a while.

I didn't think I'd like it because I'm not super into shooter games, but the stylized graphics make it a little less violent. I've heard from others that the soundtrack is repetitive and headache-inducing, but I really like it.

Overall, I give it a 9/10, definately would recommend.

I mean the game is like easy 3D, no physics. There are no really depth in build, strong build are OFTEN the same and you'll try to mixup the same items on all characters to get damage.

But the biggest mistake for me is the bugs and gamedesign. Opening a chest that drop an item in the void, respawning after falling on the ground out of the safe area (so respawning 1 HP and dying), having the pink medusa pathing throught almost impossible obstacles. And the RNG of the chests is absurd, I did a run where litteraly 15 chests spawn in a pack but the medusa went at 2km from that position. It's weird and not fun, almost look like spaghetti code. 

I think the devs should pull out the fingers out of their ass, they get the money, now it's time to polish your EA game. Because yeah, for me, it's still an early acess.

I've never (I think?) written a game review, but playing this game makes me feel like I have to say something. 

BAD: The game isn't hard. It's not hard at all. It's actually really easy. It just scales absurdly at every boss fight. You'll die dozens of times because you don't know what killed you - every single time. You'll be doing just fine, but then suddenly something will just be absurdly powerful, and you won't know how to deal with it, and you'll die. You'll probably never know how to deal with it, unless you go read the wiki - and, sorry but, any game that REQUIRES you to go read a wiki on the game is a failure of delivery. 

Yes: ultimately, it's a roguelike, so it always depends on having A) a lucky run, and B) enough unlocks to win the game. But don't call the game hard, if it's just going to kill you unfairly. Hard games are hard because they require a honing of some skill set. This game doesn't have that. It has hundreds of random things happening at once, and your character is just sort of jumping around shooting at stuff, hoping that you don't have all your health drained suddenly by you'll-never-know-what (it tells you at the end of the round what enemy killed you, but even after watching recordings of my runs, I can almost never make sense of what causes my health to deplete suddenly). 

GOOD: The character variety is really great. Each character plays very differently, and the technical skill behind is character is unique. Those technical skills are learned quickly, so the learning curve isn't steep at all (again, it's NOT a hard game). It's just too bad that it's overshadowed by all the chaotic nonsense and literal randomness of this game.

The music is really excellent.

One of the staples of the roguelike genre and for good reason. The first few hours of the game are brutal as there is no tutorial and there's an overwhelming amount of items and enemy abilities to learn. However, as you start to pick up on what each item does and how they interact with each other, you will start to know which items to look for and prioritize. As you get better at understanding how to counter each enemy and the optimal builds for each survivor, you get an unparalleled sense of satisfaction as you get better and better runs. The difficulty of the game is one of its charms as the unforgiving RNG nature of drops makes each run a unique challenge. The most rewarding feeling is when all the variables line up in your favor and you cruise through the end of a run melting everything on your screen that killed you in previous runs.

The feathered enemies aren't quite as fun to attack as they are in Serious Sam games, but it's still pretty ok and above average for a decent amount of time.  Solo only perspective as of this review.  Worth it.

This game in very dumb terms is like a 3D Binding of Isaac for its loot choices, without restricting movement. I would even compare its maneuverability with something like DOOM, a game that punishes you for sitting still or not continuously moving correctly. The array of loot leaves the player with a different experience every time you play, and this is something that makes the game truly replay-able to the death.

PS: Mods are so damn good at making an imported character from another franchise look and feel as themselves. It sets up an example for many titles to appreciate and admire- how a game can be loved for itself and the ability to be modified for a more personal experience. 

I hope to see more titles be as challenging yet still alluring as Risk of Rain 2 made itself to be.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded Narkara and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Charles White Jr.[4] (born August 2, 1994), better known as Cr1TiKaL (pronounced "critical"), is an American YouTuber and Twitch streamer. Best known for his commentary videos on YouTube—as well as his live streams on Twitch, where he most often streams gaming content—his content is distinguishable for his monotone voice and deadpan delivery of comedic commentary.[5] In addition, White is a co-founder and co-owner of esports organization Moist Esports and co-founder and member of musical duo The Gentle Men.

As of August 2022, White's YouTube channel has gained over 5.6 billion video views and over 11.2 million subscribers, averaging 151.4 million views per month on the platform;[6] his Twitch channel has gained over 4.3 million followers and over 59.3 million views.[7][8]

An amazing game, you can tell so much love and time was put into the game. Not a single bug that I've run into so far. I normally don't enjoy replay factors in video games when it comes to trying out the game with multiple different characters. But this game is different for some reason. The varying game play from character to character in this game, makes the whole game feel completely different with each play-through. Not to mention the fact that because it is a rouge-like, every play-through is already a different enough experience to begin with. The procedurally generated worlds are beautiful, and work great with the art style that the developers chose. Stellar game, 10/10, would recommend to anyone.

This will be the only game ever that I will willingly throw money at anytime they release dlc.

Once you learn the rich history behind that song in relation to the first game and the developmental journey of this games early access It just gets better and better.

Risk of Rain 2 is a no-holds-barred Roguelike (note: NOT a Rougelite); it does not pull its punches, it forces you to make choices within tight constraints, and it often will put you up against odds and obstacles that seem insurmountable.

You're plopped unceremoniously onto an alien planet in an escape pod, environment so wide open or vertical that your running speed and basic single-jump seem comical in how insignificant they are to deal with the game world. You're expected to try and find a teleporter, a stone structure with a pair of horn-like prongs, to reach the next level - but doing so summons a boss monster that has a suitably massive scale as well. Said boss can manifest in the first level as: a beetle queen that summons forth more bugs and coats the ground in acid (in my opinion the easiest possibility), a massive stone golem that can punch you from the ground and fires a perfect-accuracy eye-beam at you intermittently, and a floating jellyfish that lobs electric balls at you rapidly, and - most dangerously - charges a massive shockwave that you have to either find cover from or escape, once it reaches low health (that or outdamage it). It's a rougelike, of course, so there's no guarantee that where the boss appears will have the cover structures any other game probably would provide you to escape such attacks.

So you might think the way to deal with all this unequivocally is to gather power for your character - find more items, get money to buy or repair them, and only challenge the boss once you have the tools necessary to beat them. Well, there's a problem with devoting yourself to that: every few minutes, enemies will passively get stronger as well, And based on what difficulty level you're playing on, that can scale up either faster or slower over time. Now while early-on you'll usually be able to passively level yourself up to boost your own health and damage to match your enemies, this quickly also becomes infeasible, because whereas your ability to gain EXP effectively falls off at around level 20 or so, the enemies' levels exponentially increase as you progress, towering into the 60-70 range around an hour into a game. You will need some way to either offset that power disparity, or go fast enough to avoid it altogether - [b]Or Else You Will Die.[/b]

It also isn't helped by the fact that while the map geometry is usually static (memorizing the layouts of places like Titan Plains or Distant Roost helps a bit), the placement of items and devices are not, and of course the offerings are randomized as well. Your character might need something that grants them a bit more movement speed, for example, but all you end up rolling is box after box of cautious slug or war banner, and you just have to, you know, deal with it. There are also some devices that can convert your items into different items for a bit more control, but of course there's no guarantee that those will show up in a level, and using most of them has a waiting period, meaning even considering to use a 3d printer or disposal will eat into your time limit more.

So it's altogether a puzzle with pieces that don't fit together: huge environments with limited mobility, power-increasing items that conflict with a tight time limit, and oftentimes enemy formations that don't have obvious answers or tactics for how you're supposed to deal with them. That's what I mean by Roguelike; those elements will clash and be rolled up from scratch, and you'll just have to deal with them.

If that sounds like a good time to you, then this game is perfect, all the more power to you. 

However, if it's not, Hopoo has been quite gracious to give us options to counteract some of this. Aside from the basic difficulty setting, there's layers of secrets that can be found and explored in this game, most notably series of tile codes that can be input to a strange portal base on Sky Meadow to complete Artifact Challenges. Now while most of them are detrimental or will make your game harder, there is a few that can be leveraged to reduce randomization - the Artifact of Command (with a code that is, comparatively, hiding in plain sight even), makes the game's build progression feel less like [i]Binding of Isaac[/i] (which, even then, that game didn't have a strict time limit!) and more like [i]Vampire Survivors[/i], where now each time you gain items, you are granted choices of what you can add onto yourself. Some will say this "trivializes" the game, but I don't care, I'm glad it exists, it has its own drawbacks (the game cannot pause while you try to decide and there's no way to discard items that might now be detrimental), and very few things that aren't cosmetic are locked strictly behind actual difficulty settings.

Most of my all-out misgivings have to do with the environment's size and scale, which I feel the [i]worst[/i] in the Commencement level; cool each time I want to attempt to unequivocally "beat" the game with a character, I have to do a 1-2 minute run-up a ramp, do some pillar stuff and platforming, then become a pancake. Aside from that, it's ok; the visuals are gorgeous, and the music is banging.

"Does Risk of rain gameplay Even translate properly to 3d" i hear you ask. You bet it does.... after having played RoR2 im actually just amazed it worked in 2d, as it seems like it was born for 3d! RoR2 is in IMO superior to its predecessor in any way.

For the newbies: Risk of rain and its sequel Risk of rain 2 are essentially your "run of the mill" roguelike. 
There are some unlockable character and loadouts, but there are no real powerups between gameplays, so you cant powercreep yourself to a win, you have to keep playing till you get it done propper! The "unique" thing for Risk of rain, is its time mechanics. The game gets harder, not based on the level, but on the time spent in the current playthrough. For the first 10 minutes or so its on easy difficulty, 20 minutes i  and it goes to hard, 40 minutes in and you get the ominous dificulty "i see you". You have to balance completing a level as fast as possible, with completing as many powerups as possible. There are 4 playable characters from the get go, and you can unlock some 8 Additional characters or so. So far the difference in playstyle between characters has been very satisfying. 
If you want a chaotic "bullethell" 3rd person shooter, or just need a New Roguelike to master, RoR2 might be one of the best games the genrer has to offer right now.

risk of rain is a game i would HEAVILY suggest more so with friends. but even alone it has lots of repeatability one downside its not a game if your short on time sense even short runs can go on for nearly 45 minutes but even so the many challenges and deep lore of the game are also a plus there always multiple ways to play one character. a good example is the huntress she can attack while sprinting you can go for damage with her first single shot primary or equip her other one two split it into 3 arrows which are better with status effects almost every character has alternatives and that's before really going into items and builds with each character. like with huntress secondary can shoot 6 arrows with a crit meaning a crit build is amazing with it. loader is amazing with speed meaning a speed build is viable sense a good number of her attacks deal more damge when she moving faster. i will say isn't anything no one else its said and there is a good amount of learning in it too and when grabbing more of something is pointless. like some items get less benefit from each grab like the teddy-bear you still get a increase but less and less each time or others that are pointless to grab after a point such as the crit glasses are pointless to grab after 10 sense at 10 crit glasses you have a 100% to crit and grabbing more is pointless. if your reading this trying to find a point to buy its a game with a lot of things to figure out such as how items work and in my opinion playing with friends makes it 10x more fun sense playing alone i find tend to need like a video or something in the background. i know my voice is just one of TONS but again if you need a reason to buy i personally would give it a try it and see for yourself your not gonna really understand the game reading reviews.

Dang. There's so much I want to express, but will try and be brief. With other roguelikes, my main issue is that I feel like I don't make any progress in the long term after failing a run. It can feel almost entirely dependent on RNG - where enemies spawn, what items are dropped, and when you can find the thing that progresses you in that one run. I can 40 minutes on feel like I have nothing to show for it. I haven't felt any of that with Risk Of Rain 2. Did I die? Maybe I earned an achievement that unlocked another item to pickup. Or maybe I learned that I shouldn't touch this shrine if I'm particularly weak. Or learned more about how two or three items work together. There's the occasional cheap "what the hell just killed me" deaths. But the vast majority of deaths felt epic and educational. So, over long term, I feel like I'm growing and unlocking more stuff, instead of just hoping for a good run. Character abilities and the way they can synergize with items can make or break some runs. I'm slowly growing an intuition towards which items to get.

That's just talking about the long term with this game. Actually playing is such a treat. I've had tons of fun with most of the characters, finding two favorites. There's an emphasis on always running and always shooting if an enemy is in sight. The gameplay can be frenetic, which is great for how easy it is to pick up. 

As a roguelike, I appreciate that there's a little more control over the items that you can amass on a run. If I wanted more of another item, I could shred another, or could choose specific items to purchase towards a build I was working on. I feel like Risk of Rain 2 nails this - allowing a knowledgeable player to create awesome builds. And that's gotta be my favorite thing about this game - that you have to put in the work to create a god build, but once you're there, it feels amazing.

I just finished beating my first final boss on Monsoon difficulty, and now want to try the other modes and modifiers I hear about - like Eclipse runs and Artifacts. It feels awesome to know a game will reward your time if you want to invest it.

I first started playing Risk of Rain 2 after a friend gifted me a copy so that we could try out the multiplayer, and I think it's safe to say that I didn't expect that I would get as obsessed with the game as I did. Honestly, even after everything has been unlocked and all of the environments have been seen multiple times, it's still so ridiculously fun to revisit Petrichor V, whether I do it by myself or with a friend. Although my favorite survivor is Artificer, every survivor is enjoyable to play as in their own way. The environments are beautiful, the music is amazing, and the lore is incredibly fascinating. The combat is also really satisfying, though the enemy scaling can be frustrating at times; I've lost some really good runs to simple mistakes and enemies dealing unexpected amounts of damage out of the blue, but it honestly makes the victories all the more satisfying.

As far as my multiplayer experience goes, harder gamemodes like eclipse will absolutely test the patience of you and your teammates. It can be incredibly frustrating to die on the final stage and leave your teammates to complete the entire escape sequence by themselves, but strategizing with my friends about item distribution and seeing our collective efforts pay off has been really satisfying for me.

Altogether, whether you have someone to play the game with or just want something to try on your own time, I couldn't recommend Risk of Rain 2 more strongly.

Absolutely insane. I've personally never played a game like this and I never played RoR1 so I'm pretty new to the genre. BUT holy shit is this game fun. A friend of mine introduced me to this game and insisted a group of friends play it. I was kind of all over the place at first and it does take a while to learn all of the different items and such. It gets easier as you go and it is not by any means hard enough to deter people from playing. The map designs are decent as well. None of them are linear and they are all special in their own way. The endless phases and waves become more stressful than you would like to think but in the most fun way possible. As someone who is absolutely in love with instrumental prog rock and similar music the soundtrack in this game is beyond words. The music that flows through your ears while you're spraying your way through hundreds of badass looking, well designed enemies is spine chilling. It hypes you up, it gets you ready to visit your next underground heavy rock or metal venue and bang your mf head. As a person passionate about music, the music in this game ALONE is worth the purchase. The game is designed to be replayed so the replay value is high. I myself found that it gets very slightly repetitive if I'm sitting here playing the game for hours and only this game but the differing buffs (items) per run and random levels make it much easier to get around the repetition. There are so many different builds with enough variation of characters (Each one has their own abilities and weapon type! There are also unlockable ones you get by doing different things while playing) that it stays relatively fresh. Some people may enjoy playing alone but I personally have a harder time playing alone. It's so much better with friends. All in all it's an absolutely wonderful game with decent level design, beautiful and unique art, amazing music, and a good time. At the very least buy the soundtrack, especially if you're into music like Intervals, Polyphia, Nick Johnston, etc.

The game is mostly fun.  But is has some absolutely glaring balance issues.  The strongest status damage in the game is something normally only found on enemies, and it can virtually one-shot the player out of nowhere.  There's no big telegraph, you get hit with stray fire, you take the status on, and if it was an enemy with a lot of base damage, you die.  This basically means you cannot take damage at all and must play perfectly or you will have your whole run ended in an instant.

The last boss also has a design that I absolutely despise.  I hate the last boss enough that the rest of the game could be flawless and I'd still uninstall it.  There is a boss phase where it just takes all of your hard earned items and leaves you practically defenseless, and there is no counter play.  There is nothing to stop it.  And the icing on the cake?  It gets to use all those items against you now.  Get lucky with a really strong set of gear?  Maybe playing with command and have an absolutely OP build?  Now the boss has it, and gets to pummel you with your own good fortune and grinding.  It's like being punished for playing instead of speed running.

I'm not sure I could imagine a worse boss for a game than this.  I loved the first ROR, but I'm not sure I can trust these devs anymore.

To say i'm not usually a fan of rogue likes is an understatement, games like enter the gungeon, hades, rogue legacy and various mobile and flash games that use the rogue like and rogue lite titles have never enthralled me very much.

This game however, has; in fact it is one of the few games that I have attempted to 100% and enjoyed the entire process to. The game feels fantastic and can captivate for hours a session, the only experience I can compare it to is some certain specific starcraft 2 arcade games that me and my friends have sunk multiple 2-3 hour runs into, reaching levels of enemy spawns and damage numbers that cause our pc's to slow and lag (which is something that ROR2 thankfully avoids outside of some exceptionally long runs and intended fuckery. Music, character's, graphics, and aesthetics are all 10/10's. Most items feel useful or viable outside of a handful of notable examples and the game is both rewarding and engaging. To give it the highest honor possible I actually purchased the dlc for this game which is something I almost never do (plus owning the dlc allows your friends to access it's contents barring the unlockable characters). I've honestly tried to find a flaw for this game to include in this review and I can't think of any. Though I praise it endlessly it may not be for everyone and a decent pc is needed to enjoy it. otherwise if your ever interested or even curious about the game it tends to remain quite cheap and goes on sale quite often with the dlc bundled for only a handful of dollars more.

in short 10/10 would buy again.

In this review I hope to analyze where most roguelikes fail, and how Risk of Rain 2 overcomes (even partially) these blunders. With over 130 hours in the game I find myself somewhat qualified, but I've seen the game played in depth more than enough to make a qualified statement on RoR2. 

To start off, many roguelikes allow the difficulty scaling to overwhelm even the most experienced of players.
-RoR2 also has a steep learning curve when it comes to difficulty scaling, but with the option of multiple different difficulties to choose from, it leaves the power in the hands of the player. This is something that I find particularly good for new players, because as much as experienced players will talk down on playing anything other than monsoon, we all know that a good drizzle run for a few hours can be just as fun, and if nothing else, great for new players to gain experience without being totally destroyed.
-Once one gets past the learning curve, they may find themself still "stuck" to an extent when they reach a certain point. 
RoR2 deals with this in an excellent way, because since scaling comes from item collection, the player is once again given the power to decide. One can decide (if their run isn't going the best or they just want a power spike) to pick up lunar items that cost a different currency than main chests. Lunar items can progress runs or end them just by the nature of their abilities, which makes them super fun, kinda like a glass cannon. Obviously the lunar coins you buy lunar items with are hard to come by, but any experienced RoR2 player knows a little way to get lunar coins *wink*. 

The next problem one finds in roguelikes is that you find yourself with a false sense of security at a point.
RoR2 is no different in this nature, because as someone who's been one shot 100s of times on double digit stages, I get it. 
-The items that RoR2 gives to combat this are pretty effective though. Anything from shields that can nullify damage as a whole to revives that give the player a second chance can be found as an item, which while not completely nullifying one shots, makes the game seem much more fair at a point.

Another problem you can find in close to any roguelike game is that there is usually one primary strategy that dominates runs. 
-The great thing about RoR2 is that 
1) Some strategies are better than other but all builds can scale to rival each other in power, and
2) Each survivor has their own kit, and some items suit one character better than another.
In this way, RoR2 has some of the best diversity in runs, and overall amazing replayability. Even if one masters a character, theres still infinite ways to play that character again, and the same can be said about the other characters in the game. At the time of writing there is 14 playable characters, and while some kits blend with others, the playstyle of each character varies significantly.
Therefore, RoR2's items, characters, and the overall nature of the game make it replayable for as long as one wants. 
The possibilities are truly endless, no run is the same.

Finally, the last major problem that plagues the roguelike community is that many times, there isn't much of a way to avoiding/escaping combat. 
Think about it, many games have the players as sluggish characters with nearly impossible to dodge enemies. While RoR2 does keep the player handicapped at the beginning of any run with no mobility for most characters, any good run ends with flying across the map, a typical feature of any run. Along with this, RoR2 gives the player many i-frames in a lot of survivor abilities, which makes dodging attacks quite an easy task.

While most of the things I analyzed above were positive, I should share some constructive criticism, because no game is perfect.
In my opinion, the time it takes to get to Mythrix by doing the pillars takes way too long, which is a shame because an obliteration is by no means as fun as a great boss fight, but most runs it seems like obliteration is much easier. If the pillar steps took less time up, Mythrix would be the most satisfying boss fight in the roguelike scene.
Other than that, there are up to 11 unique areas with 8 mains maps to be cycled through, (13 and 9 with the DLC) which can make runs significantly more boring as play count goes up. Along with total bosses in the game (13) combat can get a little stale, but a simple increase of maps and/or bosses would be a great improvement to replayability!

tl;dr: Get the game, most replayable roguelike and ultimately prevails where others fail.

The timed difficulty increases can make it quite challenging at first, but I found that after getting better at the game it is quite a nice edition. The characters are quite diverse and found it enjoyable getting all of them, however the same cannot always be said about unlocking the alternate versions of some abilities. Particularly, the alternate abilities for one of the starting characters the commando requires you to complete 20 stages in a single run of the game, and another one of his requires you to kill a very challenging boss. If you are a completionist, some of these achievements may be a bit of a burden, but I think that the pros out weigh the cons heavily with this game.

Risk of Rain 2 offers a great experience to be had with friends, serving as a perfect fit for those quick sessions you and your party can jump right into.  First off, the visuals are beautiful, going for that simplistic, aesthetically pleasing design.  The soundtrack is pretty rad too.  The difficulty of this game is handled mostly well, offering easy-to-understand controls for players to get accustomed to, but can become painstakingly difficult as you progress, which is fine!  In my experiences, Monsoon (Hard Mode) required me to completely change up the pattern of my play style.  The process of trial and error was fun for me to develop, however what it boiled down to was [spoiler]play solo, starting on stage 5 onward, immediately run to the teleporter, start it asap, and evade all enemies while chipping at the boss hoping no elites happen to spawn nearby.[/spoiler]  That's what worked for me, I'm sure more seasoned players have better strategies, however it transitioned from being a fun time to more of a chore.  For Monsoon, it felt like less of a skill issue and more of a luck thing + required less engaging tactics.  Aside from difficulty [i]which is chosen at the player's will[/i], each run will have the players acquiring a variety of unique items, allowing them to go nuts with stacking attributes like speed, homing missiles, and chaining attacks.  Each character plays pretty different from one another, so try and find your favorites.  Finally, the major unlockables you can work towards besides new characters are their alternate abilities and mastery skin.  These rewards range from fairly straightforward to more advanced.  These are great little challenges that increase a player's skill and give them a new reward to try out.  To me, this game manages to have good replayability while not hosting an overwhelming amount of content to unlock.

Risk of Rain 2 delivers entertaining game sessions for solo or group play, looks stunning with its use of colors & effects, provides plenty of variety while also maintaining a beginner friendly introduction, and has a minute amount of challenges that will surely keep players hooked for quite a while.

This game is pretty fun to play, personally I think it is better and also easier to get Achievements if you have more than 1 player. I would recommend starting on Drizzle and working your way up. If you are even somewhat of an achievement hunter like me, I would focus on getting one Achievement at a time, preferably ones that are simple. As you get these Achievements you will unlock Gear that you will receive when you open a chest, and if you accomplish a feat for a character you will also unlock an alternate ability for that character. There are also other characters to unlock. 

I recently unlocked all the Achievements for this game, it was a fun ride. Sometimes it could be frustrating, but that is like any game. Sometimes you will have no idea about how you died. But stick to it, keep going and it will get easier, as you unlock new characters, abilities, and Gear. I would recommend getting the Survivors of the Void, as you will need it for unlocking all Achievements, plus some of the Gear from the DLC also helps.

Lastly, I found this to be a very enjoyable game. Go get it!

Before ror2, i was a nobody. I was lonely, helpless, broke, and at the worst point of my life. My wife left me, took the kids, and made me pay child support or i'd get sent behind bars. I had no money and was constantly looking for outlets of my despair such as alcohol and drugs. But on this one fateful day; i had booted up my PC for the last time to say goodbye to my anime waifu desktop wallpaper, who had been by my side the whole time, but instead i decided to open up steam, looking for a game to play before my wifi and electricity cut out. That decision was single-handedly the most important decision i have ever made, changing the course of my life as i knew it. I looked around for a game to spend my final $20 on, and i found it. Risk of Rain 2. it seemed like a good game to play before i succumbed to the darkness around me. I played it, beat the final boss on Drizzle and my mind suddenly burst. It was like a thousand pounds were being lifted off my shoulders, as i realized my true purpose in life. To play ror2. At that moment i had the knowledge, strength, and willpower of a thousand men and women by my side. My life did a 180 as soon as i had seen that game over screen. I picked myself up and got my feet together. I found meaning in myself and had the courage to get my life back together. I started an e-business centered on helping young people who were in the same situation as me get their lives back together through the power of Risk of Rain 2, which has gained a massive following and has caused my money to skyrocket. Now I am living the good life, in a nice mansion off the coast of California, with a beautiful wife and a pair of kids who I will love forever. To this day I still make my students and I take daily recitals and prayers to Hopoo games in eternal gratitude for what it has done to me and my friends.

I've been reflecting lately on why some roguelites click with me and some don't.  It's not enough to say whether the game is good or not.  I've bounced off of many massively popular games like Enter the Gungeon, Dead Cells, Spelunky, etc.  Those are undeniably good games, but I couldn't get into them properly.  I tried many times.  They just never clicked.  So what's different between them and games like Binding of Isaac and Slay the Spire; games that have taken over my life at different times?

I think more than anything else the answer for me is excitement over the possibilities of the run.  EtG and Dead Cells are fantastic action games, but runs feel more or less the same.  Maybe you get a new item and it changes your playstyle a bit.  Maybe you get a strong build and you complete the run.  But for the most part, you know what to expect.  You have a couple of items/weapons equipped, they may have some synergy, they may be strong, but that's it.

Then look at BoI.  Because there is no limit on the number of items equipped, and because all items affect all other items and effects stack, you can get absolute god runs, and you can get antisynergistic nightmares.  Anything and everything is possible.  And because of the sheer amount of different items in the game, it's tough to force certain builds.  You never know what you're going to come across.  And that's where the excitement comes from.  What complete nonsense is going to happen on that next run?

I've only put a few hours into Risk of Rain 2, and already I know I'm going to put hundreds of hours into this game, at least.  The game is good, of course.  I could list all the reasons why the game is good, but much more importantly for me, the game is exciting.  It clicks with me.  It gives me the same sense of wonder about the next run that BoI does.  The god runs that nearly break the game, and the duds.  What's the next run going to be?

If anything I'm saying is resonating with you, buy RoR2.  Don't wait for a sale.  It's easily worth the asking price.

It's fantastic. It feels like a game from a bygone era, but with the quality of life improvements of something modern. Singleplayer without having to be online, private multiplayer, tons of secrets, including areas and unlocks, and unlocking new characters and skills are rewarding without being too difficult. It's a game that you can pick up and play for 15-20 minutes, or for 6 hours straight, and it's not as difficult as one would expect from a rogue-like. I slept on this game for too long, don't do the same.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

personally i have reason to believe this is the most overrated game on steam so here's why:

- little to no content in terms of stage variety, literally every stage is just a different colour pallet with one minor unique thing being either pools, drops into the void or tall trees, none of them stand out or feel any different from the last if you play the game the only thing you might pick out from a certain stage is that you can do a certain thing to unlock a certain character, item or ending and if you've already done that once then the stage loses any and all significance, just another enemy kill and chest cycling run
- boring gameplay loop, spawn on different coloured stage, kill same enemies on every single stage, fight enemies to get money because it resets every stage so you're basically just running around fighting solely because your money resets so you can open chests and then when you open chests you just scrap all the items you dont want and then find a printer that dispenses an item that gives you damage or crit, depending on what you want to stack & then just use all the scrap to stack that singular item for a "build", then you activate teleporter kill boss, collect anything you didnt then go to the next stage, nothing changes, there's no gameplay modifiers aside from artifacts or anything that feels like it changes as you go through a stage
- bosses are just big enemies rather than bosses, they even spawn in with normal enemies whilst you fight them - to add to how unimpactful they actually are you can make it so multiple of them can spawn and it barely changes anything, for comparison in Isaac & Gungeon if you added more bosses you would feel the difficulty because the fight is more personal and bosses are more of a threat
- your weapons and abilities do not change when you pick up items so you're essentially stuck with a singular set of 4 abilities than you spam non-stop when they come off of CD for an hour if not more... the game is so character dependent its painful and if there isn't a character that feels fun and matches your playstyle you simply won't enjoy playing the game, all other roguelikes have items etc that alter your attacks & how they function allowing you to create crazy attacks and do nutty almost gamebreaking things, the only gamebreaking cool combos that you can pull off in this game is either infinite healing or insane burst both of which are extremely bland and dont make for a particularly good experience
- the DLC gives you one character that you actually have unlocked for buying the DLC and the other one is locked and you have to play to earn it aside from that it actually adds a single bonus stage for stage 1, 2 and 3, all of which don't feel any different from the base game stages!
- the only drive the game gives you to unlock anything is the fact that the base characters you get are extremely boring and basic and dont have any burst in their kits meaning that if you want to kind of build other than high attack speed with either crit chance, item proc or debuff you literally can't so you kinda are like forced to go damn i want to unlock these other characters... personally i couldn't be asked to do that because i played mostly with friends so there's no point in joining their runs just to cripple them by forcing them to give me stuff or just being crippled and useless so i just modded my save file and even after playing and having a go with most of the characters it all just feels the same
- the games story isn't really explained aside from in lore tidbits that you'd have to read in your own time, so its not very interesting imo
- it looks colourful and nice and its optimised really well which is a saving grace i guess
- other than that enemy design is all fairly uninspired and boring in my opinion, lizards, mushrooms & constructs made of metal, stone or clay and they either smash the ground or fire a projectile at you, they all die the same and feel the same, the most unique enemy in the game is the slime because it splits on death and considering every single roguelike has a slime that splits on death i think it highlights how boring the enemies are
- difficulty doesn't scale with the stage but rather time which makes absolutely 0 sense considering your money resets every stage so spending more time to get more money and collect things works against you in a way which is absurd, its like getting punished for exploring the stage and making sure you've used all the resources the game gives you and yes you can say "play faster idiot" but having your money reset every stage so you can keep getting into these fights over and over again just so you can start the snowball of chest opening is boring and it wastes time only for the game to bump the difficulty regardless, SO if you open all these chests and get nothing of value you can essentially softlock yourself into a loss because you "wasted time" when in reality the game just wasted it for you

there's a whole bunch more i could list on why this game is overrated and extremely bland in comparison to other roguelikes & roguelites on the market but if you've played a lot of games in those genres you'd probably understand why i feel the way i do about this game

At the time of writing this I have owned the game on both PC and console and I love it! Its great way to kill time letting hours fade away as you grow stronger and stronger, unlock new character and loot and meet better bosses. Its a great solo game but oh god does the fun only get better with a mate or two, and with the unique modifiers you can add at the start each run will amaze you and offer a new experience.

So all in all one of the best games like this out there, I would highly recommend this to anyone who loves a good challenge or casual gamer alike.

It's hard for me to find anything necessarily wrong with this game, it offers so much for such a simple game, plenty of exploration, level to level progression and an emphasis on getting stronger and finding better gear, an absolutely banger soundtrack (Sky meadow is the best I will fight) Plenty of character choices and variety for the characters too, though unlocking some of them can be a pain, I even thought some impossible at first, the longer I played, the more I realized it was too hard at all, I went from starting off barely able to even get to stage 5 on the default difficulty to now doing monsoon and modded runs to up the difficulty, there's a huge emphasis on improving how you play, your awareness and everything, and I've enjoyed every second of this silly game I've played, there's also a TONNNN of logs and information and even lore you can read up on, I continually come back for a run or 2 each day and even you can play with friends, 100% worth all it's merits, just a banger game overall, plus you can use mods and add like dbz or TF2 characters or something lmao.

Addictive, challenging and fun. This offers an experience both unique enough and similar to it's predecessor that both can be played and enjoyed in their own ways. The potential for insane builds, hidden unlocks, uniqueness of characters and simple to learn gameplay loop leads to a pretty addicting experience. The coop only increases the fun further. One issue I have are the length of runs can feel pretty slow at times, especially if you just want to get a quick game in. This can sometimes be worsened by the "One more run" effect but you can determine if that sounds bad. Another is the initial style of drops, i.e. random drops doesn't feel like the best way to play the game. There are relics that let you tweak this, including choosing your drops to really customize your build. This feels more like the way the game is intended to be played, which is odd to not start with. There are also missing QoL features like a description of items when viewing them in menus. Like a tooltip or something

This game looks really boring and dumb, and I didn't think I'd ever try it until I was convinced to give it a shot. To sum things up, it is an amazing, immersive, and satisfying game that I don't think anyone explaining it could give justice to just how good it is, which is why I so strongly recommend just to play it and see for yourself.

Like I said, I can't give it true justice, but I'll try. Relatively big learning curve, but learning the mechanics is fun in itself. Every survivor/character offers a completely different playstyle and there is 100% chance there's at least one you will like. The items you receive, usually due to RNG, make every run even more different. One run you might get insane items that let you two shot every boss, another run you might get thrown tons of single stat boosts like speed and let you traverse an entire map in less than three seconds. If you still can't find a survivor you like, the game offers even MORE versatility and lets you switch around their core abilities to somewhat similar ones after unlocking them. The game is insanely hard. Obviously, there are easier modes, but the harder ones literally make me want to pound my keyboard, but somehow in a good way. Even after dying in a really good run, I don't lose motivation to play like I would after dying in Minecraft with good loot. I just get more determined to play again, because the game is just fun at its core. And oh, the MUSIC. Music is impeccable. The final stage music gives me chills and actually gets me in a massive weight on my shoulders, final boss type of mood, which is amazing (Like I said, IMMERSIVENESS!). Finally, the lore. The lore isn't shoved in your face, you don't need to know any of it to understand the game, which I really liked. As I played, some really bizarre things were going on that I asked questions about, which is cool that there is a bit of unknown in the game that I don't have to explore if I don't want to. 

I've been sad because video games seem to be less fun for me now. Risk of Rain 2 blew my socks off and lets me have great videogame experiences, ones that I haven't had in a very long time.

Risk of Rain 2 is one of those games that I think I could have loved if I found it before I started having to worry about paying bills. The combat is exciting and fluid, the soundtrack is quite good, and the sound design is incredible. There are a bunch of different characters to choose from and the game seems to have a lot of depth, which can be especially rewarding for reflective players who adapt on the fly to subpar conditions. On paper, this game is right up my alley.

I bought this game expecting a punishing but fun experience: something I could look forward to improving at after a long day at work. Get in a couple runs before bed, make mental notes of what to change in my game plan after every loss. All good, right? In reality, I boot up the game and my mind starts churning.

[i]What am I doing with my life?
Why am I trying to get good at this game?
What's the point?
Grandpa's dead. Grandma's dying. My dog is covered in graying fur and lipomas.
I miss my sisters. My friendships aren't what they used to be.
You know, when you think about it, our time on this planet is so short. Wait, am I still playing this game?[/i]

And I stare at the little khaki-colored character on the screen, whose smooth light-toned helmet is just a little too similar in shade and shape to a sad, bald head. I watch as this strangely melancholic little man sprints and scoots around, alone, watch as he desperately searches for a way out. Time's ticking.

I won't leave a bad review for this game. It has all the makings of a great indie title. But for me, this game consistently leaves me full of existential dread. Maybe it's the time factor, maybe it's the muted (but tasteful) color palette, maybe it's the large and mostly empty landscapes. Or maybe it's just the Commando's helmet. That darned thing reminds me of elderly men who've lost their hair, lost their families, etc etc. Whatever it is, it makes playing this game a real bummer.

I'll keep playing this game in the near future; maybe something will click and I'll start loving it like I know a younger me would have. But in the meantime, I'm gonna go pet my dog and tell my sisters I love them.

This game is insane. You don't need me to tell you it's good, just look at all the reviews. It speaks for itself. I have never played a video game that keeps me coming back long after I think I'm done with it. I have probably a combined total of 200+ hours between Switch, PS4 and PC, and feel it's time to write my thoughts.

Risk of Rain 2 is perfectly fine-tuned sheer chaos. The game is designed for you to get so powerful you destroy the game itself, to the point you're standing there motionless eliminating every enemy on the map, until you get one-shotted by a fucking Elder Lemurian. Maybe next time you'll beat the final boss. Even then, the game is far from over.

On your way to that point though, every run has a purpose. New items dropped into the pool of available ones become available by completing missions in the game, and each level has secrets, and there are entire freaking secret LEVELS that are only hinted at through item descriptions. They took the sense of wonder from a metroidvania or open world game, and crammed it into a high-intensity action roguelike. I still find myself in awe of what this team of 2 people hid around a corner, and how they could create an artistic product that is never not fun or interesting. I really just don't get it. 

The characters each feel like a completely different game. You got a blink sister with homing arrows, Spider woman with a big punch, a Cowboy with backstab crits, a turret builder (go bungus), Wall-E if he were made for warfare, Mr. bomb-drop guy, floating fire and ice caster, and some absolutely sick new characters with the DLC. They each breathe new life into the game and feel like you're picking up something that's brand new.

It's high in my list of top 5 games ever made and it has become my palate cleanser, my comfort game when no others are quite doing something special. The new DLC is totally sick too, and completely changes aspects of the game I thought of as "static." This game just doesn't stop surprising.

[h1]Risk of Rain 2 is rogue like game with rarely seen feature like difficulty scalling with time.[/h1]
[b]About the gameplay:[/b] You landed on unfamillar planet and you are trying to escape by using items found on chests simultaneously fighting (or avoid) various enemies and bosses. The game ends when you successful escape from planet or you died (I don't tell about secrets ending)
In first runs you will propably early die, but you will get achievements, aka new drop items from chests, multishops; new characters and skills for them to use in future runs.
Graphics is minimalist, but is eye-friendly
Best feature is possibility to play with your friends (or strangers if you don't have).
And if you are fan of maxings you'll spend a lot of time to complete various achievememts
Don't forget about eclipse mode. If you think monsoon is easy, here you can check youself.
My favourite part of this game is when you are overpower on late stages. These a lot of objectails shooted from monsters and from you causing small lags. (If game lags, you are OP)
Of course you can add various mods, E.g. new characters, somes gameplay changes and more.
                                       [b][u]Pros: [/u][list]
 [*]challenging difficulty scalling with time
 [*]11 uniques survivors (playable characters) (+1 is secret and +2 is from DLC)
 [*]over 50 types of monsters (enemies)
 [*]over 15 bosses (including secrets ones)
 [*]148 items differing in rarity and 38 equipment (with DLC)
 [*]Multiplayer support
 [*]a lot to do if you are trying get 100%
 [*]a lot of environments with randomly generated chests and teleporters and small,but with significant changes E.g some doors is closed, but next time is actally opened
[*]Doesn't weigh much on the disk
[*]Mods support[/list][/b]
[b]   [u]                                 Cons:[/u][list]
[*] I don't found it   [/list] [/b]
In ending:
If you are rogue like fan, this is [b]MUST-HAVE[/b] for you
If you aren't still you won't be dissapointed

The game is good, but,  when it comes to multiplayer, it has some significant flaws that can make it a real drag to play with other people over. This was a real deal-breaker for me since I bought it to play with friends and acquaintances.

Specifically, the looting in the game is often a race between you and your teammates to see who gets busted and who becomes irrelevant as the game moves forward. All loot is available to all players, and if you're playing with people you know this might not seem like a huge issue, but as anyone who's familiar with RPGs will know, having to do the accounting on loot to keep everyone balanced is a drag but neglecting it simply ends up having one person farther ahead than everyone else too.

And, upon dying, you snowball into total irrelevancy and quite quickly lose the ability to catch back up - one death you can come back from, though not easy, but two is run-ending for you - even if your team eventually wins, it won't be fun as you'll basically just be along for the ride. This is especially brutal since runs can last hours while you're unable to meaningfully impact the game any longer.

In my personal opinion, the game desperately needs something akin to loot instancing like what most ARPGs have long since grown accustomed to. If you are only looking to play this with friends and not on your own time solo, then I suggest perhaps rethinking it. I know I should have, it wasn't correct to make this purchase for me, and I hope this can help others avoid making the same mistake as I did.

If you think that this isn't much of an issue for you to worry about, and you like everything else on the box, then the game is probably a great pickup. It just sadly isn't something I can *personally* recommend.

good:
-progression
-mechanics
-gunplay
-movement
-character design
-bosses
-emphasises achievement collection
-difficulty
-freedom to play the game in different ways
-music (holy fuck is it good)
-story/lore
-multiplayer
-item design
-character balance
-continual updates from devs (including new characters, achievements, stages and items)
-unofficial mod support
and the dlc is good too

bad:
-updates are decently spaced out (1st dlc came out 2 years after launch, but some larger free updates were in between)
-two artifacts (modifiers for your runs) completely trivialise getting all achievements (which includes completing the game on the highest difficulty on each character)
-multiplayer relies heavily on each player not taking all the items for themselves
-after getting all achievements, the only thing left to do is the eclipse runs, which are absurdly hard and require you to beat the final boss on each of the 13 characters 8 times (>100 runs)

overall an easy 10/10

One of the best roguelikes in gaming, hours upon hours of fun to spend mixing and matching a huge swath of items with different characters, as well as challenging yourself in a variety of ways with Artifacts. There are also mods which are really easy to install to extend the gameplay and add lots of QoL features.
It's also an amazing multiplayer game, i've never had a single issue with the game outside of mods, save for the update when they added crossplay with Epic users, in which you an only play with other Epic users, not Steam users. Otherwise, multiplayer is perfect.
Next, the music is phenomenally great, absolute bangers from Chris Christodolou. Although a heads up, if you're looking for the tracks on YouTube, they're not named by where they play in game, it'll be annoying to figure out which ones are which. And if you want to listen to Void Fields without that speech which doesnt occur in game, Chris has linked it in the description. It's unlisted, so you cant search it, and no one else I heard of has uploaded the speechless version.
For the achievement hunters, be wary of this one particularly difficult one: Ethereal. For what you get out of it, I think it's a downgrade of one of your best skills, but the condition to require it is exceedingly difficult: taking absolutely no damage during a prismatic trial. it will take you extremely long to get, because you essentially need the perfect conditions for a run

Risk of Rain 2 can be fun, but the experience it offers is as inconsistent as its framerate. You, or someone you play with, [i]will[/i] die in less than two seconds and have no idea why. The recently deceased will be saddled with a heinously punishing gear disadvantage, dooming them for the rest of the run. They'll die again at the start of the next stage, then sit in spectator mode doing absolutely nothing until the run ends, or the next stage starts the cycle over. 

If you mention this online, the prevailing wisdom you get from the community is to install a bunch of mods and avoid using half of the characters. I guess those are options, but the game has had the same problems for three years. You'd think the studio would have implemented optional revives, catch-up mechanics or item sharing by now.

This is one of the best games I've played. The idea of starting out normally but get items to become godlike and destroy anybody in your path is amazing. The characters have there abilities and weapons which you can unlock more abilities by getting certain achievements for that character, it's such a cool idea. This game is very addictive and fun but the best thing is that it's so re playable. No character is "bad", you just have to play them right. Artifacts are a great way to play your game differently whether you make it easier or harder. It's not to hard to unlock them either. The multiplayer function is great to. whether it be with friends or with randoms, you can always play with somebody. And not only that, if you think your too good for the game there is the eclipse game mode which really test your skill by giving de-buffs every time you beat the game. I can't really say anything bad about this game exept for the occasional 6 BURNING which shreds your health. Dam you Grandparent. This is a repetitive  rogue like which is my opinion a perfect match. I hope somebody reads this so they can play it too. 10/10

I'm a bit nitpicky when it comes to what constitutes a roguelike, but despite being full 3D and realtime I've got no hesitation in calling RoR2 a proper Roguelike - and a good one.

Shoot, chop and kite through literal hordes of angry aliens, trying to keep up with the ever growing difficulty curve. Randomised items that do things like make enemies explode on death, arc lightning off your targets, summon a giant beetle monster to guard you, or more regular bonuses like boosts to attack speed and critical rate.

Graphically it's a glorious saturated, stylised extravaganza of colours and explosions and effects. Each map has it's own distinct theme and are often as high as they are wide, with you climbing cliffs and giant spiraling tree branches while defending yourself.

The sound effects are distinctive without being annoying, clearly allowing you to identify them, and the mastering is done well. Most of the player's tools and weapons also sound good, and the thoonk of the Engineer's grenade is engraved into my brain by now.

Gameplay wise it's simple - the longer a run goes on the tougher enemies get, and the more likely it becomes to see elites and even some bosses start cropping up regularly. You need to balance finding and buying items, killing enemies to get XP and coins, and getting to the next stage before too many difficulty levels have gone by. 
There are some environmental puzzles and exploration is encouraged - you need to find the exit portal the hard way unless you happen to have an item that can ping interactables on the map.

The game keeps you on your toes every run. Despite being overwhelming by nature the combat feels fair - even when the difficulty level hits truly ludicrous levels of one-shot bullet hell, you've powered up to fire missiles every third shot and set everything on fire while every enemy killed spawns daggers that home in on nearby enemies, while triple jumping through the air and moving three times base speed.

Soundtrack's good as well, a good accompaniment to both the quiet moments of wandering towards the next chest and the more frenetic periods of combat.

Overall, highly recommend, play with a friend but good for solo.

As a lover of Roguelikes I have to say Risk of Rain 2 is perfect. It's tough yet rewarding. Simple yet complex. Each character feels smooth and is perfect depending on how you play. 

The game is hard as nails at times. Sometimes it feels bullshit especially if your going blind into the game. But once you figure out how to play and you find a character that fits you. You'll be able to play for hours

The game times can stretch to an hour (Timer when I beat the final boss) or more (Runs can loop infinitely) So it isn't great if you just wanna pick up and play for a bit. But even then if you have the time it's perfect.

The multiplayer is fun and even better if you have friends. Just try not to piss each other off or no one will have fun

Absolutely amazing game. Always a fun experience and the music is a stellar compliment to the gameplay.

The game runs smoothly once loaded even on low end PC. FPS count gets very high compared to other games. If you die (or when) it boots up quickly, and voila, you are instantly back in the game. Whole user experience is very well thought out. Only the initial loading takes some time, even from a SSD. In singleplayer there is also pause option that comes handy with children in the house.. You can get your ROR2 fix easily during the day, which can not be said of many other games. 

The game itself is more addictive than most abusable substances. 

Agility of most characters is so fluent and so much is happening on the screen at once with vivid colors it is like you are getting overload of information that is totally enjoable. It is power fantasy driven action but you can and will die a lot. Once dead, you have to start from the beginning like good old days. 

The game is short and you can play it through in one sitting, which I have done, with friends or alone. Of course the game is more nice to play with friends, but it's totally cool to play this title alone also. It gets repetitive but IMHO it is not boring but every second good time, except when game over hits...

Get it. You will not regret. I recommend for old school gamers because the difficulty can be ramped up very high. I recommend for people with kids, this is quick gaming fix you need. For others see gameplay videos from youtube etc, and decide for yourself. This is my 3rd favourite timesink, first being Fortnite and second Valheim.

6/10 for Multiplayer,
7.5/10 for Singleplayer.

The BAD
1. Same problem as Binding of Isaac: no tooltips for items under many conditions. I don't get the design philosophy behind it. It forces you to alt-tab 1000 times until you have the items memorized. It's annoying in Singleplayer, and f-ing annoying in Multiplayer. Speaking of which...
2. Multiplayer doesn't really work. The ideal and boring way would be to boost one person to infinity and perhaps have some others get support utility. yaaaawn. Further complicated by the fact the you cannot trade items. "hey I found this, u need it?" "sure, let me run 3 minutes over the whole map". speaking of which...
3. Scale and Downtime. The maps are "too large", or more specifically, traversing them takes waaaay too long. That brings me to downtime. This game is too fast when it shouldn't be (item choices and so on in Simulacrum or multiplayer in general without a pause function. Also, collecting boxes and charging the portal when you burst the boss down. Stand there for 3 more minutes doing little to nothing. How fun.), and too slow when it shouldn't be (why is the final boss not the final boss, but being tired of running forward for 5 minutes straight? It may motivate you to go for movement items in singleplayer, which is already annoying, but in multiplayer most people will end up holding W while the rest of the party is already done completing all tasks and waiting at the boss area). It dampens the fun in subsequent runs. Speaking of which...
4. Replayability is so-so. Although I am certainly wrong on this, it feels like there is little new to discover after reaching the first final boss. It's not really inciting to go for specific character builds if you have little to no influence on which items you are offered. The cryptic character unlock conditions don't help. I wish they were more clear. Speaking of which...
5. There is more, like bugged magma worms or enemies in general, especially in multiplayer, that end up going to heaven and out of your reach, but points 1-4 cover the gist of it imo. So far, so good. Speaking of which...

The GOOD:
Smooth gameplay, items can be clearly distinguished, stages are different, characters feel different enough

Overall, I think this game is worth picking up on sale for Singleplayer. I reckon it's more for people who heavily enjoy Warframe, but also like games like Hades or, of course, the original Risk of Rain. I found it too same-y and empty, with some unnecessary design decisions. While the core gameplay can be more fun than Binding of Isaac, picking up items is too much of a hassle. The decision whether you should go for the next level or search a couple more boxes while the difficulty increases with time is not one that I found particularly interesting.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game is great. Enough of a skill cap to keep you interested, a ton of unlocks and stuff to do, and multiplayer keep this game fun for a very long time (if that wasn't obvious). Below I'm gonna go into some areas of note, so expect a lot of text.

BASIC GAMEPLAY: The transition to 3 dimensions from 2 was done very well from the first game. Traversing the map, kiting enemies, even returning items feel similar but with more depth, which is great. Most of the survivors and their abilities all work well together and mix up playstyles well enough. The items are fun to play into the strengths of, but that kind of falters towards late game (I'll talk about that later). The basic dynamic of finding the teleporter and getting to the next level is comfortably simple, and the scaling difficulty puts enough nuance onto it that you can play fast or take your time depending on your preferences. Overall, it's very easy to understand and has enough depth to keep it interesting for a while.

GAME BALANCE: I have issues with how ROR2 is balanced vs ROR1. In the first game, your items meant a whole lot more. Since you couldn't manipulate them and simply got what you got (on top of less items generally), you really had to work with what you got, and the high enemy TTK's reflected that to make a difficult but very fun experience. ROR2 feels too transfixed on the "god run". It's not as concerned about player/enemy dynamics, and more concerned with getting you enough items to kill enemies faster than they can attack. Likewise, enemies are balanced around this to kill you faster than you can kill them if you don't dodge properly. This makes gameplay a lot less interesting later on because enemy differences become a product of the size of their healthbars, where enemies simply become something that will one-shot you if you dont one-shot it first. This also means you never end up taking less useful and more interesting items because they don't simply make you do more damage. When was the last time you ever used squid polyp or warbanner to lock down an area and play more defensively? It's probably never, because its better 100% of the time to simply turn them into crit and ATG. Because you find so many items, you end up mostly getting every item in the game if you go late, except for the bad ones which you've scrapped and printed into better ones because why wouldn't you? This results in most runs feeling the same, which is a shame because I really enjoyed runs in the first game where you would find items like desk plant or barbed wire and be forced to play around them because they're just the tools you have. This is my main problem with the game though, so don't let it sway your opinion too much, as it only really comes into play past a couple hundred hours.

STUFF TO DO: This game does a great job of using unlocks to keep you interested. Achievements are out of the way enough to mix up your gameplay early on, with some being really good ways to teach the player (I loved unlocking soulbound catalyst by finding different newt altars for example). On top of that logs are a fun way to add to the 100% of the game, even if some (voidling) seem to never drop. Hidden realms are another awesome extra in the game that are cool to discover at first, and fun to revisit in later runs. Artifacts and eclipse also provide (mostly) fun modifiers to your runs to shake it up a bit once you've gotten better at the game.

ARTIFACT OF COMMAND: They should have never brought this back. Artifact of command allows you to pick your items, effectively breaking the gameplay loop and turning monsoon difficulty into super-drizzle. In a game that already gives you a ton of options for manipulating your items, all of that is thrown out the window in favor of leaning further into that "taking the best items so every run is the same" type gameplay that gets you those boring, unbalanced, and time consuming god runs. I've heard too many people ruin the game for themselves by setting their expectations too high for their runs by using command, and I simply think the option should have been relegated to modders and not made easily available for no penalty (because yes, you can abuse it to bypass otherwise fun achievements too). If you play with command already, just trust me that getting better at the game will be much more fun with the proper gameplay loop, and if you're for some reason reading this before buying, never turn it on. Don't even use it for funny gimmick runs because it'll tempt you to use it for evil. I'd rather they remove this than frailty.

LORE/SETTING: Petrichor V is an awesome setting. An alien planet that actually has vastly different biomes, creatures, and secrets that are all well developed really give this game a ton of nuance. All of the survivors and aliens you find are sick, with every single detail of the game given an extensive lore entry in the logbook (seriously I fucking love the logbook). There's even stuff to find in game that let you participate in the lore (I don't feel writing about spoilers so you'll just have to use your imagination). All of the lore is detailed and just cryptic enough to be interesting even after reading everything, and every other detail of the game is very nuanced and colorful.

TL;DR AND RATING OUT OF 10: I said a lot of bad stuff in this review but this game really is a masterpiece. So much stuff to do and such clean gameplay that you won't even notice any of the negative thoughts I have about this game. It's very easy to sink a lot of hours into this game and I'd say it's worth the time, but that won't stop me from seeing more potential in it.

I absolutely love this game. This game is the best action roguelike out there right now, hands down, and I've played a lot of roguelikes. Like, a lot a lot.

Once you get the hang of it, the game puts you into a kind of flow state with all of its weird features and items blending together into a tightly balanced and thoughtfully designed experience while still being chaotic, messy, fast-paced and silly.

If I was to place a criticism upon any aspect of the game, I would say I am not a huge fan of the "sudden death" that tends to end most failed runs. It's fun to fight against a massive horde and eventually get overwhelmed, it's less fun to get blasted from full health to none by some big metal balls you weren't looking at.

I loved this game at first, but it all went downhill after trying to unlock new characters and abilities. Some are absolutely trivial, while others will take days and days of grinding to unlock what are essential game pieces for the game. What a shame that such a brilliant game is completely overshadowed by these restrictions. Might as well have double the character cast with all the movesets, but might as well not since most people won't unlock these. Huntress I feel is a case to the extreme especially for the casual player or people who value their time. To me, this character is unplayable without her alternate moves, but good luck doing that for a week of "Man I hope I don't take ONE POINT of damage" else that's 20-30 minutes of lost time. I've never been so disappointed with a game more than this, because It's so fun, but doesn't deserve these restrictions. Again, these alternate unlockable moves might as well be a new character entirely, and it's a shame they are basically permanently locked for most people.
