I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Let me just start off by saying that this game is fantastic and that the only reason I am leaving this review as negative is because of what the devs did with the difficulty of the game after the release of the survivors of the void dlc, and the devs probably look at negative feedback more than positive feedback. So basically what the devs did is that they significantly reduced the difficulty of the game.

 Now first off let me explain how the difficulty of the game works. So how it works is that there is this timer mechanic where about every so often the enemies would become stronger and would appear in larger numbers. There are also 3 difficulties to choose from that affect this timer. If you played on rainstorm (aka normal) before survivors of the void the difficulty would increase about every 2 minutes and 10 seconds. However if you played on drizzle (aka easy) before survivors of the void the difficulty would increase about every 3 minutes, and if you played on monsoon (aka hard) the difficulty would increase about every 1 minute and 20 seconds (even though it says it increases the scaling by 50% for monsoon and reduces it by 50% for drizzle).

 However now monsoon is old rainstorm and rainstorm is old drizzle and drizzle is now stupidly easy. Now idk if this was a bug that not a lot of people have noticed (because i have never seen people who make content on this game comment about it or notice it). Or if it is just that the devs wanted to make the game easier. Now if it is a bug pls fix it although if this is intentional i have one question, why?

 To me, making the game easier is worse because now it is a lot less important to actually get good at the game which was one of the most fun parts of this game. To learn how to get loot quickly, To learn how to play the characters, to learn how to use an item the most efficiently, and to learn how to dodge attacks. Now before the dlc you had to know how to do all of these things to be able to win a run on normal which for me was really difficult. But it was really rewarding to slowly get further and further in every run. It was very rewarding to unlock a new character because most of them require you to complete a challenging task to unlock them. And then there is the final boss which I have always respected for being very challenging but fair and actually feels like the hardest part of the game instead of one of the easiest parts like a lot of other rougelikes. It really puts your skills to the test and you will die over and over (at least before the difficulty was nerved).  But then you get that one attempt where you actually manage to beat the boss and it feels super satisfying . Then after the fight you get a great ending and a new character that you really feel like you earned because of all you did to get to this point.

 Now take what I said in those 9 sentences and throw it out the window because that's not the game now. The game on normal now requires very little skill to complete and if you want to challenge yourself you can’t except for eclipse i guess but if i'm gonna be honest old monsoon is harder than eclipse 8. For the reasons i have listed i wish that the devs will fix this bug (at least i think it's a bug because i know the difficulty was nerfed after the launch of the dlc and the difficulty being nerfed was not in the patch notes).. Because if they don't fix this bug, in my opinion they are taking away a great experience from a lot of people because the amount of skill required to beat the game now is much lower than it used to be. So please fix this if this is a bug,and if it's not a bug then i guess the game will stay the same because if the devs change something it is because they think it would make the game better (although if this was intended it would have been included in the patch notes). Although I would hope if this was the case the devs would change there mind.

To put it simply, this is one of the best games I've played in a long time. I'm not that interested in these kinds of shooter games, but this one definitely caught my attention. I first got it around 2 years ago, and I loved it straight away. Though I had no idea what I was doing, since I got the game with no prior knowledge. I played it for about a week before slowly forgetting about it because I was playing lots of other games at the time.

A year later I found it again, and started playing. I got addicted right away, and started playing it every day for around 2 months straight. This game has incredible replayability, and is super fun and enjoyable, even if you're not into this kind of game like I wasn't.

Everything about this game is great, the story, the characters, the monsters, the artifacts, and my personal favorite, the itemization. The itemization is one of the reasons I think this game is so replayable. There are so many items to choose from, so many combinations between the items, and so many combinations between the characters and items. The game even has multiplayer, though in that the items are usually unevenly split among the players, with 1 person normally getting a lot more than the rest. Despite that, this is one of my favorite games, and I highly recommend you give it a chance.

This game is very hard if you just picked it up, but after some time things will click and stealing lunch money from lizards is gonna be a breeze.

This game has 4 difficulties that people talk about the most.

Drizzle
Rainstorm
Monsoon
Eclipse

If you just wanna run around and blow lizards up, play on drizzle so their fireballs become nothing more than spitballs.

If you want to just blow stuff up, but still want a risk of dying then play on rainstorm.

If you want a challenging experience then play on monsoon.

If you want to feel like your progressing on getting better at the game and you don't mind dying a lot to master it then play on the bonus mode eclipse.

For a newer player I would recommend to start off in rainstorm or drizzle and to learn each of the items and how they interact with each other and each character. Furthermore, learn each of the maps and plot a route to travel to get all of the loot quickly and effectively. Then after winning a few runs you can choose to go to monsoon or eclipse.

This is a a magnificent game. Super replayable, smooth gameplay, incredible soundtrack and atmosphere.
To me, it was a tremendous improvement over RoR1 in practically every single way.
Buy this and buy the expansion - it is more than worth the bucks and the studio that made it definitely deserve your money for making this. Even if you've never played a rogue-lite before, you'll probably really enjoy it. I like it more than others of the genre, but that's probably because of my personal flavor, and that those games seems to be more about having razor-sharp movements and reaction speed. There's still a challenge to this game, but there's ways around having to play at 99% capacity to enjoy a good, long run.

10/10, the only thing I'd want more is even more expansions and even more characters and items.

Risk of rain starts off a little slow.. then ramps up exponentially. It’s what I call a casual game where there’s a linear learning curve of easy to play, somewhat hard to master with a massive dose of RNG. 
Eventually you really start stress testing your PC and things go so insane that the game shuts down.. that’s what I call it a win. 
Luck really does play a factor too, be prepared to be playing, thinking you’re dominating just to be one shot by an overloading worm that decided to turn left.

This game satisfies the voices in my head. It lights the synapses in my brain and represses my urges. There was this spectrum rider at our school that everyone disliked with a fiery passion. I introduced him to this game and he died of epileptic shock. This event is now known as "the incident" and I am no longer allowed within 5 feet of any autistic people let alone children effectively granting me an immunity shield to other people's autistic urges. However, I can't seem to distance myself from my own autism urge to yell at the top of my lungs and digest colouring utensils. Great Game!

This is probably one of the hands down most fun games I've ever played in my life. I do not particularly enjoy roguelikes (I hate getting a "really good build" going only to ultimately lose it), and yet I find myself playing this game all the time, so I feel like this is pretty important context. Make no mistake, this is a roguelike game, and you will ultimately die in it. But you'll want to keep coming back to it because you don't want to let this game be better than you.

It's great for passing the time, and this is especially true for the Switch version, which I also ended up buying and have clocked nearly as many hours on as on my PC. This game keeps a lot of what Risk of Rain 1 did so well: INCREDIBLE soundtrack, weird level design, and the characters are all so unique. Risk of Rain 2 feels like the game they wanted Risk of Rain 1 to be, and all they had to do was just make it 3D.

The expansion is pretty cool as well, highly recommend it because the "void corrupted" items make for some messed up builds. 10/10 game, get this one as soon as you can.

I have to go outside the game to get a mod manager just to have basic QoL in the UI like "on all screens, I can tell how many items I have and what they do" in a game all about getting lots of items and what they do. The UI in this game is thumbs-down-worthy on its own.

And that's not getting into how I spent like 45 mins of my first 2 hours in the game thrice-overing maps for teleporters because it's a flat black panel with mild particle effects that's 5% as visible as it should be for something utterly vital to enjoying your way through the game.

I have some ups and some downs to comment on the gameplay itself, which definitely seems like it can be fun if you 1. Download 3rd party mods to make the worst parts not a dumpster fire and 2. Have friends who do the same, but the fact that I have to go that far not to improve an already-good game, but bring it up to minimal quality-of-life standards, is a big thumbs down. I don't generally recommend things that require hoop-jumping when there's so many good games out there with good UIs and good visual design.

I really enjoyed this game at first, but the more I continue to play it, the more I'm baffled by the overwhelmingly positive reception this game continues to enjoy. Once you've played for a a few hours, you've seen basically everything. The game consists of only a few maps, ranging in design from basic to generic, and the main premise of the game is you want to run around the map until you find a teleporter, beat a boss (or bosses) and escape to another map until you beat the final boss; however, the longer you spend playing the game, the more the difficulty ramps up. Ideally, you want to find a balance between finishing the stage in decent time and farming enemies for money to buy items and upgrades, because if you book it straight to the teleporter, you're likely going to get your ass handed to you by the boss(es). 

The main issue I have is that a lot of the initial challenge comes from the fact that the maps are humongous and largely empty, and (barring a a couple of exceptions) have little in the way of landmarks or other identifiable features. Because of this, it is A) absolute hell to play without some form of movement speed items because it will otherwise take you 15 minutes to get anywhere, and B) very easy to get discombobulated and waste a lot of time running around looking for a teleporter and realizing you're checking the same empty corner of rocks you checked 5 minutes ago...and now there's boss monsters spawning all around you instead of basic enemies because you took too long. However, this goes away once you realize the teleporters will always spawn in one of a set number of spots, which is where some of my boredom began to kick in.

On top of this, there is just not enough variety in terms of anything except characters. I do love the character designs and the variety of characters (although, as with most games of this genre, some are infinitely more useful than others). Everything else gets very stale, very quickly. First, unless you have the DLC, there are a limited number of map environments; Stages 1-4 will always be one of two map options, and Stages 5-6 will always be the same, so you'll very quickly start to see the same environments repeated. There are a large amount of items and upgrades, but a lot of them are locked behind achievements that can be either difficult to unlock, or have such unusual conditions to unlock I would have never discovered them on my own if I hadn't looked at the achievement list (i.e., purchase the same upgrade 7 times in a row, kill a boss in less than 15 seconds, die three times to burn damage, etc.) This goes doubly so for character skill upgrades, most of which have really out there requirements to unlock, such as killing X number of enemies in one shot while airborne, killing Y number of enemies with exactly 1 HP remaining, land a hit while moving at Z movespeed, kill boss A with character B on map C with skill D, etc. 

Also, a lot of the items just feel the same, even if they look visually unique. For example, there's an item that makes lightning bounce between enemies and one that makes fire bounce between them; an item that heals you when you kill an enemy and an item that makes enemies drop a healing orb when killed; an item that increases your sprint speed and an item that increases your movement speed, etc. A lot of them just do slightly different things and it just did not give me enough variety personally. Also, you unlock most of the items the same way, just by killing enemies, getting gold, and then paying to unlock a chest. There's a lot of different chests, which is exciting at first until you realize they all largely contain really crappy items and the only differences are what category the item falls under based on the chest color (i.e., green = healing items, red = damage, purple = utility). There are some noticeable exceptions, but I see them so infrequently that it really feels like they're not even in the game at times and most of the time I'm running around with the same handful of items.

Anyhow, I could go on, but this is already the length of a novella and I think I've made my point. I did truly have a blast with the game at first and I still play it occasionally in short spurts, but I just don't see myself playing this for dozens to hundreds of hours like I did with Vampire Survivors, Binding of Isaac, Dead Cells, Hades, etc. There's just not enough to keep me engaged and hold my attention. 

tl;dr - not enough variety. same handful of maps, lots of same-y items, same basic gameplay loop. characters a strong point, but some are OP and some are laughably bad. most stuff has weirdly specific unlock conditions I would have never discovered w/o looking up.

Each map is different and unique, the characters are all good (some broken and fun) and have their own special playstyles/abilities, the lore in this game is an inescapable rabbit hole, the game is not as high end as you might expect, especially if you lower your resolution on fullscreen (in case if you're experiencing FPS lag), and it's generally a good game that plays super well.

In conclusion, *buy this game*

The HyperX QuadCast™ S is a USB condenser microphone that both sounds great and looks great. The supremely stunning RGB lighting and dynamic effects will add style and flair to any stream or setup and is customizable via HyperX NGENUITY software. The QuadCast S is an all-inclusive mic, featuring an anti-vibration shock mount to help quiet the rumbles of daily life and a built-in pop filter to muffle plosive sounds. Instantly know your mic status with the LED indicator, and simply tap-to-mute to avoid awkward broadcasting accidents. With four selectable polar patterns, this mic’s prepared for nearly any recording situation and features a gain control dial to quickly regulate input sensitivity. The included mount adapter fits 3/8” and 5/8” thread sizes, compatible with most stands. QuadCast S is certified by Discord and TeamSpeak™ so you can ensure that your microphone is broadcasting loud and clear for all your followers and listeners, and you can also monitor your mic in real time using the convenient headphone jack on the back of the mic. It’s multi-platform compatible, so you can deliver quality sound output whether you’re connecting to a PC, PS5™, PS4™, or Mac®

It gets a little confusing trying to figure out what each icon means, and they don't give you any indication in the game until after you choose an item. The story is very weird, I have no idea what is going on, why the aesthetic or character designs. But that never matters anyway. It is frustrating getting one-shotted out of where late in the game. Never feels great when that happens after over an hour in one session. I also wish there was more progression of the characters, other than the unlock via achievement. I don't even know what some of achievements mean, and there are so few. 
Anyway, the game is worth full price if you have a group of people you play with and you like rogue likes.

Good rougelike, select from a handful of characters/classes and drop into an alien landscape where you gain 'credits' by killing mobs which are used to unlock random (and some non-random) loot boxes to equip yourself with buffs, all the while the difficulty level steadily increases as time goes by. Simple but colorful and appealing graphics, runs beautifully on the Steam Deck. If you're a fan of roguelikes there is a lot to appreciate here.

The 1 criticism I have is there seems to be no permanent progression to speak of. In other roguelikes such as Synthetik or Let It Die you'll gain some sort of character or weapon EXP each run, at least a little progression for each run. Nothing like that here, you essentially 'git gud' by learning level layouts, buff abilities, what to expect from bosses, etc. Some may like this sort of system, I'd sort of like to be able to pick out my favorite 'class' and really chalk up a bunch of EXP for them, or see my favorite buffs get EXP. Minor complaint, the game is a great experience regardless.

418 hours of playtime, at least more than 100 hours of hunting achievements that fried my patience and will to live and trying to improve and more than 300 hours just having a fun time with mods, and yet after all of that I'm yet to legitimately beat any survivors above Eclipse 4 and will never recover from Mercenary: Ethereal. But enough of personal experiences.

Risk of Rain 2 is a highly replayable FPS Roguelike with hundreds of achievements, hundreds of items, different ways to modify your runs that make it either challenging or a casual stroll in Satan's neighborhood, tons of characters with unique gimmicks, a well written story, and tons of Bosses and Monsters that can either be difficult, challenging, average, or straight up bullshit that you whine upon their presence. 
This game doesn't aim for a balance, though that doesn't say it makes it lack fun, in fact it's the opposite; it's imbalanced that you either have a run where RNG mocks you and makes you deal no damage for the entire run, a completely average run that never happens unless you're a streamer, and a run where you're either a god or your PC just crashes upon entering the teleporter. Deaths can feel so punishing and sometimes straight up broken, on the other side of the coin, Wins can also feel really fulfilling but sometimes borderline unfair.

Lost your mind after being humiliated dying to a Lunar Chimera instead of the final boss at the top? Fret not, with the help of Artifacts, you can modify your runs to a different gamemode, now instead of being harassed by pillars you can shamefully die inside as you run the perfect setup only to die by a Malachite Brass Contraption that you didn't pay attention to because there were too many Lemurians strafing around you, very enjoyable experience indeed.

I'd say take a break if you're stressed but due to the sheer amount of fun I had with mods I used to play 12 hours a day so I'd just be a hypocrite by saying that. 
Now I'll introduce you to what kept me from getting burnt out from this game (Note: It didn't stop me from getting burnt out by consistently waiting for 3 days to get a decent Prismatic Trials seed for that Mercenary achievement) and it is a popular concept called [b] Modding [/b]. Just install R2modman, link it to RoR2, install some mods, and you're good to go, unless you have a PC like mine which takes 20 minutes to load the game everytime I play with mods. As of this review there are currently more than 2,000 mods in Risk of Rain 2 [strike] half of it are probably deprecated but that's besides the point [/strike] and that's just wild, majority of mods include but are not limited to: More artifacts, run modifiers, new characters, new enemies, more skins, more items, a complete game rebalance, UI changes, [strike] huntress ass [/strike] and text mods that no one cares about.

This game is not only worth your time, it also actively eats your time, my verdict is that Risk of Rain 2 is truly one of the games of all time.

It's replayability, 2404 hours should speak for itself :)

I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game recently to try out since it was cheap, so he installed it on his computer and he started playing. A few days in and he already has 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. For my first time playing, I picked Commando and was mercilessly demolished by my own son. I asked my Son for help and he took me through some basic tips and tricks. Its been a struggle to learn, but I am finally getting to the point that I can play with my son. I loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories, especially.

I feel like I'm missing something with this game. There is not one thing in this game that makes me want to play it for longer than half an hour. Sure, this is a fine game but I feel like the gameplay is just the same thing that I experienced from the last run that I played. 

But with all of these positive reviews of this game, I feel like I might be giving this game a rough time, so I'll probably keep playing the game to see if my opinion on it changes. But for now, This game is fine. There are little to no bugs, I can tell that the devs put a TON of work into this. But this game is not for everyone. Even if I'm the only person who doesn't thoroughly enjoy the game. 

Edit: I think I have finally cracked the code on why I don't 100% enjoy this game. I don't feel like this is my kind of "Cooperative game." I always feel that when I am playing this game with my friends, It's not usually about the team, it's about the individual players. I also don't generally like games that are based on some sort of luck. I like a uniform game where I can control it, but maybe that's the thrill of this game. Also, I feel like I am the third wheel when I am playing this game. It always seems that I never do enough damage, I can't kill bosses quick enough, but when I see my friends play the game, ON STAGE 4 OR 5 THEY KILL THE BOSS WITHIN 10 SECONDS. LIKE HOW????!?! I can see why this game is so appealing to some audiences, but the randomness and just my utter inability to understand what I am doing wrong makes it impossible for me to enjoy. 

This is a 100% biased review and this should not be used as a tipping point on whether or not you should purchase the game. I say try it out (with friends), and if you don't like it, refund it.
Risk of Rain 2 is a good game

Not a game I envisioned liking when it was first taking off with people, but becomes very addicting fast. It encourages going as fast as possible, picking up items, which provide most of your character's power. In singleplayer you just take what you can, in multiplayer you coordinate a bit to help build to each character's strengths and weaknesses. Picking up multiple copies of items amplifies the effect, such as picking up two medkits doubles the healing received when they activate. Almost all items are passive and apply view your normal movement and damaging abilities, letting you focus on staying alive. A little ways into a run you will usually have enough items to begin doing crazy damage to keep up with the progressive scaling, to the point of sometimes just clicking once to attack might clear the screen of enemies from dozens of effects stacking, but you can never fully let your guard down as you typically die in 2-5 hits or so even with a lot of defense. fun both solo and with friends, and glues you to the screen. Even the starter 2 characters are good fun once you figure out what their strengths are. The game also doesn't punish you for using the provided unlockable game modifiers or playing on lower difficulty, letting you unlock challenges with modifiers or lower difficulty to help you unlock things.

Is playing without the Command artifact the ultimate form of cuckoldry?

I cannot think or comprehend of anything more cucked than playing without Command.

Think about it rationally. You are shooting, running, jumping for like 60 minutes solely so you can get a Squid Polyp. All that hard work you put into your run - dodging Stone Golem lasers, getting annoyed by six thousand Lesser wisps spawning above your head, activating Shrines of the Mountain all for one simple result: Your inventory is filled up with warbanners and Monster Tooth necklaces which cost money.

On a god run?

Great. A bunch of garbage items which add nothing to your run end up coming out of the Chests you buy. They get the benefit of your hard earned dosh that came from killing Lemurians.

Never played the first one. My friends just wanted to try it together. It's a good game. Performance is phenomenal for everything going on. Had a blast playing it with 3 friends, but it's not one of those games where you need them around to spin up a game. I think we unlocked almost everything just to have another reason to run through the game again. There are different routes you can take, tons of secrets and little gimmicks to learn. The randomized item combos make for interesting builds and force you to change your play style. Each character does this as well. I didn't necessarily care for the music at first, but it grew on me, which shows me just how well done it is. The expansion is probably also worth it. My only issue with the game are the quirky physics when you become too powerful, one step forward and you fly out of the map. So, if you want to scale up to endlessness, it becomes a very odd and uncontrollable experience. Even when you remove all your speed/jumping gear, your base stats can get so high that they do the same thing to your character. But only for speed & liftoff... DPS no longer matters, Health no longer matters, it's just who can one-shot who first. That's my only complaint and I get it, it's a hard thing to get the scaling right over that much time, without making a game gimmicky in one way or another. Other than that, what else can I say? I'm waiting for RoR3 I guess :)

This is a game about economics.

On the surface this seems like any other roguelite, mechanics wise, think ridiculous item combos like in Binding of Isaac. As you progress, just like in BoI, you permanently unlock more items that can spawn in the game but the starting selection is limited enough that after a few hours you have learned how most of them behave and the additional unlocked items feels like a trickle of useful tools that gets added to your arsenal the longer you play. You also pick from a range of unlockable characters that play [i]very[/i] differently, making the variety in builds always feeling fresh.

The major thing RoR (1 and 2) does different is [i]the clock[/i]. As the timer goes up, so does the difficulty, so you have to find the balance between staying in the level to get all the equipment and moving on to the next one. I generally don't like being on the clock, but in this game it works really well. It's what fuels all the strategies, how you choose to clear the level and encourages risk-y approaches. It's not as stressful as it might seem but rather it makes you aware of the painful seconds you lose with detours and gives you the choice between meeting easier enemies with less gear or more elites and more gear, this is something you need to decide based on the items you've gotten that far in the run.

I loved the original (in 2D pixel art style). and was surprised how well the formula translated to 3D, making it easily one of the top 3 roguelites of all time, in my opinion. Just like the original, this is a timeless design and I'm sure people 10 years from now will find it just as engaging and exhillerating as I do now.

Risk of Rain 2 is like a siren’s song. It lures you in with interesting characters, flashy combat, and a vague yet intriguing story about a planet covered in crashed spaceships. Then you look at the top right corner of the screen, see that you’ve been playing your current run for over 65 minutes, and realize you’ve completely torpedo’d your productivity for the day.

It is absolutely incredible just how hypnotic this game can be. Everything about it feels so “immediate,” like the developers have injected instant gratification into every aspect of its gameplay. Enemies dramatically explode or flip over when you kill them, loot chests have a punchy *THUD* sound when you open them, activating the teleporter for the next stage feels like you’ve just hit the launch button on a nuclear missile. The constant feedback of your actions make Risk of Rain 2 feel amazing to play, and the music just elevates this experience to godlike levels.

If you’re going to get this game, there are a few things you should know. First off, the game was designed around co-op, but (in my humble opinion) it doesn’t do a great job of balancing for that fact. Gold and XP from kills is shared, but items are not, and items are what truly give your character power. On every map, there are a limited number of loot chests containing random items that can potentially provide huge boosts to your character. However, once a chest is opened, nobody else can use it again. This often leads to massive power imbalances in which one or two players amass a huge inventory of items, leaving the rest of the team firing peashooters in later levels.

Another (potentially controversial) issue I have with the game is the fact that once you die in co-op, you need to wait until the end of the level to revive. I understand the thought behind this, as the whole point of Risk of Rain 2 is that you will eventually lose, but this just creates even larger power gaps between players as the game goes on. You cannot pick up items while dead (obviously), and items cannot be dropped either, making this a snowball effect that just ends up feeling bad. Especially when those more powerful players continue to steamroll everything in sight, dragging the rest of you along for the ride.

Overall though, Risk of Rain 2 is a remarkably well-crafted experience. It offers a huge amount of replayability, combined with an unorthodox progression system and lots of little secrets that make the whole world feel very unexplored. If you’re a fan of roguelikes, co-op games, or experiences that will suck away all of your free time, Risk of Rain 2 is an excellent choice.

Today I have a story to speak about. A man named Parker and his pet Trout. Walking down the creek was his favourite route. Parker loved his trout, without a doubt. But one day, an escape was committed by the trout. He was out. At least, he felt of joy, but who was still looking for him? Parker, the little boy. But there was worse out there, said the koi. You might be cooked, and eaten with soy. This frightened little Parker, but he had marked his trout with a marker. One day, Parker was at the pond, where he found his trout. Parker thought he was gone, but the trout was still around. It was a rainbow trout, a pretty one, I must say. One day, I wish to eat it with glaze. I hoped and prayed the fish would escape again, and would meet his glazey end. Turned out, that's what happened! One day they were walking along the pacific ocean with the trout in his bag, so the salt water doesn't hurt his little gills. Yes, later on they live most of their life in the ocean, but the trout was not quite yet to begin this motion. I saw the boy and his little trout, and I took it from him, and ran all about. He was put on the grill later that day, a fine tasting fish, eh? I said to Parker, as he cried for his fish. So I gave him a little plate of my dish. He agreed, the trout tastes good. They became trout hunters and used bows and arrows made out of string and wood. They would do this forever, if they could. They would bring it home, and enjoy the meal. This cooking man was the real deal. He looks older than me, over 35 "How old are you my guy" Parker asks, and was given an answer that give him a surprise. "I'm 54." The man said, just then, there was a knock on the door. The man threw acid at the chefs face! What a disgrace! The cook managed to survive, and would continue to be alive. The cook died roughly 25 years after the acid incident. Oh, how Parker had grown! He found another boy with a trout, all alone. He took it and cooked it, and carried on the legacy. As the smells filled the house, Parker played a nice melody. He told the boy the stories of the chef, until he died too. But the boy kept it going. He found a boy with a pet trout once more, I know you've heard this all before. But at the end of the day, Parker carried a legacy soon to come your way. Look out for a man suspiciously holding a bag and tape to keep their mouth shut until they can eat. If you see this man, run, and call the police.

Risk of rain 2 is a roguelike that takes a completely different approach from it's predecessor.
it being a roguelike, you die, a lot. that's no exception here.

Every character in this game feels like butter, they all control smoothly in their own different ways, from huntress teleporting all around the stage, pecking at monsters until they die, acrid ground pounding down a mountain to crunch the beetles at the bottom, with the amount of things tightly packed into this game, like the amount of different upgrades, the lore, the character designs, there is a lot to love about ror2.

I would recommend this game plus the [url=https://thunderstore.io/package/Wonda/Refightilization/]'Refightilization' mod by Wonda.[/url] It allows you to respawn after death as a monster, being able to help or sabotage your fellow players to respawn as the character you died as, it's a hoot having to deal with your friend who was turned into a giant glob of orange slime as he shoots shurikens at you.

The best Rogue-like on the market, hands down. Incredibly satisfying gameplay, grueling yet teaching in its execution. Runs that are chaotically fun. An incredible amount of world building without ever speaking a single word. And with the DLC, i have high expectations for the future of this game. Hats off to you, Hoppo Games.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 17 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to use a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

>Commando mains furiously describing how vanilla is the ultimate experience
>Mercenary mains cracking their skull open on their keyboard to kill one stone golem
>Huntress mains describing how printing 23 crowbars is the perfect strategy
>Void Fiend mains crying
>MUL-T mains do not exist and if you know one then one of you is schizophrenic
>Engineer mains creaming their sweatpants at the sight of a mushroom
>Captain mains stealing every chest in the stage so they can die with 12 warbanners
>Rex mains emptying a bottle of Valium into their mouths watching their healthbars
>Artificer mains being useless in the air >80% of the run
>Bandit mains trying to backstab only to get one tapped
>Railgunner mains struggling to focus on the game while surrounded by gorgeous naked women

The most interesting Roguelike Game ever in my opinion. (I HATE Hades and Binding of Isaac and always thought that this genre sucks tbh). 

Its basically a third person shooter (except Railgunner OP) on Steroids.

Lots of Secrets to discover, for example Artifacts (which are always optional) which alter your playing experience BIG time, you can even take out the randomness and decide which iteams to get.

Even the Lore has some great depth.

Unlimited Framerate, runs absolutely fine on a GTX 1060 6GB with no frame drops, even 1 hour into the run (when it gets... well, HECTIC to say the least).

Very hard at first, but the more you play the better you and the game get.

PLAY IT

A little bit of [drones] by my side
A little bit of [ukuleles] is all I need
A little bit of [chronobaubles] is what I see
A little bit of [Grandparents] in the sun
A little bit of [Mithrix] all night long
A little bit of [Sky meadow], here I am
A little bit of [elites] makes me [die]

This is the only review I've ever left for a video game, so I'm going to keep it short: RoR2 is gaming distilled into its most perfect essence. The art, sound design, animations, music, and gameplay, are all so incredibly tuned to be a delight for every sense that I still get chills when fighting secret and final bosses. Online Co-op is the closest to classic sleepover couch co-op of any game I've played. The game modes are endless, the runs are always interesting, and nothing can ever replace the joy of my computer grinding to a halt as it tries to display and give sound effects to ten thousand purple shrimp missiles launching twenty times per second as the bullets of my dual pistols find their way lovingly into the floating giant jellyfish before me.

This game, should be among one of the top games for its release date. The combination of multiple mechanics and the looting system alone are very fleshed out. The characters are all detailed and have multiple areas in which you can grow them. I have no complaints for this game, except that I would love to see more dlc's and more characters being released a little more frequently. The replayability of this game is the highest of any game i've ever seen, on par with minecraft or terraria. This game, is worth it full price, and should have the price heightened because of how good this game is.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

It's a fun game in some ways... the action, graphics etc are all good... but this game has major issues that make it no fun for me, especially with multiplayer.

The game does not encourage team play, so expect even your friends to just do their own thing and not help you or play as a team. Not their fault really, it's the way the game is structured.

My biggest problem is the loot system. Loot opportunities should be instanced, full stop. This is a semi-ARPG, with shades of games like Borderlands, but roguelike. ARPGs have moved to instanced loot for a long time now, because devs of ARPG games learned that it is not fun to play multiplayer and have your team mates jump on everything like lootgoblins and gain momentum, while you get weaker and weaker and miss out on the cool stuff. This takes me back to Diablo 2, players all trying to grab the items after a boss was defeated. It's not a fond memory, and gaming has moved on in the 20 years since then. It's particularly harsh on new players trying to run with more experienced ones.

Personally I hate that the game's mechanics encourage a competitive experience of all rushing around trying to be the first to get to the shrines, loot boxes etc. I end up starting to put in less and less effort, as I watch my team mates all stack up on speed items so they can grab stuff faster. I don't want to always start with all-goat hoof build just to be able to have a chance.

In multiplayer, the game creates a feedback loop that feels bad to me: the faster and more experienced player(s) grab more and more of the share of the loot, then the weaker ones start to die as the difficulty ramps up, and when you die you sit back and watch til the next stage, so you fall progressively further and further behind. Then, of course, you are almost guaranteed to die again on the next stage... and again... until you are just little more than a spectator for most of the run. Pretty much every run with more than 2 people I have played goes this way. A few players try to help, be kind, help the weaker ones to catch up... but the pace of the game means there is little time to be deciding who should take loot anyway. The game rewards pushing and pushing, and it's more efficient to just keep getting more OP as an individual and let the weaker ones fall away and get carried.

Even if you had a generous team mate thinking about your intended build, most of the items are basically good for any build. Only a few are real specialist pieces - obviously melee characters will benefit more from focus crystal, engy from fungus... but let's be honest, when the player who should have the item is on the other side of the map, are you really gonna bother leaving it and tagging? Nope... you grab and scrap later.

I like co-op games where you stick together and your skills synergise, and the party falls or stands on their teamwork. ROR's mechanics encourage everyone to run off in different directions to try and find their own loot, only coming back together for the teleporter event. And of course, as the strong players get stronger this continues to be viable for them... whilst you, the noob, won't be able to keep up even if you try, further increasing the chances of dying alone.

Again, the basic gameplay loop is quite fun, and playing solo or with just one other person who you know isn't going to compete with you for items can be fun, but so far my experience of larger groups in this game leaves me feeling frustrated at the loot system. I should not have to base every build around getting as many speed items as I can as early as possible just so I can be in with a chance of grabbing a few items later.

And this is playing with people I know... I can't imagine how bad it is with trolling randoms.

The game also feels kind of empty, hollow... storyline is almost nonexistent, I know that's kind of the point, but I don't feel any urge to keep playing it personally.

Was a skeptic on this, friend and I got for each other on a whim during a sale. I had always heard good things about the first Risk of Rain but never played it. Risk of Rain 2 seemed to be well regarded too, but again, I didn't think I'd be interested.

I have to say I'm impressed despite being a bit meh on this one at first. There is a lot to like here and there is a learning curve that feels rewarding enough to keep trying while still feeling challenging. The main game having an adjustable difficulty progression is a nice touch and has made it easier for me, who is new to this series, to get into the game more deeply and "get farther" (helping me stay motivated to keep trying)

Not every class is my cup of tea, but that's actually a plus, in my opinion, because there are so many different  ways to play and with different loadouts per class, you can make change your playstyle even on the same character.

I feel like this game deserves the praise it gets and plan to revisit it regularly.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

10/10 there is no actual lack of rain

3 things:

It's incredibly fun: I didn't think I'd see a 3rd person arena shooter roguelike at any point, but boy am I glad I did. Risk of Rain 2 is accompanied with hours of hilarious, rage-inducing, and outright ridonculous gameplay. You wanna go the speed of light? Hit that order shrine. You want everything to explode when you use your basic attack? It'll take a few loops, but you'll get there. Do you want to bind an autoclicker to m1 when playing Huntress? I highly recommend it, she has auto-aim and it's just nice quality of life.

It's incredibly beautiful: people might look at risk of rain and be like "huh this isn't hyper ultra realistic 967k graphics, this shit is ugly" but the atmosphere of being on a desolate planet alone (or with 3 friends) becomes bigger and bigger as the game gets harder and harder. The deep and dark colors create an environment that really seems like it wants to kill you, which is exactly what the game wants to do. Trust me, you'll spend enough time looking at your health bar and enemies to mitigate the worry of the world looking the same.

It's replayable: to piggyback off of the "looking the same statement", RoR2 is only the same, if you make it the same, and it's really hard to get 2 similar runs back to back. Since Risk of Rain 2's release, they've added a plethora of maps and map variations that make the environment feel different each playthrough. The item randomization is solid (aside with a slowly creeping item bloat). Most of all, there's a massive cast of characters, 4 different game modes, and tons of modifiers to change your run. Everyone I know that's picked up this game has sunk at least 40-50 hours in it. I can't guarantee you will do the same, but I can certainly tell you that from my heart, (and my playtime) I think this game is worth every penny I spent on it 10-fold and more.

[h1] "Play that Ukelele for me" [/h1]
Review by Unam 

I'm a huge fan of the Roguelike genre, but Risk of Rain 2 is the best one I've played. [i] It is Magnificent [/i].

Everything about this just clicks together perfectly like puzzle pieces in a jigsaw. Let's start with a few basics. This is a Roguelike, meaning that your progress through a run is always different from other runs, and if you die you restart from 0. In the base game there are a total of 11 Survivors that all behave differently from each other I'll give you a quick rundown of all characters:

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Name[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Commando[/td]
        [td]Jack of all trades that works almost anywhere[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Huntress[/td]
        [td]Nimble but quick character that can dispose of most enemies in a flash[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]MUL-T[/td]
        [td]A tanky robot who can melt tanks and resist most damage[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Bandit[/td]
        [td]A Survivor who specializes on hiding and dealing massive damage behind the backs of enemies[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Artificer[/td]
        [td]A destructive Survivor that has mighty offensive abilities (and a jetpack)[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Acrid[/td]
        [td]A melee, ranged hybrid who can melt tanks quickly through the use of poison[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Captain[/td]
        [td]The Captain's strength is his ability to call down a variety of tactical drops, and can take care of most projectiles in a rush[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Engineer[/td]
        [td]A smart Survivor who uses turrets and good positioning in order to execute the enemy[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Loader[/td]
        [td]A melee Survivor with a grappling hook that can get her anywhere[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mercenary[/td]
        [td]A swordfighter who moves lightning fast through most enemies[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]REX[/td]
        [td]REX is a special one, as most of his attacks consume his health, making everything a balance between health/attack[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Everyone here is unique, and you will most likely stick to 2-3 Survivors, but every one is worth experiencing at least once. You start with only Commando, but you can unlock most of the other characters through special challenges. However, you can't just rely on your survivor. This is where your items come in. These provide a boost to a specific skill, examples include Movement Speed, causing Bleed, firing Rockets, and so on so forward. You rely on your items, without them you are nothing. Items are always random, meaning that you will have to improvise what you do depending on your items and plan accordingly. Items are divided into categories, from Grey which is common to Red which is super rare but provides IMMENSE POWER. The key to victory is to deal enough damage, manage your speed and your reaction time, and have enough healing to be able to react to a hit. The longer you take, the harder it gets. This means that alongside everything else you have to be fast. This creates interesting chemistry between all these factors, where it can get quite ridiculous and fun. 

The game also offers a variety of interesting environments with little secrets that are always fun to explore. Some elements are always randomized to keep things fresh. There are some random events that can also trigger randomly that can be quite a challenge. The enemies and their designs are fun too! Some real standouts are the teleporter bosses which you fight to progress to the next stage. Unless you have a good run where you instantly kill anything in a single second these will prove to be tough. Everything will challenge the most hardcore of players. Most items have to also be unlocked through challenges, much like the Survivors. It will take you multiple hours to unlock everything there is to see. Even after you beat the final boss, the game will keep you coming back for a lot. 

Hopoo has crafted a great game that takes a fresh spin on the genre. Congratulations to the small team on crafting something very special for me. You've made it through this entire review, trust me, this is worth it. I would still pick it up if it was 60 Dollars.

The first game introduced me to roguelikes, and by it's own it was an amazing experience.

For a while, I was reluctant to buy the second game because it felt like it was the first game, but with an additional dimension, and for me, the 2D platformer feel of the original was the charm.

Oh, I was wrong. The game not just adds a dimension, but a lot of depth and possibilities. The soundtrack is absolutely beautiful. Hearing ...con lentitud poderosa after spending years with Coalescence in my playlist hit me in a way no other OST did. Props to Chris Christodoulou!

This could be a hard game, a VERY hard game if you want. But also could be a cakewalk, there's so much room for experimenting with builds and item combinations. There's no need to gatekeep difficulty, you play how you want to play, and that's the beauty of it.

RoR2 is an absolute masterpiece that surprisingly surpasses the quality and replayability of its predecessor. Boasting an obscene number of gameplay combinations (character choice each with a completely distinct play style, mix-and-matchable alternative ability options for each character which can further change play style, game difficulty, solo or co-op, mix-and-matchable gameplay modifiers or "artifacts," a "new game plus" mode in Eclipse, an "arcade" game mode in Prismatic Trials, many distinct win conditions, a toggleable DLC that profoundly affects the meta), odds are there is a combination of settings that nicely fits your skill level and preferred mode of play.

On top of that, the audio and visual designs of the game are impeccable, being both incredibly informative in the heat of battle and quality in their own rights. Chris Christodoulou brings an incredible soundtrack that excels in establishing and affirming tone.

I'm typically not a fan of roguelikes because I often find the gameplay to become stale far before I reach significant measurable skill thresholds (e.g., winning a run or beating new game plus), but Hopoo Games mitigates this by splitting up progress into achievements, three main difficulties, and the eight-step progression track of Eclipse. Having just beaten Eclipse 8 on my first survivor, I can attest that every threshold along the way both seems feasible at the time and is satisfying but non-trivial to actually accomplish.

Whether you're a fan of roguelikes or typically avoid them, I cannot recommend Risk of Rain 2 enough. It is easily one of my top 5 favorite games of all time.

One of my favorite rogue-likes. Risk of Rain 2 is best played with a couple of friends in my opinion but it has loads of arcade-y kind of content and bosses that scale with number of players, so the solo experience is one unto itself and still well worth exploration. When you are playing with friends, though, this game quickly turns into a madhouse of insane item-survivor ability combinations that turn crowds of enemies from grindy assaults to waves of explosions. It's like a joke that never really gets old, and because of this i find myself coming back to the game every few months to put a few more runs in. 
I highly recommend this game, I'd buy two copies so a friend could pick it up with me. I feel like there's more connectivity issues now than there used to be, but nothing so frequent or game breaking that it makes the game a chore to play in my experience. 

Also, just a tip, most of the survivors in the game benefit most from effects that trigger on-hit, as each bullet fired gives you an opportunity. There are a couple of characters that are a bit of an exception to this, but almost always you're gonna benefit a lot from stacking bleed, crit chance, or mini-rockets (seriously, i cant hype up the mini-rockets enough)

Risk of Rain 2 is an extremely addictive game with satisfying moment-to-moment gameplay and a progression system based in achievements. The game starts out very simple with its item pool to ease you into a larger stockpile of items that you'll be able to get. You'll be having to listen to most of the tracks quite a few times, but they're all at the very worst bearable. The graphics aren't exactly cutting-edge, but the artstyle is pretty charming, and the lack of high-def graphics allows for more devices to run it.

tl;dr : An absolute masterpiece, both for a roguelike AND for a third-person shooter. Although lacking in a select few areas, the game's prominent modding community provides a multitude of QoL improvements.

Pros:
+ Beautiful visual style
+ Character roster covers a wide range of playstyles and strategies; if a certain character's gameplay doesn't feel fun, there's most definitely some other that will
+ Extremely fun multiplayer and singleplayer
+ Strangely enough, the one roguelike where I actually still have fun even if I lose (which to me is a very important indicator of a good game)

Cons:
- Certain features are not in the game by default, though this is remedied by modding. The game doesn't have the ability to save an in-progress run which feels like an extreme oversight considering that runs can go well over an hour.

[b]Note: I personally play the game modded. Thunderstore is the mod manager I use due to it's simplicity (and it auto-downloads dependencies), but I believe there are other mod managers as well. The following mods are what I highly recommend to make the game the best experience it can be:[/b]
+ ProperSave: Adds mid-run save support to the game. Progress is saved at the start of each stage so you can quit and resume later. Also supports separate run saves for each game mode along with multiplayer.
+ ItemStats: Changes the item pickup text to better describe what it does. Also lets you check item descriptions just by pinging them on the ground.
+ LunarCoinShareOnPickup: Lunar coins picked up in multiplayer are given to all members.
+ DropinMultiplayer: Lets players join in during an in-progress run, giving them items/levels if needed.
+ PauseInMultiplayer: A bit buggy, but helps you freeze time in multiplayer in-case somebody needs to do something.
If you ever wanna feel like a god. This is greatest, most fun, enjoyable and repayable for a lifetime game ever made.

Sometimes the simple things are just amazing as a starter. To keep everyone happy, a good-flavoured soup can really hit the spot. French baguettes or a white bread plait both go really well with this.

Ingredients

1 onion, peeled and roughly chopped

4 sprigs of thyme, chopped

2 cloves of garlic, peeled and roughly chopped

2 tbsp olive oil

900g carrots, peeled and chopped

1.25 litres chicken stock

400g tin of coconut milk

Sea salt to season

To serve

200ml softly whipped cream

10g affilla cress

Crusty homemade bread

Method

1. Put a large saucepan on a high heat and sweat the onions, thyme and garlic in the olive oil until nicely softened.

2. Add in the chopped carrots and reduce the heat to medium. Sweat the carrots for around 10-15 minutes to release the maximum flavour from them. Add the chicken stock and bring to the boil. Reduce the heat to medium and allow to simmer until the carrots soften.

3. Once soft enough, blend with a hand blender. Once blended, add the coconut milk and return to the heat for 3-4 minutes. Season to taste with sea salt.

4. When serving this soup, I like to give it a froth for presentation purposes. To do this, pour the soup into a jug and use the hand blender on a low speed with up and down motions to make the soup frothy.

5. Pour into a bowl and then top with a dollop of whipped cream. Place a piece of affilla cress on top of the cream and then serve with some crusty homemade bread.



Olive tapenade bread
This olive tapenade bread works really nicely with bacon and onion bread. Serve slices of the two together before any dinner party or special occasion to truly impress your guests.

Makes 1 large loaf or 2 small loaves

Ingredients

500g strong white flour, plus extra for dusting

7g instant yeast

2 pinches of salt

2 pinches of caster sugar

325ml tepid water

Olive tapenade

Olive oil for greasing

1 egg yolk, beaten

Method

1. Combine all the dry ingredients in a mixing bowl. Then pour in the water and mix with a fork until the dough comes together.

2. Tip the dough on to a work surface dusted with a bit of flour and knead for 10 minutes until well combined - when you press your finger into the dough it should spring back. The dough should also be nice and smooth. Place it back into the mixing bowl and cover with cling film or a damp tea towel and allow to prove for an hour in a warm place.

3. After an hour, knock back the dough. To knock it back all you need to do is punch all the air out of the risen dough. Now you are ready to shape. You can make either two small loaves or one large one. I like them smaller, but it's entirely up to you.

4. To make one loaf, roll all the dough out into a flat rectangle on your work surface with a rolling pin. The length of the dough should be the same as the length of the tin you are using, the largest tin you can use being a 2lb loaf tin. Spread the olive tapenade evenly across the whole dough with a palette knife.

5. Now roll the dough like a Swiss roll, nice and tight, and then seal the edges with your fingertips so it doesn't open in the oven. Grease the baking tin with a little olive oil and then set the bread into it. Cover with a damp tea towel and allow to prove for 15-20 minutes.

6. Preheat the oven to 180ºC/400ºF/gas mark 6.

7. Brush the beaten egg yolk over the whole surface and then place into the oven to bake for 40-45 minutes. To check that the loaf is properly cooked, tip it out of the tin and tap the base. It should sound hollow. If it doesn't, return to the oven for another 5 minutes.

8. Once cooked, tip the bread out and allow to cool on a wire rack before serving.



Herb-Crusted Rack of Lamb with Sweet Potato
This was the cut of meat I most wanted to learn how to cook when training. If you don't want to do this yourself, your butcher will French-trim the rack for you. The Dijon mustard brushed on really complements the flavour of the lamb and allows the crust to stick.

Serves 4

Ingredients

2 racks of lamb cut in half (3 bones per serving)

Salt and cracked black pepper to season

Olive oil

2 tbsp Dijon mustard

8 pearl onions

2 little gem lettuce, sliced thinly

1 tbsp butter

For the crust 4 slices of stale bread made into crumbs

Small bunch of parsley

4 sprigs of thyme

For the sweet potato fondant 1 large sweet potato, peeled

2 tbsp butter

300ml water

2 sprigs of thyme

Method

1. Place the lamb on a chopping board fat side up. Lightly score the fat layer with a sharp knife. Next, generously sprinkle the lamb with salt and pepper. Mop up the excess seasoning with the meat, ensuring it is thoroughly coated.

Heat some oil in a frying pan on a high heat. Seal the lamb by placing each side in the oil long enough to develop colour. It is simple: no colour equals no taste, so make sure you brown the lamb properly.

2. Transfer the lamb to a preheated oven at 190ºC/410ºF/gas mark 6 and bake for 7-8 minutes. While the lamb is cooking, you can prepare the crust.

3. Place all of the ingredients for the crust into a blender and pulse several times until it looks nice and green. Pour the mixture into a deep dish and set aside.

4. Remove the lamb from the oven and brush generously with the mustard. Dip the lamb into the crust mixture coating it completely. Dip it several times to ensure an even coating, then allow the meat to rest for 10 minutes covered in tinfoil.

While the meat is resting, make the fondant. Cut the sweet potato with a sharp knife so you are left with 2cm-thick rounds. With a 5cm fondant cutter, cut out four perfect rounds of sweet potato. Keep whatever is left over for a purée.

5. Add the sweet potato, 1 tablespoon of butter, water and thyme to a small frying pan. Cook on a medium heat for 5 minutes on each side until softened but not overcooked. Once cooked, pour away the liquid and cook the rounds in a little olive oil and the other tablespoon of butter with the pearl onions, until coloured on the outside.

6. Sauté the sliced little gem in a little olive oil, 1 tablespoon of butter and salt to taste for 30 seconds in a separate small saucepan on a high heat.

7. When you are almost ready to serve, place the lamb back into the oven for 3-4 minutes. Slice through each chop once ready. This is best served pink.

8. To plate up, put a little carrot and star anise purée and some of the little gem lettuce on a plate, then sit a portion of lamb on top. Add one piece of sweet potato fondant, a couple of pearl onions and spoon on the warm red wine jus (see panels).



Pear tart tatin
This elegant dessert is designed to serve two, but you can easily make an extra tatin or two to serve more. I find vanilla pods dusted with icing sugar are the perfect finishing touch. Dry the empty pods after you have used them in the ice-cream to use for decoration.

Serves 2

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Risk of Rain 2 is a game that starts out feeling difficult, but once you get the hang of things you begin to feel like a god. It is a real power trip. Eventually, easy mode is just used for unlocking things. The medium difficulty also becomes too easy eventually -[spoiler] once you begin to utilize artifacts such as the artifact of sacrifice and artifact of command [/spoiler]. Starting out, you may feel like monsoon difficulty will be impossible to ever complete, but in time you will get the hang of it and monsoon may be the only difficulty you will play.
Overall, a fun experience with a lot to reach for and unlock. It can truly be satisfying to see how much you improve over time.

Bought in EA, bought the DLC when it came out, 1000's of hours in RoR1.

I love this game. But after repeatedly losing hours of enjoyment due to unbalanced game play and getting one hit even after 1.0 landed and a DLC dropped is maddening. 
It feels like the developers lost their minds towards the end of the game.

No spoilers, but the proper ending level takes everything fun about the game and makes me hate it.
Some of the levels are less fun than others; but the last level is a lesson in the opposite of proper game endings  and design. It is pointless, huge, ugly, empty, and has enemies you only see there, along with possibly the worst boss in a game I have ever played. This coming from someone that grew up beating all sorts of awful NES games.

The game is still in need of serious balancing as evident by the comments section alone.
(Funny, half of the people bring up legitimate issues, while the other half just pull the git gud card. Sorry wimp, this isn't Dark Souls where there is a reason and rhythm to everything in which skill and attention pay off.)

All in all, I cannot recommend this even at a discount until they re-balance certain aspects to bring it more in line with the first game. Rage quitting out of a cheap shot 2+ hours in a rouge lite is some cheap BS, and causes me to come back to this game less and less.

That means I won't buy any DLC if I don't play the game! Ruh Roh.

[h1] Good god, I love this game [/h1]

Risk of Rain 2 is a near perfect example of roguelike game design, wrapped up with a lovely visual direction and a phenomenal soudtrack courtesy of Chris Christodoulou. There's ample choices of survivors to pick before crash-landing on an alien planet, and in true rougelike fashion they're all very varied in gameplay and get unlocked as you get a handle on the game. 

It is very easily to get overwhelmed and frustrated in your first hours, admittedly, Trying to comprehend the various enemies that never stop spawning, figuring out which powerups are worth your time and synergize with your chosen survivor, trying to find the goddamn teleporter to move onto the next stage [spoiler] Protip: Follow the sparkling red lights once you see them [/spoiler] and then getting your butt kicked by an unexpected horde or unfamiliar boss that seems to kill you in one hit. 

But stick with it, it's like riding a horse. It may try to throw you off, but once you get the handle on it everything opens up, and with the right skills and builds you will be virtually unstoppable. I can't express the absolute power trip and visual spectacle a synergized, overly powered-up run gives me. It stops being about surviving the horde, the horde has to SURVIVE you.

And in typical rougelike fashion, there's plenty of powerups, hidden realms and additional abilities and assists to unlock, which just add further to the game's incredible replay value. It's even got a DLC now that adds even more to the game, and opens up even more possibilities in every run. And the best thing is only one person in a multiplayer lobby needs to own the DLC for other players to experience it. 

Of course the game has multiplayer, so if you have 1-3 other friends who play the game, rope them into the chaos, it's always a fun time. Fool around even more with survivor synergy and beating the stuffing out of every single enemy foolish enough to spawn in your way.

In short: Buy this game, pick your survivor, stack your powerups, and CHALLENGE THE MOUNTAIN.
