Risk of Rain 2: A Clean Roguelike Experience

Few games with actual replayability while keeping its gameplay fun and entertaining. After your first ever run, you just feel like you've done so good you could do a lot better the next run, unlocking and learning what each item does as you play more and more.

With items, obviously comes with Survivors. You can tell each Survivor has a unique role and utility with their playstyle, at least in a group. A composition is also very important, as much as an entire group going for the same Survivor is fun, you have to admit having a built composition is a better way of enjoying the game.

And with a variety of Survivors, comes with a wider variety of enemies to fight against, and trust me, there's a LOT of different enemies, not to mention any of them has a chance to become practically any type of Elite to spice up your run.

Your time is limitless, but the more time you take between each stage, the harder it gets, and I learned that the hard way. The game keeps you more or less on the move depending on what difficulty you're playing on. You CAN take as much time as you need, but at your own risk of quickly getting overwhelmed in numbers and could easily cost you your entire run.

You also get different choices on how you want to win/end your run other than just defeating the same final boss over and over again. However that does not mean they're easier or simpler to get through.

Overall, Risk of Rain 2 is incredibly fun and the replayability is insane thanks to a lot of RNG factors differentiating each run from another, and I also recommend playing with a couple friends, it makes the game even more fun when you got a couple buddies you can escape different planets with. There's a lot that I haven't even mentioned, otherwise this review would be close to endless, so I'm putting it up to you to explore the rest of the game yourself.

(On a side note, modding is also a thing on this game, however I haven't tried it myself so I can't really express an opinion towards it.)

I fall for Risk of Rain 2's trick every time. An hour into a good run my character is plastered head-to-toe in bizarre power-ups, like a katamari rolled through a novelty shop. Yes, I have three teddy bears strapped to my thigh, but those are important, because teddy bears have a percentage chance of blocking all incoming damage. Obviously I have seven needles stuck into my head. How else am I going to massively increase my attack speed? When I'm loaded down with dozens of items, Risk of Rain 2 always fools me into feeling unstoppable. "I am a golden god" echoes through my mind. And then something hits me so hard it knocks the godhood right out of me, and whoosh. Dead in an instant, game over. How did I ever think three teddy bears would be enough?

Have you ever wanted to hit an all-time high AND an all-time low in dopamine release at the same time? Well if you have a good Risk of Rain 2 run just before you watch your entire family get murdered you may just get there.

Risk of Rain 2 is a third-person shooter rogue-lite game with both singleplayer and up to 4 player multiplayer modes. I have played this game since it came out, and have experienced every iteration of the game and can honestly say that this game is one of the best solo time-killing games as well as one of the best fuck-around-with-friends games on the market. Every single run is a fun experience, and every character feels hand-crafted to have their own style. Items are (for the most part) fun to pickup and incorporate into insane builds, and tons of wacky combinations exist and can be found simply by playing. Each level is well crafted and the secrets the game holds are very well made. The game is designed well, and that's only half of why it's fun.

If a good engine and basic gameplay loop set the game up to be homerun, the balancing sent the game past the stands and into orbit. [i] Nothing [/i] in this game feels balanced at first, and its [i] wonderful [/i]. This game has balancing, and is balanced (for the most part) but the fact that Hopoo managed to make it feel like any run is broken is a development miracle. Want to run at the speed of light? Drink 40 energy drinks and watch your health evaporate as you hit a surface too hard and take the 1045720592 fall damage you were building up from spacegliding everywhere. Want to erase enemies from existence? Stack up crowbars and grab a big laser cannon and watch as you obliterate a beetle so hard everyone in the universe collectively forgets it ever existed just before seeing an enemy who is about to do the same thing to you. Want to play a supportive role and set your team up for success? One word: [b] [i] B U N G U S [/i] [/b]. EVERYTHING feels good to build and stack as you watch enemies evaporate before your eyes. The base item not spicy enough? Use the lunar ones! Insane upsides with (mostly) crippling downsides create crazy new iterations on any build. [spoiler] Use enough and you just might defy religion. [/spoiler] Go on, build a run that makes you think you'll kill god and then actually go do it. Nothing is stopping you, except god. And he'll put up a good fight.

If [i] that [/i] hasn't sold you, the modifiers might. Throughout playing you can unlock 16 different modifiers that can both make runs easier or make them so mind crushingly difficult you'll wonder how the devs even won with them on. But that's the thing, [i] they didn't. [/i] When the modifiers first came out, the devs said that they still haven't successfully won a 4 player lobby with all 16 active. I haven't been able to, and after about 5 tries it's easy to see why. The modifiers add even more new ways to experience an already vast and great game.

"But I don't like Roguelites" I hear you cry as you inexpliciable look at the store page for a roguelite. Well don't fret,l this is also includes a Survival Arena gamemode where you and friends can defend against wave after wave of increasingly powerful enemies. It's a great experience because all those busted item builds can be done here, and it's arguably easier to do. You can also throw on modifiers to make even more chaos. Hell, you can even [i] access a mini version of this mode in a normal run [/i] if you feel so inclined.

But if [b] [i] THAT [/i] [/b] hasn't sold you, I still have one trick up my sleeve. I have about 200 hours in the game. 0 of those have been played with mods. This game has third-party modding support, with mods that add items, levels, modifers, characters, and even fucking gamemodes. I have occasionally browsed the mod database and HOLY FUCK is there a ton of random stuff that all seems fun. Old characters from Risk of Rain 1, New characters based on no IP, various anime characters, League of Legends characters, items that break the game, items that [b] break[/b] the game, an arena gamemode where you fight monsters to get items then fight your friends, and even [i] breaking the 4 player limit on multiplayer [/i]. The modding community seems incredibly dedicated to this game, and I can;t blame them at all.

If you're concerned that you won't be able to get your money's worth from this game, I got my money's worth from the base game alone and the amount of mods that exist eclipse the base game's content tenfold. I can't recommend this game enough, both as a solo experience to chill out and de-stress after a long day as well as with a full lobby of friends on a Friday night. 10/10 would 100% complete again.

I am a 56-year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing Risk of Rain. I am a single father to my son, who is now 15. My son recently started playing Risk of Rain. In less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing Risk of Rain. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. Risk of Rain reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Risk of Rain 2 is a beautiful game with near infinite replay ability.

Risk of Rain 2 (ROR2) is one of the only games i own that i truly believe i could play forever and still find new things to do and enjoy it every time and additionally one of the only games with a that soundtrack i could also listen to forever.

The game features a large and varied array of items, each of which feels unique , even when having similar effects. This huge amount of items allows for an absolutely mind boggling amount of combinations and subsequently a massive amount of different builds. Every item feels like it has some amount of usefulness, be it some more than others, however each item has its place. For example the great and holy bungus (Bustling Fungus) emits a healing aura upon standing still for a short time, due to how the game requires you to be constantly on the move this usually sucks. HOWEVER the bungus is absolutely insane on the engineer class due to its interaction with the engineers stationery turrets.

Not only do the items feel varied but the characters aswell. Each character feels and plays completely differently which only furthers the replayability. One run you could be machine gunning people down with Mul-T and his nailguns whilst another run you could be swinging around the entire map in a singular second only to punch the teleporter boss so hard that it dies in a singular shot with loader. Not only do the characters feel varied from eachother but every character features multiple skills to choose from which can drastically change how you play, such as mercenary who can go from a full melee to what is essentially a ranged build.

But arguably the best part of the game is the absolutely jawdroppingly good sound track that accompanies the game. The composer (Chris Christodoulou) is an absolute musical genius. I still remember being thrown into the sundered grove my first time since its new theme track and looking upon this beautiful green mushroomy forest which was slowly beginning to full up with enemies, i remember farming up some gold, opening the red chest and getting the brilliant behemoth. And then the big drop hit and i can still clearly remember the feeling i had as i had an absolute euphoric feeling as i exploded my enemies into oblivion missiles flying everywhere all while being serenaded by Chris's sweet sweet soundtrack. I genuinely cannot stress enough how good the soundtrack is.

Overall ROR2 is one of if not the best games I have ever played that constantly keeps me coming back for the wonderful gameplay, and if not the gameplay for sure the music.

10/10 Engineer supremacy

PS: the song i mentioned earlier is titled "They Might As Well Be Dead" go check it out on youtube if you wanna hear it and sub to Chris while you're at it.

This should be the perfect game for me. It has the perfect mechanics that I prefer - I like the elements of chance combined with skill. It has a rich backstory and 3-dimensional characters. It's a point-and-click adventure with a large degree of autonomy. You are able to choose your own motivation, and play your character the way you'd like to. There is real humor, and you can choose how far to take the humor. You can choose to waste your time reading small minutia, or skip through it. Your character feels like a real person, with real struggles, and real decisions to make. Add to that a mystery in a science-fiction setting, and, in theory, I should be writing a rave review right now.

Here's my problem - it's very, very emotionally dark, to the point where it's affecting my mindset. At 16.3 hours, I'm about 25% through my first playthrough. I've had about 3 or 4 sessions of play - every time I stop playing for the day, I just feel empty and lonely. And, to an extent, I think much of the darkness is necessary for the subject matter - the mystery you try to solve just serves as a backdrop for the psychological landscape of struggling with addiction, amnesia, and discovering who your character is and who he wants to become. There are certainly bright spots - the humor, and crossing things off your task list. But everything - every mystery, every thought, every interaction - is anchored in the fact your character is a very broken man in a very broken world.

Now, I'm a highly empathetic person, fighting my own battles with depression to begin with. In all likelihood, and based on the raving reviews, I'm an outlier. It would probably help if I didn't keep playing for an hour longer than I intend to each time just trying to find a bit of sunshine for my character, and accept that I might just need to be patient and play through to the end. However, I think the strength of the game is the downfall here - I'm making decisions on when to tackle tasks, therefore the developer couldn't add bright spots to help with pacing. And pacing seems to be the main criticism of many of the other reviews. Maybe the emotional darkness would be easier to handle if the artwork was a little less gritty, but again, that kind of goes with the subject matter.

I really, really wish I could love this game. I really tried to love this game. I will likely try in the future to love this game. But right now, if only to warn someone else fighting their own battles that right now may not be the time to play this game, I cannot recommend it.

OVERALL: 8/10

PROS:
ROR2 is close to a masterpiece. It's a blast to play with friends or by yourself with loads of content to unlock, even if you only buy the core game without DLC. Even after burning out on this game, coming back after a few months is like a breath of fresh air. It's an easy to learn, but hard to master game that requires memorizing items and locations of certain shrines. Every character interacts differently with each item/equipment, so you need to familiarize yourself with these things to maximize each survivor's potential. The need to stay on your toes and make quick decisions is crucial to being good at this game.

CONS:
Depending on your system, you will most likely end up crashing the game at some points. It's good practice that after wave 10+ to lower your settings a little bit. The music is fantastic, but it does get repetitive after the first few hours. Hopoo Games doesn't update the game very often these days, so if you're use to games that have new content coming out every month you'll be disappointed. Lastly, if you're with other players and you end up dying later in the game, it is very difficult to catch up with other players in terms of items.

It is a rare instance that a games sequel manages to improve on its predecessor in every manner. In the days of low-effort sequels and crap reboots, a game that follows up on what came before and improves it is a welcome breath of fresh air.

What is even rarer is a game that manages to change visual mediums entirely, from 2D to 3D and yet somehow manages to maintain the art style, game play, and atmosphere of the original game.

Risk of Rain was clearly a labor of love, and Risk of Rain 2 is as well. The music is fantastic, the visuals are stylistic and beautiful to look at, the characters provide a wide range of unique play-styles to choose from. The Rogue-like formula works well with the generated items to make each run feel fresh and unique even on the same character. The secrets, minigames, and puzzles encourage repeated exploration and working with friends is a real treat. 

This game deserves to be played and appreciated for what it is, and it is absolutely worth your time.

Risk of Rain 2 is an absolute banger of a game

Rouge like games have always been my favorite types of games to play and this one nailed it. Risk of Rain 2 is a rogue-like where you find items that make you stronger in both obvious and unpredictable ways as you run through plenty of stages until you meet the final boss. This game has lots of ways to play and every survivor has it's own wildly different playstyle. Some are instant killing machines while others use their own health to destroy enemies. 1 run will never be the same as long as you try something new or choose artifacts to spice up the run even so, this game gives you all the freedom to run wild.

This game has a incredible OST and pretty vivid and nice to look at art style. There are tons of skills and abilities to try out and a HUGE amount of items to test out. Runs that go well can branch off in wildly different directions, where items twist character abilities into novel new uses. One item might sound awful on one character but godlike on another. The vast number of enemies, items, and abilities make for an endlessly replayable experience. Risk of Rain 2 isn't worried about giving you OP abilities because it knows that eventually, the difficulty level ticks up and up the longer you play until it reaches the infinitely scaling challenge.

There are dozens of hours of content available, and achieving godlike builds is unimaginably fun in a 3D environment. The adjustable difficulty, while not perfect, makes the game nice for new players and veterans. Risk of Rain 2 doesn't evolve the roguelike genre, but it does iterate on it in a exceptional way.

My only gripe with this game is that as every character has a different playstyle, there's a chance you won't unlock your unknown favorite character for a long time. So you have to have the patience to play the characters you don't like and possibly waste a few runs trying to unlock characters and you will possibly quit before that. 

Some tips from my experiences 

Some items can brutally detrimental, but you'll learn what to avoid with experience. Stay away from lunar items if your trying to have a good run. Then afterwards you can mess around with them eventually you will know what is good to use.

Try to do more runs without the Artifact of Command. This artifact can be quite fun at times and can be useful for that "perfect build" but remember that this a rougelike game and taking away that rng makes the game pretty boring being able to choose the best items all the time. Remember that printers and scrapper exist. 

In multiplayer, you should not grab every item you can. Leave some for your teammates. Otherwise they die easily, which kills the fun for them and makes it harder for you. Checking on your teammates item count is as easy as pressing Tab.

Time is the biggest variable to literally everything. Almost every aspect of the game that scales at all, scales heavily with time. Sometimes it can be better to just move on instead of spending 10 minutes getting every single chest on each level. You should be spending no more than 5 minutes per stage in stages 1-3.

That's about all Risk of Rain 2 is a brilliant rougelike game and remember to keep moving.

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

As it takes place with many characters, starting off with Johnmando. Who lands on the planet after the ship his crew was on is attacked and destroyed by Providence a God like entity. After many heroic fights, Johnmando, Johnforcer, Jondit, Jontress, Han-Deeze Nuts, Jongineer, Jiner, Johnper, Good Dog, Johncenary, Sigorney Weaver, Jeff, and Heretic work together to kill Providence. However, their attempts to escape fail, and only Johnmando, Good Dog, Heretic, and one other survivor (Your characters) survive. This is spoilers from the first game, and if you're reading a review for the second game, instead of first beating the first game, I want no complaints from your dumb ass, I'll spoil the section where we are at present then. Speaking of which. [spoiler] Johnmando is captured by void infesters and becomes the John Fiend, Good Doggo spends time in puppy jail but escapes, Heretic wills herself back to life as a ghost embodying relics, and the other survivor presumably heads back to earth, and gathers a new force of heroes to try and save those left behind, and stop Mithrix's influence. Upon arriving the team are tricked into dropping onto the planet, and their ship captured by Mithrix. It is up to the team, and you to fight off the barbarous natives, who are less equipped than you. At your disposal you have much more advanced technology, chemical warfare, weapons probably banned by the Geneva convention, and literal fucking magic. Rescuing the already captured John Fiend, Good Doggo, Heretic, Biolantine, and Johnificer the team is completed. A team of soldiers must find all the survivors, kill Mithrix, and spread Manifest Destiny. The rescue team in question includes Johndit, Captain John, Johnmando, Johngineer, Jontress, Sigourney Weaver, Johncenary, Mul-T DEEZ NUTZ and Johngunner. However, the longer they stay, on the planet the stronger Mithrix's influence over the planet becomes, with Providence already out of the way, the storm approaches, starting merely at a drizzle, becoming a rain storm, and before too long a monsoon. As Mithrix's power and influence increase, so too does his will, his creations, and the risk of rain. [/spoiler] Nice...

[h1] Okay the Real Review [/h1]

The music in this fucking game rocks my socks, it's a great synthwave pattern, that increases as the game moves further into its eclipse. The controls are smoove af, and the best part is how broken the game can become. Protip movement speed is amazing, especially if you're going so fast that your collision can kill enemies. It can be frustrating especially when playing by yourself, but with friends, this game is always just several hours of fun. Sometimes the goal isn't even to beat the run, just get a broken build, and laugh about it until Mithrix's Monsoon drenches everything in anti healing enemies, and then you die. One of my favorite bits, is the fact that achievements are tied to certain big unlocks. You get an achievement, and that achievement unlocks you an item or an ability, or maybe even an alternate skin. This is where the game shines, to me at least. It really feels good when you go out of your way, get an achievement, and then that point forward you may receive the boon of said achievement in game. More games should do it, and it made this game fun all the way through.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]

I highly recommend this game, it's fun, its fast paced, it can be picked up, and put down whenever (kinda like the family dog). It's got great music, a bunch of different game-play options, and some really awesome multiplayer dedication. But most importantly. It's got a beautifully dedicated team working on it, that regularly update, check on what players feedback is, get ideas to implement, and know how not just to make but how to maintain a game.

Risk of Rain 2 is a very fantastic game, from the characters, gameplay, music and even more. The game defiantly has a lot of love put into it. The best part of this game though is enjoying it with friends, I've had my fair share of extremely odd deaths but my friends and I shrugged em off with some laughs. The game also features some of the best ways to stack items ever, of course your opponents get stronger too if you aren't careful...

Next is the DLC which adds two really fun characters and the corrupted items which add another layer of depth to the game. And all the other goodies that come with it.

The game even has the prismatic trials to show off your skills, the simulacrum which acts like a horde mode, and even harder difficulties with the eclipse mode, which has occupied a lot of me and my friends time these days with the game.

Now what I dislike, which is such a small small list. 

Co-op deaths. I wish there was a system or a way to revive your allies while on a floor, becasue if you die early on your friends either have to feed you items next floor, or they have to rush the floor and leave immediately before the game gets too hard for the next floor. Personally this doesn't really frustrate me but it's there.

Overall very fun game, when friends ask if I'd recommend this game, I'd say yes in a heartbeat.

There's something truly special about this game. At about 90 hours now and it's easily one of the best purchases I've ever made, so much so that I bought it a second time on the Switch. That fact that it's only £20 is a steal, I would have happily paid £50 for this game.

Quick rundown: it's an action/roguelike with the aim of murdering everything to become more powerful, in an attempt to murder stronger things. You pick up items which can do anything from increase your attack speed and health, to making ever attack explode or being able to crush everything in the area by jumping. A multitude of enemies (and variations on those enemies), bosses, items and levels all of which are beautifully handcrafted and accompanied by a gorgeous soundtrack. The developers have put a lot of work into making this game something special and polished. This is a far better experience than the vast majority of AAA games at the moment and it really shows.

Ok, so I love this game, because it always is able to tread that line of same old same old and new, and in fact even now I'm still seeing new enemies and bosses, or finding nooks and crannies I wasn't aware of. I first found this game through youtube, and immediately fell in love. The mechanics of this game can make the beginning runs a bit tricky, but the good news is that you can make those mechanics work for you, and very often, as long as you can survive the first level, you are pretty much golden. What this roguelike does a bit differently is that itis forgiving, without being forgiving. You can make it so that you choose all items and are rained upon by them, but the moment you get cocky? That's when you get your shit pushed in and die faster than you can process. There aren't too many different characters, but each character ends up playing vastly different from each other, and if you find that you don't quite like any of them, even with DLC (which I also recommend)? Then that's fine, because the modding scene for this game is huge and frankly quite easy to understand, so you can add as many characters,bosses,enemies, and items as your heart desires. As a final thing, I think ScottFalco said it well when he said that this game goes at your pace, and you choose when it ends.

I bought this game on recommendation from a buddy like maybe a few days ago? and already have 24 hours playtime. This game is legit probably my new all time favorite. I can't remember being this into a game since like Skyrim came out. As you gather more and more items you slowly become extremely overpowered. In any other game, this would become boring, but somehow, in this game, that's exactly where the fun is. You can melt enemies but there's so many it still feels extremely well balanced. It's a game that somehow feels both easy and difficult at the same time in the most fun and satisfying way. There are so many hidden secrets in the game, and all the different playable survivors feel incredibly unique. Gameplay is incredibly smooth and natural feeling for all the survivors. There's a survivor meant for everyone's play style.

This game is a goddamned masterpiece and honestly triple-A studios need to be looking here for where the future of gaming needs to go (343, EA, Blizzard, Bethesda, looking at you guys). I've gifted it + the DLC to my cousin and a friend already.

Absolutely Amazing!!! Every hour is sure to have so much fun packed in it. Great diversity, still getting updated, and great modding support. If you want even more fun, I recommend the survivors of the void DLC. The cost is so worth it, 2 new characters, a new tier level of items, and more! I hope this helped, download if you like rouge-lites/likes, dungeon crawlers, 
 and/or third-person shooters. With a sprinkle of a late game god complex.

35 hours in and I feel like I'm just getting started. 

I've only got half the characters unlocked; maybe only 2/3 the items and enemies recorded. 

The characters are hard to explain. Each one genuinely has their own identity and play style. The first time playing each character feels a bit laborous once you've got some time with a different one; but after giving each and every character a legitimate chance, you soon realize that each and every class is genuinely fun to play in each their own way. 

Each have pro's and cons, and each have their way's of managing the cons. This game was well worth the purchase. I bought 2 more copies, one for my wife and son to join in on the fun. We all absolutely love it.

I got it on sale; but knowing what I know now, I'd of happily bought at full price!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Is it fun? Yes.
Do I recommend it? Certainly.

Unfortunately, after almost 30 hours of gameplay, I can confirm that this game doesn't have the same replayability as most other games sharing the label "rogue-like". The item pool itself is also very limited and only a very few items change the way you play throughout the game. Most are just there to make you do whatever you were doing already, but with more dps.

I really like the game.  It's awesome when it works, however most of my runs end because it doesn't.  Enemy damage scaling has been off for a while now.  Most runs feel so awesome, only to die in one hit to... well anything.  You never know if it'll be an elite enemy, boss, etc., but it rarely feels fair.  
Yea, you can argue, "Just don't get hit," but when a game is like 30 minutes cmon.
I'd like to see a patch that makes normal mode feel normal again.
You are weak, then you are a GOD! And then you get weak again and died in one hit. This is the cycle of Risk of Rain 2, you shoot and kill things, then they shoot and kill you.

This is an amazingly fun game.  Working through the different areas, learning a bit about each item, deciding on builds that are not only fun, but easily destroy your enemies, and of course, the challenge when you screw up your build and get obliterated five minutes into a run. Just...  make sure you turn off the PvP rune before you go deep into multiplayer.  People can be jerks.

Game got LOTS of issues design wise. First there is no automap, and no natural way of look around. Staying on low ground is a continous downside, literally. There are also no indication of enemy except if you catch where the shots comming from, which quickly gets discarded as you get flooded pretty fast (10+ min in game). Pick ups are not as easy to "pick up" on, turning off enemy corpses basicly a must less it clutters the field hiding boxes you should pick up. The game has an overal bad visual design when it comes to differentiate betwean stuff and other stuff.

The big ones. There are a lot of attack types from enemies that are locked on to you. While they have a minimal visual qeuee when it actually lands, from other visual clutter these become untracable. Further more there are attack types that shows on the ground, but thats the last place youll looking at as most enemies taller then you and you generally look upwards as flying enemies are priority due to theire angle of attack cannot be line of sighted.

The next big one is line of sight is okay from bosses, but not continous line of sight, thats a nono. There is never enough cover that could provide a decent moving oprunity while still in cover against boss. If you stay still the random adds will overwhelm you quickly. Also some bosses attack don't have a discerning telegraph, it just spits you from nowhere.

The game very well know its own flaws, hence all the heal options in game, that pretty much dictates if you get enough crap you deal with boss before it chews trough youre deffenses, if not then you done. Game has no skill requirement other then really good 3D navigation skills, and pixel perfect searching eyes to see all the hiden bits and bots scattered on the map.

You pretty much have to learn the map to even have a chance to make a path, and it actually kills exploration at that point as there is a set way of going to places. (story mode, there are random maps, god i dont wanna try those)

It sounds exciting, but no. The whole game feels slow to be honest. The amount of walk around especially after a portal just kills the flow. Some enemies are so slugish and even the fast ones can easilly tracked by mouse.

This game would need to redesigned pretty much in all aspect. Oh the gold gain is horrible, there is almost no qeuee or feedback that you got gold, you just know that you do cuz you killed but thats about it. Even the health to gold statue i used a lot before i noticed i got a text message what happened. 3D printer is random, holy shit its so bad all around, the designers have 0 clue what a game should be.

Btw i dont know how to refund usually its on propertiers but now its not. 86 minutes :/

[b] Highs and lows: [/b] You can either feel like the most indestructible abomination, surging through stages at breakneck speeds while vanquishing the world that lies before you- or like a pathetic helpless worm thrown into a world you don't understand and can't get your footing.

    It can be overwhelming to figure out what item does what while beetles, cute jellies, and ancient stone constructs attempt to purge you from existence, yet enjoyable to explore the different possibilities and combinations- and use that to unleash hell. This game offers many different ways to experience it should you choose to change it up. Much to explore.

Absolutely amazing game!
While I did not expect too much and was initially put off by the idea of the game and the artstyle, I now cannot stop playing it.
Hours fly by and before I know it, I look at the stage timer at 1h+ while it felt like maybe 15 minutes passed.

It's chill and relaxing, especially in the early stages and gets incredibly intense the further you go.
Prepare to die, like a lot but it's part of the game. Everytime you grasp more of the gameplay, the challenges and the mechanics behind it all and with each run you get further, get better, closer to beating the game.

There's also 3 sets of difficulties, with an "easier" mode that gives less enemy skaling and more HP regen as well as normal and a "super mega hard" (Monsoon) difficulty that basically reverses what the easy one does.
Meanwhile, the further you go and the longer you play a run, the harder the game gets too. More enemies, with more health and abilities leading to downright ludicrous amounts of earlier boss-level enemies as regular mobs.

There is really only 2 ways to end a run, either you die early on or when fighting the main boss, or you loop (essentially deciding not to fight the boss yet and go through a few more levels before) and get to boss-level status where you singlehandedly nuke enemies and bosses from existance mere seconds after spawning.

The game really does let you go crazy if you make it far enough, with each run feeling different, due to the loot and enemies being entirely random. Maps are not procedurally generated as in other rouge-like games, but handmade and feeling immediately familiar while still providing new things to find and new challenges each time.
Items you find give you various stat boosts, from abilities to passive stat boosts like attack speed etc. and you can stack them...a lot!
The game has no problem with you stacking +1000% attack speed or 100% crit chance items letting you experience god-like powers, provided you last long enough to find them.

At last, the lore and exposition is sparse, kinda like the Souls games, with almost everything being cryptic, requiring your imagination and giving you information mostly through what happens (or doesn't) ingame. Stages have secret paths, bosses, puzzles to unknown teleporters and the game has several endings for each run.

Graphically, it's got a sorta unique art-style. I wouldn't call it amazing or realistic but it doesn't want to be that. It's simplistic in nature but works damn well and has its own charme.
Performance is mostly stellar but be warned, if you go crazy and keep the run going long enough there will be so many effects and mobs on screen that it will tank. That's to be expected though with what's going on.

Sound wise, each character has their own movement, ability and weapon sounds that fit them. The music meanwhile is an absolute masterpiece, all handcrafted for the game, ranging from intense rock to downright relaxing tracks, which each stage playing a different song.

As with any rogue-like, when you die, you loose every item and the progression in the levels you had. The one thing you keep is a permanent currency you can use in a sorta hub-world that you can access by opening a portal there. While there, time stands still (aka. the game doesn't progress in difficulty), you can relax and trade items in for others as well as unlock permanent ones that you can then acquire in the runs. There's something more too it but I won't spoil it.

To sum it all up, I really didn't expect to like this but damn, it is such a charming game to play solo or in coop, unlocking new characters and abilities and finding what works for you and trying to "build" your character as much as you can with the random loot. If you have any interest in rogue-likes, do yourself a favour and grab this game!

I really tried to enjoy this game, I really did. Unfortunately, you can only slam your head into a brick wall so many times before you realize you aren't getting through. Risk of Rain combines two genres which I love, shooters and roguelikes which makes it all the more confusing that this game fails to impress. 

   - One major problem I noticed was that the combination of these two genres somehow managed not to take only some of the highlights of each genre, but also almost ALL of the lowlights. While many modern shooters are fast-paced with great movement, Risk of Rain somehow manages to feel slow both in pacing and in movement. You often have to choose between being fast and being powerful if you even have a choice.

    - Another major problem is the simple lack of variety in gameplay. Unlike most modern roguelikes, the maps are repeated as opposed to generated meaning that every time you go to a map, it's almost the exact same map as last time. It's much akin to listen to a great music playlist over and over, it's cool the first couple of times but after a while you can't help but feel like you need more variety. 

    - In Risk of Rain, there is almost no critical thinking required. Great roguelikes such as Hades or Enter the Gungeon require players to think logically about whether or not it's worth the risk to get a new item as well as weigh different options to try to get items which synergize well with the items you already have but Risk of Rain is *mostly* absent of these mechanics. If you have the money, open a chest, if you don't, don't. There are a few places where you can decide what you get (outside of Artifact of Command) but these too leave little option in what to get meaning that you can lose (often) due alone to not getting lucky.

Overall, I'm sure a lot of people enjoy Risk of Rain for it's unique characters and gameplay style, but for me it fails to impress. Risk of Rain fails to innovate and somehow manages to capture neither the charm and excitement of roguelikes nor the fun face-paced feel of a shooter. Despite this, I'd say the game is well designed and developed so I wouldn't blame anyone for enjoying it.

Hopoo has done an amazing job of breathing new life into a game that was already engaging and beautiful. They removed some small aspects of Risk of Rain 1; the climbable ropes and Life Savings, for instance; but the aspects of ROR1 that are totally missing from ROR2 are few and far between, and every single change Hopoo made is well worth it. The environments are completely immersive, the soundtrack is (once again) freaking brilliant, and the enemies (whether they're new or re-imagined) are even more beautiful and badass than what Risk of Rain 1 offers.  I was skeptical of the remake, as I know others have been, but Hopoo absolutely outdid themselves with Risk of Rain 2 and they have only improved what was already wonderful

Risk of Rain 2 is a perfect sequel to the original Risk of Rain. The original has a great soundtrack, fun and replayable gameplay, an interesting story and an excellent soundtrack. Risk of Rain 2 takes everything from the original and expands on it. More maps, more story, more items, more monsters, more secrets and more survivors. There's very little that Risk of Rain 2 doesn't improve from 1, although my beloved Enforcer is gone, which is sad.

A big selling point is the shift from a 2D platformer/shooter to a 3D combat focused game, which is a real improvement. While combat in the first game is fun, after a while it becomes a game of lining up enemies and positioning. In RoR2, the combat is much more reaction based and you can't see everything, which makes mobility and speed much more important. Unlike the first game, getting better doesn't just involve knowing the best items and survivors, now dodging Golem lasers since you know how to maneuver makes you feel awesome in a way the first game can't and shows the player the improvement they have made.

RoR2 is a "Roguelike", but its very free form. Unlike something like Rogue Legacy where content is locked off by progression and death, very little of the game can't be unlocked in a couple of hours, if you have a guide. The only exception being 1 survivor and certain items, which is weird since artifacts that completely change the game can be unlocked in your first run while very good items cannot, but it's not that big a problem.

My advice is to completely ignore everything outside the game, the guides, the speedrun videos, and the crazy 100+ crowbar Huntress videos and focus on playing the game. The game is meant to be a slow burner where heroes come slowly and secrets are obscure and subtle. After you beat the final boss, then find out how to unlock everything else. I think you will be able to appreciate the game more that way. Two thumbs up!

Phenomenal game with endless re-playability. It's become a go-to for the last year or so whenever I'd like to pick up a co-op game with a friend. There are so many ways to play this game, many characters to choose from/unlock, and as a result there are endless strategies to discover as you go through each stage. I'll often play with the artifact that allows me to choose items so I can pick my stack of upgrades that is best-suited for the character I selected. But it's also a pleasure to play with the items randomized, as it can yield some interesting upgrade combinations that I wouldn't have thought of!

It's great that you're able to change the game style through the various artifacts that you can unlock - finding a fun combination of them to play with has been a joy. The different game modes are such a nice refresher if you're in the mood to play something slightly different. Each stage in and of themselves have so many secrets to uncover; at times I'll forget about the timer just because I like to explore the stages!

As an aside, the art style of this game is truly a pleasure to look at. It's pretty hilarious that as you obtain new items, they're tacked onto the avatar of the character you're playing. It just feels like a lot of thought went into this game, and I adore it!

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

This game could be fun, but it's not due to sheer negligence. The developers literally bend over backwards in order to to make this a painfully unenjoyable experience. Have you ever been playing your favorite game, just leveling up on the grind and getting sweet loot.. only to just implode with 100% damage to death for no reason at all out of literally nowhere? Yeah me neither, because it's literally garbage design. 

This game does not understand replay-ability in the slightest. The rate of mobs/death once you have 3 rows of items is absolutely ridiculous. Instead, it just has these crappy little boring runs that never get any more enjoyable or rewarding. Always ending in the most boring and anti-climatic ways. "Wow I got 1-shot by some BS out of nowhere", or "Wow, I killed the final boss without taking any damage at all".

It's either way too easy, or ridiculous as hell and you lose all of your hard work instantly with no actual challenge presented. There's not some fight or puzzle that I lose, just needlessly self-exploding suicide mobs that spawned directly behind me silently while I fought the other 250 mobs in front of me, my bad I guess.. not. I honestly tried for so long thinking it was just my mindset, nope, this is just objectively terrible. Thanks, but no thanks. 

Imagine you're playing Counter-Strike and you're in a 1v1 situation. You clutch the round, get hyped, leave a spray, and knife the wall before sticking the defuse. Then you're quickly debriefing the round and planning for the next buy with your team. At the last second while defusing, you are shot in the back of the head by a "6th man" and lose. That's this "game", exactly. Trash, I know. I thought it was '5v5' too, I dunno what to tell you. *shrug*

I can get screwed and stripped of everything I work for in real life unjustly, I play games to get away from this hell of a reality. Once you are unfairly stripped of your run by bad design, you will never want to continue playing when you are forced to start over again. The beginning stages are a snail's-pace soul crushing experience of painstaking boredom. Especially in direct contrast to the run you literally just had unfairly ripped from you.

Feeling strong and starting to have a little bit of fun??... "FUN IS DETECTED" and soon thereafter you are suddenly forced to start over. Back to the 0 item equipped trash gameplay. They have no clue as to what makes something actually "fun", or how to embrace actual carry-over progression to unlock it's own natural "replay-ability". Wait, I thought this was a "VIDEO GAME".. by definition meant to be "FUN", oh? Hmm. Inexcusable.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

It can seem tough at times when you first jump in, but as you unlock more and more, the game starts to feel more and more rewarding as you turn up the difficulty and reach stages previously unattainable. With the inclusion of build diversity and a better understanding of item synergy, artifacts, as well as the inclusion of lunar and void items, the game is an instant 10/10 for fans of the rogue-lite/like genre. For those who are not avid fans of the genre, the game is still well worth the price and with a friend or two, your experience will only get better. 13 hrs on PC version, 74 hrs played on console(yes, it is good enough to warrant buying it twice).

I decided to give the game another chance and I have to say I found it fun this time. In true roguelike fashion, there are loads of items that can make or break your run, and admittedly it's rough finding out what items do what when there's a timer looming over your head at all times.

HOWEVER. I still stand by my belief that this game is too much in love with making annoying as hell challenges the method to unlock characters and items. Devs, if you want people to actually play with all the items, skills and characters, DON'T PUT THEM BEHIND STRANGELY SPECIFIC CHALLENGES like using a certain character to beat a certain specific boss that's not even guaranteed to be found in a run. I just finished a run where I had to land 30 consecutive shots on enemy weak spots and it was frustrating and grindy, not fun.

I would say this is a solid 10/10 in my book.  Risk of Rain 2 is a 3rd person rogue-like loot shooter that has tons of replayability and the fun is multiplied the more friends you have to play it with.  You can also choose to do casual runs and make silly ridiculous builds or challenge yourself with speedruns or "artifacts" to modify the gameplay to be more intense.  While graphically simple, the art direction is beyond amazing, the soundtracks have a lo-fi feel to them that adds to the background, and it runs with little to no stability issues making it super accessible even if you're still running Windows '98.

Would gladly recommend in a heartbeat, and the DLC adds even greater levels of content.

A lovely, stylistic game with a unique take on the rogue-like genre. The music and setting of this game elevates it considerably, without compromising in the least in regard to game-play and the overall experience. Coming from someone who typically doesn't play this genre, this is a pleasant surprise, and a wonderfully fun experience with friends, or even on your own for fun.

Game is extremely repetitive and boring. Equally as unfair as isaac but lacks the variety and metagame/strategy that makes TBOI entertaining.

The entire gameplay loop can be summarized as:

Run around level to find chest/terminal/shrine.
Open chest/terminal/shrine with money and get a marginal damage/defense/mobility increase. If no money, kill enemies until you have money.
Repeat steps 1-2 for 10 minutes.
Find the teleporter and press E on it.
Run circles around boss and shoot until boss is dead. There is a 5% chance the game spawns a cluster of enemies offscreen that kill you in half a second.
Go to next stage and repeat from step 1.

Most disappointing sequel to a game in quite a while.

At first it feels like a breathe of fresh air, you get to discover your favorite game with an added dimension, and with that comes complexity but you suddenly realize that the roguelite aspect is much more reduced, builds are much less wacky than the first game and the world feels much smaller somehow, it's more tedious than the first one and multiplayer is kind of garbage 
also you rely much more on the items than on the first game, but they refuse to make items fun and the chests mechanic doesn't translate as well to the Z axis.

Really should have had ziplines to replace ropes. The maps could have been bigger if there were more ways to traverse. Hell, the most fun characters to play are the ones that have extra movement mechanics.

Several characters are still either completely OP or worthless. This game is even more RNG dependant than the last. The level design is mediocre at best and awful at worst. The levels are far too big for lower mobility characters so you'll be running huge distances. This is even more frustrating in multiplayer.

Risk of rain 1 worked primarily because of its 2d environment. The devs unfortunately tried to literally translate many of its items and features without regard for its functionality in a 3d environment. It ends up feeling like a mess.

I've spent many hours on this game at this point and it was purely because I thought it would get better. I was wrong. This game isn't fun like the first one was, nor does it have its style. It's an exercise in frustration and nothing more.

The worst part about it for me is how character abilities are completely sidelined lategame in favor of just stacking more and more items. Good items are too obvious. There is no build diversity. Character quickly only become the sum of their items. Enemy design is just poor. Overall the game just feel sluggish. HP sponge game. Relies on one shot to kill the player due to how broken some health regen itens are. Note that lots of this also applies to ror1. Ill never understand the love for this series when it just commits sin after sin when it comes to good design.

They should have made your success more weighted on proper usage of skills instead of collection of items. Every god run just evolves into the same play style of lightspeed death ball.

[h1]RISK OF RAIN 2 REVIEW[/h1]
September 13th, 2022
13 hours in at time of writing

Just finished the game today, on the second try! I will finish my review now, as well. 

Why is this game immediately better than most other games?
Hmm, let me think- oh yeah, NO MICRO-TRANSACTIONS. Every (except two) new survivor is a grind to get and is usually well worth it, unless you just hate it's playstyle, but most survivors are not too terribly different. The only thing you could pay for other than the game itself is it's lone DLC which is not at all required but also worth it, and it throws in the other two survivors.

Why else?
Completely randomized sessions.
Every time you play this game it will be different. The levels are on rotation, but there is a limited number of them, so I'm talking about potential treasures and encounters. Every session has the potential to be a 'god run' and give you a ton of chests right off the bat, and every session has the potential to be forbidding of help to the player. You are the one with the brain. [i]You[/i] adapt, [i]you[/i] survive... or you die.

Perhaps another?
Every item (and arguably survivor) is useful and worth finding. Every item adds a permanent buff to your character unless it is discarded/traded by the player. And all of them are very useful and will aid you greatly in your many journeys. 

How about one more?
The art style and optimization is amazing. Consistently high FPS except for in MASSIVE fights, and I have a 2gb GPU! Not to mention the world design, background lore, and character designs. Everything just looks great, and will accompany your eyes nicely every time.

Surely there must be some cons though, right?
My only complaint is that there is no cross-play between PC, Xbox, and Playstation (something every multiplayer game should have), and also there is no Mac support. The only bug I encountered was with the Bandit survivor, where it would keep playing the reload sounds for about ten seconds after I finished reloading. But it has only happened once so far.

What about the BOSS FIGHT?
Even if you do survive four phases, there is no guarantee that you'll make it to the boss level and thus the only way to properly end the game unless you're looking for it. I did a few early runs, not having known how to get to the boss, and proceeded to complete around eight phases before dying, wondering how to get to him. Eventually I found out, did the pillars, got to the boss arena, annnd died with hardly any of the boss' health remaining. At the time of posting this review, I have just recently beaten the boss after discovering that he has, in fact, FOUR intense phases before you finally defeat him for good. Each one was very difficult, most of the time spent was trying to dodge his insane abilities. Solid fight though, reveals a bit more of the lore with a twenty-second cutscene at the end followed by the credits.

In conclusion, there is no reason NOT to buy this game. It will satisfy any gamer, no matter your favorite genre.

I've been a big Risk of Rain fan for a long while. It was a game I could play on my, at the time, mega potato PC for hours on end. So imagine my surprise when I heard Risk of Rain had a sequel coming out? And in 2.5D??? I remember freaking out over seeing it.

One of my biggest gripes with the first game was how slow it felt, without the Glass artifact. Yeah, yeah, call me a cheat, a casual or whatever, but the bosses felt like massive bullet-sponges that you just had to flail around with, and it was obnoxious to deal with. That mixed with the 2D aspect made the whole ordeal even slower, for while it was fun, there wasn't really much wiggle room for player expression, if that makes sense. RoR2 fixes this issue immensely, through a mix of scaling items, big numbers, and a... is it a 3D or a 2.5D game? 
Regardless, having the freedom to run around also helps adds depth (quite literally) to the fighting done. 

However, these big numbers are not just for you, but also the residents of the planet! The risk of (rain) death always looms above you as long as you play, even in an amazing run, and that's always a pleasant experience.
I also really enjoyed the recent 3D printer/scrapper addition. While it wasn't always there, it's a nice way to salvage a run, and bring a fair amount of consistency to the game.
I'm also glad they kept the artifact system from the first game, sometimes it's nice to slap on Command and instantly win, or slap on Glass and coin-flip on a victory.
Did I mention this game has mods? Oh, so many mods, from QoL to new content entirely, it's amazing.

Overall, worth the price, the game has infinite replayability (tm), unique survivors with varied skill sets, and even some familiar faces (RIP Chef)! As for the DLC, I have mixed feelings about it, if we're being honest, probably wait for a sale or skip it.

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I was skeptical at first of this game as I wasn't sure I would like the fast pace of it and being timed. Turns out I love it. I feel like a lot of care was put into making this game available to gamers who aren't the best at any sort of shooter games what with the different difficulties, characters, and drones (NPCs that heal and automatically attack for you). However, I will say that with the hardest difficulty (monsoon), I think the sweet spot in the amount of players is two. I feel like with three or more there aren't enough items to go around and with just one you're the only target soaking up damage. 

I am a bit of a completionist to a certain degree and will try my best to 100% the game. It doesn't have so many achievements to where it is daunting with some really challenging ones that did take me a good bit to get. The difference in the character design really helps with the replay-ability of the game. I highly suggest checking all of them out first and trying to avoid having just one "main". 

Highly suggest this for a group of friends. I feel like if you'd play it by yourself you'd tie of it a bit too fast.

Pretty nice roguelike, with some flaws. Recommend if you have someone to play with.

The gameplay follows a pretty standard roguelike route. You go through multiple stages, with each stage ending with a boss fight, eventually ending up in the final stage against the final boss. If you die, you start again. There are items in the stages that can be found to boost your character and a lot of hidden secrets to interact with There's a lot of random factor in the game, the items, stages, and bosses are all randomized, leading to some runs being godlike and some being just weak. A somewhat unique feature in this game is the loop mechanic, meaning that you can loop to the first stage again rather than proceeding to the final stage to fight the final boss.

The game encourages fast gameplay by making the difficulty scale with time. The various items and equipments in the game can create very chaotic gameplay, with some builds can easily win the game without doing much. This leads to some sort of balancing act of whether you farm for more items or proceed to the next stage.

There are no permanent upgrades in this game, just more unlockables, similar to games like Enter the Gungeon. You can unlock items, character skills, and more characters by completing challenges in the game (Steam Achievements). Personally, I didn't really like this mechanic. Some of the challenges are just really hard or heavily reliant on RNG. Since this challenge unlocks skills, items, or even characters, it can be frustrating as you can find yourself grinding a lot just to complete it. 

There's single player and multiplayer modes. Two years after release, I find it pretty hard to find multiplayer games to join. Granted, there's a discord server for finding groups. Still the single player and multiplayer gameplay differs significantly.

Before we go in, let me say that Risk of Rain 2 is a Roguelike. Not everyone enjoys playing Roguelikes. Understand? Good.

Risk of Rain 2 is a very good game! Everything feels so fluid and well made, and the game runs surprisingly smooth for the amount of particles and models on any stage. There are 3 difficulties that either help or hinder your gameplay, and at the time of this review I have yet to beat the harder of the 3 (known as Monsoon) solo. Speaking of solo runs, there is a muliplayer option for Risk of Rain 2 and with the right group of people things can get quite hilarious. Tho one thing I will criticize is the fact that if you die on a stage in multiplayer, then it is almost impossible to pick yourself back up and not die on the rest of the stages! So a revive shrine would be helpful each stage instead of reviving at the start of the next one. All that being said, Risk of Rain 2 is a very good game, with updates still being made. Definitely worth the purchase IF you enjoy Roguelikes.

I'll admit, when a buddy of mine bought me this game, I thought I was going to play for like 2 hours and drop it. I'm not much of a roguelike enjoyer, but I was curious as to why this game had such Overwhelmingly Positive reviews. 
Now I know. The gameplay loop, characters, and enemies are all so genuinely fun to fight. Playing with friends is also fun because you'll always have at least one item wh*re who'll be the main character for the run. 
The soundtrack goes hard. Listen The Rain Formerly Known as Purple, and then listen to They Might as Well be Dead, and then listen to Nocturnal Emissions, and then listen to Con Lentitud Pedorosa. I can't pick just one track, Chris Christodolou does such an amazing job with every track in the game they all slap. 
The lore is deep too, not in your face. Item descriptions you read in the main menu and the environments tell you the deep plot behind the game. It's all so sad and wonderful. 
If you like roguelikes, you'll love this game. If you have friends looking for your next game to play, you'll all love this game.

Overall Risk of Rain 2 is a very well made game for casual play and for those who like to grind out these rouge-like shooters.

Risk of Rain 2 is a great concept made by tragically prideful and unreceptive developers who will actively make fun of your performance in the game and write off any criticism on social media as you being an ignorant, sore loser of sorts. Deleting the players' health with half of the game's contents (in normal difficulty), to dissuade the player from choosing the difficulty that they like most (making fun of you for playing on low), or to make constant DPS aura bosses when your game has melee characters: all of these are clear problems for normal people, but the holier-than-thou devs are on a mission to keep everything that one could find obnoxious in and make you feel guilty for disliking it. 
You may like the game, but be aware that it has blatant design flaws that will [b] not [/b] be fixed. It's bad enough that these are there to begin with, but the devs are too all-knowing to ever admit that they could've messed up in any way.

I have not played this game as much as other people nor have tried doing multiplayer mode due to offline responsibilities, but RoR2 is that type of game that I'll come back to every now since the runs don't last that long.

There's always that "one more try" essence in rogue-likes which this game captures it very well. The characters I have right now (5 I think) varies vastly from one another so I'm fairly certain that anyone can find the character that they're comfortable with.

I highly recommend RoR2 to anyone getting into rogue-likes or games in general, or a chill yet fun gaming session with friends. Kudos to the team for making this game!

I'm not sure how I feel about this game.

To begin with, the gameplay is very good. It's fast, it's dynamic and every character feel very very different. Also, it's a multiplayer rogue-like with good gameplay. There is like... 2 of those so the game gets a lot of points for that too.

But, in my opinion, the rogue-like formula of looting a bunch of stuff without having any choice feels a little bit outdated. There are some fun new tools (like the 3D printer) to help with that and you can give items to your teammates in multiplayer but that doesn't change the fact that a bunch of random loot is a very core mechanic to the game.

The other thing is that exploring the map quickly is a very important skill to practice in this game. Overall it's a good thing and to me, it's quite fun to practice that but it makes multiplayer require good coordination and communication between everyone. I'm kind of mixed about that because it's a fun challenge but it makes an already hard game even harder for new or casual players.

Anyway, game good. 7.5/10

The amount of synergy, the smooth integrity, and the musical flow of this game is unmatched within the modern gaming world. Words fail to describe the level of awesomeness that this game is.
   The goal of this game is for you to never feel lost. No matter how many times you play, what you do, or where you go, you're always doing something right. The goal of the game, no spoilers, is to go through stage upon stage of a diverse, alien landscape completely overflowing with hostile threats. You can take as much time as you want during this wondrous escapade, too many secrets for even reddit to explore completely. the catch? Every single second you spend gazing at it's splendor, collecting precious resources, and fighting fiends, the game always gets harder. It. Never. Stops. Will you master the game and achieve an unmatched power level, defeat the game before it beats you, or fail to advance faster than the game does and succumb to the doom you fight so desperately against? Your adventure awaits.
This game changed my life. Solid 11/10!

Since there's no neutral option, I ultimately have to give RoR2 the thumbs down although I have fairly mixed feelings on the game.

I've tried picking up RoR2 multiple times since it's release and shortly after putting it back down, and it boils down to a problem I don't have with other roguelites: Maybe 75-80% of runs end in frustration. Since this isn't a problem I have with other games in the genre, so I played a few more runs and found that it really boils down to what feels like a lack of any control over most deaths. 

Didn't get lucky enough to find mobility? You are incapable of dodging often enough to survive the late game. Didn't get lucky enough to find decent sustain? Unless you're already an experienced player who's not getting hit at all, your run will bleed out. Don't have a good build? Enjoy a 15-25 minute last boss fight which is mostly running in circles pinging away at a gigantic health bar, where one mistake will lead to immediate death. And these are the cases where you know what killed you. Often times you're managing a crowd of enemies just fine in the late game, and then oops, your health bar vanished for no apparent reason. This is compounded by the fact the only info you're told about your death is what scored the killing blow.

Everything else is there. The assets are great, the map designs are for the most part great, with a variety in environment, enemy designs are solid with the iconic foes from the first game coming back, survivors are all fun to play and the items are as decent as ever, boss fights are generally okay. But it comes together into a lategame that feels overwhelmingly influenced by RNG and enemies that can one-shot most any amount of HP,a game that doesn't really allow you to understand why you died and how to improve from it.

Alright, 
[h1]Risk of rain 2.[/h1]

It has a very addictive and replayable, great gameplay loop: Kill monsters, get money, get items, kill more monsters, get money, get items, go to the next stage, repeat. The enemies come to YOU instead of YOU coming to [b]THEM[/b]. And, instead of the difficulty increasing per stage (Even though that is a factor) it increases with [b]TIME[/b], and that always keeps you on your toes and gets your heart racing in intense moments.

Characters compliment this greatly, as they all feel unique with their own gimmicks, playstyles, and all of them are at least PLAYABLE (some, more challenging than others, but every character can get a good run.)

The soundtrack is definetely not an atmospheric one, it sounds more like a great music playlist put together in a video game (except ...con lentitud poderosa since there was a particular level design choice that fit each other SO WELL, but I'm not going to spoil that), like hotline miami 2, but Chris Cotod.. Chris.. OKAY LET'S JUST CALL HIM CHRIS is a very talented composer, and made most of this soundtrack worth while.

Graphics are fine. Not much to say about this, it has a unique style but this ain't next gen, understandable for an indie studio that has been used to creating 2D games. 






Are there any negatives?

Waste of time.  Game is centered around a mechanic where difficulty increases with time.

Each level starts with a 30-60 second lull with no enemies.  There's no way to earn $, and literally nothing to do but wait for enemies to appear behind you.
Each level ends with a boss fight alongside a 60 second babysitting mission.

The core roguelike mechanic revolves around playing fast to avoid higher difficulty...and then the game intentionally wastes time at the start and end of every level - resulting in half your time being spent doing nothing or walking around.  This wouldn't be a problem if the game didn't become so punishing so quickly at higher time gates or if the fps gameplay was more fun.  But enemies spawn randomly and constantly backstab you.  Bosses are incredibly boring...they only deal damage through a singular cheese mechanic, but more likely you take damage from a flood of mobs - including random semi-boss enemies.  Nothing makes any sense and you usually die to fall damage or some stupid bs.  I tried to like this, but it's really disappointing.  The devs have pulled every f*cking trick to make the game more difficult, and the result is no fun...a bunch of cheesy BS that can only be beat with cheesy BS...such a waste of a game.

and it can be modded (with friends too) adding a buttload of replayability to the game.

[b] The Good: [/b]
The randomized items add to the uniqueness of every run
The artifacts allow you to modify the gameplay style to how you like
The characters are all interesting in their own right
The items are usually very interesting and can change up how you play completely
And the variety in the levels will keep you coming back for more without piling too much on you.


[b] The Bad: [/b]
This actually only has the same issue as risk of rain 1 where you don't start off with everything unlocked, you'll have to play through the game a few times (playing through a game takes about 30m to an hour or 7, depending on your style) in order to unlock everything so you can have fun in the ways that are fun.

[h1]So now the standard game rating:[/h1][list]
[*][b]Story: whatever/10[/b] The story takes a backseat but the observant will see it and appreciate it.
[*][b]Gameplay: 10/10 [/b] Extremely fun.
[*][b]Presentation: 10/10[/b] Fantastic artstyle and aesthetic.
[*][b]Soundtrack: 11/10[/b] One of the greatest soundtracks in video game history, it's on my list of songs to listen to normally, and it's good enough that normal people (not game nerds) would listen to it too AND not judge you for it.
[*][b]Replayability: 10/10[/b] Extremely fun to keep coming back to, playable offline, playable with friends, and modable

This game is a trip. It takes rogue like dungeon crawler type games to an insane level and brings out the beauty of the genre. The items in the game are all very unique and bring an enjoyable experience to getting them. Lunar items giving you downsides while giving insane upsides is also a really fun way to spice up a run. The multiplayer in this game is also really fun. It spikes the difficulty up to make it more fair and also drops more boss items depending on the number of players. For a majority of my hours I played this game with my girlfriend, and while most of it was spent her dying at the beginning of stages and me carrying when we played Monsoon, it was still an incredibly fun experience! I love everything about this game except for one thing. If you have the DLC that was somewhat recently released, then enemies named "blind pests" will spawn in. I HATE THESE THINGS, they fire the second they spawn in and do insane amounts of damage. Other than this enemy I actually really love everything that the DLC brought to the game! All in all this is a 10/10 game and is worth the buy no matter what the price.
