I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

As a rouge-like should be. The progression system does get more and more difficult as you go down the list of characters. However, if you were to take into consideration the four archetypes of players, this game hits all of them. Explorers will be able to explore each level and discover different areas of reward, killers will be able to mow down enemies, socializers will be able to show off their cool builds to people and different random runs, achievers can show off that they beat the game on Monsoon in X amount of time with Y artifacts enabled, you get the gist. 

Risk of Rain 2 is the pinnacle of hitting all four player types within a rouge like genre and will probably continue to be for a few years until they make something even better.

Risk of Rain 2 is a wonderful game that takes everything we loved about the original 2D game and further improves it in a 3d space. 

The gameplay is easy to pick up and fun to master, the art style is simple yet very pleasing to look at and the music is catchy as all hell.

If I want something challenging, I set the difficulty to monsoon and actively pick artifacts that would make the game harder. If I just want to murder waves of countless mobs after a long day of work I have those options as well.

Its a great game to play with friends, multiplayer works very well, and on the easier settings its great for younger kids as well.

Its a game you can pick up and put down very easily, you don't have to invest a lot of time into it, but if you want to unlock all the achievements then there is enough content that you can invest the extra time if you wish. 

Also (sorry valve) if you have a switch then this is one of the games i strongly recommend getting on that platform. It's perfect for playing during a long commute.

This game really makes you feel like rain.
Risk of Rain 2 is a surprising achievement not only for its insanely fun and accessible monster hunting action, but also for its seamless cross-platform multiplayer and non-intrusive free-to-play mechanics. Removing much of the supporting systems' complexity from games like Monster Hunter leaves a core that’s immensely fun to dive into for quick sessions or hours on end, even if the depth outside of combat and crafting is occasionally lacking.

When Covid locked everyone inside I stopped seeing my dad over the weekends for four months. We had played Risk of Rain back when I was seven, so when he found out that a second game had been made, he bought himself and I a copy so that we could play well we were both stuck inside. He passed away five months ago, from a heart attack. Now when I play this game all I remember are all my fond memories of unlocking characters and reading through logbooks. just a month after his death, I bought a copy for my cousin who had been almost as close to him as I had been, since her parents weren't the best around, and now I had spent nearly as much time playing this game with my cousin as I had with my dad. we still miss him dearly, but all of the fond memories lighten the pain.

 ( Also, me and my cousin just bought the new DLC and it's dope as hell! Fun times all around. )

I played this game on beta for 12 of my 16 hours and returned a week ago to play with friends. I didnt like it much back then but since it had been a few years i decided to try it out again. The game has not improved in any metric whatsoever in those years, with the exception of new content which only goes to make the game more of a cluster f*ck.

Visuals
The art style of this game is simple and works well for the game. That being said, playing this game past the first 20 minutes is visual diarrhea, there are so many brightly colored flashing effects and massive areas of effect that totally destroy visual clarity, that it makes it difficult to even look at the game at the worst of times. 

UI
This games UI is not good. Its not bad but its not good either. Its really unhelpful overall though, especially in the places it should be most helpful. I havent played this game in three years. There are dozens of items. Why dont they say what they do before i pick them up if they can brick my build? Is it really that hard to program? I shouldnt have to get a mod that doesnt work in multiplayer to try and decipher what a rare item does when i see one of it's tier once a game. 
Another UI complaint I have is a specific experience where I opened a scrapper, and right after a monster spawned in from of me. When youre in a menu in a game and an enemy appears, what if your first thought? Mine is escape. Escape from menu. Every game for 20 years. Not this one. It opens my pause menu and click back onto the screen to escape that. Where i click back in is where my best item is and it eats it. Nice menus.

Gameplay
Of every roguelike i played this game has the least build diversity. Items are all passive stat increases to your character or on hits for your character. The exception to this being activated items and lunar seed items. 
The activated items are one of two things, buff for your character or area damage.
Lunar seed items can brick your build if you dont know what they do. This has happened everytime ive tried picking one up. I complained about this to my friends and they said "oh yea i dont get any of those it usually isnt worth." Neat.

Final Thoughts
Third Person Shooter Rogue-like with entirely generic and uninspired mechanics, poor visual fidelity and less than great UI makes a game that I will never play again. I know a lot of people love this game, including many of my friends but its just so... underwhelming. The final game for me was great up until the final 2 round. In the next to last round I got one shot by a chain of explosions set at my feet by a dying enemy right at the beginning of the stage, sitting me out for 15 minutes waiting for my friends to complete the level, followed by the first item I picked up in the next level bricking my build from high attack speed on hits with ranger to a replaced primary skill that could only be deployed every several seconds, with no tracking aim. I went from massive thousands of dps per second to low hundreds. Games trash man, I dont get it

The game is overall great with a few hiccups here or there. 

Gameplay is fun, addicting, and has a great loop that makes you wanna keep playing, in the last two weeks as of writing this review I have added 35 hours to my previous time played. While I am not the biggest fan of the games soundtrack it is enjoyable enough and it is a good listen on occasion, although I would rather listen to my own music or a podcast. Graphically it is good as well, and the fact I can run it near max settings on a 2018 700$ gaming laptop is very pleasing for me since I don't have to give up fidelity for more frames. The character selection, map, and item selection is good, with the base game giving a wide selection of playstyles and terrain to have fun with and master your skills.

Some downsides is mostly having to do with difficulty. It can be extremely easy, even on normal mode, to fall drastically behind to the progressive enemy strength curve. Be it from not enough chests and multi-shops spawning, to the stage teleporter being far away from spawn or the teleporter being hidden inside or under some stage geometry. Enemies gold and xp not scaling as quickly with their levels be it from the timer or stage makes each beginning stage very slow, which causes the loop of being behind in items and on the timer which dictates how hard the enemies have gotten. My only other real issue is the relatively small character pool and enemy variety, I wish there was more base characters and enemy variety in the game, since it can get boring at times playing the same characters over and over and killing the same enemy but with different attributes and such if you are on a long gaming session. I've also occasionally ran into spawning falling through the map, but it's only happened to me a couple times in my 38 hours of playing,

Overall the game is good, it has some personal grievances with me but nothing severe, after all I keep playing the game lol. While the issues the game has for me can cut into its fun factor from time to time, in the grand scheme of things it isn't the end of the world. I highly recommend this game, it is a solid 8/10 experience, be that playing by yourself or playing with friends.

Notes:
I recommend buying the Survivor of the Void DLC; it includes a couple of extra things, new dimensions, and 2 new survivors to the game that make the game even more fun! 

When you first start out a run, there are different "stages" that the run goes through. The three difficulties (Drizzle, Standard, Monsoon) determines how long/fast each stage progress through time. This game is the literally definition of mayhem when you progress longer into your run.

WARNING: Runs are NOT savable. You have to complete them in one sitting, either beating the game, obliterating yourself, or disappearing (fate unknown). (Although you could kill yourself but it could prove difficult when you're broken OP and kinda pointless to take a loss).

While this game is soloable (solo runs), it is more fun to play in multiplayer. Modded versions (both single and multiplayer) are also common and are also very fun as well. 

Overall, the game is a massive blast to play, especially with friends! Highly recommend getting this game 15/10!

Risk of Rain 2, a game I didn't care about in a genre I hated, has become one of my favorite games. 

TL:DR - Risk of Rain 2 is a Co-Op (4-Player) Third-Person Rogue-Lite with a focus on 13 unique characters, who gain items through semi-randomized stages on various parts of an alien planet, traversed by using teleporters. Their main goal is to survive and escape via a multitude of exits, but most predominantly their captive ship, which the main boss has on lockdown. The game has a blend of character abilities and items, which alter how every run is played, ranging from minor buffs such as "+5 extra armor", to "Every kill summons sentient spectral daggers which lock onto a target and bleed them to death". There is a very large amount of lore to every item in the game, every character, species, etc. It also rewards the player for playing the game and completing achievements, as every achievement unlocked adds a new item for use. It has curated challenges every week, a wave-based survival mode, and a mode which adds up to 8 extremely hard modifiers on the hardest difficulty based on your skill. Every mode has a leaderboard as well. 

As I said at the start, I never really liked Rouge games. I enjoyed the few I played and welcomed the challenge, but, I like to hoard items in games and play a certain way, and since you lose everything when you die or win, I ended up not playing as much because I always had to change my playstyle away from what I liked. With Risk of Rain, I get to pick a character and set of abilities which are always there, but are affected by the items I get. It allows me to play in a style I want, but each run is changed due to the way I need to utilize that character's kit with different items. In this, Risk of Rain gives the player great amounts of freedom. Below is a short summary of each main feature. 

The Characters: Risk of Rain 2 has 11 characters by default (13 if you buy Survivors of the Void) all of whom offer a unique playstyle, different from the rest. By default, you will have 2/11, and the others are unlocked via basic challenges told to you in the selection screen. While some are similar by means of primary attack (Loader and Merc are primarily melee for example), their other abilities dramatically alter how you traverse the planet (Loader can swing around the map with a grappling hook, place electric drones, heal on hit, and no fall damage; Merc can dash multiple times, weaken enemies, and has a double jump). However, every ability in every slot can be changed via completing challenges for each character, unlocking new ways to play a character (Loader can do an AoE explosive slam instead of the shock drone; Merc can throw blades instead of dash). These challenges will usually test your skill with a character, as they encourage you to do goofy things, or give you insight to different strategies (One of loader's challenges reveals that gaining momentum to gains extra damage). Additionally, beating a run on the max difficulty will unlock a unique outfit for each character. 

The Items: There are 6 (7 with Survivors of the Void) item tiers in Risk of Rain 2. The color is related to the tier of the item, ala Borderlands. Despite the term 'Tier' being used, almost no item is truly useless. Every single item is good and has a place for a build in the game. Each tier has items that correlate to their purpose, such as White items being basic upgrades, Green items being more for utility, or add benefits to attacks. Red items are considered Legendaries, and dramatically increase the player's power. Yellow items are Boss items, as they are exclusively dropped by bosses, and each boss has their own item, albiet with a small chance to drop. Orange items are 'Equipment', or an extra, universal ability, which can drop randomly from chests and are usable by all characters. Blue items are specialized items which come with a great benefit, but yield a great handicap. Uniquely, they can completely change your character's abilities in exchange for others. All items are unlocked via playing the game passively, and unlocking achievements. An example for each tier is listed below. 
White:  "+25% attack speed"
Green:  "Gain an additional jump".
Red:      "Killing an enemy has a chance to resurrect them as an ally until their death"
Yellow:  "All critical hits deal bleed damage, enemies bled to death will now explode"
Orange: "Gain 100% critical chance". 
Blue:      "+100 damage, but -50% health"

The Gameplay: The game starts with you landing on the planet with nothing but your skills. To progress, you need to find a teleporter, indicated by distinct red sparkles it gives off. While doing so, you will be constantly attacked by monsters. Defeat them to earn gold, use gold to open chests scattered around the stage. the difficulty is based on how much time you've been playing, and will mercilessly punish slackers who cannot loot or kill efficiently. The game is incredibly simple, yet the more you play, the more intricate it becomes. Enemies will scale with your level, new monster types will begin spawning based on the time and stage, and even elemental variants will become more common. There are 6 (7) elemental types, which all give bonuses to the monsters, and possibly even their allies. Ranging from healing each other on their death, removing your ability to heal/cloak, or simply inflict freeze or fire (These 'Aspects' can drop for players, giving you a permanent, passive elemental buff, but its a 0.025% chance). Eventually you may be 2-hours into a run and ONLY bosses start spawning because the game understands you're too powerful for default enemies. Then, they too, become elemental, special bosses that can negate some of your status effects or healing. The game thrives on chaos and extreme power-tips. Additionally, Risk of Rain 2 has a lot of secrets, such as endings, items, and even map details that open new areas, all found via exploring the stages. The game has more than just the repetitious, yet satisfying combat loop, It rewards exploration and experimentation. 

The Lore: it may not look like it, but Risk of Rain as a series has some impressive lore. It covers every single item in the game, as well as every single species, boss, stage, character, and even reflects some entities not found within the game. It has a very large world building scene, all discovered via the log entries and some key details on the stages, reflecting the way in which Dark Souls covers some of its stories. In that regard, Risk of Rain also delivers, as it elaborates on the tale of each item and their original wielder, the main bosses' emotional states and background, the survivors of the crashed ships on the planet, etc. There are hundreds of logs to read, which are given to you as you use an item for the first time, defeating an enemy, finding it on the stage in a hidden spot, etc. The game rewards your time in more ways than just power. It rewards your curiosity as to why you're there, or why everything wants to kill you on sight. 

Overall, Risk of Rain 2 is an astounding game. It offers exceptional gameplay, paired with a huge amount of build variety per character. It has a massive stockpile of weapons, gear, and items that make you feel like you're gaining strength, as most items provide meaningful stats. The stages are all unique and isolated from one another so it doesn't feel like you're playing the same map every stage; it has a massive artistic appeal due to the designs of each stage, enemy, and attack. The game respects our investment to it. The more you play, the more you devote time to achievement hunting, or to a character, it will respect you enough to reward you something new, every time. A new item, a new character, or a bit more lore to help understand what your purpose in-game is. I'd definitely recommend buying this game at full price if you like Rogue-Lites, or want to try to get into them.

While the faithful recreation of the "rofl lol get wrecked noob" kind of messages every time you die may be charming to some, it wasn't what I was looking for and will be a turn off to players looking for a single-player rogue-like experience to unwind to, so I can't recommend this game on those grounds.

To put it another way, I don't care to spend my evenings on a rogue-like that berates me for dying when dying is an integral and expected part of the rogue-like experience.

The best enjoyment of  risk of rain, is how how much you can customize the experience, from which of the survivors you want to play each giving different play styles, to being able to customize that further with alt skills adding more variety. Hell, maybe you dont like a certain aspect of your characters kit at all? Use heresy items and you have even more options.

Want just a fun ride without much stress, or even a good way to learn a character and unlock things? Well you have drizzle, and you can play drizzle with no penalties, maybe you want to kick it up a bit and play rainstorm or monsoon? That's also perfectly viable, and by doing so you unlock some extra goodies that arent remotely mandatory what so ever.

want to really punish yourself and play eclipse? Go right ahead! Test your endurance and brace that brutal challenge, you can do that, and the game will never force you to do so as it provides as much benefits as playing drizzle.

Maybe you really wanna make a run interesting and start turning on artifacts? Sure, thats a great way if you just want something different. This even includes the double edged sword known as command since using it actively slows you down late game, but it can be really good for those tricky unlocks, or maybe your a loot goblin who wants a raw power trip, well then turn on sacrifice.

The biggest strength of Risk of Rain, and why its so popular is that it provides many, many ways to play for different people, and all of them are correct. Can playing with randoms who dont have the same playstyle as you be annoying, yeah it can. But that can go for any game, LFG options are available even if outside the game.

Drizzle, Monsoon, Command, Glass, Simulacrum, Eclipse, all are equally valid ways to enjoy the game!

The only issue I have with this game is you can play the game where you can select the items you get at a given rarity (as opposed to random items) by using an artifact (you unlock them in game). There are I believe more than a dozen artifacts, but this one artifact COMPLETELY CHANGES the game.

Yes you can not use it, but it makes builds so much more powerful and satisfying that the game feels way slower and harder (in a bad way) without it.

I wish that in game when you got an item, instead of getting a random item you could choose from 3 or 5 options, I think that way you wouldn't be able to go absolutely crazy OP builds and also have some RNG in it.

I'll try to keep this brief. I have multiple friends that play this game over and over, doing run after run after run, for hours on end back to back. They convinced me to buy the game and DLC while it was on sale. 

The game has many playable characters which have different mechanics, attacks, and play-styles, this combined with the many random items you find throughout the game give it a lot of depth, and pairs nicely with the mechanic that directly ties enemy difficulty to how long the run has lasted.

It's a decent game, unfortunately that's all it is, and I stopped enjoying it after only three or so runs, after that it's just the same repetitive slog, where your fate is decided by item RNG. 

It's not worth the $25 price, and absolutely NOT worth the almost $50 price when you add all the DLC into the mix. I'd only suggest getting it if it goes on a really big sale.

Be advised that this game needs some serious quality of life enhancements to make things less painful for anyone going into it solo and blind. 

Here is some advice: 

- Commando, despite being the marquee character, is probably one of the worst in the game. Pick someone else as soon as you can. 
- Play on the lowest difficulty level until you learn the game, then ramp up the difficulty from there.
- Your primary objective is to find the teleporter and activate it. Go open more chests later once you have the money from the teleporter fight.

Easily my favorite roguelike game of all time. RoR2's gameplay loop is like doing weed without the doing weed part. You just get so absorbed with the flow of the game you lose focus of your surroundings and can only really think of the game. Which shows how solid the gameplay is overall.

One thing I need to bring up is the music. The whole soundtrack has a weird and alien motif to em all that also fits with the otherworldly feel of all the maps you go to throughout the game. Not to mention they are straight up bangers in their own rights.

The game itself lets you choose between a set cast of characters that are still being added with more upcoming updates and dlc. No character in this game plays exactly like the other which helps add another layer of replayibility on top of the already high ceiling of replayibility in the game.

My personal favorite thing about the game is how it goes about with the unlockables. They range from equippable items to characters to even character abilities. I love this unlock system so much is because to unlock one these options you always need to do a specific thing while playing the game. Some challenges may require you to kill a certain amount of enemies with a specific ability, maybe you have to reach a high speed level while playing with a specific character. Some of these challenges require you to do things with certain characters that you might not have thought to do before and in turn you would also get a cool unlockable to use on your next run. Its a constantly moving feedback loop that makes the gameplay all the more exciting.

RoR2 is so hectic, so fast paced, that returning to this game every once in a while may just lead to more hours of insane fun.

9.1/10

I'll start off by saying this game plays very well but it's not even close to what some of the tags say. I don't understand how this is a rougelike. Rougelike games typically require some level of skill. For instance, it's nearly impossible to grab items on the screen without taking severe damage since the enemies just never stop spawning, even for a couple of seconds. The more you kill, the more they appear more quickly and in increased numbers. So you just aim your cross-hairs and keep the trigger pulled while hoping for an escape path, This game is a 3D bullet hell where you're constantly surrounded by an increasingly large swarm of enemies. I don't find bullet hell games fun but, if that's the kind of game you enjoy, this one plays well.

Edit: You can give me all of the clown awards you want. I didn't allow comments because I'm not opening myself up to abuse from die hards. Games like Hades, Going Under, Streets of Rogue, and Gunfire Reborn share common traits like learning enemy patterns, proper timing, and using the battlefield to your advantage. Risk of Rain 2 is a never-ending-swarm simulator where none of those concepts apply and most of the reviews or tags are misleading and not helpful. People should know what they're buying before spending hard earned money on this game.

Leaving a review for this game is fairly challenging  as i have mixed feelings on it. So i will break it up into pros and cons for simplicity sake. (This review will largely focus on Monsoon the highest difficulty setting, but will be applicable to other difficulties as well.)
Pros.
-lots of characters and variety for many different play styles
-the rouge like characteristics keep runs fresh and interesting
-the recent SOV update is extremely polished and mostly added good things to game.
-Its a nice casual game to run through with friends.
-the game is very in depth and has a lot of neat little features and tricks that you can learn with each character.
Cons.
-its difficult when playing with friends to keep track of the amount of items each person is getting, often times leading to one player being severely under-powered.
-If you are playing with friends and die early on in a stage you are punished severely, you will not collect any items putting you way behind, you will get no XP, and you will spend the entire rest of the stage simply spectating others playing. this can lead you into a downward snowball of being repeatedly  killed at the start of stages due to the increasingly stronger enemies, and the distinct lack of levels and items.
-for a game where runs often take hours to complete, often times they end with you being killed in one shot by something you could not see coming.
-By far the worst of the negatives comes with the change to one of the final bosses, Mythrix, and more specifically the addition of phase 4 where he takes ALL of the items the player has up until that point. in many scenarios this will result in a swift death, keeping in mind one would have spent hours getting to said final boss. for some survivors like Railgunner who has adequate range and little need for items this phase provides nothing but a simple hurdle. but to those without ranged attacks, Mercenary, Loader, Acrid. This phase seems completely one sided and unfair. The issues is further exacerbated by certain items. if you were to pick up an item that gives you a summon, he now has it and will actively use it against you while you have no movement speed, defense, or health to protect yourself. using another example, if you were to pick up an item called safer spaces (which blocks the first hit you take before going on cool-down) on a character with little ranged it becomes near impossible to actually damage Mythrix which is the required action you need to take in order to receive your items back. there is many more examples of items that almost completely nullify your chance at winning the main point is that this phase limits what items you can and cannot pick up, or forces you to seek an alternative ending for certain characters leading to a rather un-climactic end to runs and or frustrating deaths caused by picking up certain items (which is one of the main mechanics in the game) it literally is punishing you for playing the game. 

With the play time that I have it is easy to discern that I largely enjoyed this game, and if you are actively interested in a casual game to play with some buddies I would recommend it. However, this game is extremely frustrating and frankly unfair at times. my main issue as should be obvious is with the added phase to Mythrix which creates a huge artifical difficulty spike, which affects certain characters drastically more than others at a point in the run where you would have spent a considerable amount of time just to get there. this game can be fun to play with some friends from time to time, but is often times extremely frustrating and unforgiving for the amount of time required for each run.

G A S O L E A N GUD

While at first this game was fun, I find it more annoying than anything. The main gimmick of the game is playing fast so that later parts aren't as difficult, but when you do that you're underpowered as shit. Even on the easiest mode, by the time you reach the last areas you're screwed no matter what. I would like to note that this is mainly from a singleplayer perspective. I have almost no friends who have this game that still want to play it. When I did play with them, the game was just as hard and unrewarding, but at least I had someone to talk to during it. Maybe it will get better as I play, but I see no reason to continue. The gameplay is unrewarding, the characters range from OP to why would you ever choose them, the areas are repetitive and depending on your character very hard to traverse, bosses are also repetitive/repeated multiple times in one run, and the story isn't gripping at all.

It is genuinely the most fun I've had getting beat up hundreds of times for hours at a time.
15/10 Highly highly recommended.

A great time! Much more than just a mindless shooter game. Beyond your character's abilities are and the basics of how to move and interact, you are given no instructions. You must fight, defend, explore, discover, unlock, and, most of all, do it as a team (or at least, teaming is much better than solo in my opinion). The game teaches you to think about your enviroment and abilities and use them to your advantage in order to progress to the next stage, and to unlock new areas and items which you probably thought never existed. The final boss doesn't have to be the end - there are other ways off of this world.

This is, THE GREATEST Rouge-like of all time. Even just basic gameplay feels great, every character has a unique gameplay style, making builds around certain aspects of their characters is great (since there aren't many items that will "ruin" a run, most items that don't fit into your build will still help you anyways), area design is perfect (since while every area has a random spawn locations for chests/the exit teleporter, but the level design itself is the same every time), and the soundtrack is GAMING. Very easy to get overpowered, but one wrong move will still throw you straight back to square one. Great for multiplayer as well. Truly perfect. ALSO MOD SUPPORT, THAT'S A THING, DON'T FORGET ABOUT THE MOD SUPPORT.

Definitely get the SotV DLC as well.

I came into the game expecting it to be as good as Dead Cells based on the number of positive reviews that it had received. It's not as good. Not by a longshot. 

Now, I'm not saying it's a bad game but... generally speaking it devolves into a big numbers simulator later in the run. This would be fine if the game was designed in a way that allows you to do amazing stuff when you get that far, like Dead Cells, but... the numbers is all you get and you either insta-gib enemies or they insta-gib you. Some people may find that to be enjoyable but I'd prefer to actually have some gameplay that goes beyond aim-kill and yes, that is just my personal opinion.

I'd give the game a middle of the road score if I could but because Steam only allows for polarized reviews I'm gonna give it a thumbs down. If only because the game feels really, really shallow.

When I first heard of this game, I thought it was gonna be pretty repetitive, hence the tagline "loot, die, repeat", but I could not have been more wrong. I first started playing the game back in Early Access, before a lot of things were added to the game. I had pirated the game at that point thinking it wouldn't be a permanent staple in my gaming diet. After my 2nd or 3rd run, I knew for sure that I had to buy this game. Every penny of the price tag is worth it for the amount of fun I've had. I can still load up the game today and discover things I didn't know you could do.

With the release of Survivors of the Void, as well as talk of new DLC being released in the future, I can not express through words how much you need to buy this game
An amazing game easily worth every dollar

It's one of the best chill n play roguelike. This game is one of the games that you can play to relieve some stress by casually playing as well as talking with friends. Difficulty of the game increases over the time, so you have to complete the levels as fast as you can and even the normal difficulty is hard to beat. I mean I haven't even completed the game at normal difficulty yet but the thing is I don't mind that.
The way game is made, even after losing you learn a lot of things about the boss who defeated you as well as the different items you got in that run so every run in the game is quite unique in its own ways. That's the reason why the game has unlimited play ability and every time you learn something new and improve from that. This helps you make a build which suits you according the way you play. I haven't played a lot of games which are this rewarding as your time n experience increases.
This is the reason why I can totally recommend this game to any casual gamer who wants to try something new.

I loved Risk of Rain and played the hell out of it, and when I found out about Risk of Rain 2 I was confident enough to buy it early access. I did have fun with RoR2, unlocking the new characters as they were added in and trying out new things, but when the last "free" character was announced, I instantly lost interest in the game. Announcing paid DLC of characters, levels, items and game modes before the game was even out of early access killed my want to continue playing, and that of anyone I knew who played it.
You can have fun playing this alone for some cool builds and hectic runs. You can have fun playing this with friends for some crazy antics and ramping madness. But if you end up paying around $35 dollars and then are asked for more than $20 more for basically the full game, I wouldn't blame you for dropping it.

A typical roguelike game will have a honeymoon phase while you learn the game, try out various builds, and find exciting combos. Once you've experienced everything the game has to offer, the prospect of playing more generally loses some or most of its appeal. 

Risk of Rain 2 is an exception to this trend in that my enjoyment of the game has steadily grown the more I play. Even with nothing new to discover, the core gameplay is fun enough that I'm now playing it more than ever. Would solidly recommend to any fan of the genre.

Pretty fun and casual little roguelike with a decently sized chunk of lore embedded, although it feels a bit cryptic and hard to read. Multiple difficulty settings and no punishment for playing on easier modes is a very nice feature, difficulty settings are also well balanced. Game feels easy on easy, challenging on medium, and a struggle on hard.

Difficulty scaling is probably the coolest mechanic in my opinion. I haven't seen this in any other game, but it works so well. It's a clever way to punish overpreparation but also reward underpreparation. It allows you to play the game two ways. You can play slow, and get a lot of money and items, or play fast, and just slay things while barely touching on chests or cash, and either way has the same difficulty.

Multiple survivors with ACTUALLY different playstyles is a cool feature. Typically games like this with multiple characters have different abilities, but overall very similar gameplay. So far from what I can tell, the survivors in this game each seem to have a specific strategy you will be using throughout the whole run. For bandit you will always be turning invisible and getting to the backs of enemies, for huntress you will be constantly sprinting, for REX you have to carefully watch your healthbar, etc.

I also heavily appreciate the manipulation you can do the RNG in this game. Multishop terminals that give you a choice of 3 items all costing the exact same is nice. Shredding items you don't want and being able to bring them to a 3D printer and making tons of an item you do want is even nicer. Artifact of Command allows you to turn off RNG entirely if you are going for a very specific set-up, and you aren't punished for it at all.

This is one of the best games in the Rouge-like genre.
The game play loop is addicting.
It takes time to learn the basics, but you'll soon find yourself enjoying the gameplay.
Different from other Rouge-likes, Risk of Rain 2 doesn't allow you to get "stronger" or get any permanent upgrades. You will have to practice your skills to be stronger. The game does have permanent unlock Artifacts and alternative abilities, which allows you to have new play styles and new game plans.

Overall, heavily recommended.

You pick up an item you can't drop without finding a certain OTHER item. This item halves your health. Now any simple attack from any ordinary mob can kill you in 1-2 hits, and they spawn like crazy.
Now imagine you make it all the way to the end, the final boss dies and his minion just whacks you while you're passing by and ends your entire run.
Now imagine that doesn't happen in the next one, and you make it to your ship only to see that you have to "defend" it while it charges up. If you don't get to it on time, you're forced to wait for the game over screen, since the ship can't charge up in time before it's game over. HOW THIS PERSISTED AS A CONCEPT BAFFLES ME.

This game is a rouge-lite type of game, with tons of replayability and many things to unlock. The gameplay is addictive, and although repetitive at first glance, depending on your build things can get very interesting. There's quite a few characters, and each character can unlock different abilities to add some flair to their builds. Top this off with different items which can synergize with your character's abilities, as well as with eachother and you've got yourself endless combinations. Playing with friends is an entirely different experience, and i highly recommend it. The game itself is not demanding (unless you get pretty far and a million enemies spawn), the soundtrack is pretty good and the visuals, although simple, have a charm to them. The DLC available for this game is what DLC should be, adds more stuff to do but isn't essential to the experience.

The only downside to this game compared to other similar games is that you cannot save your progress during a run, which can be inconvenient since the runs can be lengthy. This forces you to either finish the run or die, which means you should reserve some extra time when playing.

Risk of Rain 2 is almost always a satisfying game to play. It features tons of unique characters, abilities, and items, and it's massive amount of achievements give the game an incredible amount of content and objectives for players to follow. When I first opened this game there were only three characters, Fifty hours in and I'm two away from having the entire roster. Initially I chose the Huntress character ,since railgunner seemed way too complicated and commando was just bad, and I enjoyed the game. The real problem arose when I realized the character had a major flaw though, she simply didn't do enough damage. After trying unlocking Mercenary I tried him, and it was fun, but he didn't work well with my friend's characters. I tried Artificer, and again I didn't do enough damage. No matter who I played I just couldn't win, especially in team play. This was only the beginning of my frustrations. So much in the game began to annoy me. Whether it was certain enemies (I HATE blind pests), bad rng, or MUL-T players taking all my crit-lenses, I was constantly frustrated by this game. Eventually the game got to me and I started to become a worse person in many ways. First it was in the game, I would hog items, I would insult my friends, I would act awful, but then it became an out-of-game thing. I became a rude, decrepit, and vile shell of my former self. Eventually it went too far and lost everything. My wife left me and took my job, my home was repossessed, and I was excommunicated from the Mormon church. I had nothing left but my steam account with this cursed game. I decided I'd load up a run, I called my friends and together we faced the immersive world of Petrichor V one last time. It was a simple run, medium difficulty with no artifacts, but that run would turn my life around. We cruised through the levels and reached the final boss in his lunar domain. This was it, my final, my last recall. Our MUL-T player was the only one left by the end of the fight, but it only took one player to carry us to victory. That same MUL-T who had stolen my crit-lenses not too long ago had won the game for us, and so it was a wonderful victory. I chose to watch the credits for the purpose of sentimentality, and what was at the end was an experience words cannot do justice. It was a strange form of bliss, not overwhelming, but more than adequate, something in my soul congratulating me on a job well done. as all the thanks scrolled past I read those delightsome words. 

"and you, yes you! Thank you!"

And all was well. My journey had been worth it. 
6/10 (blind pests really ruined the experience).

[h1] Risk of rain 2 is the kind of roguelike where you wanna have just one more quick run before bed but end up playing till dawn. [/h1]

[b] Visuals: [/b] 
The art style is easy on the eyes early on, but as the run continues and your screen starts to fill with clutter, the diarrhoea christmas lights at later stages can be seizure inducing.

[b] Story and Setting: [/b] 
RoR2 doesn’t hold hands and guide you through its story because honestly there is not much story going on here. There is rich lore to explore for people who want to.

[b] Music: [/b] 
The lo-fi melody perfectly fits the perilous environment and matches the gameplay with synced rhythm and tempo. Sound design is good too.

[b] Gameplay and progression: [/b]
Drop into a planet, kill monsters, get money, buy items. Rinse and repeat until you become powerful to one shot God himself. Fast paced with constant running, jumping, sliding and juggling between primary weapon, secondary weapon, abilities and equipment. In each run the difficulty increases over time, which is an innovative approach to deal with difficulty. The roster is filled with unique characters who each have their own gameplay mechanics, making the game feel completely different. 
Most items can be obtained by completing specific challenges. You can also unlock game modifiers to make the game easier or more difficult to your liking. The challenges are one-of-a-kind, and the rewards are meaningful enough to keep players interested.

[b] Game time: [/b]
There is no limit. It stops being fun when you decide so.

[b] Online: [/b]
There is co-op to enjoy with friends and difficulty scales with the number of players. And if you have no friends, rest assured because all achievements are attainable through single player.

[b] Bugs: [/b]
No bugs or technical issues.

[b] PC Requirement: [/b] 
Without a decently powerful PC the game faces severe lags and occasional crashes in long runs where you loop multiple times and a million things are happening in the background. Lowering graphical settings can help to an extent.

[b] DLC: [/b]
Survivors of the Void DLC adds excellent new characters, stages, items,  enemies and alternate endings.

[b] Price: [/b]
Worth every penny.

[b] My only problem with the game is it doesn’t have a save system. Once you start a run, you will have to see it through to the end. I want to be able to stop at any stage and continue from there later on. I don’t always have hours required to do multiple loops in one sitting. Although there is a mod for saving, I would love a native option. [/b]

[b] Rating: [/b] 
The Devs are continuously supporting and updating the game which is commendable. The community is very active and you can add tons of community made [b] mods [/b] to breathe new life into your game. 
I highly recommend it. [b] 10/10 [/b]

Wish there was a middle like/dislike button. Decent enough roguelike with one of the best OSTs of all time, but lacks the depth of builds that many other roguelikes have. It always seems to be pick up everything except the like 2 items that will brick your build, and sometimes you win. Pretty lame when you compare it to the build customization and choices you make in games like Isaac and Dead Cells. Get those games before this one, and listen to the OST of this game on youtube (The Rain Formally Known as Purple=amazing).

It's rare that I find a shooter that I like. It's rare that I find a multiplayer game I enjoy. It's *especially* rare for a game to be both of those things, but still something I can have any amount of fun with. Risk of Rain 2 is all of that and more.

There's bound to be at least one (if not many) playstyles you enjoy out of the selection they give you, the game has a way of keeping things fresh from run to run by changing both the layouts of their maps and which maps you come across entirely, the progression system is straight nutty, and all of this is wrapped up with mind-melting visuals and beats to back it up. If you're worried about not having any friends to play it with, that's totally viable; I've probably spent at least 65 hours on my own at the time of writing.

Give this game a shot. It may beat you into the dirt for a while, but when you get into the flow, there's nothing that quite matches this game at what it's trying to do.

A while my bf had bought this game, and played, then getting it for me to play it with him.
Then I also had done a few runs with some of my online friends. 
Since I am not a Pc native, I'm very glad that this game has controller support
I have played on a Dell Inspiron 15 3000 (2019ver), and the game certainly runs well, with a little lag but after a while it smooths out
Because this game is a roguelike, things are not unlocked off the bat, but with each subsequent run, you get more entries on items, environments, artifacts, enemies, and can even unlock characters , so it always feels like you're getting something out of each run.
And it gets even better with friends. (and possibly more successful runs)
As you get deeper into playing the game you'll also learn that certain items are good for each character. With that mentioned; the modding community is absolutely amazing for "Do you like Sett or Kindred from lol?" You can play them in this game as skins for the existing "survivors"/playable characters  
Don't like how rng based items are? You can get an artifact for that; which those also unlock depending on how long you'll play/if you're willing to do the work to unlock them.
And the addition of the void expansion, its integration feels very natural to the game itself. 
This game is definitely worth the price.

Risk of rain 2 is a game that takes a little but gives a lot, like enough to fill the mariana trench and then some. And yet each and every aspect of this game has been so polished and refined, it’s absolutely insane. For instance, there’s currently 11 survivors in the game, (with an additional 2 with the DLC), yet each survivor plays so much differently from each other, and every single survivor is viable, not a single one can be defined as ‘bad’ (except commando lol).The survivors are so diverse that there’s truly a playstyle for everyone. Wanna fly around hurling fire and lightning, while summoning ice walls to freeze groups of enemies? Wanna spray bosses in poison and watch while their health bar whittles away while standing in the background, laughing maniacally? You can do that.  Wanna go around shooting random enemies while calling in an entire AIRSTRIKE? Wanna guess what i’m about to say next? You can do that. Also there’s a timer and a little difficulty meter that shows that the game is steadily getting harder as the time on the timer grows. This is such a good decision, by rewarding the player with an easier time when they speed through areas, and loot and kill efficiently. This also means that the game respects the players time, no one wants to spend an hour and a half only to have their run ended by a random enemy.

[h1] Riskiest decision [/h1]


Risk of Rain 2 made some great decisions in terms of design and visuals, and this game differs a LOT from the previous games. One of the biggest and obvious changes is its transition from 2d to the 3d plane. Probably the biggest risk that Risk of Rain 2 took and boy was it the right decision. The whole feel of the game just fits with the 3d aspect, and it adds an insurmountable amount of absolute chaos to the game. Hordes of enemies run up in front of you, sneak up from behind and flank you left and right, you’re constantly running around and doing your best not to get overwhelmed by the crowds of enemies. And movement feels so smooth, sprinting around, jumping above enemies while trying to keep your distance from the swarm on all fronts.

[h1] flood of music [/h1]


The music fits the game so well, that for me, the game and the soundtrack are completely synonymous, the music makes the game and the game makes the music. These tracks are absolute headbangers, the guitar riffs of tracks like ‘You’re gonna need a bigger ukulele’ and ‘köppen as F̷̬͈͚̃̄̚ὐ̶̻̃̉͠¢̵͉̩͇͍̒̾̕κ̸̢̻͆̔ ‘ mesh with the chaotic goodness of Risk of Rain 2’s gameplay and combat and let you know just what you’re in for. And the music also serves as a guide, when the music really starts to pick up indicates that you should be at the teleporter event and trying to move to the next stage, and if it loops, that means that you have spent way too long on this stage.

[h1] You're gonna need a bigger ukulele [/h1]


To sum up the difficulty of the game… It's hard, like really hard. There’s three difficulty options: drizzle, rainstorm, and monsoon. None of these difficulty options ever make the game feel ‘too easy’ or ‘unfair’, hopoo did a great job of balancing this game. And this game is EXTREMELY challenging, especially on monsoon. The boss fights are intense and there’s no feeling like the one you get when you complete a teleporter event that you fought tooth and nail to get through. And without spoiling much, the final boss is almost certainly going to make you look like an absolute fool, he’s a tough fight for sure. Now if the three difficulty options aren’t enough for you, you can spice things up with artifacts, these are gameplay modifiers that seriously shake up the game, there’s one where it lets you choose whichever item you want to pick up whenever you grab an item, making it a lot easier to get those fables ‘god runs’. Or if you want to make the game harder, you can activate one where it takes away 90% of your health but allies deal 500% damage.

[h1] conclusion [/h1]


Risk of Rain 2 is easily my favorite roguelike games, in the top 10 of my favorite indie games. The amount of replayability this game has when you can choose different builds for different survivors with different loadouts is nearly infinite. The game ran absolutely flawlessly on my pc, with no issues in sight. This is a game that you can always boot up after a long day at work and just have fun.

Risk of Rain 2 easily gets a 9/10 in my book.

Absolutely excellent. Risk of Rain 2 is the rare sequel that builds and adapts upon it's formula without making it's predecessor obsolete. In that sense, RoR2 is almost a spiritual sequel in the sense of how different it plays from the transition from 2D to 3D space, but it clearly is a sequel in the best way. Each character on offer here brings such uniquely different playstyles, that every run feels challenging in a way that it didn't before hand. You're given abilities that make you feels powerful, but enemies that require smart use of those skills to be successful. And, the game is paced in a very clever way, making you feel powerful as a newbie and cunning as a veteran. It has secrets that encourages players to share information they have found. There are builds that synergize in ways you wouldn't expect. 

Ultimately, Risk of Rain 2 is a triumph. A roguelike that feels old-fashioned in it's presentation by being simplistic: runs that are random and require skill, but also completely modern: extremely distinct characters and playstyles. Please, pick this up. It is one of the best multiplayer experiences I've encountered in years.

"WHAT THE HELL KILLED ME?
I WAS LITERALLY UNKILLABLE, I DID THE MATH! I DID THE MA-A-AAAATH!" - You, probably 4 hours into a multi-looped run.

Wrong, you are never unkillable.

The game will ALWAYS get you the second you let your guard down - and that's why it's great! 

No matter how strong or powerful your build you have to stay engaged and on top of every movement, or this game will end you and your dreams of killing Mithrix the god of hammers and salt, and boy has he got salt in quarry loads from all my suddenly ended runs.

Buy this game, buy the DLCs, make friends and play this game with them, cry at eachother when they steal your red item for the 10th god damned time in the run because you picked up a crowbar they wanted at the start of it. ALSO MOD SUPPORT! INFINITE POSSIBILITIES!

I loved this game up until the recent updates. The recent updates/expansion completely broke the game's net code causing it to be impossible to play with anyone above ~150ms (e.g. anyone in a separate geographic region). I have had instances where people on 1Gbps fiber connections playing together, someone in Asia and someone in the US, where game latency got upwards of 30 seconds. Someone in Asia spawned into the next level more than 30 seconds after the people in the US.

Played through the entire pre-release and beta without too many issues with their net code, but something has changed recently which has made playing with people in other countries near impossible. The current state has made the game unplayable with a number of people in my friend group, so I therefore I cannot recommend this game to anyone with similar geographically scattered groups.

Definitely one of the better looter shooter / roguelites  I've played next to Enter the Gungeon. Achievements are actually meaningful to progression since they unlock new items, characters, abilities, or game-modes, exponentially increasing replayability. You can also spend hours in the logbook reading item descriptions that contain lore for both new and returning players of the series. Probably one of my all time favorites, all I can say that is bad about the game is that the Survivors of the void DLC isn't necessarily worth buying at first, I'd recommend playing Vanilla before deciding.

One of my most played games for a reason. Keep coming back to it with or without friends. The gameplay is unmatched and I've been rooting for it ever since launch. They followed through their roadmap and they made even better dlc. It's a roguelike so if you don't like resetting after a death, I'd suggest playing another game. The death loop is not for everyone but once you get the hang of the mechanics and looting systems, hours will pass by without you noticing how much time you've spent on this game. And as always, friends are a core part of what makes this and anything more fun than it already is! 

[b] TLDR [/b]
Probably the best 3D roguelike out on the market. Good class variety and a LOT of mechanics to mess around with. Friends make it even better.

I don't usually enjoy roguelite types of games. They often feel boring and repetitive after awhile. I thought Hades was boring and everyone loves that game. What makes Risk of Rain 2 different from other games in the genre is how each run feels brand new and things constantly change in the game. The maps are different each run and the abilities you acquire are different as well. The game is gorgeous and the music is incredible. It is easily the best roguelite game I have ever played. It is worth buying on sale for sure. I would buy the DLC as well. Avoid playing with cross-play on if possible.

To Describe Risk Of Rain 2 is to Describe Insanity itself. Lemme put this as simply as I can. Try to imagine Cthulhu. Now try to imagine putting him on the moon, giving him a murder boner because his brother died because YOUR group of survivors killed them in the first RoR, and then he turns the entire planet you are going to, into a planet that wants to murder you. Full of items that gradually mutate your character from a simple helpless survivor to something Doom Slayer would say "Nah I ain't screwing with that". And imagine said survivor being so powerful he can one shot bosses with but a simple graze of shotgun or swing of a katana. And then you die by a piddly fireball from a Lemurian and you sit there wondering "WTF was I killed by?" And then you get angry at your loss of progress and then try again. And again. And again. Until you beat the final boss or die by an RKO Bomb outta nowhere again. And then you do it again. 

That. Is Risk of Rain 2.

If you like shooters and roguelikes, this is a must-try. Every part of this game is simply magical.

Characters: Each one feels very unique in playstyle and they are all so fun to play. Wanna point and shoot? Wanna teleport around? Wanna be an amalgamation of spiderman and one punch man? How about bird? Sit back and watch your machines do your job for you? The variety is top notch.

Items: There are SO MANY items. And most of them are very fun to use. The element of randomness gives you broken combinations at times (it's a great trip) or quite bad ones (and you try to survive and progress all the same). Both of these make for interesting games. At times you get complacent because you think you're strong and suddenly you just die. On the other hand you feel hopeless as the levels pass until you get the one item that saves your run. As long as you don't take the bullshit deaths and RNG seriously, it's always fun to get back into a new game.

Atmosphere: I think this is what makes me keep coming back to this game. The maps are really good; very interesting to traverse and play through. The music slaps hard. It just feels so damn good as you go through the environments, riddling enemies with holes.

And if you're bored with all that? Then you have game modifiers that significantly change the way you play. You can make challenge runs, or make ridiculous builds, or even simply get to the power trip stage of the game within the first 5 minutes,

Lastly, the DLC released (Survivors of the Void) took the game to another level. Almost zero complaints about it. The included content was like a breath of fresh air with new maps, music, characters, items, mechanics, the works. All of this fits with the existing content nicely to make a very cohesive bundle. The devs have done one hell of a job with it and the game as a whole. They also listen to the community and fix the various issues present (ty also for buffing Arti <3 she deserves it).

I think my only gripe with this game is that after playing it, I can never enjoy the first Risk of Rain the same. I am a huge fan of the first iteration and what they've done with RoR2 is nothing short of phenomenal.

I highly suggest this game if you haven't played it, you may have seen it around, or heard the name a few times, but what's so special about it? Why should you buy risk of rain 2, Thats a question i'd love to answer. There is one part of game design that i think is the most important. Fun. A game isnt playable, if it isn't fun, now let me tell you why risk of rain 2 fits that category. It has diverse and unique unlockable characters, multiple stages with various variants, all of which are a blast to explore, even the worst ones, the items are all interesting and fun, nothing makes me happier than seeing a soldiers syringe drop, and that only increases your attack speed by 15%, there are some bad items, and sour ends to runs, but the good ones make up for it, and last but not least don't get me started on the shenanigans that can occur when you get one, maybe two friends to play this game with you. Knocking dunestriders into pits, coming up with the wackiest most overpowered strats of all time, watching the enemies behave in stupid ways, all of it, is fun. Risk of rain 2, is a fun game, an experience that can keep giving, and if you feel so challenged, try eclipse mode, as if monsoon wasn't already enough. Buy this game, It's good.

One of the most addicting video games I've ever played.
Purchasing the game without knowing anything about it was one of the greatest recommendations that I got from a very good friend of mine. Curiously, there were a couple of aspects of the game that made me want to keep playing. For example, I really wanted to beat the game in the beginning and I wanted to unlock all of the characters. After that I wanted to get the abilities for each character. There was always something that kept me going. But the most important aspect was that I wanted to [b]get better at the game[/b]. Learning the characters that seemed the most interesting and experimenting with different loadouts and playstyles, even if they mostly lead to defeat, were significant elements of my playthroughs.
It's also worth mentioning that time seemed to pass faster than usual while playing this sometimes surprisingly challenging and difficult but ultimately fun game.

if I had to give this game a rating on its own I'd give it a solid 10/10. 

1. unique art style that really fits with the game.
2. solid replayability, like that's literally the point of the genre but some people just kinda stop after they've 100% the game.
3. Genuinely FUN characters, just like how that dev(I think co-founder of the studio?) said: the different characters' "balance" aren't as important as the fun aspect. Not his exact words but basically what he said
4. Lots of items for multiple types of builds. 

If I had to give the community a rating I'd give it an 8/10

1. Most random people you play with are epic, plenty of art for the artsy people as well as plenty of just overall laid back people.
2. However some people try to min/max the items they get in multiplayer which is suuuch a tilter. Like BRO just chill out and have some fun and stop trying to do the whole "your bleed is better on my captain while you're loader". No shit sherlock, I'm trying to have some FUN not tryhard at a roguelike. 
3. Lots of people will only play modded, there's plenty of stuff in the base game but they just want to overload it and have 4x the items which is just wack to me. 
3a. Yes There are some fun mods like certain character mods, but from what I have experienced, modded characters are generally too busted and you get a boring breeze through mithrix. Granted there are multiple balanced ones such as Miner, but then you get the teammates that are playing as sett and nemesis enforcer.

If you were looking for a game review this is the wrong place but if you want to know how to make a chocolate cake, this is the place for you.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Grease and flour three 8 in pans (We often line our pans with parchment paper as well)
In a mixing bowl, add the dry ingredients: sugar, all purpose flour, unsweetened cocoa, baking soda, baking powder, and salt. Whisk these dry ingredients for 1 minute to blend.
Add softened butter a few pieces at a time while the mixer is on low speed. Mix until the dry ingredients look like coarse sand and the dry ingredients are moistened. Scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl.
In a separate bowl whisk the eggs, milk , oil and vanilla until blended.
With the mixer on low speed, SLOWLY add about half of the egg mixture to the dry ingredients. Increase the speed to medium and mix for 1 1/2 minutes at medium speed. Scrape the bottom and sides of bowl. Add the remaining egg mixture in 2 pourings, beating for 20 seconds after each pour. Scrape the sides and bottom of bowl.
Next, slowly add the cup of hot coffee (prepared instant coffee or brewed) and mix another 30 seconds until blended. The chocolate cake batter will be very runny. Don’t worry!
Pour into 3 prepared 8″ pans and bake at 350 degrees for 25 to 30 minutes or until the center of the cake springs back to the touch or a small wooden pick comes out clean or with just a few moist crumbs attached.The cake layers will pull away ever so slightly from the sides of the pan. 
Cool the cakes 10 minutes on a wire rack and then turn out of the pans.
*Yields approximately 9 cups of batter, plenty for three 8 inch cake pans and a nice, tall cake

Pork Vindaloo Recipe

Ingredients

15 dried Kashmiri chiles (see note)
2 teaspoons toasted whole cumin seeds
2 teaspoons turmeric
2 (1-inch) pieces of cinnamon
9 whole black peppercorns
7 whole cloves
1 teaspoon sugar
10 garlic flakes (or 2 medium cloves garlic, roughly chopped)
1 inch-piece ginger, peeled and roughly chopped
1/2 cup palm vinegar, or 1/3 cup rice vinegar
1/2 pound pork shoulder, cut into 1-inch cubes
Kosher salt
1 medium onion, roughly chopped (about 1 cup)
1 1/2 tablespoons vegetable oil
1 cup water

Directions

Combine chilies, cumin, turmeric, 1 piece of cinnamon, 5 peppercorns, 4 cloves, and sugar in a spice grinder. Grind until a fine powder is formed. Transfer spice mixture to food processor or mortar and pestle and add garlic, ginger, and vinegar. Process or pound until a fine paste is formed. Scrape out paste into a small bowl and set aside without washing food processor.


Place pork in a large bowl and season with salt. Add half of spice paste and turn pork to coat. Add onion to food processor and process until a paste is formed.


Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed saucepan over medium heat until shimmering. Add the onion paste (do not wash food processor bowl), remaining 4 peppercorns, remaining cinnamon stick, and remaining 3 cloves. Cook, stirring constantly, until onion is soft and oil is fragrant, about 5 minutes. Add remaining spice paste and cook, stirring occasionally, until the oil separates and mixture starts to sizzle, about 5 minutes longer.

Add pork and cook, stirring occasionally, until browned, about 10 minutes. Add water to the food processor bowl and swirl to rinse. Pour mixture into pan and bring to a simmer, stirring occasionally. Reduce heat to maintain a gentle simmer, cover, and cook until the pork is fork tender, about 1 hour longer. Serve immediately with bread or rice, or for better flavor, cool, store overnight in a sealed container in the refrigerator, and reheat before serving.

Play with friends that you can communicate with in a voice chat as you're playing. Don't be ashamed to tell them 'Rainstorm' is hard at first. Familiarize yourself with the items. Learn which of your friends are loot goblins. Get good at the game, or what you [i]think[/i] is good; the game will not agree.
Set everything and everyone on fire, including your friends. Run so fast you can move from one side of the map to the other in a single second. Make everything explode just by looking at it. Become literally incapable of dying. If these things interest you, I recommend this game. If they do not, you're weird; but I still recommend this game, because you really need to become interested in those things.

The Fire Spirit card is unlocked from the P.E.K.K.A.'s Playhouse (Arena 4). It spawns a very fast, area damage, short-ranged Fire Spirit with low hitpoints and moderate damage. It resembles a small chunk of flaming coal. Fire Spirit launches itself at its target when attacking, destroying itself on impact. It is the same as those spawned by the Furnace. A Fire Spirit card costs 1 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy
The Fire Spirit's area damage is very useful against swarms of weak, small troops like Goblins, Spear Goblins or Minions. However, due to its relatively low health, placing it next to these units will result in it dying before it can attack. Placing the Fire Spirit at a distance allows it to safely deploy.
Against the Mother Witch, you want to place it close to her instead, so that it is killed as part of its attack instead of being killed by the Mother Witch, otherwise she will spawn a Cursed Hog from it.
If timed correctly, a Fire Spirit can damage all the Lava Pups just as they explode from the Lava Hound, defeating them.
Due to this splash, an effective strategy is to pair it with troops that deal high single hit damage but are easily stopped by the small troops mentioned, such as the Mini P.E.K.K.A. and Prince.
The Fire Spirit will connect to a Princess Tower provided it is equivalently leveled. Although it can easily be stopped, its cheap cost often lures out cheap spells and can cause opponents to over-commit Elixir-wise with their defenders. If used at the start of a match, it can also act as a way to tell what deck your opponent is using based on the card that they use to stop the Fire Spirit.
Fire Spirit can compliment pushes effectively due to its good cost-to-damage ratio and fast movement speed. For example, if the player is pushing with a P.E.K.K.A. and Fire Spirit behind and the opponent drops Minions to counter for example, the Fire Spirit drops the health of said units to be finished off by a Zap or cheap ranged units to protect the P.E.K.K.A, letting her continue towards the tower without taking extra damage.
It is most effective with fast moving troops like the Hog Rider, as they will not collide with each other as much during an attack.
A Hog Rider and Fire Spirit combo can make short work of Cannons.
The player can use units to soak it up. For example, the Skeletons or another spirit result in a neutral Elixir trade.
For more Fire Spirit value, a Furnace costs 4 Elixir and can spawn up to 7 Fire Spirits, giving the player almost twice as many Fire Spirits for their Elixir. It can allow for more consistent chip damage to Crown Towers and can bait spells due to its cost. However, the Fire Spirits do not spawn all at once, and its upfront cost is higher, so in a situation where the player needs quick area damage, the Furnace is much less versatile.
Occasionally, it is a good idea to combine the Fire Spirit with spells to defeat certain troops for a low Elixir cost. With a Zap, it can defeat anything up to Wall Breakers, with Arrows, it can defeat anything up to Skeleton Dragons, with Fireball, it can defeat anything up to a Night Witch, and with Lightning, it can defeat anything up to an Inferno Dragon. Use these combinations when you are lacking better counters for these troops or to get a good Elixir trade that would be granted compared to using two Spells.
Pairing the Fire Spirit with Electro Spirit is very effective, as they both cost 1 Elixir, which will only use a total of 2 Elixir. This combination can take out units such as Princess, Minions, Archers, Bomber, Firecracker and can even completely stop a Goblin Barrel with the help of the Princess Tower. This combo can help a lot of decks which try to bait The Log or Arrows, since the combo is very effective against swarms. It is also good on the offensive side, having more damage potential than The Log and can hit air. The player should make sure to deploy the Spirits a short distance from their targets to ensure they can finish deploying and attack successfully.
Although the Fire Spirit’s area damage radius is not enough to completely stop a tower-centered Goblin Barrel, there is still a way to counter the Goblin Barrel with Fire Spirit, although 2 of the Goblins will still get one hit on the tower (240 total damage at tournament standard). Place the Fire Spirit on the tile directly behind the tower, and if timed correctly, the Fire Spirit will push one of the goblins toward the tower, and it will one-shot all 3 goblins. This trick is very precise but can be pulled off consistently with practice. A tip for timing: Place the Fire Spirit at the exact moment when the Goblin Barrel is one tile above the river.
Satisfying and engaging, endlessly playable. I find myself comparing all other roguelikes to this (and most of them don't come close)
