Risk of Rain 2 is a great, action-packed roguelike that is perfect for someone looking to get a taste of the genre.

Much like any other game in the genre, RoR 2 gives an endless amount of replay value without really ever going stale. When I first bought this game, I put 60 hours into it in the first 2 weeks alone.

One thing that this game gets right compared to other roguelikes is its ability to make you feel truly unkillable. While you can definitely get to this point in most roguelikes, RoR 2 takes it to the next level, to the point where some runs have you zooming across the map at mach 11 and killing every enemy in your vicinity just by standing next to them. There are certain roguelikes that seem to cap you from completely steam-rolling the game (Enter the Gungeon comes to mind, with most weapons having a damage cap against bosses), while RoR 2 seems to embrace the idea of becoming God and wreaking havoc. Even then, in this god-like state, you are vulnerable to being one shot by any random enemy that lands a hit on you late game, so it still forces you to be on your toes even deep in a run, which is a tight balance that RoR 2 is able to pull off.

Beyond the gameplay, RoR 2 has a very appealing stylization that gives it the look of an alien planet that it was going for. It has very smooth edges with low amount of visual detail up close, while being able to convey distinctly what each enemy and object on the map is supposed to look like. Complementing the visuals, the sound track goes hard. With a lot of the games I play, I like to mute the in game music in favor of my own, but I simply can't do that with Risk of Rain 2. They did an incredible job on the music for every stage in this game.

Another feature in this game which puts this game over a lot of other roguelikes is its multiplayer. Very few roguelikes even have multiplayer, and even fewer are able to pull it off well, but RoR 2 does both. You can play with up to 4 people online with item spawn rates going up to compsensate, and it is a blast. There are some hiccups with multiplayer, with the main one being that if you die, you are simply forced to watch your friends continue to play and collect items without you, but I'm not sure how you would fix that problem anyway. Overall, multiplayer is a welcome addition to RoR 2.

The criticisms of this game are few and far between, but the chief one I have with the core gameplay is the teleporter events late game. Anyone who has made it to "super late game" (which is to say anytime past your second loop through or so) will tell you that having to wait for the teleporter to charge in late game is a big waste of time. What ends up happening quite often in this late game scenario is you will start the teleporter event, kill the boss instantly, and then have to wait the 2 1/2 minutes or so just sitting in the circle waiting for the teleporter to charge. This grinds the gameplay to a halt and slows down what should be a constant fast-paced game, in my opinion. My suggestion is this: if you kill the teleporter boss in under 1.5 seconds, cut the time it takes the teleporter to charge in half. This might not solve the problem completely, but it might help the stagnation of just sitting inside the circle and doing nothing. Beyond this complaint, the gameplay stays fun and exciting all the way through.

Overall, this is a top 5 roguelike and a top 10 game all time for me personally. The feeling you get insta-killing everything on the map once you get to a certain point in the game is unmatched, and the journey to get to that point is engaging as well.

Despite the fact that I've played this game for 150 hours I think I'll leave a negative review.
I had a lot of fun playing this game when it just came out. Most of my hours are from the first version of the game when it wasn't "overbalanced".

While most of the game loops are very solid, the characters are interesting, maps are gorgeous, achievements are fun, and more, the thing that ruins this game for me are random incredibly unfair enemy encounters that end a normal good run.

Death comes whenever the game wants you to die, and it doesn't matter how early or late you are into the run or how strong or weak your build is. And everytime it happens it feels like there's nothing that you could've done to save the run. It feels 100% unfair. 

Here's one example: Somitemes instead of a regular boss the game spawns a group of elite enemies. I got 5 Elder Lemurians with shields. That means I had to both keep my distance from them and stay in the teleporter so that it charges up and stops the regular enemy spawns. And on top of that to kill a shielded elite I had to keep shooting it or it will regain all of it's shield in 2 seconds AND it has a lot of hp AND it is one of the most aggressive enemies in the game AND there are 5 of them AND I'm playing as a class that has to be close to enemies to damage them. Obviously, I died

Here's another one: I was having a 1 hour long run and trying to get to stage 50 in the simulacrum mode. At wave 40 the game gave me a modifier, an artifact of glass, that reduced my hp to 10% and gave me 5x damage. I died immideately. -1 hour of my life, can't wait to do it all again.

These things happen very often. 90% of my runs end in dissapointment and with a feeling that I've wasted 30-60 minutes of my life.

It's good.  I like it.  Run around, frantically shoot at stuff, and feel your brain turn to goo as the scene steadily dissolves into flashing neon explosions!  I find each of the survivors to be quite unique, and they all take time to learn to play effectively.  The items often don't seem like much at first, but as they stack up can have significant impacts on gameplay.  Playing with artifacts can have a massive impact on the game, allowing for greater variance between runs.  Then there are the alternative game modes which I haven't even really touched after 175hrs, so there is definitely a lot of content here.  Oh and the soundtrack slaps.

It has some problems.  Most notably, how common it is to die instantly at pretty much any point in a run.  This actually seems to get more likely the longer your run goes on, which makes it that much more frustrating because of how much you stand to lose.  As a rule, I think one-shots are a design mistake except in exceedingly rare circumstances, such as during major boss fights on the condition that you can learn the behavior and learn to avoid it.  Alternatively, they're fine when you won't lose much progress.  In this case, you might lose an hour or more of playtime in a way that feels pretty cheap.    

But despite some design choices I find pretty questionable, it is on the whole a very fun game and I do not regret my time with it.

I loved the first Risk of Rain so much that when the second one came out and I saw it was in 3D, my initial reaction was "Oh no, they've ruined it. There's no way they'll be able to recreate what made the first game so cool."

I'm happy to report that I was dead wrong.

The core loop here--killing enemies to get gold to open chests to get items to get OP combos to utterly destroy King Nothing--is so incredibly satisfying that I find myself thinking about it when I'm at work or in class, or out having a fancy dinner.

Pre-loaded with challenges to complete to unlock even more items, characters, and equipment, there's no shortage of goals to work toward. Unlocking playable characters, items, equipment, alternate ability loadouts for characters, relics... there's a ton. I haven't come close to unlocking everything after 70 hours, and that's *with* help from the wiki (which you'll most likely need, as some of the requirements for unlocking new things are insanely specific).

The music and art are impeccably designed and executed, and create a stylish, unique atmosphere for you to romp through. Animations are fitting, not distracting, and communicate exactly what they need to. This thing looks, sounds, and FEELS like nothing else in the best way possible. Every character has their own unspoken personality, and every environment feels alive and lived-in.

$25 is a steal for this much high-quality content, made an even better value proposition by the engine and mechanics behind it all that make you want to do it all again immediately, but maybe a slightly different way; just one more run. If you can find it on sale, picking this up is a no-brainer. And once you realize you love it, pick up the expansion. It's more of the same high-quality, cranked up to 11 with purple-hued particle effects. What a game.

I was *this close* to leaving a glowing review of a stellar game, then one thing ruined it all.

My save got wiped.

I did some research to try to fix it. I discovered there is a bug that can occur, but it's fixable. Unfortunately, mine is not. The bug I found involves the game making a new, empty save and refusing to acknowledge your old one. The fix is to simply copy the contents of the old into the new. I, however, don't seem to have an old save. I have two files: One which is completely empty (0 KB in size), and one with contents, but a whole ton of 0's in stats that definitely should not be 0's.

This promptly killed any and all interest I had in this otherwise really good game.

I absolutely love this game. The devs have done an incredible job taking the fantastic concept from RoR 1 and translating it for a 3D world, not only recreating it but also expanding on it and making it a joy to play.

[h1] Answering a question nobody asked or wanted to be answered:
"What if we made a roguelike where a single mistake instantly ends your 30 minute run?"

From the creators of risk of rain 1 here is risk of rain 1 again but this time its 3d with barely any new content!!! [/h1]

The entire "ThE GAME getS hArDEr the MORE TIme YOu Spend in a RUn" gimmick is so so stupid and ads absolutely nothing. 
This is never an issue unless you are playing a slow character and the rng doesnt give you any movement speed items which just feels unfair and stupid.
The game being harder on later stages is literally the default for the genre anyway.

After like ~30 minutes the enemies already one shot you so pretty much nothing changes from that point with the exception of the endboss becoming borderline impossible.
You can spend 5 days straight looping levels and farming up items just to instantly die on the third stage of the WHITE HUMAN WITH A HAMMER final boss because he takes all your items and then one hits you with a single shot because hes max level.
Whats the point of spending the entire game collecting items just for it to take them all?
And the race against time at the end these arent reasonable challenges they are arbitrary garbage designed to screw first time players over.

In every other roguelike dying is part of the experience but here it always feels like youve been cheated cause its always without a fail some random critter that swatted you out of the air with a fireball probably from off-screen too and just like that your 30 minute run is over.
The progression is pretty bad all around you unlock a handful of items but half the stuff ive unlocked still hasnt even shown up hours later cause the drop rates are just that stupidly low.
While other games in the genre have you go up against sometimes hundreds of different enemies across tons of areas you are mostly just shooting the same bug, lizard and flying skull through your entire run.
They just get tankier and later come in different flavors of monster energy [elites] glowing in a random color making them stubidly tanky while still being the same stupid little bug.
Other roguelikes have interesting enemy and challenge designs but all risk of rain has to offer is basic projectile spitters and melee attacks the most interesting attack pattern that isnt a boss is a big lizzards linear spread of fireballs. yawn.
All the maps feel exactly the same with no enviromental hazards or stage gimmicks just stage 5 has some flying rocks that sometimes hit you and throw you off the map deleting most of your health. yawn.


Random elite enemies make any build that isnt bleed and attack speed worthless.
Being thrown off the map by unreasonably high knockback attacks gets you stuck in a loop of being reset to the island just to fly off at mach speed cause your momentum wasnt reset.
You constantly get thrown into the stratosphere if your toe clips an incline with too much movement speed.
The teleporter charging always finishes at 99% not 100%.
Some basic enemies lock onto you with hitscan and then shoot you while off screen or plant near insta killing acid puddles on the ground that you wont be seeing cause you are looking up shooting at the aforementioned goons.
A few bosses have big AOE attacks that mostly just one hit you or put 300dps dealing burn stacks on you and all your drones unless you hide behind a wall which rarely ever works sometimes I had entire mountains between me and the center of the attack and still got hit.
Player drones get stuck on everything including the floor whenever possible and just sit there until they die to some basic enemy attacks.

Maybe not that big of a complaint but the item/monster/area log in the main menu doesnt have a button to mark all as read so you have to click every single entry to remove the notification like cmon you added a 3d model viewer but you forgot something this basic??

Oh did I mention that its been 2 years since this released on steam?


All the items amount to is [dmg on hit] or passive stats anyway so theres never really a "feel" of having a special build you just always shoot the same gun at the same 3 types of enemies the only thing that changes is how fast their healthbars go down.
You spend most of the game just stacking lowest rarity items anyway.

Theres no alternate routes to take or any noticable difference between a near 100% savefile and a fresh one.
The biggest run changers are the artifacts (various modifiers) that you have to unlock in an utterly mind numbing challenge room where you just kill enemies while you get shot at waiting for keys to spawn for a few minutes.

This is just not a good roguelike but at least its actually a playable game unlike the first one.
25€ is a pretty steep price for a half assed remake like this
Gungeon or Rogue Legacy 2 are cheaper than this and they are infinitely more polished and have more content.

In conclusion this game is great if you want a headache from hearing the same player gun shooting mp3 for 30 minutes straight.

Risk of Rain 2 is a great game that offers several different ways to play. Unlike most roguelikes I've played, RoR2 not only allows the player to choose between several different characters who all have their unique move sets. The game also gives the player a plethora of different ways to build their character while playing.

The game hosts a mysterious and quite fascinating story that unfolds as you get further into the game. Different locations the player visits, all either tie into the overarching story or tie into an individual character's story arch. This allows players who want to learn more a reason to play every character and to use their specific skills.

However, the game has one major shortcoming. Playing alone can become quite boring. The interactions you have with your friends or teammates, the pressure you feel when you have to carry your team to the next level, those feelings aren't there if you play alone. Although, there is a solution which is to join the Risk of Rain 2 discord where you could play with other people.

Overall I've had a blast playing the game so far and there is a lot more for me to explore in this game!
8.5/10

Much like RoR1, RoR2 comes with a welcome host of challenges and reworks both from and new to the RoR franchise. I feel that if you have the time and money, it is well worth your attention. I've never really been into rogue-likes; I've tried several and they never really meshed with me until I tried this one. I truly think the multiplayer aspect is underrated, being able to do runs with your friends makes for a crazy and chaotic time that can't really be matched playing single-player. Like any rogue-like, stacking whatever items can get things out of control in short order, but the different survivors make it so that you and your buddy can play totally different builds and don't need to BOGART each other's items. (fuck you though Jake, I called the first backup mag, idgaf if you paid for it)

I also really love the progression system. There are plenty of survivors, but you only start with a couple, and need to complete certain in-game milestones to unlock the others, which is cool because you start with more basic characters and abilities to learn the game, and then as you unlock more, their abilities and synergies are pretty whack compared to what you've had before, so it makes for totally new experiences. The last dude I unlocked had this thing where you paid life for your abilities; that was pretty nuts to me.

I feel like the music in this game is pretty trippy, like I think you could just vibe to it, and it doesn't necessarily line up with the tone of the game, but in a sense that almost makes it work better for me. Every run isn't this huge, intense battle for my life where I'm on the edge of my seat waiting to see if I live or die, it's just another run, and if I die, then I can just boot back up and start another. I don't know, I think there's a certain beauty to the contrast of what you're doing and what you're hearing, and it really just hits for me and makes it much more bearable to keep doing runs after a big loss.

I see this as one of those games where I'll pick it up and play it pretty extensively for a weekend or so, then drop it and forget about it until I get another urge or I see a friend on. Then just repeat that cycle until I've actually exhausted what it has to offer, but in this case, I don't think that cycle ends until a potential RIsk of Rain 3 comes out.

I don't play a lot of video games, but I've logged over 110 hrs of active play of risk of rain 2. Its a five star game and everyone should have the opportunity to play it.

It's fun for what it is. It has a scalable difficulty, you could choose from three separate difficulties so almost everybody could get into the game even if you're not too skilled at these types of games. Story is very basic which is fine. I'm sure there's a deeper lore to be found if you investigate the areas thoroughly but hey, I haven't met anybody buying this game for it's story, people buy this because the gameplay is fun.

Levels are cool and unique, enemies are challenging enough and you could get pretty OP if you find a really good build for your character. The replayability is decent, people that are fond of the rougelike games have to spend more than dozens of hours before they get sick of this. Items are distributed properly in levels so you'll want to explore a bit more if you want to find them all. Characters feels great to use, some are a bit hard to master but you'll get used to it in time.

And of course there's a few downsides here and there, the main two for me being:
1) That sometimes, the teleporter is hidden in very obscure places that if you're a new player, it could get so frustrating just trying to find it if you don't have a scanner. It helps that  they've added fireflies around to indicate that a teleporter is in the vicinity but sometimes, it blends too well with the surroundings that it makes it difficult, especially for the colorblind, to see them.
2) Unlocking stuff is hard, I understand when it's the costumes since it's a type of flex to have the alternative costume for your character proving that you've beaten the game with that character in its hardest difficulty. But for the skills/items to be so frickin' hard to get? It could get overwhelming for new players, heck, I personally haven't unlocked everything since some of them are so frickin' hard to do. For someone just casually playing the game, it's a bit sad not being able to use the alt-skills or the locked items just because some of the requirements for unlocking them are a bit too challenging for an average player. Though, I'd say that you're going to be fine even with just unlocking and using the easy ones to unlock but it's just a shame that you couldn't use the item/skill you wanted just because of some bullsh*t requirement.

Asides from those two gripes that I have with this game, all I've got are praises for how fun it is to play. 

Final Rating: a solid 8/10 game
Good purchase (+ DLC) even when not on sale.

Red beams of light shoot down from the starry sky above, there is gunfire ablaze, the sound of creatures roaring and approaching from the horizon. It seems like all hope is lost as we are doomed to fall to these foes, but I have faith.

I believe this battle can be overcome. I had put my heart and soul making it this far with the items I have collected and the experience I have achieved. I had my friend by my side and with his trusty sentries I knew we would make it through. 

The air smelled of blood and gunpowder. We had won the battle but not the war. We knew they would come back, they always do. The next wave is upon us and they would come harder. It was at this moment that time seemed to stop for me and my friend. We both had our focus on the same thing but very different thoughts, because it was at that exact moment, the red beams of light, came fully together.

With a loud CRASH the giant hunk of metal falls from the sky and utterly obliterates my engineer's turrets. He is heart broken and my astonishment is blinding. I was dumbfounded, what could have caused this terrible event to occur? The wave came and with it he died due to him not having defenses. As I slowly fall to the same fate, I came to realize something, something terrible.

I dropped a diablo strike on his turrets fuck.
10/10 game.

Why don't you have this game yet?

I'm a sucker for third-person shooters so this grabbed my attention fairly quickly. I played the first Risk of Rain and pleasantly enjoyed that and found the timer concept a challenging but fun feature to learn to juggle effectively. This timer has made a return in this game and I'm finding a similar enjoyment of learning to balance it effectively once again, however this time it's bigger and more intense than its predecessor. From the beautifully-varied environments to the wonderful selection of characters each with their own distinct abilities this lives up to being a worthy sequel to the original. I find myself booting up the game to play a single run of it but end up doing many more in one session, it's an addictive loop of wanting to do better each time and with all the characters to choose from you can mix it up and keep it entertaining for many hours. However what makes this game truly shine is when you can spend time on it with friends, and this co-op gives it some serious replayability. Get some friends together and go have a blast with it, laugh about how nuts it gets because it WILL get nuts.
Titanic Plains is the only good 1st stage.

An amazing 3d rougelike with so much potential for messing around or serious play. Amazing for casuals and speedrunners alike.

If you're ever looking for a game that will give you countless hours of fun this is a great investment. I had a silly time when I was like overthinking a lot and just starting a run on Risk of Rain 2 and some music helped me a lot. It's great with friends but even better alone. I like it a lot because I can start a run and not need to worry about backing out if I need too do something. I will forever be greatful for this game it got me through bad time fr fr.
It's like... literally my favourite game on pc. Well I say that about like 3 games, but THIS IS ONE OF EM

Risk of Rain 2 is one of the best roguelikes out there.

The gameplay is challenging, demanding you to learn the mechanics.
The story leaves you thinking, and wanting more the longer you play.
The music is beautifully written.
The art design and originality truly speaks the genius of Hopoo Games.
Everything ties so perfectly together, this game is a work of art.

Looking forwards to where Hopoo Games will take the future DLC packs.

This game has infinite different ways to play. There are so many different items that are all unique and compliment each character in different ways. The enemies are memorable and have unique traits and flaws like i have never seen before. I highly recommend you buy this game and get your friends to buy it too. It is a great co-op game and brings out creativity in teamwork. The Survivors of the Void DLC also is great and brought new enemies, bosses, endings, items, and more. I highly recommend buying any and all DLC available.

Great gameplay, very replayable, amazing music 10/10 game

Pixel style looter shooter romp a dooder that was a blast to play even if I had no real idea what I was doing or what was going on. Waves of baddies and me with weird gadgets, abilities, and guns a plenty just blowin em all up. Yay, really tho, it was a lot of fun and I found some actual progression and unlocks/hidden stuff that made my efforts feel actually worthwhile. with a good enough variety of areas and opponents, combined with well balanced and tight game play I thought it was a well crafted game. That was all before I even got into it with friends, on comms, which made it even better. Its great reviews are well earned, and I think it would still hold up rather well if I picked it up again today.
Over the last month I've played about as much of this game as I played Risk of Rain 1 over the last 8 years or so. I love the first game, but this one is so fucking good.
good game if you like good games

Great rogue-like game with nearly limitless options for play-throughs. Every run will be different. You spawn in, run around and hunt for loot while killing mobs, teleport and repeat. 

This game is easy to play, difficult to master. The gameplay loop is very simple but there is a unique difficulty scale where the difficulty increases the longer your run lasts by time. Early on you have to juggle looting with moving on so that you don't get overwhelmed. 

I've had this game for years and still come back to it constantly. I can't recommend this game enough, I love it.

If I could only play one game for the rest of my life, it very well may be this one. Unbelievable depth, replayability, variety, and most importantly, FUN. Grow into a god, die in one hit, and then do it again, and again, and again, and...
Very fun alone and with friends, Takes time very difficult game. Once you get to the higher stages I would recommend a decent graphics card. Overall great game
Great game with endless replay value.

If you like rogue type games, this is perfect. 

Summary
Basically you play as a character. And that character has a special ability within them. Then you go on an adventure and try to go the highest you can. And during that you can get upgrades. And that's really it, from my experience. 

What I thought was fun
It was really enjoyable to get upgrades and trying to proceed further. But what I have been enjoying is the achievement hunts. There are so much achievement that if you complete them you get an item that can be in your game. And achievements for characters, and just regular achievements. That is why I've been having a blast. 

Should you get it
Like I said if you like rogue likes then this game is pretty good. Read other people summary if you want more depth but I'm trying to make my review simple. I bought it 8 dollar on G2A but it is worth it for 25 dollars. But that's really it. Already 47 hours and there are more things I need to do on that game.

I have many hours into this game and the possibilities are endless, However the downside comes from multiplayer aspect which I sometimes assume the devs never really sometimes test this. The game allows you to stack items in which gives you a effect and the effects stack depending on the number of stacks. Theres Artifacts in which it allows you to modify your game to a different complete experience. The game is meant to give a rogue-like feel your not attended to win every run your meant to learn the mechanics as you progressively unlock stuff. The things I may say the game is lacking is bug tests and multiplayer stability.

Bugs such as (Crossplay doesn't work perfectly yet...).

Now lets issue all the problems in multiplayer (The multiplayer community is sometimes toxic from cheat, hacking, modding, and even just starting tp from the gekko and stealing all the boss items in a multiplayer game, in some cases the 4th player never spawns when its a 4 player lobby (this occurs sometimes, or when connecting to a certain windows 10 device for some reason), the game is sometimes facing a underlying issue of once a single person dies in a multiplayer game their just out of the game cause their too weak to progress from the next stage of the run (however some mods actually fixed this issue but doesn't mean the vanilla game fixed it thats why I'm issuing it),

Many players complain about lag even tho guys the internet isn't meant to connect half way from the earth plz learn to read tags or ping before joining instead sending hate messages after joining plz aka. learn common sense!)(I have read some of the discussion page and people are begging for "easy mode" when its like rainstorm is normal and monsoon is hard, it is meant to be difficult drizzle is meant to be easy again... LEARN COMMON SENSE PEOPLE!).

This has been my review of the game and it is a excellent game I do recommend playing it! (The Review will be update if I find issues or bugs or just updates in general!) Milestone : I did it i played 1000 hours of your game!

Yeah, it's pretty fun I suppose.
I put a little bit of time into it every now and again.

Risk of Rain 2 is simply the best rogue-like game ever made, even beating the holy light of Binding of Isaac. You have a wide range of characters to play with, each with different abilities, that have different playstyles yet all still rely on picking up the best items. RoR2 is simply a masterpiece and its soundtrack says so too.

Now with a DLC adding two new characters, new stages, new enemies, and new items, RoR2 is sure to bring you entertainment for as long as you live.

I HIGHLY recommend RoR2.

I thought I didn't like roguelikes, well, this game proved me wrong. Despite some weird happenings caused by the random spawns, like when items fall off the map making it impossible to get them, this game is definitely one of my favourites both as a multiplayer and also solo game. Every game is different and the overall atmosphere is somewhat eerie making it feel like you're part of... something really cool. Fun game, also the most satisfying combat I've probably ever experienced. Thought I should review this with this many hours.
An absolute wonder of a game that only gets better the more you play. Hopoo are one of the best game devs out there!

This is one of the first roguelites I played and I enjoyed my plays on it. The variety of the survivors and items makes it have high replay value. This is the game where you can really customize your runs. Multitude of difficulty modifiers and artifacts which modify the game make it so that you can change how you wish to play the game. Also, due to its item-stacking system, at a certain point, you will feel like nothing can beat you and you'll just obliterate everything in your path. 

However, it does have a bit of a grind to unlock everything (I still haven't unlocked all items!) and sometimes the game can reach a point where your system slows down due to the plethora of particles appearing on the screen. Also, even if you reach the point where you obliterate every enemy in your path, they can still kill you - quite easily, in fact! It just takes 1 small mistake and your run is over.

Regardless, it's still a joy to play. I recommend this, especially with friends.

+++Very flexible challenge and difficulty system that allows one to either cheese it, or experience great suffering and glory. (Easiest difficulty with OP modifiers for a relaxing run? I won't judge. Halo-style Legendary All Skulls On run for maximum pain? Good on ya.)

+++Lots of game-changing items to allow one to utilize the power of MATH and NUMBERS to create truly game-breaking builds. (One of the character's challenges is basically encouraging abusing math and stats to deal a million-damage shot.)

+++Very unique classes allow for very interesting paths for builds. (Character specializes in poisonous Damage Over Time? Why not set enemies on fire and make them bleed in addition?)

++Lots of obscure easter eggs, secrets, and other hidden goodies. (Wiki, much?)

+Optional lore tidbits for every single character, enemy, and item. (Having only played 2, I definitely feel like I'm missing out on a good chunk of background. Not enough to deter my enjoyment of the gameplay, though.)

-It is possible to get one-shot and just instantly die from an attack or combination of attacks. (Best solution for this is to play it smart and avoid jumping into high concentrations of enemies... but that's difficult for melee characters, for example.) 

--I'll admit, platforming over an abyss isn't my thing. I hated that in Destiny 2, and it still makes me shaky and sensitive in this game. (Feel free to remove this negative if platforming doesn't bother you.)

If you played the first game, even though 2-D, most of the fundamentals are applied here. You get a character, go through a level getting upgrades and levels, but try to keep a pace as the difficulty keeps increasing slowly. Obviously jumping to a 3D environment you don't have some of the benefits of its predecesor like a wide field of vision and easier to locate items and teleporters, but is nonetheless a enjoyable experience in every playthrough.

For anyone new to this game and doesn't know about how the first one works, I must aware that this is can become a difficult experience for a rookie. I haven't touched the first game in years and still had to relearn a few things, but is still all about how you invest your time on each level and try to not stall too much. Each character plays completely differently, so aside of achievement hunting and unlocks you'll find one to main and master a route. Combined with co-op and an quite active playerbase, you'll get a very different playthrough each time much like any other roguelike out there. Just be aware that a single run can reach more than an hour quite easily, so try to play the game when you have plenty of free time to spare. Unfortunately, the time investment is one of its few flaws. Unless you get the propersave mod, there's no way to make a checkpoint to keep playing later if you need to stop for any reason.

To be fair the negatives are very scarce besides the time investment issue. Some players might get easily lost looking for the teleporters, which while solved by just looking for red particles it also means low end PCs won't have that solution if they have to turn most settings down. This is specially the case with Sulfur Pools, which although my PC already has its years yet able to run some current games easily (For example Doom Eternal and Monster Hunter World), this map in particular seems to ask for an extra oomf even at lowest settings. Overall, some small hiccups which current PCs won't have any issue.

I enjoyed the first game and already getting more invested on the second. I recommend getting propersave just in case you need to stop due an emergency or something, and you're good to go to spend whole afternoons in just a pair of runs with this game.

It's a fun game but there are a couple of issues that make it not as replayable as it seems. 
The bottom line is the skill expression is lacking. It's not completely absent, but the game doesn't reward you for playing it a lot. 

1. The power creep

I understand that the game is PvE but that doesn't excuse at least trying to balance the survivors.
More recent survivors like Railgunner can achieve consistent runs every single time yet characters like Artificer and Commando are more reliant on item RNG. 

RNG should make the game more replayable, not make you feel like you were put in a scenario where there is nothing you could have done. At some point you will realize when the run is dead no matter how well you manage your time. Sometimes you don't get a single damage item as Commando or a single utility item as Artificer and your 15 minutes of that run is wasted. 

If all the survivors from the beginning were designed have the same consistency as Loader, Railgunner, Acrid, Bandit etc. then it would be fine. However, Hopoo seems to randomly decide when to balance survivors instead of it being the core focus. 

A good example is Mercenary gaining the expose mechanic. A bad example of this is with the new burn changes added in the latest DLC, Artificer's flamethrower now does less damage. 

I understand some survivors should be more difficult to play but that comes to my next point.

2. The difficulty is mostly fake.

There are some things you can react to as a player but a lot of times your death is going to be from a random stack of collapse or overloading orb or a blazing stone titan. Mechanics that either have very little counterplay or no counterplay at all depending on the survivor you play as. One shot protection is designed to protect players against these kinds of interactions, but more and more effects are added to bypass one shot protection. Yes, you could just get a raincoat every run or a blast shower, but itemization isn't something to rely on in risk of rain. 

Dodging in the game isn't difficult, you can circle strafe the majority of the enemies in the game and the rest are hitscan with no way to reliably dodge their attacks. 

This is also probably why there isn't a true melee survivor in the game. The attack that ultimately ends your run is something that isn't under your control most of the time. Mercenary is the only melee survivor in the game, yet the only solution was to add i-frames on a 5 second cooldown or don't even play him as a melee survivor. 

The first 5 minutes of every character all have a fun gameplay loop, but as soon as you enter mid-late game things start getting stale. Eventually every character plays the same as soon as the run gets good. You're only going to be pressing 1 button (usually your safest yet still most damaging ability) while running around in a circle. The uniqueness of each character is lost the further the run goes. 


Which comes to my final point - There really isn't an incentive to master a character when item RNG is so important.
 
Mercenary is probably the most complex character yet this is probably all by accident. Cancelling skills probably wasn't even an intended feature. Even if you are very good at playing Mercenary or any other character, there aren't really many ways to express your skill. The difference between a Mercenary that is mechanically skilled at cancelling vs a Mercenary that simply understands when to play safely is marginal. The difference between a Loader that has mastered movement vs someone just picking Loader up for the first time is negligible. 

In the end, optimizing your play doesn't increase your chance of success in a run by much. 

Not every PvE game needs to provide dedicated players with the ability to show off their skill, but the best PvE games reward you for the time you spend in them. 

It's games that properly reward you for mastery that keep you coming back for more.

Despite being riddled with a lot of questionable, if not bad design choices, this game is incredibly fun and will make your brain rot.

 (DLC is not necessary for the best experience, btw. I would instead say that in its current state, its clearly too buggy and rushed. Maybe pick it up while its on sale.)

The music is as usual great, the characters all feel pretty diverse and have their quirks, the gameplay is overall very enjoyable although i think that hopoo should really try to add features that the players have been asking for YEARS- a restart button, ways for dead players to keep up with the others, the ability to drop items in multiplayer, as well as small reworks of older survivors like commando and huntress, that really need some sort of buff. They are both fun in their own way but are completely outclassed by every other survivor in the game.
Changing the final bossfight a little would also be welcome as it can be cheesed with enough mobility and i guess a bit of experience. Funny moon man literally cannot touch you if you are in the air, and i believe that he should have a (reasonable) attack that can inflict pressure on high mobility players as well.
Maybe remove the final countdown before leaving the moon and make the ending cutscene trigger once you have reached the spaceship? Having to run from void reavers and moon explosions(?) is already pretty exciting by itself, i dont think that having to do ANOTHER useless "teleporter event" is very fitting, besides, the reavers cannot get within spaceship range, and if you dont attack them, you have no way to die. So, what is the point of the timer? Maybe make it shorter or make the players do something else instead of just waiting.
Some lunar items would also definitely benefit from a rework, for example gesture and brittle crown have NO drawbacks and can be picked up whenever, it really doesnt matter. 
I would mention the autoplay issue, which is a big one, but honestly as this point its useless because the devs would have to spend ages to completely rebalance the game from the start in order for its gameplay to feel more skill based than rng based. And i dont think they have the time, or the motivation for that. I just wish lategame was fun and didnt break completely with you killing all enemies on the screen just by looking at them.
Aaaaand many more problems.

I have to mention a last thing; one of the main selling points of this game is its multiplayer element. Yeah, a multiplayer that is only enjoyable with friends, because random lobbies are not fun. Please do consider adding the changes i mentioned at the start of the review, as the multiplayer experience really needs some extra polish.

Though, to be fair, you will only start to notice the games design issues once you have several hours into it, and at that point you will most likely be too addicted to care. Its still a fun game that i enjoy very much, so i still recommend it, despite probably sounding very judgemental in the above paragraph.

Do not get me wrong, this game is a lot of fun. But there are some major flaws in the game design.
There's a lot of items to find, a lot of secrets to 'uncover', things to collect and unlock. Which is nice, even if I don't agree with the method of which some of these are gained.

I've gone through this game on multiple characters and to some degree I do enjoy the game, but it is one of those games where, there's a lot of good but also a lot of flaws.
Many times, some characters feel like they weren't finished or perhaps not even properly tested and another problem is that you can play for about an hour or so, eventually get fairly comfortable and then die to a single hit. 
Such, gathering health items or some of the defence items to try and negate damage is only going to matter early on.

There's been updates to try and fix some of the problems, though I still feel the game could be better. A few tweaks on some of the available character choices, some item changes and a change to the method of which difficulty increases and, I think it'd be a perfect game for its genre.

[ The Survivors walk past the motel on the highway while O Sweet Death plays. ]

[ Coach breaks through the boarded up door to a convenience store Safe Room in the park, unlocks it and everyone walks in. ]

Coach: Report unusual behavior...

[ Nick opens the cash register with his pistol and smirks. ]

Coach: Barricade your homes...

[ Ellis opens a gun cabinet and looks inside. His expression of bewilderment changes to a devilish smile. ]

Coach: Avoid all contact with infected individuals...

[ Rochelle is studying a map as Ellis places a pistol on top of it for her. She pushes it away as Ellis studies a Combat Shotgun. ]

[ Coach is shown reading off a piece of paper as he holds a chocolate bar. ]

Coach: Wait for official instructions. Heh, wait my ass!

[ Coach crumples the paper and throws it away as he walks towards the others eating his chocolate bar. Ellis has attached a grenade launcher, sniper rifle, a pipe bomb and first aid kit to his back. ]

Ellis: Kill all sons 'a bitches.

[ Ellis racks his Combat Shotgun. ]

Ellis: That's my 'ficial instructions.

[ Ellis kicks out the Safe Room door and they open fire on a group of Common Infected. Chocolate Helicopter begins to play.]

[ Coach punches an Infected in the face, knocking it down. Rochelle brings her axe into the face of a Common as Coach walks up to the downed Common. ]

Coach: This used to be a nice neighborhood!

[ Coach beats the Common's face in with the stock of his Chrome Shotgun. ]

[ Ellis and Nick run along the highway, when Ellis is tackled by a Jockey. Nick turns around.]

Nick: Shit!

[ Nick fires. Cut to the downed plane in the crash site. ]

Rochelle: What the hell was that?

[ A trio of mud men notice them and charge. ]

Ellis: Hey watch out!

[ Cut to Ellis and Rochelle hiding behind a fallen tree. Rochelle hushes Ellis as a Spitter appears on the other side of the tree. ]

Rochelle: Shhh... This is some grim shit we've got ourselves into...

[ The Spitter hacks up acid at the camera as the scene cuts to the Survivors fighting in the streets of Ducatel. ]

Rochelle: Get back! Get back!

[ Coach and Rochelle fire briefly at the horde before the Survivors run away. Ellis is helping Nick walk. Cut to the Survivors climbing a stairwell. ]

Coach: [ Panting from exhaustion ] Who the hell...puts an evac station...up thirty flights of goddamn stairs...

Nick: [ Exhausted ] Come on Сoach...maybe the helicopter...maybe it's made of chocolate. [ Chuckles ]

[ Coach scowls at Nick. ]

[ The Survivors reach the top of the building. Ellis is calling out. ]

Ellis: Hey where is everybody? Helloooo!

[ Four helicopters are seen flying away in the distance. ]

Rochelle: Ok, this is not happening...

Ellis: Anyone here?

Rochelle: ...This is not happening. This is not happening.

Coach: Aren't they supposed to be saving our asses?

Nick: Looks like there's been a change of plans.

[ Cut to jets bombing the embankment to the Louisiana Naval Shipyard, a Horde in the French Quarter, and a tractor trailer being blown into a group of Infected on the bridge. ]

Rochelle: [ Into a radio ] Stop the bombing run!

[ Cut to the Veterans Memorial Bridge collapsing into the river. ]

Radio voice: Jesus Christ! That's coming from the bridge!

[ Coach is thrown back onto the hood of a squad car as an explosion hits a gas tanker in front of him. Nick rushes over to help him. ]

Ellis: SHIT!

[ Nick looks up in surprise. ]

[ Ellis is attacked by a Charger in a burning shack. It roars, bursting through the wood, sending him flying. It then picks him up. ]

Ellis: It's got me!

[ The Charger pounds him on the ground. He grunts out loud. ]

[ Cut to Nick followed by a group of Infected climbing a roller coaster in Whispering Oaks. Nick is pulled up by Rochelle as a fireball engulfs the Infected. ]

Rochelle: Hang on!

[ Two hazmat suit Infected walk through flames and turn towards the camera. ]

[ The Survivors run down a hallway to an elevator. Ellis melees a Uncommon Riot Infected, but loses his Sniper Rifle to a Common Infected that trips with it's arms raised, making it fall out of his hands. He makes it inside the elevator, but a Smoker grabs him. ]

Ellis: Ah, what the hell-OWW!

[ Nick grabs onto Ellis, pulling him away from the infected as two Common Infected keep the doors open. Coach takes a chainsaw and decapitates the Infected and severs the Smoker's tongue. ]

Coach: Goddammit! Eat that shit!

[ Ellis collapses on the floor, and removes the tongue still wrapped around him. His expression of disgust turns to shock as he looks out the glass window, down at a swarm of Infected. ]

Ellis: Holy shit...

[ Coach helps Ellis to his feet as Rochelle hands him a grenade launcher. ]

Rochelle: Hey. "Kill all sons 'a bitches", right?

[ Ellis sheepishly nods, grinning at the grenade launcher. ]

[ The floor count changes from five to four. Cut to the Survivors on the stage of the Dark Carnival finale fighting a horde. Coach throws a gas can into the fireworks. ]

Coach: YEAH!

[ Ellis shoots the flying gas can with his Combat Rifle and it explodes above the horde of infected. ]

Nick (voiceover): I have not...

[ Floor count changes from 4 to 3. Rochelle cocks and fires a heavy machine gun from the porch of the mansion in Swamp Fever. ]

Nick (voiceover): ...come this far...

[ Floor count changes from 3 to 2. The Survivors are fighting a Tank on the Veteran's Memorial bridge. ]

Nick (voiceover): ...to die now.

[ Floor count changes from 2 to L. The doors of the elevator open up. As the Survivors prepare, Coach revs up his chainsaw to fight the horde. ]

TLDR: most important part is below... 
I've been playing a lot of this one since I got it. It doesn't concern itself with too much other than enjoyable gameplay- a feature that is ******* rare these days. I like the music, I like the different characters (and subsequent different playstyles) and every character is a viable character to play if you're willing to practice. Or, like me, you might find a character the seems to just suit you. You can play this game over and over again and beat it over and over again with your own goals in mind. That might sound kinda odd, but you'll see what I mean. For instance, there are quite a few achievements to complete so I'll start a game up with that achievement in mind. The whole game could theoretically be beat in minutes if you're really good. Or, you can drag the game on for hours at a time (like I do) and see just how rediculous your character can get before you either decide to win on your terms, or, possibly die instantly because you're 3 hours in and you stood still for a single blink of the eye. Either way, it's fun. 

MOST IMPORTANT PART and I gotta put my Karen hat on for this one- this is a HUGE mention for any game nowadays. I have only encountered 1 bug and, honestly, I'm relatively certain it's because I'm using hardware from like 2014. And it occurred because of the shear amount of chaos that was occurring on screen after a run that I had dragged out for hours. And it wasn't even game breaking at that, I just got a kind of black box for a few seconds on screen that corrected as soon as things calmed down a little. Almost like the carnage was "too much so we had to censor it" in a way...Other than that, this game runs clean. I've never once crashed. Not once. I can't remember being able to say that about a game since way back in the day when I was on original Xbox. Honestly, It's like these devs don't even care about haphazardly piecing code together. And I never even remotely got that feeling like they rushed it. Where's all the bugs? How am I supposed to play or even enjoy a game that functions correctly? It's like these devs understand how systems and code work AND they're creative and quite frankly I'm offended and they should be ashamed. Where's the obvious signs of "rushed-developer" suffering? Did they even try to have someone breathe down their necks from the top? I bet these monsters even write thorough/understandable/helpful notation for their back-end coding. Disgraceful. Who actually understands how to use a graphics/physics engine suite these days? OH, btw, these blinkered philistines didn't bother to lock a single element of the game behind an additional pay wall. Seriously? No micro-transactions at all? What... do they expect me to simply have and enjoy the game that I already paid money up-front for? The ****? They'll never be AAA. No sir, not this way.  I just don't understand how a development studio can expect to release a fully functional/stable title, reasonably priced, that's also enjoyable and expect to make it in this market.

Have you ever wanted to become powerful enough to fight god? Then this game is for you. It's one of the best roguelites of all time, and is every bit of addicting as you've ever heard it to be. It's an incredible feat of a game that I recommend to everyone.

It is one of the most mechanically satisfying roguelites in existence. They trim the fat to make it extremely streamlined so that you can focus on exponentially growing the amount of dopamine in your brain. Touch down on the planet, kill stuff, collect items, kill the boss, and don't linger for one more second. The gameplay loop is immensely satisfying. It's so easy to sit down and play this game for 10 minutes, but then you realize your entire life has gone by and you've spent 40 minutes playing, and now you're an unkillable god being. It's insane.

You don't get the same amount of power from other roguelite/roguelike games. Here, your power is exponential (and occasionally linear). Items stack to continue to raise the stakes of what you can do and how much you can resist. You're constantly hoping for and looking for items that are complementary to your characters kit. And when you do, it's just the right rush.

The characters are excellent, with their abilities being unique enough to make you re-think your favorite strategies every time you switch off of your main. The art direction is superb, the soundtrack is sublime, and the enemy variety is top notch. I've played the game for over 100 hours at this point and nothing has started to wear on me.

The more time you put into Risk of Rain 2, the more you get out of it. At first, everything is new and mysterious, the enemies are difficult, the items quirky, and the bosses are majestically powerful. But the longer you play the more you put the pieces together. Soon you'll know what the items do just by looking at their icons. Soon you'll start to understand the deeply rooted lore, hidden in logs and item descriptions. It's a vastly beautiful painting that slowly comes to form with the more time you invest. It's a really incredible experience. Not to mention, you can do all of it in a really top notch multiplayer experience.

The achievements are what got me hooked again lately. They're quite attainable, and for the first time in a long time, I've 100% a video game. One of two in my Steam library. The itch to complete them to get the additional character skills or skins was mind bogglingly addictive.

Beyond all of this, the DLC has been top notch. There's been a few updates that have had major inclusions to content that have been free, and the first paid DLC came out and it was worth every penny. I can't wait to see what else Hopoo has in store for us.

My only complaint:
I would have loved it if there was a "training room" of sorts, that you could go into to test damage values and stacks of items, and learn if items stack linearly or exponentially. There is the artifact of command, but that's just not the same, and still takes time to get the resources together to test things. Beyond that, if you play with the artifact of command, there's no item tool tips to help you remember what the items are, which is difficult if you don't see a lot of an item (especially red items). So even with my 100+ hours of experience, I've got the wiki open for reference. It would be nice to be able to just see all that in game.

All in all, it's difficult, it's fun, and it's infinitely replayable. NameBrand.

Gameplay loop; But fun. The eternal rogue-lite dilemma of game design. However, I still think it's a great pick up to play alone, or with friends. Has multiple modes of play, optional collectathons, and a difficult yet rewarding system of fundamentals and mechanics (and easy mode, if that's your cup of tea). All the characters have their own niches and all feel unique to themselves, as well as maintaining an ubiqutiously intricate balance centered around immediate versus long-term power. All of the survivors kits are fun to use depending on your play style and help you learn how to become better at the game through trial and error. The item system, while relatively less balanced, is also well designed in it's own right. The process of learning which items are better than others allows complex decision making while looting to evaulate the risk vs reward of your choices, while not outright demanding it if you only want to W+M1 slam some bosses and elites. No item is useless, and everything can work if you try hard enough, which I believe is a huge strength of the game.

Tl;Dr- Can be monotonous, but also fun in it's simplicity. Enjoyable as a tryhard or casual with lots of content to explore. Still updated and patched as of posting.

(Minor spoilers ahead)

I both love and hate this game. It has produced some of my absolute best moments in gaming period. The reason I'm not recommending it because it's also produced some of my worst, and those are getting more numerous by the day.

Risk of rain 2 hooks you in by how amazing it is in a lot of aspects. The ease of introduction to new players, the gradual progression of beating stages and unlocking new items, the differences in character playstyles being some of them. There's a whole load of stuff for you to do and explore early on. The problem arises when you unlock everything you need to unlock and explore everything the game has to offer. Once the novelty wears off, all you're left with is the run themselves and when a run goes bad you're left with absolutely nothing but pain and misery. When it's my fault I accept it, but the game has it's fair share of bugs and bad design choices that can end your run through no fault of your own.

The timer is by far the worst offender in run killers. In my many many years of gaming, I HAVE NEVER had to manually leave the game because it outscaled me. Here I have. In fact, it has happened many times. No, I'm not spending huge amounts of time on a stage and picking up every chest, I know how to play. This happens even if you stick to the "under 5 min per planet" rule, particularly when playing low base damage characters. The enemies after a certain point just turn into bullet sponges. When this happens, it's beyond frustrating, as you have to manually exit out of the run as you can't progress. One time when I knew the run was already over because of this, I decided to kill the secret boss on Siren's call just to see how long it would take. I was playing commando and it took 20 whole minutes of holding left click for him to actually die. I guess if this game lets you achieve the highest of highs, you have to be ready for the lowest of lows. 

Mithrix fight is not fair. Not fair towards Mithrix I mean, as long as you're playing certain characters. When you're playing no mobility ones, it's not fair towards the player. His moveset is great on paper, but terrible in practice. One time I was playing captain and had a few wax quails and other small mobility items. I was dodging his attacks perfectly until he decided to charge and swing 2 times in a row for some reason. This obviously ended my run as it was undodgeable. So since I have to deal with this huge problem as captain, do I get high damage? Nope, the fight lasted like 15 mintues and then I died to an undodgeable attack. Captain sucks. He's fun though. Let me contrast this by an engineer run I've had. For some godforsaken reason, the devs decided it would be a good idea to make mithrix focus drones and HE CAN'T EVEN HIT THEM. With engineer, the Mithrix fight looked like, no joke, place two turrets down -> stand on top of a pillar -> watch. Even though I won, I felt so empty and disappointed that I might as well have lost the run. Feels like this shit hasn't been playtested even once. I want to add that in both of these examples, I had average builds, not some lucky god run. So is there any reason for me to ever pick captain again if I want to win? That's obviously a rhetorical question. One more thing about Mithrix... there's a reason other games make bosses immune to CC. When I played Rex, all I had to do to beat Mithrix is root and shoot him and he was dead in three rotations. Horrible fight, wasted potential.

Dying to bugs isn't fun. Especially when you're over an hour into the run and got a fairy decent build after many failed attempts. I've had "death by planet", a possible bug where even the game doesn't know what killed you (as I've read on the internet) happen to me multiple times. It isn't possible that I'm just imagining this, as I've cleared every enemy on the stage and just died randomly to nothing. The other time, I was on stage 15 I think, had many stacks of topaz brooch + the red barrier item and I've been noticing that my barrier seems to turn off and on randomly, even when I'm not in combat. Of course, a bit later I died because my barrier was in "off" mode while there are 200 enemies on screen. My guess is that in late game many calculations need to happens so sometimes it just bugs out.

I've already mentioned the bullet sponge problem, but my god it doesn't get worse than the moon area before the Mithrix fight. What a slog to get through, the fast pacing the game had before this area comes to a complete halt. Even if you were oneshotting enemies before this area, here you'll have trouble with lunar enemies and for all the wrong reasons. Instead of these enemy types being a challenge where you have to strategically outsmart them, they're just another huge bag of health with moderate damage. Not to mention that in this stage mobility characters have a HUGE advantage. if you're a low mobility character with not enough damage to consistently kill lunar enemies, good luck. Not only will you have to spend 10-15 minutes running from pillar to pillar and standing in place, but sometimes you'll get softlocked by two flying machine gun enemies that will not even let you get near the pillar. Worse yet is when they spawn on you while you're charging a slow pillar and you can't kill them. You'll have to spend 4 minutes running to the other side of the map to charge another pillar and then 4 minutes to return to this one, hoping they'll not be guarding it. Fun and interactive gameplay. Meanwhile you can choose a mobility character and skip this stage entirely sometimes by just flying towards Mithrix. What a joke.

If you couldn't tell already, I'm writing this review after a failed frustrating run. What pushed me towards uninstalling this game and writing this review is realizing that Risk of rain 2 does not respect your time. I was aiming to complete Acrid's alternate loadout challenge which requires you to kill scavanger. Pretty simple, right? Apparently not. I had a decent build, clearing enemies with ease as I've had 4 charges of my R skill with a few bandoliers to reset all 4 cooldown stacks. I've also had the red item that lets you jump high and slam into the ground. I've encountered a scavanger at around stage 10 and obviously went to kill him. The thing is, he was physically unkillable for me as far as I can tell. I've tried everything, from applying many many blight stacks, to slamming him with the red jumping item from 10km into the air and trying to combo it with damaging equipment, but nothing. His health acted like it was in a different game. It's not even that he was healing, he just took aoe dmg from my R and dropped to 50% health, but when I slammed him with apparently 10000% damage he didn't drop below 90%. On one slam, it appeared as if he actually gained health. I was tracking items that he was gaining via chat, but he only gained useless stuff. I found out he actually spawns with already equipped items and there's no way to tell what they are other than looking at them on his 3D model. This is way too much to expect from players, especially when there's already so many things going on on the screen because it's lategame. Yes, I know I could have skipped scavanger, however as I've mentioned previously, there's nothing left for me to unlock so I don't wanna just wander aimlessly into higher stages. Before I clicked play, I set a goal to unlock the alternate loadout and the game robbed me of that.

All in all, Risk of rain 2 is just like League. It hooks you in with awesomeness, but before you realize it you're addicted to the high it once gave you. The high rarely comes again and all you're left with is frustration, anger and disappointment. The worst of all is the feeling that you've spent time that could have been spent doing something else. If you have the strength to uninstall after unlocking everything, by all means buy this game it's worth it. However, if you have an addicting personality, STAY AWAY.

This is by far one of, if not the, greatest rouge like games I have ever played. There are a ton of items to make every play through different. Every character is unique and extremely enjoyable to play. My favorite is Huntress, but every character is viable with the right items. I like the look and variety of the enemies and the difficulty gets harder as you play, but that is what makes it so fun. And just when the game starts to feel repetitive, artifacts and the recently added game modes can change how you play and make is much harder or just more chaotic and fun. Amazing game and would recommend to anyone looking for a great rouge like game to play solo or with friends.

This game is my absolute favorite roguelite to play with friends, and by myself. It has a long, but smooth learning curve, and it is still fun to play and improve even after 400 hours. At first it feels like the game is very rng dependent, but over time you find lots of ways to influence your run and beat the rng. Even on monsoon, almost all games feel winnable to me. If you play long enough, eventually the game will give you what you need for a god run.

Depending on the survivor you play as, it has a nice mix of mechanics driven gameplay (both with aim and movement tech), or just game knowledge based characters that don't demand too much mechanical skill from the player. You can sweat it out in the extremely difficult eclipse mode, or just chill and watch the numbers go up, while the entire screen gets covered in explosions in the easier difficulties.

One piece of advice for new players, start on the "drizzle" difficulty. This game has a lot of mechanics, a lot of enemies, and a lot of items to learn. The higher difficulties just force you to make decisions faster (because difficulty scales with time, not just the level), and it can be frustrating to feel like you are losing to the clock while you are just learning the ropes. Once you've beat the games a few times on drizzle, then try the harder difficulties and focus on being efficient, and you'll find they aren't that bad.

Risk of Rain is action rogue-like game. Game is great and awesome, although dev team disappoints in few points. Visually, thank God it is not another pixel indie game. No hate, but indies can do better. Each map has different color pallet and looks unique and beautiful. Sounds, audio cues and musics are fine. Some of the musics are really interesting. Now gameplay, it is what you expect from genre. Keep repeating each map, playing different heroes, getting different items with a small change in each map. If you were never into this genre, ROR2 might change your idea. It is that good. And another plus for Modding community. You can 100% this game in 90hours, and another 90hours at least playing mods. Adding more items and heroes and lots of other stuff. Repetition hasn't bore me yet.

I've had a lot of fun with this game, especially since the new update. There's lots of replay value in this game as you try to unlock mastery skins and achievements, as well as try new builds for each of the survivors. Speaking of survivors, a lot of the survivors are fun to play and draw from common archetypes. While some of the abilities aren't exactly original by any means, I think this is actually a good thing, as it makes it very easy to grasp a survivor at a fundamental level and lets the player worry more about learning how the item system works in this game.

And of course, the items are really what make this game stand out! Traveling through the different environments and picking up different items to play to a survivor's strengths or transform how they play completely is something that's really fun about this game!

All this would be really lame without some tough enemies to fight however. And this game isn't lacking in that department either! There are plenty of enemies with different attacks to learn and dodge, and the game does a good job at keeping you on your toes especially at the higher difficulties. Some of the bosses can be challenging too, especially for a newcomer.

If I had any advice to give to new players, it would be this. Make sure to get plenty of items. If you go too fast, you'll just thrust yourself into battles you aren't ready to face. But don't spend too long either! It's about finding the right balance of looting vs moving. And of course, always stay moving. The key to staying alive in this game is to dodge, dodge, DODGE! While in the early game you may be able to shrug off a few hits, as the enemies scale any hit can become lethal. So stay moving!

All in all, Risk of Rain 2 is an excellent game and I've had a lot of fun playing it.

I loved Risk of Rain and I really wish I could love Risk of Rain 2, but it simply won't run smoothly on my computer. The game stutters enough to not be enjoyable and causes me headaches after a few minutes of play.

I don't think I lack the system requirements: I've got an Intel i7-8700 CPU, 16 GB of RAM (4 required), and an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2070 which seem way over the recommended setup. I made a few attempts at reinstalling/configuring it in different ways, but they all fell short.

As for what I've been able to play, I'm not sure the 3D suits this genre very much. A lot of mental energy is spent just figuring out which enemies are there, and due to their size, movement, and distance actually trying to aim at them gets painful very soon. I think it would be better off with some kind of enemy radar and aim assist (you'll be aiming at A LOT of small enemies): I don't think Risk of Rain has ever been much about aiming as it's been about choosing your target priorities and combos togheter with the items you drop, which the 2D version lets you do while relaxed on the other parts.

There is a large variety of characters with different skill sets, Some characters are easier than others but most are tend to be easy to learn and have fun with. No matter how many times you die, loop, kill millions of enemies or beat the game, entertainment just keeps coming which compliments the replayability of this game. You grow stronger with near endless items stacking with each boosting your stats or chances  (Opening chests fuels my gambling addiction :)))))) With the new Survivors of the Void DLC brings 2 really fun characters, New items and alternative items that can corrupt others and give them new purpose and an endless game mode 'Simulacrum' which is equally as fun as the original. Its also very fun to play with friends (If you actually have any) and grief the run with 30 consecutive Glowing Meteorite equipment. Honestly, 5 hours in this game feels like 15 minutes its crazy how unique this game is it really feels like one of a kind. definitely recommended

Excellent successor to the fantastic Risk of Rain. Punishingly difficult roguelite shooter gameplay with nearly infinite replayability. Especially fun if playing with a friend or two in co-op mode.

My one complaint is that all achievements can apparently be earned while using Artifacts. Since the use of Artifacts can dramatically alter the difficulty of the game, this effectively renders every achievement trivially easy to obtain, and therefore not really an achievement at all. Want that special skin that comes with the Mastery achievement for your favorite character? No problem! Just activate the right combination of Artifacts, and waltz right through your run on Monsoon difficulty. Very questionable design decision, Hopoo. "Mastery" should actually mean something.

It's good for a bit, but as you play, you begin seeing flaws. Good thing this game has mods! Mods allow you to fix practically all of the issues with this game's balance. Riskymod + Riskyartifacts + Elitereworks + Dropinmultiplayer + Notenoughfriends is probably my go-to mod setup. Riskymod reworks the game balance entirely, riskyartifacts adds a few more artifacts for your gaming pleasure, elitereworks gives elites more impactful abilities while toning down their tankiness and huge damage, dropinmultiplayer allows friends to join mid-run and gives them some items to catch up, and notenoughfriends allows you to play with up to 16 people instead of just 4.

Here's a full analysis on the game:
Shoutout to my friend who genuinely got me this game and made me love shooting small beetles and lizards (you decide if that is real life or ROR2).
(TL:DR: This game is polished and has great combat/enemies/characters/items. 10/10 would break the game again)

Controls & settings:
They are incredibly well done even on default. It's subjective on what you'll use but it is still super good and the settings are just perfect. It can decide what you need for decent visuals and fps very easily.

Bugs: 
I love choking on void field air while I slide off the map eighteen times, and that is one of the only bugs that is there. Besides small little effects on my game or visual bugs, I'd say it is quite polished.

Combat:
As a quick-paced, roguelike and mild Third-person run-n-gun, I've entirely enjoyed the play-style despite it being the first I've played. Weapons don't feel overpowered unless you use items well. The only issue is that gup makes me feel bad for killing everything in sight.

Movement: 
I love moving at mach-1 due to infinite red whips and flying with bandit and railgunner. Holy shit why am I allowed to do this, it feels like a crime and it is super fun. This is the first time I've actually been able to escape the police because I have immense speed.

Optimisation:
The game runs smooth as fuck, nothing is cluttered and even the lowest settings will work for most people. Granddads running 1998 windows vista laptops will most definitely not be able to play, but at least they get to see commando dead on the title screen :)

Enemies:
The bosses are amazingly fun to fight, and enemies aren't too overpowered unless you are deciding to fight on monsoon in loop 40311 and you are 48 days in. The game is well-balanced and unless you're playing crowbar huntress you are on your toes at all times.

Achievements: 
Characters are blocked behind achievements, which gives more progression and allows you to pick a main quite easily because you learn their abilities quickly and want to try to get them. Items are a bit hard to get sometimes but that is reasonable. It would be good if you could hover over what items did with artifact of command though, so that new players playing with their friends aren't left in the dust.

Characters:
Speaking of items and characters, they all are special and unique. Some are even quite powerful if you use them well. Such as void fiend. 100% corruption is fucking overpowered but takes time to get. Artificer is seen as bad by some people, but clearly they do not own air fryers because you can literally be THE orbital strike (take that captain!).

Conclusion:
Overall, this game is the first I think I have ever reviewed that gets a solid 9-10/10. With such polished gameplay and dlc being made to increase the replayability of the game even further, you question why it isn't even more expensive.

The incredible feeling of being 30 minutes straight in a run and suddenly dying and still wanting to start another run, is something I haven't felt for a long time with this kind of games. What the people at Hopoo Games have achieved with the 3d scenery and how it works hand in hand with the mechanics of a Roguelike. The variety of characters, strategies and objects is something that definitely made me fall in love with this game. Anyway the great variety and quantity of items was the only thing that I didn't feel worked well in the game, because at the end it's not that you choose an item that you won't find again, but that as the runs last more than 30 minutes you will end up getting all the items (which I have to admit is funny). 8/10

I didn't really *get* Risk of Rain 2 until recently. Rather than emphasizing a lot of planning and strategize-ing like other roguelikes, it instead rewards in-the-moment decision making: which items you prioritize at any point in a run, which enemies in a hoard you take out, etc. It makes for a fun experience and when it gets dull, the other characters change the dynamic so substantially that it is like playing a different game. Must play if you have friends with the game too.

When I first heard one of my favorite games, Risk of Rain, was getting a sequel that would be 3-D instead of 2-D, I was very excited, but skeptical if they could pull it off. Now, 300+ hours in and 100% of achievements unlocked, I can safely say my expectations were blown away. The essence of the original was kept expertly intact making this game, which gives a familiar but still new and exciting feel. The returning characters and items all retain just enough to keep them true to their form, while tweaking some bits to fit the new environment and play style of a 3-D world. Even the soundtrack returns with the same amazing and atmospheric presence, Chris did a great job with it and I would rank it up with some of my favorite game music like Mick Gordon's Doom soundtrack. I cannot recommend this game enough to fans of rougelikes or really anyone who can appreciate a game that expertly does what it sets out to do.
