Ok, this has been driving me crazy for seven movies now, and I know you're going to roll your eyes, but hear me out: Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.

Here's why:

Think about how quickly the entire WWWIII (Wizarding-World War III) would have ended if all of the good guys had simply armed up with good ol' American hot lead.

Basilisk? Let's see how tough it is when you shoot it with a .470 Nitro Express. Worried about its Medusa-gaze? Wear night vision goggles. The image is light-amplified and re-transmitted to your eyes. You aren't looking at it--you're looking at a picture of it.

Imagine how epic the first movie would be if Harry had put a breeching charge on the bathroom wall, flash-banged the hole, and then went in wearing NVGs and a Kevlar-weave stab-vest, carrying a SPAS-12.

And have you noticed that only Europe seems to a problem with Deatheaters? Maybe it's because Americans have spent the last 200 years shooting deer, playing GTA: Vice City, and keeping an eye out for black helicopters over their compounds. Meanwhile, Brits have been cutting their steaks with spoons. Remember: gun-control means that Voldemort wins. God made wizards and God made muggles, but Samuel Colt made them equal.

Now I know what you're going to say: "But a wizard could just disarm someone with a gun!" Yeah, well they can also disarm someone with a wand (as they do many times throughout the books/movies). But which is faster: saying a spell or pulling a trigger?

Avada Kedavra, meet Avtomat Kalashnikova.

Imagine Harry out in the woods, wearing his invisibility cloak, carrying a .50bmg Barrett, turning Deatheaters into pink mist, scratching a lightning bolt into his rifle stock for each kill. I don't think Madam Pomfrey has any spells that can scrape your brains off of the trees and put you back together after something like that. Voldemort's wand may be 13.5 inches with a Phoenix-feather core, but Harry's would be 0.50 inches with a tungsten core. Let's see Voldy wave his at 3,000 feet per second. Better hope you have some Essence of Dittany for that sucking chest wound.

I can see it now...Voldemort roaring with evil laughter and boasting to Harry that he can't be killed, since he is protected by seven Horcruxes, only to have Harry give a crooked grin, flick his cigarette butt away, and deliver what would easily be the best one-liner in the entire series:

"Well then I guess it's a good thing my 1911 holds 7+1."

And that is why Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.

Honestly baffled at how Hopoo games consistently makes such a polished masterpiece even better. With how many variables there are, it's a marvel that the game doesn't constantly break.

Another thing, this game has such a deep and encapsulating lore. It's both horrifying and monumentally tragic at times.

Not to mention the visual flair atop the technical masterpiece, all bundled together with a bomb ass soundtrack.

My only complaint with this game is a few "challenging" implementations, as they put it. (I.E. the void fiend's charge, twip twip being unkillable, etc.)

Its close to being fun, but its not quite there. There are a lot of little things that make the game feel like its designed to make the game longer but it just makes it boring.  Enemies barely spawn for the first 2 minutes of a stage so you just wandering around killing like 3 enemies a minute so you can open maybe 3 chests before you open a teleporter.  Annoying enemies spawns that have been added in the DLC make it more likely to just die to newly spawned enemies and just end runs of 30+ minutes, that felt like you barely got anything going.  The game could definitely benefit from more items more quickly.  Just can't recommend it until it tries to be less time wasty in the earlier parts of runs.  It does get better with spawns and monsters the longer into the run you go, but by no means every run you can get strong enough to where you don't just get overrun or 1-shot by a newly spawned enemy or boss 45 minutes into a run.

A fantastic sequel to a fantastic game from a great indie dev. Item combinations in this game and the freedom of play can make any character and build feel godlike, and there's so much chaos to be had whether you're looking for an easy run, a normal run, or a tough-as-nails run. Every survivor feels unique and fantastic to play, and while some have a few kinks in them, everyone is viable and everyone can have you feeling unstoppable with the right build. Multiplayer scaling is a bit ludicrous, so the more players you add the exponentially harder it gets, but it's still a lot of fun. Even if you're not a fan of the RNG element, the game has an unlockable item-selection mutator that lets you play the game with your own builds every time. If you like roguelikes, this is a must-get.

Great game. Truly, it is. The effort that went into the modelling of every item, enemy, and Survivor is incredible, the work with the maps and obstacles is amazing. There was clearly a lot of effort that was put into the making of this game. I truly do love the "unlock different parts of the game via achievements" aspect of the game as well, as this is not a common sight. This game is definitely a very fun game, whether you play solo, or with up to 3 friends, the game play is almost always different, as you start at a random location, have random drops in chests, ect. but you also have the survivors playing differently, and you can even change the attacks on your character to change how that character can be played. For example, MUL-T can have the starter loadout of Auto-Nailgun, Rebar Puncher, and Retool, or you can have the Power Saw, Rebar Puncher, and Retool, or even double Rebar Puncher with Power Mode, allowing for this character to be played in different ways. Plus, with so many different characters that can be played, two games are almost guaranteed to be different. I highly recommend anyone reading this review to play the game, and even get the DLC, as the DLC adds new enemies, maps, items, and two new Survivors that play nothing like the other Survivors in the game. I truly think that this game is an amazing game that definitely deserves to be purchased and played by many people, for it truly is a great game.

So I'll list the pros first: RoR2 is very addictive. Runs usually take around 40 minutes assuming my retardness doesn't end them prematurely. Even when that happens, i just play again. There is a lot of RNG involved. From triggering item effects, to stage variants and what drops from chests. Personally i think this is really good and gives the game replayability. Even though item drops are random, there are still ways to make a proper build with the right items through scrappers, multishops, the lunar bazaar and 3d printers. Risk of rain is a game about numbers. There is lots and lots and lots of damage calculating and chance. I love having brain aneurysms thinking about fictional numbers, There is the game's trademark "difficulty increases with time" system. It's not as impactful as you may have been led to believe. Just take your time lmao.
Now i shall list the cons: Balancing does not exist. With enough experience it's easy to tell what surviviors, skills and items are better than the other. And finally the biggest con is the required grinding. Most surviviors and their alternate skills as well as items are locked behind achievements, Most are easy, but just as much is unreasonably difficult.
I still  think that pros outway the cons and you definetely should play the game along its DLC

Risk Of Rain 2 is one of the most fun rouge like games out there and the best part is that you can play this game with your friends. (this review is spoiler free)

I'm assuming that you have read the main steam store page and have a general idea about what this game is about, but if you haven't I will make a short summary. In risk of rain 2 you play as one of many survivors going stage by stage killing enemies and bosses while picking up a bunch of items. In stage 5 in which you can either loop or do something else that I won't spoil (this other thing completes the run). You wont be able to slowly grind stages as the difficulty increases with the time.

[Positives]
- the gameplay is fun and action based
- the items are diverse and can synergise together to make unique builds
- the multiplayer is really fun which makes this a great game to play with your friends
- the UI looks great and is understandable 
- the rogue like elements makes this game insanely replayable
- there are achievements and unlockable skins and items
- the game is polished 
- each character is unique and each offer a unique experience

[Negatives]
- The monsoon difficulty (which is the hardest difficulty) can sometimes feel a-bit unfair but this might just be a skill issue on my part
- Some achievements are really specific which means you can't try to get a certain achievement but that is really just nitpicking 

In conclusion the polish, diversity and overall fun of Risk Of Rain 2 makes it one of the greatest rouge like games out there. I hope this review helped you decide wether or not you should buy this game

Risk of Rain 2 is pretty damn close to being my favorite videogame of all time, and that's going up against a lot of games that have moved me emotionally in ways that I'm still working through, and games with decades of work put into them that resulted in perfectly handcrafted experiences. I don't know if I would call Risk of Rain 2 a perfect game, but it's by far worth the price of admission as well as the cost of the DLC content. No other game just has as much in it that I specifically enjoy as this game does, and that's saying a lot, like seriously this game is so packed with content and skill based learning curves and all of it is fun and engaging to me, like, how did they even do that.
So anyway I'm gonna be writing a multi paragraph essay about this game just to show how much I think it's worth your money and to give a general skim of what you're getting yourself into, starting with my own experiences with it.
The game paces it's content out in a slow, continuous dripfeed, both in terms of it's lore and it's items/characters, so you're never overwhelmed except maybe at the very beginning if you're new to roguelikes, but I was and I got along just fine after a small adjustment period where I had no idea what was going on. I'd STRONGLY recommend that, even for your absolute first time, you do not play on the easiest difficulty (Drizzle) unless you absolutely need to as an accessibility tool, everyone's different and if you have limits that's understandable, but I guarantee you will get so much more out of the game's default difficulty of Rainstorm. It starts with small victories, you get past the first boss fight, you start to get more items, find little hidden areas in the maps, maybe you even do a few runs with your friends. You start to learn whats generally good and whats generally less good, but you can turn those items that you don't want into scrap to potentially make it into better item. You start to stack items to enhance their effects and build out a few really solid runs. At a certain point you'll start to get consistent 'god runs' where you're able to blast past the difficulty scaling and make enemy spawns a joke, or even have the game play for you, that's when you bump up the difficulty from Rainstorm to Monsoon.
In my opinion, Monsoon is when the game changes from great to amazing. It goes from a fun playground of looting, shooting, and picking up fungus to a final exam on your knowledge of everything the game has to offer. You need to know what to look out for, when you need something, what enemies to focus on, and how to approach and manipulate their behaviors. This probably seems trivial and obvious to someone familiar with the genre, and it might be, but Monsoon is when the game totally just clicked for me. Enemies will start to rapidly outscale your ability to fight them, and you become increasingly reliant on movement tech and skill to avoid damage since its harder to recover health. It's really not that hard once you're used to it, hell at this point Monsoon feels like playing on Drizzle to me but it really shines a light on how good the fundamentals of each character you unlock are, and how they can interact with the game world.
Every survivor in this game feels like you're playing a totally different game in the best way possible. Simple dodge and shooters, mobile melee characters that can air combo opponents to death, dudes who build turrets like you're back in the 2fort intel room, there's a blood mage type character who leeches and spends health to do insane damage, and a giant tank with arms who swings off of pillars like Spiderman to charge up a singular punch that one shots bosses. Every character you unlock may seem simple on the surface, but underneath lies a whole host of clever techniques, good item synergies, and even variations within each character due to the addition of unlockable alternate abilities. There's always something to learn and grow from in every death, something that you could have done just a little bit better, or a different way you could have approached that encounter to have an advantage, or some way you could have made it out of a bad situation with a sliver of health left. Time pushes you forward, so you're always on to the next area, fueled by your desire to outcompete the situations you find yourself in, driven by the hope of some saving throw type item that turns your situation around, and with the size of this game's item pool, they do often come. You can get runs with bad RNG and still push through purely on skill and the tools the game gives your base character, and to me that's what makes this game special. It's a game you can totally take apart and push to the brink of its limits until your game is just enemies spawning in, instantly dying, and an endless pile of XP orbs and gold flying into you, but its also a game that can kick your ass, and it can because it knows you can always fight your way out of it.
Risk of Rain 2 is great because of it's fundamentals, and the fact that you can take those fundamentals to their absolute extremes if you know what you're doing. And hell, I didn't even mention the game modifiers, alternate gamemodes, or the DLC content, but it all just makes the game so much richer. If you have the money, please consider picking up a copy of Risk of Rain 2, I promise you won't regret it.

Risk of Rain 2 is a 3D rogue-like survival game on an unknown planet. For such a "widely acclaimed" game (15-20K daily players, nearly 150K reviews with an "Overwhelmingly Positive" score) it's [i]astonishing[/i] how the devs could've released such a half-baked buggy mess of a DLC ([b]Survivors of The Void[/b]) with only 1 tiny little patch that barely addressed anything (2 whole months in and counting).

So does [b]RoR2[/b] deserve the hype? It's a great game, sure. But instead of praising it ad nauseam, I'll just point some nitpicks... 

[hr]
Why are some Survivor alt skills so much better/worse than their counterparts? Just to name a few:

✔️ Commando's Tactical Dive is notably worse than Tactical Slide. Giving Dive something as simple as a 1s i-frame on activation would balance that.

✔️ Engineer's Carbonizer Turrets should be able to "sprint" (to proc corresponding buffs and finally offer a viable alternative to the otherwise dominant Bustling Fungus strat on Gauss Auto-Turrets).

✔️ Loader's Grapple Fist is useless compared to Spiked Fist. They need to be differentiated better to warrant a choice. Loader's Gauntlet skills are a good example of a sidegrade. The Fists are not.

✔️ Captain's Diablo Strike... what's even the point of this thing? It has no place in a game about [i]speed[/i]. Cut its drop time in half (10s), double its cooldown (80s). You can already delete most bosses in 5 secs by normal means anyway once you get going. Make Diablo Strike Great Again (!?) 

And that's just to name a few. 

Oh yeah, almost forgot. Inconsistencies and lack of clarity:

❌ Overloading Worm is not an Elite monster, so why give it the "Overloading" affix? Just rename it to "Overcharging" or something to that effect to avoid any confusion (e.g. [i]assuming items that proc off Elite monsters work on it, when they actually don't[/i]).

❌ Currently, the Burn and Ignite status effects stack on top of each other (thus appearing to be the same) while doing dmg independently (e.g. count as 2 status effects for the purposes of Death Mark). Why? Simply give Burn a separate HUD icon (a red flame instead of orange, if you like).

Yes, extremely minor. But attention is in the detail.

Same goes for Hellfire Tincture's debuff (which also counts towards Death Mark). However, this debuff (to both self and enemy) is invisible. 

❌ Captain's Defensive Microbots should be a passive skill proper (like every other Survivor) rather than an item. 

As an item, it can be lost to Scrappers, 3D Printers, and Shrines of Order. Despite this (losing Cap's signature item), Drones will still gain Microbots. Additionally, if Captain transforms to Heretic, they will keep the personal Microbot but Drones will lose them. And if any Survivor morphs to Captain via Artifact of Metamorphosis they will gain Microbots (for the remainder of the run) despite morphing into another Survivor afterwards.

Bonus points? Defensive Microbots' logbook entry [i]still[/i] can no longer be acquired as of v1.2.3 

❌ Why is Altar of Gold using the same (albeit recolored) model/render as Shrine of Chance when every other shrine is unique in design?

C'mon, Hopoo. Give Aurelionite a proper shrine.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

A lot of people would say that loading cargo is a dull job. The Loader could not disagree more.

Other jobs don’t supply their employees with a fully articulate titanium exoskeleton capable of lifting 250 tons.

Other jobs don’t allow their employees to meet the crews of countless starships from across the galaxy.

Other jobs don’t let you use your exoskeleton for your own entertainment, much less outfit it with custom-built grappling hooks powered by a winch capable of hauling up to 100 tons.

Other jobs don’t involve being approached by a legend among the UES work force, and asked to embark on a classified mission to the Uncharted Territories.

Other jobs don’t involve fighting exotic and strange alien creatures, and exploring mystical ruins on another planet.

A lot of people would say that loading cargo is a dull job. The Loader could not disagree more.

If you like rougelikes then this is perfect. Firstly, the game scales with time. At first you may not notice it but if you take too long you may be starting over. A lot of items are about proc/proc-chains. Some synergize better than others but for the most part there are no bad items except maybe a few that I think are underrated.

The characters are diverse in their abilities but there are specific roles they fill. There's alternative skill you can unlock that can drastically change how a character plays however preference should still be considered unless you want to do what is meta. Map diversity is alright (Better with DLC) and with it's official release it has a Boss instead of just being an infinite loop of the same stages. There's also a difficulty for everyone and even if you find it's hardest game mod easy there are plenty of mods that can fix that.

The DLC I felt really fleshed the game out more. Before items felt like they were lacking. Granted a lot of the items are really strong, the non-void items they added filled the main item pool fit well with some ok additions to lunar items if you choose to use them. A few more stages were added which is nice since they are quite good IMO. The characters from the DLC are pretty fun and fairly strong once you learn them and the game also brought new enemies to table as well as a 2nd final boss.

Lastly the modding scene is huge. If there something that you think should be changed or doesn't quite fit there's probably a mod for it already. Not to mention the modding community is very helpful in diagnosing problems with mods and the creators are usually quick to respond about bug report. Want mods but not sure where to start? There's a modding channel in the official RoR2 discord and people there for recommendation and the official modding discord a great place as well.

Also join the Starstorm 2(mod expansion) discord for a fun time.

One of the best roguelike games of all time, and some of the most fun I’ve had on a game. I don’t have loads of hours on this game, but I can say for certain that pretty much every hour I do have has been phenomenal. There have been very few times where I’ve gotten insanely frustrated. 

Ratings:

Soundtrack: 10/10- one of the best and most fitting soundtracks for any game ever.
Visuals: 8/10- very stylised but it works very well and the environments are beautiful 
Combat: 10/10- very very fun combat that feels very rewarding and can be very challenging
Movement: 9/10- with the help of items movement can be very very fun and always feels fluid and responsive.
Progression: it’s really fun to work towards unlocking characters and it makes the rogue like format so much more enjoyable since you have things to work towards every time. 

Overall 9.5/10

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

[h1] The Best Kind of Rain [/h1]

Never have I fallen in love with a roguelike harder than I have with Risk of Rain 2. This is my most played game on Steam, and I reckon it will stay that way for quite a long time. The gameplay loop feels satisfying, and it's gratifying to discover that you've improved since your last run. The soundtrack for this game fits beautifully, with special mentions being The Raindrop that Fell to the Sky and The Rain Formerly Known as Purple. This got me into Chris Christodoulou's other works, and I've left feeling just as emphatic as I am with ROR2's OST. 

These feelings have only been amplified with the release of the game's first DLC. I'm having a blast going through all the new content, and I'm awaiting the next expansion(s) to give me more reasons to enjoy this already near flawless game. Highly suggest getting the DLC if you enjoy this game, cannot recommend it (or this game) enough.

In roguelites you're generally meant to play around RNG. Items affect the optimal way for you to play, and you adapt to what you get on a run, or you make guesses based on what you hope will happen with future drops. ROR2 isn't like that. Item RNG is just "this item is good" or "this item is not good for this character" or "this item is always garbage". Since you have very, very little choice in what items you get, this is pretty bad. It's complicated by the fact that unlike the star of this genre, Isaac, you can't always outplay damage. A LOT of damage is completely unavoidable, including a lot of attacks that can one shot you or juggle you into 100-0 combos. The primary way you mitigate damage is by deleting enemies before they can hurt you, but spawns are wildly random and some classes are reliant on long cooldowns to deal with certain types of enemies. It's common to have absolutely nothing spawn and just be running around with nothing to do but memorize item locations so you can speedrun them later, and not uncommon to have random hordes spawn that, given the wrong rng with enemy types and modifiers, mean unavoidable death. Also, most bosses have a desperation attack that will kill you if it hits, and avoiding them can only be done by having good item RNG or in some cases good terrain and enemy pathing RNG. Even having godly items isn't always enough, since a few bosses can and will fly out of range of all attacks for certain classes and one shot you if you try to run to the teleporter.

The game also does an absolutely piss poor job of communicating things to you. I enjoy figuring things out on my own, and this game sucks for it. You basically have to use a wiki for a lot of the core things that make the game somewhat tolerable work. It's got a lot of extremely lazy design and implementation - the game will tell you exactly how every item functions in the menus, but the in-game tooltips are absolute trash and in some cases not even present. The visual language of the majority of attacks does not in any way represent how they actually work, and some of them will probably take you dozens of times dying to before you understand how divorced the mechanics are from what the game visually communicates.

The only way I can recommend this game would be if you don't enjoy the discovery aspect of roguelites, you intend to play exclusively multiplayer (I've heard there are more items which mitigates rng if you're playing diverse enough characters) and you don't mind extreme, extreme randomness, both in terms of player power and incoming damage (which is, generally speaking, not mitigated by skill but by luck).

e - I have to say, the more I play, the more I see this game as a collection of flaws that really shit on a core good concept. Almost every mechanic is either poorly implemented, has no reason to exist, or only exists as a really weak band-aid for another really bad mechanic. The game is addictive because the genre is so untouched, but in terms of game design it's an absolute trash fire and I regret giving a cent to the hacks to developed it. Shooter mechanics are inherently good and hard to fuck up really badly, but they managed to make a game that's so random that in all the time I've put in can only think of maybe 2-3 times where I felt like I made a good decision or a good play, and almost always everything that happens good or bad is 100% luck. I'm sure if you spend a lot of time studying and playing around some of the worst offenders like the scaling system you can mitigate that to some extent, but it's just not fun in any way and good systems are entertaining to learn. Good roguelites you can look at every death and learn something from it. This game you almost never have anything you can learn.

I got this game as soon as it appeared on Steam, as I loved the first game - and was disappointed. I returned to it a few months before the DLC was released, and fell in love with it. Partly due to the expansion and polish it received in the interim, and partly assessing its on its own merits.

It's a great game to get into a flow state and zone out in action. It has beautiful aesthetics, amazing audio, and subtle yet fascinating writing. And it has great networking optimization so that I can play with friends on the other side of the globe with minimal discomfort.

Moreover, it appears the devs love it and intend to extend it for the foreseeable future; so I'm just looking forward to see what's coming for the most recent addition to my favorite games of all time.

Probably the best rougelike, though I'm not a fan of rougelikes in general. Game has very good art, standard music, decent selection of characters etc.

The survivors of the void dlc/update was a highly anticipated and rare addition that this game gets, unfortunately, aside from the new void items which there's a handful of good ones, was generally sub par. The rest of the update/dlc added Railgunner who is probably the most overpowered early game, but becomes completely useless afterwards. It added a void character as well that I haven't played but have only heard negative things about. The worst part was probably the new enemies being better off out the game than in. The new gamemode it added was also pretty good on the other hand, but there are flaws it has such as the beacon going to impossible locations resulting in death no matter what. In the normal game, you can spawn inside void regions and have a huge disadvantage instantly that you can't do anything about, void enemies can also simply not appear, leaving you on 1 enemy left until you decide to just give up and teleport to the next stage.

The game in general, without friends, is not very fun. 
With friends, you can get a solid 50-70 hours of enjoyment, despite those hours, half of it might be you just doing the same thing over and over. The game needs more content still because unfortunately there is a clear meta - a small number of superior playstyles which makes thinking outside the box doomed to fail which sucks for any game and double sucks for a rougelike - luckily, this has been addressed a little in the DLC with void items, but there are only a handful of useful ones, A lot of your playthroughs will mirror the last however the argument can be made that every play through is different if you don't have command enabled, but then it becomes an RNG fest which will result in you getting one tapped by round 3 or 4 although you can still get one tapped even if you are broken overpowered - challenging the meta is not really encouraged. The game needs better scaling for long runs, if you decide to loop after defeating the round 5 boss, the game turns into either you one tap or you get one tapped.

There are a handful of boss fights in this game, however most of the bosses are braindead and too easy, and in general the boss fights are nothing impressive and could do with a rework or new bosses. The final bullet spong- bosses are kind of a chore to fight, they aren't very fun nor very challenging and they both have a phase where they can one tap you (why?), which is the only threat they will ever give.

Whilst the review seems pretty negative, in terms of rougelikes it is probably the best one I have played despite this. Its gameplay is what makes the game and makes it fun even with those downsides primarily when playing with friends. It is also polished, not having any glaring glitches outside of the DLC content. If you enjoy rougelikes then this game is probably a must have.

[i ]A hyper-speed experience that utilizes time mechanics to further enhance game play. [/i] 

That's a brief description of Risk of Rain 2 in my opinion. With randomization on item drops and many characters to choose from that have different play styles, the possibilities of what might happen when you start are limitless. 

The music composed by [u] Chris Christodoulou [/u] also encapsulates the game experience well.  With the music from the opening credits to the menu theme, to even just passive music.  It all ties together.

Seeing that Risk of Rain 2 supports multiplayer, and from what I know has a decent build for it just creates even more paths of play.  Join up with some friends, or play alone and conquer the game, whatever you want to do.

The game creates a choice in game on how to balance item gathering and teleporter usage, which encourages skill growth as eventually you learn how much is enough. An anti-loot goblin feature to say the least. 

Also a personal peeve I have with games that market infinite features infinite possibilities, often those games just end up overwhelming me and make the time unenjoyable.   Though with Risk of Rain 2, the customization is simple yet expansive.  There's so little yet so much.  It's... a nice change of pace.

The story is incorporated into the game via the opening sequence, cut scenes, logbook entries and such.  Fast enough to understand for combat junkies, lots of details for the lore fanatics.  

Truly a masterpiece I didn't expect to enter my steam library.  A welcome one for sure though.  

[b] Highly Recommend, Overwhelmingly. [/b]

this game has eaten my life more than any gacha game ever could. I spend my free hours playing this game. I spend my taken hours ignoring my responsibilities to read the ror2 wiki. I spend the hours without any technology thinking silently spiteful thoughts about how bad artificer is. 

Okay for real though this game is kind of a masterpiece in most ways. It's replayability is kind of insane which makes sense because it's entirely built in. Not only does it take multiple runs to win, there are also many different ways to win, be it beating the final boss, obliterating, true obliterating, or, if you have the DLC, true obliterating. 
There are many different ways to go about a run, depending on which survivor you chose, and you'll probably find that you have a lot of fun with at least one of them. You can play as MUL-T and hit as many times a second as possible, or play as MUL-T and try to go as fast as possible for a crazy high damage utility, you could also play as MUL-T and get high damage sniper shots, or you can play as MUL-T and get crazy proc chains. There are technically other survivors too.
One thing that I don't like as much about this game is that while it does seem like you have all the agency in the world, in reality, every run without crazy artifacts are gonna look the same past the first 15 minutes. Items are random in this game so over time each run will slowly begin to look like every other, because while you may get more of some items than others, by the time you get enough items to start to have at least half the game's content at once you realize that this is exactly the same run as the one before it. 
Some items, and more importantly some survivors, are horribly unbalanced. Things like ceramonial daggers and brilliant beheemoth can turn your runs into clicker games while items like wake of cultures can literally kill you. This wouldn't be a problem if the two item's weren't both legendaries. Artificer struggles to survive at every stage of the game while engineer struggle to die as soon as he gets a white item (bungus). 
I think that this game could use a little bit more patching and some more content to make runs actually different from each other but overall its an insanely well made game. The music is amazing, the way that damage works is just as complicated as it is genius, the way enemies spawn is a little monotenous but pretty damn smart as well. If there's one thing I can say about this game, it's "read the wiki." Not even because you have to, the game is relatively good at explaining itself. I just think you should read the wiki because it's fucking cool. 

TL;DR: well made, poorly balanced and becomes very same-y after a while, but still really really well made.

Risk of rain is the best game i have ever played in my life.
Not the best *rogue-like*, not the best *loot-a-thon*, not the best *whatever*.
THE best game, i have ever spent my time playing. 

As of writing this review i have played a mere 129 hours, but that is in the span om roughly 14 days, because this game is SO fun.
I can name countless runs where something completely busted happened, only for that same interaction needing some fine-tuning 2 stages later because of the fantastic scaling enemies have in RoR2.

I have been playing mostly with the command artifact (that's how i have the most fun, sue me) which makes me able to pick what items i get myself, allowing for endless build possibilities resulting in even more fun!

If you like roguelikes and if you like fast paced gameplay with tons of replayability, it's a no-brainer.
Otherwise just pick engineer and go afk for 5-6 minutes at a time, you shoud be good ;)

I recommend Risk of Rain 2, because I think it is a very good game.

Risk of Rain 2 is a celebration of what it means to play an action game. It draws you in, and keeps you coming back for more. For the relatively small amount of time I've had with this game, I have yet to grow tired of it. 
RoR2 is a character-based rogue-like, each character appealing to a multitude of play styles. You could sneak around enemies as Bandit, dance through the air for minutes at a time as Mercenary, sling across the map and pound a beetle in the face as Loader,  air-strike an angry floating bell with Capiain, or gun down bosses as Engineer (missed a few, they are all good dw).
RoR2 rewards every play style. You can comb through every familiar nook and cranny for crates, making sure to squeeze every bit of loot possible out of the level, or you could burst through each level, dancing past, through, and in between bosses. 
RoR2 is not afraid to let it's players become demi-gods, but will test whether or not they shall remain, or be dethroned. RoR2 is not a game that will leave you shattered after loosing your best run. 
RoR2 is a game where your shattered runs become a grafted blade the player's wield for the rest of their runs. 
RoR2 is a nonstop heart-pounding adrenaline run.
RoR2 is absolute peace of mind.
RoR2 is panic-induced chaos

But, if you asked me what Risk of Rain 2 was, I think I would call it a work of art.
Blood, sweat, and tears put into a game that, in this day and age, delivers all you could want and more without skipping so much as a heartbeat.

I recommend Risk of Rain 2, because I think it is a very good game.
Very good, very fun, take it at your own pace, just get ready and no, this is DEFINATELY not entry level gaming

Have you ever wondered what 'Apotheosis' means, or what it would even look like? This game. Right here. You boot it up, get into your first run not even on Monsoon difficulty and [b]BAM[/b] yer dead before you even hit stage 4. "Well that sucked," you think to yourself as you start up another run. The next few runs might yield much the same, you figure out what items do what and some potential combos that could work... that is, until you finally get [i]the run[/i]. 

I'm talkin about [i]the run[/i] where you so much as look in the direction of an enemy and it gets obliterated from existence.

I'm talkin about [i]the run[/i] where, in conducting death-by-disrespectfully-looking, you set off a chain reaction where you set off all the health bars on the entire map as, one by one, they deplete each one faster than the last.

I'm talkin about [i]the run[/i] where, as a consequence of all this OP bullshittery you are no longer racing against the in-game timer trying to out scale you, but instead your very computer as it tries desperately not to crash long enough for you to finish your run.

I'm talkin about [i]the run[/i] where you finally face off against the final boss and get him to his final stage, and it dawns on you that what he does next throws all your OP bullshittery back in your face, denying you the satisfaction of victory and likely pisses you off for a good ten minutes before you inevitably start another run.

For you see, when I say that this game is a textbook example of Apotheosis, I don't mean that in regard to the characters you play. I mean that [u]you, the player,[/u] ascend to godhood as you turn this game into your private playground and the enemies and items into your toys which you abuse with reckless abandon. Then, when confidence surges within you, you kick up the difficulty to Monsoon ready to take your rightfully owed Mastery Skins...

Only to get humbled by a pair of Blazing and Overloading Lesser Wisps four minutes into stage 1.

10 outta 10 would recommend this game which also happens to prove that overconfidence is, in fact, a slow and insidious killer. Plus it has an extensive modding community and multiplayer which can also be a modded experience.

I will try to be concise and direct with this review. This game is incredible if you are seeking a certain gameplay style. It takes some time to get used to, but don't be ashamed to use drizzle or rainstorm to get the hang of things. It can be punishing, but this creates this intense, authentic feeling of kill or be killed. The items combine with the character variety, creating so much replayability. The skill ceiling is high, but the random elements take enough out of your control to both make random runs become incredible, or other runs an upwards struggle.

This game shines brightest with friends. It gets very difficult, and if one player hogs items it can be a struggle. Personally, I would recommend trying 2 player co-op, then feeling out 4 player up. If you want, there are mod managers that allow you to make the game better suited to your friend group.

There is story, there is an ending, but the point of the game isn't to beat it. It's to play it. There are achievements if you feel like you need goals to strive for. Try your best to get every character to Eclipse 8 once you get good. Don't take the meta too seriously, fans tend to obsess over it. I recommend this if you want something you can hop back into. I don't recommend it if you are looking for something you want to complete, but if you want, you can always try Eclipse, RoR2's ascension system.
One of the best games ever made, although it's style might not be for everyone go ahead and give it a shot.

Risk of Rain 2 has proven to be one of the best games I've ever played in my life. For a very long time I craved for a coop game to try and live again old times when I played along with my brother and friends. Hopoo Games managed to make it possible with this absolute gem.
Gameplay and overall mechanics are well balanced and extremely fun, with plenty of items and different character abilities for you to find the play-style that suits you better.
It's also a living proof that games do not have to be ultra-realistic to look pleasing.
Chris Christodoulou has achieved an amazing work of art with his soundtrack to this game. A progressive-rockesque music that gives you the chills again and again.
The Survivors of the Void DLC didn't disappoint. Brings 2 interesting new characters and a plethora of items.
I cannot recommend this game enough.
Hall of fame. Forever.

I feel like I am really going against the grain here, but Risk of Rain 2 is, in my opinion, not nearly as good as people make it out to be. Sure, the game runs reasonably well, the music in the game is fairly good and memorable, and the graphical design is inspired, but that seems to be where my interest ends. The roguelike mechanics of the game are too punishing. For every one good run you get where you get good item drops and good RNG with the bosses you fight, there are five, ten, fifteen runs where you get horrible item drops and bad RNG. Without the right item combos, the characters feel incredibly slow and immobile. The damage output from all but the sweatiest characters is dogwater without the right items to back them up, which you rarely seem to get. Part of the fun of a roguelike comes from the fact that you enjoy losing and look forward to starting your next run, which never seemed to happen for me in Risk of Rain 2. Maybe I am not the right audience for this game, but several other roguelikes that have come out in a similar time period just play much better without the extreme lulls that Risk of Rain 2 seems to have. If you enjoyed this game, that is great, but you will probably enjoy Gunfire Reborn even more. People hold this game on a pedestal like it is this incredible genre defining game, and I really don't see that.

In a sea of roguelikes, Risk of Rain 2's gameplay loop is what you'd expect from the genre, and with that gameplay loop in mind, I initially was worried for what the co-op play would be like. As expected, it is a pretty big problem. Players able to snatch multiple items from the boss, and then not being able to trade items to the other players. I think if this game added more in the way of co-op it could shape up to be a good game, perhaps great (think reviving downed players, or being able to trade with your friends if you accidentally pick up multiples of the same item). But what you get from this game is just sort of an all over the place mess. In one of my friend's words, it's "more fun to think about than play" which I would wholeheartedly agree with. The main game up until the final boss is pretty meh, nothing spectacular happening there. 

Spoilers for final boss below.
[spoiler] The final stage though is almost legitimately unfair with it's damage-scaling, with the enemies that you encounter in the stage not even worth fighting as they are literally just damage sponges that can tank more damage than you could ever put out without killing yourself in the process. That's not even mentioning the final boss fight which is the most piss-poor excuse for a boss fight I've seen in a while. Mythrix's attacks are hard to handle, and not in a good way. So much so that if you're in the air at any given moment for one attack, you're pretty much instantly dead. This, paired along with his cringe inducing "bad boy" dialogue that's spammed and the fact that he often will just attack thin air, but when he actually manages to hit you through some bullshit makes for a frustrating, not even rewarding to complete boss. [/spoiler]

This isn't to say that I didn't enjoy the game, a third person item-collecting roguelike is a very interesting concept. But the enjoyment that I DID get out of the game is vastly overshadowed by enemies being able to one-shot you for no particular reason other than "haha you've spent 45 mins on this game already, wouldn't it be funny if we deleted all your progress?"
Until they add a reason to actually play co-op (such as, I dunno... making it so that when you get killed you have a short period to be rescued by your teammates) and/or fix the damage scaling mechanic I give this game a thumbs down, as it is just not enough fun to play for what you're doing.

Honestly the best roguelite I've ever played. It's 3D which is really cool but the best part about this game compared to other roguelites is the control you have as a player. Stages and items are still random but things like scrappers/printers, the bazaar between time and multishop terminals give you still a bit of control. Its quite the learning curve but you'll get there in no time. There are tons of cool items to find, use and combine and honestly no run is the same. There are numerous secrets and realms to find and when you've finally found them all there's endless new ways to experience the game. Different characters, different gamemodes and modifiers for your runs. Fun with friends but alone is great too.

Great game to sink some time in for a good hour and just grind your way through waves upon waves of monsters. I would say it's a bit less forgiving than most roguelike games even from the get go (I spawned on top of a fire beetle and died in just 7 seconds so that's fun lol), But you can play it on an easier difficulty if it's a bit harsh for you (I'd say if if you're struggling at stage 3 consistently maybe you'd lower it down for awhile until you're comfortable).

**EDIT: Although I forgot to mention this, I will say that Mithrix (aka the final boss) is quite the tough boss even after beating him thrice. So it's quite understandable if you did lower your difficulty because of him as he does feel unfair to fight against certain characters and certain builds after a certain point. 

The RNG can somewhat turn people away from this game as you can never guarantee a build that you like will be done in a run but I would say how you make of what you're thrown with is what adds to the fun of it (unless you loop it until you get what you want but by then your enemy isn't the mobs but your frames dropping with how many mobs that are bound to spawn by then).

There are a variety of classes to play and I will say the weakest one is the commando but ONLY if you don't know how the game works yet but all other classes are fun and unique in their style and power fantasy.

Although you can play mindlessly and just hack, slash, shoot or spit your way through the mobs, but if you're TRULY interested in really making your DPS or DEEPS go up in a variety of ways, then I truly recommend reading up on how the items work and installing these two mods through the Thunderstore Mod Manager which can help TREMENDOUSLY such as:

- BetterUI by XoXFaby
- ItemStatsMod by ontrigger

Those two are really helpful and don't really change but just improve your experience of it along the way as the item descriptions are a bit vague. 

And since we're already talking about mods, Other mods I would wholeheartedly recommend are:

- SettMod by lemonlust ( Really well thought out mod that just works beautifully aside from pummeling a few bosses! )
- Goku by kingginryov ( Takes a bit of time to get used to but it gets real good real quick, plus you got the DRIP )
- QoLChests ( Now I would've put this on the previous list but part of the challenge of RoR2 is being quick on your feet and your eyes as well, so this is more for a truly casual experience of not wanting to be paranoid if you left a chest or two behind )

I've only played the base game so I can't say anything about the expansion but I've sunk 25 hours in just playing the base version and your curiosity and theory crafting brain will be the limit to how many hours you'll sink in this amazing game!

I bounced off RoR 1 pretty hard, but the extra dimension in this game adds a lot to the experience.  You'll likely feel confused and a bit directionless for a few hours, but it'll eventually click (a few streams or tips thread will help with that too). Wholly recommended, and the DLC is super worth it too.

Personally I have found myself lately becoming very angry while I play Battle Royale games. My days used to be filled with getting home from work, starting my PC, and just being... mad... while I played video games for 3 hours in an effort to calm down. I was reaching a boiling point of dissatisfaction with a hobby which I identify myself with strongly and I began to feel dread as that identity seemed to clash with my outlook on gaming. Why was gaming, which has such a profound place in my life, which was meant to bring me the most joy, making me feel so miserable?

Enter Risk of Rain 2. A friend that I just had gotten closer with asked me if I wanted to play Apex together sometime, and I embarrassingly had to tell him that I didn't want to play a BR with him because I can get a bit toxic in the heat of the moment, and didn't want to accidentally hurt his feelings or leave him with the wrong impression. So he suggested Risk of Rain 2 and gifted it to me for us to play together. I logged 50 hours that week.

I have re-found my love for gaming in the nice long runs as the 4 time heavyweight boxing champion of the universe, Loader and in the "Peekabo I'm behind you" back stabs with Bandit.  Yes - I still get mad by some BS death to a lemurian, a lesser wisp, or those STUPID rats that joined the fray in the latest DLC, but I just get to start all over again and think of fun new builds I can try with my next attempt. Suddenly the only people in my lobby are all trying to beat down the same enemies as me, rather than trying to end my game prematurely. Suddenly I'm [b]happy[/b]. 

This game is great. The soundtrack is awesome, the gameplay is so fun, the builds are diverse, and the community is full of wonderful people. I love Risk of Rain 2, and I think you'll love it too.
Fun gameplay loop, lots of ways to customize so you don't wear yourself out, and new content still being added. This is an A+ roguelike.

If you like video games in which you murder everything as quickly as possible before they murder you, collecting a vast array of unique power ups, all while trying to "escape" a planet that progressively gets better at killing you until it either succeeds in finality or you murder a god, Risk of Rain 2 is for you. 

Simple yet stylish art style, a great cast of unique and fun characters to play and unlock, 4 player online co-op, a boat load of unique items and effects that can make runs feel different and make you feel like an invincible hell beast, and even a budding modding scene. Plus some lore that gets into that cosmic high fantasy that really needs to be explored by other games. 

It's a rougelike, but a fun one. Plus you get a Ukulele. What's not to like?

In risk of rain 2, you start out as an idiot with a gun, and over the course of 6 or more levels you continue being said idiot with a gun but now using your favorite item as a gateway drug and having so many of them that you are physically unable to live without it. The gameplay loop consists of you stealing people's amazon packages until you can find a teleporter to get you closer to the sweet release of death or some sad idiot with sibling issues. Difficulty increases with time, so you'll find yourself either doing a hectic impromptu speedrun or perishing. It's very easy to die and the game gets incredibly chaotic at later levels, so you better hope you got yourself some tougher times or you are going to violently explode the moment the difficulty reaches impossible. Luckily stacking items can get you some ridiculous benefits. Building characters can get really insane.
Build highlights include:
- WHY DOES SHE HAVE SO MUCH BARRIER WHAT EVEN
- purity go brrr
- my blood has been replaced with syringe
- bungus
This game also moves from a 9.5/10 to a 69haha/10 when you play with friends. Get a buddy or two and you will find yourselves giggling like idiots at 3am joking about REX's relationship status while you decimate anything that breathes.
also if you don't play exclusively on monsoon you are cringe >;;()

[b]Risk of Rain 2[/b] is one of those cases where the transition to [b]3D[/b] actually enhanced the experience, though not without its awkward moments as the devs have admitted when translating characters from the prior entry to this one.

But over-all it has been a solid and thoroughly enjoyable experience even solo as I tend to play most of my games that way, though of course with friends the experience is further made even more fun as you'd communicate with everyone to try and distribute items to where they need to go to be able to push further and further into your runs.

The [b]DLC[/b] that has come in has been a blast to play with the new items and characters both old and new, definitely will be looking forward to anything else the devs have got cooking up.

Though if you haven't already check out the first entry, as it is $10 as of this review, if you're curious where this game has come from and have the spare cash to splurge with. Highly recommend both!

Boom, you crash landed on an unknown planet and you're about to realize your mortality. Played every game and you think you're some Fortnite Ninja shit... huh. WELL GUESS WHAT, you're dead kiddo, you picked up this game and thought you were some hot shot, gonna play Monsoon huh. No, you piece of shit. You're about to realize fear, the kind that has you shittin blood. Here's how it'll go: First, you'll confident. Then... you'll fear... you will realize mortality and that only reason you haven't died is because you're not meant to... yet. Next, confusion "What killed me?!??!" followed by a cosmic pounding delivered by Dwayne the Rock Johnson (the guy from fortnite) himself. Lastly, tears... and godDAMN they will flow, like the dueling rivers of the Tigris and Euphrates. I'm so sorry, sweet sweet child, you weren't ready, none of us were....

One of the biggest turnoffs with Rogue-Likes for me is how they prioritize luck and mental math over actual gameplay. Very few people find that fun and even fewer find it more enjoyable than nearly any other type of game. They have their niche and I do try to enjoy them, but going to practically any other genre is a drastic improvement.
Risk of Rain 2 is one of the few examples of that not being the case, though. Almost entirely because of the artifacts (game modifiers) and diverse character selection. It plays like an actual video game which is much more than most Rogue-Likes can offer.

7/10, absolutely worth a try if you enjoy Rogue-Likes with actual gameplay.

Risk of Rain 2 is easily the perfect game for people who love the roguelike genre. It features constant action, a variety of playable characters EACH with flexibility for different types of play styles, lots of content to explore, and there's always room to learn. That being said, since the game always has room to learn there's clearly a bit of a learning curve, but not to worry because Risk of Rain 2 also has a GREAT and helpful community to help you out when you need tips or advice. Before I found this game I felt as if and was completely convinced videogames have gotten boring, but after looking for games with roguelike elements with multiplayer capabilities, I was lucky enough to come across this game and from that point on I found the feeling I had been longing for over a long time, an actual DESIRE to hop on and play, and a constant feeling of refreshment of excitement every time I play as if it was the first time I played again. So like I said before, if your looking for a game with roguelike elements and multiplayer capabilities, I recommend this game to you. This is easily a 10/10 game from me.

Great graphics, great gameplay, great game. What more might you need? To entice you to mayhaps buy this game, here are some pros and cons that I can think of from the top of my head.

Pros:
•Immense replayability. With basically every run being different, and the large selection of paths and items, not to mention the characters, it makes for a great variety; and so, a lot of replayability.

•The playable characters, survivors, have different siills you can unlock via doing challenges for them. Like how commando can get a tactical slide if you beat the first teleporter event before the timer reaches 5 minutes. 

•There are plenty of stages and hidden stages, and all of them look amazing and are all pretty unique

•Most items allow for some really fun builds, and a lot of them are unique. Will O' The Wisp detonates enemies on kill, and so on.

•Enemies are very unique, some being more difficult than others (obviously) and some being very easy to deal with. Wisps are really easy to kill but fly in the air, making them a pain for mercenary.

•Artifacts are game changing mechanics that you can apply before a run, and really change how the game is played. The artifact of command, for example, lets you choose any item of the rarity you get from something, like a chest.

Cons:
•Some items feel as though they're just there to pad out the total number of items, and aren't very unique.

•Doesn't give close to any instructions for most unlocks, requiring most things to be looked up to figure out how to unlock. You CAN always just play for an excessive amount of time to find these things, but if you want to not spend a hundred hours figuring out where the void fields are, you might want to look it up.

The sign is a subtle joke. The shop is called "Sneed's Feed & Seed", where feed and seed both end in the sound "-eed", thus rhyming with the name of the owner, Sneed. The sign says that the shop was "Formerly Chuck's", implying that the two words beginning with "F" and "S" would have ended with "-uck", rhyming with "Chuck". So, when Chuck owned the shop, it would have been called "Chuck's Fuck and Suck".

This game, like any rogue-like, is tempermental and defies any expectation of a smooth learning curve. Under most circumstances I do hate this, but running up to 200 hours, I have the secret to making this game fun in three easy steps

1. Create a public classic lobby. Enable the artifacts of honor and glass (you will have to unlock these, but the process isn't very long) and set the difficulty to Monsoon. Be sure that rules voting is disabled. Democracy is weakness.
2. Recognize that the game is no longer a PvE TPS, but a cooperative psychological horror. People WILL join without reading the rules settings of your lobby. Your role as the lobby owner is to watch them fumble and fall and cope and seethe and mald. You are a scientist with one question in mind: "Why do people presume they get to have fun in the game you purchased". Observe people disconnect after getting one-tapped by a flaming lesser wisp. Observe Acrid players not even have a chance to begin play. Try and get into the mind of what your players' goals and motivations are now that they are in a stressful environment. This is the true fun of RoR2.
3. Slowly modify variables. Is a player being just a little too persistent for your liking? Type in the chat "let's kick this up a notch" and add two artifacts of your choice. Are players taking too long grinding on the first level and you're getting bored because you already know difficulty scaling swallows the meek? Just activate the tele yourself without warning them as soon as possible. Their expectation of being allowed to play your game is putty in your hands. The most horrifying part is that there will always be new players coming in to replace those who rage quit.

I have not found myself getting so invested in a game so quickly as I have with this one. It's a bit confusing at the start if you go in blind, especially if you aren't familiar with Rogue-likes/Rogue-lites, but once you know what you're doing, you have all the freedom to experiment with so many different characters, items, artifacts, loadouts, builds, etc. 

I have yet to play a few of the characters, but of the ones I have played, they all have a unique playstyle, and it doesn't really feel like any one character completely outclasses another one in every aspect. Yes, some are obviously better than others, but IMO the difficulty, items, and characters are very well-balanced. 

One thing that I can see being an issue for some players is the amount of time you have to commit to just one single run. If you aren't playing fast, a normal run can take upwards of an hour, and if you go for some achievements, some can take even close to 2 hours. Some people just don't have that kind of time, and there is no way to pause your run, close the game, and resume it later. If you run out of time, you're forced to abandon the run, unless you want to leave the game open on the pause menu for hours until you get back.

I bought this game completely on impulse, and I can say with 100% certainty that I do not regret it, and I will probably continue to play this game for quite a long time.

Also worth noting: the DLC is 100% worth it, but if you only play with friends, only 1 person needs to have the DLC and can enable it for everyone in the room.

The story of lives. Lives ruined and lost due to the actions of two men, who did not understand the responsibility or gravity of godhood. The seeds of betrayal, unjust justice, and wicked plots. A story of normal people, thrown into the most unknown forces of gods and deities. Men, women, creatures, heretics, and glass frogs. A planet of forced creation, and wretched design. A place unmarked by space, and unheard by sentient life. A savior that imprisons, and a master of bombastic ambition. Blueprinted evil, and incomprehensible danger. Gods entwined with mortal men and women. All under the gauze of rain. The somber tone of the pitter patter of rain. A drizzle. A soft and forgiving storm, calming and welcoming. A rainstorm. A harsh, but manageable barrage of water. A monsoon. The true test of rain, powerful and unforgiving. As those immature gods danced their dance of spite, and tested each other's patience, mortals intervened. They flew their curiosity too close, and paid a gruesome price. As the soul-full savior ran ruin upon the mortal vessel, the humans lost all they had brought. Their tomes and ammo, their goat hooves and teddy bears, all lost to the great false planet. Parasitic tar, flame powered masks, beetle empires, and crabs from another plane. No one was safe, very little survived. And once that vessel fell to the earth below, there happened to be a chance of a storm. A storm of unparalleled strength and fear. A storm brewing, since the betrayal of a brother. A storm of blood, and of pain. There happened to be a risk of rain.

This game has never made me rage quit, it makes me mad to have been killed by an overloading brass contraption, but never enough to really stop playing the game. Risk of Rain is fantastic.  Risk of Rain 2 is fantastic in 3D.  Once you've mastered Risk of Rain 2 the DLC is there to reinvigorate the game and give you renewed fun.  Definitely worth your time to the tune of a few... hundred hours.

As a single player game, it's a pretty fun time. As a multiplayer game, it's awesome. I've played this a ton with my siblings as a way to keep in touch when we're several hundred miles away. Would definitely recommend if you have some time and some friends to play with. It's very fun to get a bunch of items that synergize with each other and your character. Expect to fail even on the easy mode for a little, especially if you're not used to this style of game. The DLC is also a great time! If you're playing multiplayer and one person has the DLC, everyone will be able to play with the items, so that's a nice plus.

I do have some gripes though...
- Dying to a void reaver explosion feels pretty dumb. One second you're doing just fine and then all of a sudden you're dead.
- When playing multiplayer, dying feels REALLY bad. Everyone else keeps playing the stage while you go get a coffee, and then when you move on to the next stage you're super underleveled and everyone else on your team is a little overleveled, so you usually end up just dying again. I wish there was something you could do after you died to contribute or keep leveling up, even if it was just a little thing.
- Lunar coins are an alright idea, but are a little off. I don't use them in my bad runs because I want to save them all up for when I get a really good run, but when I get a really good run I don't actually need them and so I save them for next time.

Gripes aside, I've played this game a bunch and had a great time. I definitely would buy it again.

Properly optimized. Graphically simple, but equally gorgeous. Gameplay is delicious. Replayability is endless. You'll never have the exact same playthrough twice in a row. Fun solo and fun with friends AND fun with randoms. A decent roster of playable characters and the roster has been growing gradually since release. I recommend to everyone who enjoys a good rogue-like/looter.

Easily one of the best games on Steam. This game is the EPITOME of Roguelike with mountains of content including a good selection of playable characters that all have very unique play styles and abilities (With alternate abilities you can unlock), an astronomical amount of items that have a very wide range of effects some of which will completely change the way you play a certain character, and tons of different enemies that keep you on your toes. I cannot recommend this game enough to anyone who might be interested in it. 

On top of all of this, the new DLC that just dropped expands on what this game already brings to the table by increasing items, playable characters, maps, enemies, and a boss fight. It's completely optional and if you're unsure then start with the base game. Of the 229 hours I currently have clocked only a fraction of it has been with the DLC. The replay-ability of this title, even at it's base, is far superior to anything I've come across which is something I value highly in a game.

All in all it's hard to pick anything in particular that I had issue with in this game. After the hours I've put in I never had any game breaking issues (If I did it was my own fault running swarms, sacrifice, and command loading up on 64 energy drinks) and It wasn't ever a dull moment. When you start to feel like you truly understand a character, the game throws a new random set of items your way that shows you a whole different pathway you never took that particular character down before or a new way to get completely cracked one shotting bosses with what might have previously been a mediocre ability.

I know this review was just fan girling, but I genuinely believe this game has a lot to offer and it's worth the $24.99 price tag, especially when you compare that tag to new releases such as BF2042 that released at a full AAA price. Give it shot!

I love this game, but there are some issues I don't understand gameplay wise:

Why are half of the green items so useless? Sometimes I will play a run and end up with 7 pieces of green scrap, or even worse.....get a bandolier after a boss fight. War horn gives you a speed boost when you use your equipment........ paul's goat hoof gives you a speed boost at all times, like who designed this? The porcupine gives an attack speed boost with a critical hit up to 3..........the syringe gives you a permanent attack speed boost, and this item is supposed to be lower on the hierarchy. Honestly there are so many more, Ghor's tome, lepton daisy, wax quail, rose buckler, red whip, will o wisp. Compare these to Infusion, Ukelele, missile launcher, fire/ice bands and leeching seed and they are not even close.  

Speaking of the green scrap, there are almost never any green scrap machines, I can tell because they added a regenerating green scrap as an item and I have used it three times out of twenty runs where I got it. Also when they added the new update, they didn't add any healing items. This has thrown the item balance tremendously off, where you will have almost no healing items and tons of damage items.

Otherwise, they really just need to fix the item balancing, because there will also be many runs where you don't even get a single red or yellow item. The yellow items really don't make sense, why do we not automatically receive these after every boss fight? There might be some condition to meet to get one after a boss fight, but if so that is so dumb, because it is like "Hey, you couldn't beat the boss quick enough because your items are trash, here have a war horn, that should help".

Otherwise, this game is pretty epic. They nailed the transition from 2D to 3D, and the gameplay always leaves me coming back for more which is why I have noticed these problems. For the price of the game, it is definitely worth it and the dlc. They put a lot of effort into this game and it shows, because there is a ton of content in this game. I am going to try and just create a mod honestly where I adjust the item settings, there may be one already out there. 

Overall, great game.

Overall Rating: [b]9.5/10[/b]
Gameplay: 10/10
Story: 9/10 -There's no campaign but the world setting and lore is great

[b]Notable Features[/b]
1) [b]Survival based Horde shooter[/b] like no other. Mobility and target prioritisation are key to winning. Like Hades, you [b]start each run from scratch and dying ends your run, forcing you to start from scratch[/b] which makes finishing the game at a high difficulty extremely satisfying.
2) [b]High difficulty[/b], Would not recommend playing on normal difficulty for newbies
3) A [b]variety characters and builds[/b] mean everyone can find their own play style

[b]Pros: [/b]
1) You can a choose from large number of build combinations of builds
2) Multiplayer w friends is the bomb
2) Drizzle/Easy difficulty makes learning the game more fun
3) Modding compatibility

[b]Cons:[/b]
1) The game does a bad job at explaining its mechanics.
2) Randomised item drops in normal mode are a bitch to deal with. However, that can be changed by acquiring and equipping an "Artifact of command".
3) You have to install a mod if you want to test out characters/items. A practice tool would've been great for those of us that are too lazy to install mods

This is a great game. Running around, fighting aliens, unlocking new items and characters all contribute to the fun of this game. However, I will say, there is a steep learning curve. If you have never watched someone else play the game or watched a lot of item and character guides, you may struggle at first. In the beginning, you don't even know why you died half the time. But after getting over that curve, It becomes really enjoyable. Not bloody or gory, easy to play casually, and much more fun with friends.

[h1] Risk of Rain 2 reviewed by soar [/h1] 

Risk of Rain 2 (ROR2, ROR) is a is a top-of-the-line roguelike that provides great replay-ability due to its randomly generated loot, enemy's, and map order. ROR provides a great balance of fun and challenge as you need to collect power-ups / perks to keep with the scaling difficulty. The difficulty scales as the more time is spent on each level so it keeps the player with the objective to beat the game before the difficulty gets too high while collecting perks and killing enemies. ROR is fun to play co-op and singleplayer. You unlock different characters with different attacks and movement types as you play the game.

Class/character based co-op shooter where you and up to three friends battle hordes of aliens/ghosts/demons with the help of rogue-like randomly generated loot. These items provide bonuses of all sorts (and the items show up on your character's model too, which is cool) and multiple of the same type stack, so you could end up super op or gimped based on rng. 
But you'll need these items as the game has a constantly up-ticking difficulty timer, so the longer you spend on each level, the harder the rest of the run'll be, so you have to strike a balance between looting and scooting.

I got this game close to release, when there was a BOGO sale going on. A friend gifted it to me. Back then? It was an absolutely fine game. Good for some hours, and some good fun, but not a lot of content. I come to you now, 3 years later, to happily testify that after the 1.0 patch, and now this AMAZING DLC, Risk of Rain 2 is the best roguelike I've ever played, and it's still not done getting content.

RoR 2 finds a beautiful balance between mind-numbing, "big numbers go BRRRR" game play and that stressful, high-stakes roguelike adrenaline that us masochists like. This game is HARD. I personally like to play Monsoon the most, and I am dipping my toes into the hardest challenges, Eclipse difficulty. But the beauty of Risk of Rain 2 is that you don't *have* to do that. Want to just have an arcadey monster killing, power fantasy party with your buddies? Turn on some alternate rules (Artifacts), go on an easier difficulty, and go to town. The game is a BLAST whether you are challenging yourself to git gud, or just taking a retina-destroying, explosive, flashy trip across Petrichor V, melting every enemy in sight with 30 procs on every action you take. 

Cons? There ARE a few:
- game EATS RAM for breakfast. once you get late game and there are 10 magma worms and 30 explosions a second, your processor is gonna be going to work. I'd say don't try this game without at LEAST 12 gigs, and really more like 16 if you want to do long runs. 
- multiplayer scaling is a little bad. It's perfectly fine on the easier difficulties, but if you play Monsoon or Eclipse with 3-4 people, the enemies will VASTLY outnumber and outscale you if you and your boys aren't absolutely CRACKED. 
- takes a LONG time to get all the unlocks, you'll often find yourself doing runs with the specific goal in mind of getting a really weird, niche unlock (10 crowbars? really, huntress?)

But really, that's all the cons I can think of. Seriously, just buy this game. It has something for you, whether you're a die-hard roguelike chad or a very casual player, Risk of Rain 2 has got what you're looking for.

Oh, and buy the DLC. It's the best DLC I have seen in a long time, in any genre, full stop.

I really enjoy this game. Its a lot of fun to sit down and play whenever I'm bored, and it has so much replayability that I don't think I'm ever going to grow too tired of it. The characters are very dynamic, no one character feeling too much like the other. The items synergize and work together better than any other rough like I've played. The items don't feel like just an upgrade to your character, but and upgrade to your other items. There are of course a few exeptions to this, but seemingly useless items are a part of the meta too, with the system of scrapping and printing. Over all I would suggest this game to anyone who is wanting a game that they can play as long as they want, without really ever growing tired.

One of the best roguelikes out there. It's fun whether you win or lose. It just gets annoying to unlock the alternate abilities of some characters, which are sometimes direct upgrades.

The enemies, the items, the abilities, THE POWER FANTASY!!! It's all so well made and so much fun. Some could say it has low replay value, but its the type of game to hone your skills at, because it can always get more difficult. And, if you run out of things in the base game, the modding community is such a lovely place to find ways to change things up. Honestly, when I played the game for the first time, I was shocked by how smooth the gameplay was and how fun the movement and shooting is.
