What can I say about this game that hasn't been said by someone else? The game can be a massive power trip simulator one run, and another you die to lesser wisps and lemurians two minutes into playing. Both of those examples are still fun because you're always learning something, learning what items go well together, or learning to pick your fights and what skills are best for certain situations. There's always something you can learn on each run, not just limited to player experience either. Logbook entries, new items unlocked from achievements, new survivors, new skills for survivors, new ways to alter your runs, rewards for beating the hardest difficulty, there's always something new to do. When you think that is no longer the case, the modding scene is massive for this game with even more difficulties, more survivors, more items, more stages, the list goes on. Solo is great on its own but playing with friends is the most fun and chaotic experience of the game.

Before this game I had no experience with the roguelike genre, and this has been a fantastic first experience. Every character is interesting and has a unique style of gameplay. I find myself playing all of them, I can't say I have a least-favorite. This along with the alternate skills adds tons of replayability to the game, even after 600 hours I still find the game fun and interesting, finding new ways to synergise specific items and characters. All of the enemies and bosses have fantastic designs, both from a creative and gameplay standpoint. The music is outstanding, while surprisingly calm for a run and gun, it sets the mood very well for all the environments. Unlocking all the achievements and filling out the logbook while reading the lore spread out through the game has got to be my favorite part of playing. And that's all just the singleplayer content, playing co-op with friends is great, the way the game scales with more players makes it exponentially more fun without just spamming enemies.

Roguelites are something of a comfort to me I've found as of late: Hades, Slay the Spire, Into the Breach, Dicey Dungeons, Don't Starve, Minecraft, all impressive in their own way. It's not so hard to impress within the framework either when it's mostly about finding a hook and giving you randomized powerups as the difficulty ramps up. Past that, there needs to be a goal. That goal can be "get to the end" or "just be alive" or anything in between, but you always need a reason to do either of those things.

I'd say that's where Risk of Rain kinda fails me. There are like 10 characters to unlock, and for the most part they are just shooty shooty. That means there should be something else that provides engagement.....and there isn't. Very few maps with enemies that just kinda spawn and then you shoot them as you look for some items scattered across the map. There are lots of items....but as you unlock items you are saturating the list that can randomly spawn, decreasing the likelihood that you'll get what you want. There are secrets as well, but they're extremely annoying in design to be frank. 

None of this is a dealbreaker in any way though! It's light and breezy and I feel like I'm playing one of those old flash games with my friends. It can be great fun! Absolutely. But I wouldn't pay full price, and I wouldn't expect that you're getting a game to sink your teeth into. Borderlands is a better option if you're looking for longform progression. But I'd play this multiplayer over Borderlands multiplayer.

This game is very pretty, it has some of the best music of any roguelite i've ever played, and it was fun for about the first 20 or something hours i played it. I suppose if you value those first experiences and aren't much for unlocking everything, beating the game in all its different ways etc you would find this game worth your time, but this game mechanically is one of the worst roguelites i've ever played

To start, the game is not satisfying to begin. Beginning any match on any difficulty with any of the modifiers you can add to the game is either boring or too risky/janky (i.e the artifact of glass) and rely a lot on either luck or time consuming running around an oversized map for items. You move too slow, every character besides Loader makes me feel like im forced to collect speed items first just so i can benefit from the advantages of being able to collect things fast, except i can't simply build for speed at the start as CC items and damage items are both necessary during those first few stages. None of this, however, would be that much of an issue if it weren't for one of the other largest issues with this game as a whole: the difficulty system.

The difficulty system is not well thought out. Being based on time is not a bad concept but does not work in the slow and oftentimes boring environments the game forces you to stay in, be it standing in a red bubble for a minute or so after killing the boss in a few seconds or running around aimlessly in the pregenerated over-sized maps for little chests, or enemies if you're on artifact of sacrifice. Its based a lot on luck, as no matter how much you master the maps and memorize their layouts, the chest spawns are so random its not rewarding to even learn. And if you don't pay attention at the start, you may not even know that the teleporter is found via its large red particles that surround it, causing even more slow and droning gameplay that is to your disadvantage as every single second that ticks on the timer means more pressure to become stronger or simply die.

The character balance is very poor. While its true all characters can be OP with the right items, getting to that point is based on how good your character is to begin with. Characters like Loader seem to be balanced well, they have excellent movement balanced by being forced to melee, but does high damage and has high survivability as a result. The same cannot be said for every other character. Some characters do too little damage to begin, such as engineer and Rex, some characters have very poor options for mobility, such as artificer and bandit, and some characters, like captain, have virtually nothing, and sometimes even cannot use their abilities at all in specific environments. No mobility, poor damage, and terrible, terrible alternate abilities like the abysmal "Diablo Strike" which seems more like a joke. And this poor balance persists through almost every single character. What makes this even worse is the poorly designed item system that oftentimes doesn't benefit a character for its abilites and rather just for hitting your enemy once.

The item system get very boring after the first few times you're overpowered. Items are very simple, even the more rare items can do things as simple as 100%+ crit damage or debuff resistance, and this simplicity limits creativity. After my vast hours in this game i found that more often than not what mattered wasn't building around my abilities, but rather just building specific items that allow me to eventually one shot anything regardless of class. Some characters benefit from certain items more than others of course, but in the long run of the game and for later difficulties all the characters bleed together into a mess of just one-shotting everything with stupid items that do all the work for you. Satisfying, but disappointingly limiting and boring after a while. 

In addition, i do not enjoy the system for unlocking items. I enjoy hunting for achievements, but some of the achievements are simply too based on pure luck in a game with sometimes multiple hour long sessions that it becomes very, very boring and unfun to simply get a single item or character ability. Take for instance the achievement to unlock one of the better lunar items, where you're supposed to chase a specific enemy off the ledge of a map 20 times. However, this specific enemy type does not spawn on maps with ledges until you loop once, which means you not only have to get far to start, but also have to get a map with a ledge, the enemy in question, and not TOO far or else you'll accidentally one shot the poor thing. Another example is the ability unlock achievement for Rex, in which you have to push a specific boss into a hole on a specific map. Which means you not only have to find the map, but also get the specific boss in 2 completely random out of your control scenarios, with a small asterisk on the map as there is a chance you can find it in the lunar shop area. (but again, its also out of your control if it will be there too.) I could go on about some of the stupider achievements, such as the one to kill a scavenger as acrid being unforgiving on multiplayer, or the terrible mercenary achievement to take zero damage.

Another issue i found with the game is how enemies work. Most enemies are fine, they serve as specific roles such as rank and file enemies like wisps, or more tough miniboss like enemies that provide more coins such as Parents and Elder lumerians. Where all this falls apart is in the elite system, and how damage scales as the game progresses. Its common to see people mention how even just one hit in the later stages of the game can spell complete death for your long run, and to me thats not a fun or well designed aspect of the game. I don't mind one shot mechanics in most roguelites, my favorite roguelite, synthetik, is notoriously highly difficult with powerful enemies who can kill you very quickly, but where that game succeeds and this game fails is in the amount of control you have over evading attacks and strategy. Other roguelikes, such as gungeon and synthetik, both have burst movement options and linear attacks that are simple to dodge but find their fair difficulty in forcing you to dance while also fighting the enemy, its satisfying and fun to play in this way. Risk of rain, however, has absolutely zero concept of "dodging" attacks. Yes, you can build to run fast, and yes, you can use your movement abilities (based on class. some classes simply don't have movement abilities.) to try and evade attacks. However, some attacks, such as the wisp blast or the stone golem laser blast have unnecessarily unforgiving speed and tracking, causing you to sometimes build around getting hit to begin with. Instead of using your skill to weave through the enemies, or using movement abilities that may give you immunity frames (with a single exception), the game opts for items such as Tougher Times which give you a random chance to resist attacks, which essentially forces a boring campy playstyle to avoid getting completely one shot in later stages or even early stages against specific bosses elite enemies. And to elaborate on elite enemies, you can oftentimes find yourself in later stages getting killed in an instant by malachite enemies or freezing enemies. None of this is skill based design, its almost completely random and out of your control which makes this game feel like a roulette wheel oftentimes, even WITH items such as the 57 leaf clover.

All in all, risk of rain 2 captivated me enough to get almost all of the achievements, but after the first magical 20-30 hours i found nothing but a boring game loop with unfun mechanics out of your control. And yes, this is all AFTER the dlc, which has fixed none of my issues. I want this game to succeed, its probably the first 3D roguelite this big with this much potential, but all i can see in this game is limiting gameplay and poor mechanics.

[h1] Why am I reviewing this game? [/h1]

Over 13 years of personal experience with games in various genres and sizes, this is the best game I have ever experienced. 

[b] What is this game all about? [/b]

Risk of Rain 2 boils down to a simple system, spawn, kill various monsters, acquire loot and survive as long as you can. While having cartoony graphics, the game still manages to revel in it, making use of every last mesh. However, due to the game being endless, scaling with stages and time, it can be easy or a full sweat to survive if the RNG is not in your favour. The game also gives the player a choice on the difficulty of the run, like drizzle (the easiest), rainstorm (normal) and monsoon (the hardest, if not including eclipse, which I will bring up later).  Furthermore, it is one of the most replayable games released to date, giving the player many possibilities with customizing your survivor in different means, learning about the lore and reasoning behind the events of the game. Additionally, you can try other gamemodes, like Prismatic Trials - pretty much the speedrun mode of ROR2, where players compete in a specific seed, which will be set for a specific amount of time. There is also Eclipse, the hardest version of the game, where after every successful run the game gets progressively harder from the first stage to the eighth. It is also possible to unlock artifacts, which can spice the game up quite a lot, for example, you can add an artifact to the run, which allows you to control the items that the player most desires (god run simulator) or make the enemies spawn with half the HP, but double the spawn-rate. Personally, I enjoy the main gamemode with Monsoon difficulty and 0 modifiers.

[b] The survivors, items, events and more. [/b]

Risk of Rain 2 has a total of 12 survivors or playable characters and one of them being a secret one. In my opinion, the amount and specialties of these survivors are quite extensive, covering many playstyles and possibilities for every player. For example, you can play the huntress, an agile marks(wo)man, whose kit makes her almost impossible to catch off-guard while blowing out huge DPS. In the beginning, the player has only one of the survivors – commando. He is easy to play and suitable for the first run. Other survivors can be unlocked by just playing the game. The items of this game have been divided between 6 categories – common (white/gray), uncommon (green), legendary (red), lunar (blue), equipment (orange) and boss (yellow). All of those items can be acquired from chests, item printers, item stores, shrines or the „mystery box“. However, equipment and lunar items can be acquired only from respective containers or and shrines. Furthermore, items are pretty much the only powerspikes the player can get and almost all of them STACK, making some combinations above OP. But if the items can turn you into a god, then how can you die? In the later stages it is possible, to get one-shot from certain enemies. Yes you read that right, your 30min run can end with a ONESHOT. In total, there are 55 different enemies in ROR2 – WOW. Additionally, some of them spawn with buffs, ranging from a basic shield to walking flamethrowers or invisibilty fields. Oh yeah, bosses, right...eeeeeh. In the first stages of the run, it is quite rare to meet a „boss monster“ even on monsoon. Usually the player has to defeat the enemy when initiating the teleporter event, which will spawn the boss or bosses of the stage. After the event, the player can advance to the next stage and all of the excess gold will be consumed and turned into XP.  There are also 4 extra events/portals/stages, which can be activated in different means.

[b] THE AUDIO AND SOUNDTRACK [/b]

Yes, they do deserve a whole article. The audio design and soundtrack are a masterpiece, I would have never thought that it would stick with me this hard. The soundtrack was composed by Chris Christodoulou an [i] „award-pending composer from Greece“ (Spotify) [/i]. The soundtrack includes 24 tracks, four of them being bonus content for supporters, who buy the actual soundtrack. I highly suggest playing this game and taking a moment to truly experience the audio. Last bit on the audio – the best feeling in this game can be experienced when killing a horde of enemies in quick succession.

[b] Final word [/b]

I highly suggest playing this game, it is an experience that everyone should be able to enjoy. The concept, gameplay and audio put together is phenomenal and, when I said that it is the best game I have ever played, I truly mean it. The game was developed BY AN INDIE STUDIO FOR GOODNESS SAKE, even outdoing massive AAA studios. 10/10


[b] The DLC [/b]

If you liked the base game, then definitely check out the SOTV DLC, it adds so many things to the game, while costing almost nothing compared to other big company DLC’s or other additions.

A unique experience and breath of fresh air in the stale, boring game meta. Very rarely does a game just decide to let you become an arbiter of death, much less break every conventional function of the core game design. A choose your own adventure game disguised as a roguelike shooter. An episode of Hoarders where storing gasoline strapped to your thigh lets you instantly kill entire swarms of enemies. A game where the high of an invincible build is crushed by the low of an enemy you thought you were ready for. I could (and might) type more into this later.

Yes this game is very good.
 Of all my time in game, personalty, I have little to nothing as far as issues with game play, optimization, or over all design.
 
The game has quite a few items, abilities and characters to permanently unlock as you play, none of which require unreasonable amounts of grinding or luck, but are challenging all the same. 98% of unlockables in game can be done just by playing solo, any difficulty.

The ability to stack items infinitely is fantastic because is gives to so many synergy's and strategy's to try and make the perfect build each run. Between the items, the enemies and the area's to explore, there is a lot of substance to this game, without having an overwhelming amount of mechanics and things to learn like some MMOs.

The devs are supporting the game well with fixes when needed. For an inde dev, Hopoo Games have a good grasp of how to keep in touch with the community and improve the game all together.

Having the option of multiple profiles in the menu meant my nephew could have his own game to play through. That way he could start with 0 unlocks and work his way up from the start. I Appreciate that as an option Hopoo games!

Been playing arcade/pc/console games since the 1970's.  This is one of my all-time favorites.  Look at my playtime, over 1,000 hours.
Risk of Rain 2 hits many things I like right on the head.  It's an action roguelike, but is non-action player friendly.  Control is easy to learn, tight and lag free on modest PC's.  Once you become familiar with the zones, the game becomes challenging since you are trying to get randomly placed powerups in the most time efficient way while the mobs are getting more powerful.  Selecting those powerups to figure out the most powerful combination for the current playthrough is a blast.  Graphics and music fit the dark sf mood perfectly.  The story is vague in a fun way.  I enjoy reading the descriptions of the zones and items.

My thanks to the Devs for the many hours of fun I have had playing this game.  Can't recommend highly enough.
My brother got it for me and now I can't stop playing

7/10 
Solid little game with some nice music. Rogue-ish in nature with an addictive loop. 

Downsides would be that it is a little slow to start with a bit of an RNG curve that can make it feel punishing at times. Often it will feel like you've wasted to much time just running around looking for items and not doing the far more enjoyable task of killing mobs. Also it seems that depending on what you are trying to achieve there are only a handful of really decent items and combinations in the game and if you go outside of those combos you are basically wasting your time. This is unfortunate given the large variety of items in the game. 

That being said I would 100% recommend the game. Easy to get into harder to master. you'll definitely find yourself sitting down for a single play through and instead burn 5 hours.

This is the best roguelike game on the market, in my opinion. The atmosphere this game projects is 100%. The first thing you'll really notice about Risk of Rain 2 is that you have no idea what the heck you're doing. There's no tutorial, and very few choices you can make at first launch. Gradually you start to learn this world and unlock new faceless survivors and items - as well as getting further and further each run, and that's when you think... 'Wait, is someone talking to me or is that the music?'  Then you spend the next 5 minutes completely zoned out and trying to decipher the lyrics to a song that might not even have any; dodging feral beasts and blasting them with a sliding shot combo. You realize just how well this game was constructed and admire how far you're getting even though it's only your second run. You come across a giant jellyfish and tackle it head on with the utmost confidence that he will fall like the remains of those before him. The music is crazy right now. There's screeching noises and explosions everywhere! You almost have him defeated, just a couple more shots! Then, 'Wait... what? How did I die?'

Back to the drawing board, only this time with someone else. Hours of fun to be had with this game. When you start getting bored there's also a multiplayer mode. Friends make this game way more fun. There's also a massive modding community with easy instructions and hours of additional content to mess around with. Completely recommend to any roguelike bullet hell fan.

This game.
What is this game?

It is a piece of art with a clear philosophy in mind. 
Ignore its core idea and it will be a terrible slog. Frustrating, enraging, demoralising.

Embrace it and it suddenly turns into the ultimate power fantasy, become Death incarnate and cut through hordes of enemies like a hot knife on butter, until you get to defeat God himself (sort of).

I hardly write any reviews at all, but I HAD to after getting the expansion.

PRO:
+ Music rocks. Chris keeps making a wonderful job at portraying a coherent picture of an alien world
+ Extremely intuitive game design
+ Goofy. This game doesn't take itself too seriously
+ Surprisingly deep lore, but only if you choose to look for it
+ Creative items system
+ Rich modding community

CON:
- Some mods could easily have been in-game options (BetterUI)
- Not so easy to get up to speed with how the game wants to be played, hints are there but they're subtle and you may learn to read them after a few hours of gameplay
- Core loop can get a bit repetitive if you're not the type of player who's in it for wild experimentation via weird items combinations
- I liked the first game's way of unlocking artefacts slightly more, although having to find clues in different maps is without a doubt a brilliant touch and really helps with world building

tl;dr
Get this piece of art and give some love to Hopoo. You're in for a great time!

Truly a game really fun.

The game really managed to transfer the core idea of the first game into the 3D world really well, it built upon the idea and improved it, the game feels more lively in many ways, the characters have more emotion, the graphics look vibrant and lively as well, the gameplay feels just right, both in Keyboard+Mouse and Controller. 

Yes, the game is hard at first, because, as the first game, it involves a lot of trial and error if you are new. However, once you get the hang of it, you start to realize what characters you actually prefer, what items are best suited for the character you chosed, what's the best way to go through this map, or the most preferable way to defeat certain monsters, and yet, even if you managed to beat the game, you still want to come back, because there's still a lot to explore, even for a 1-hour adventure.

And, from the new features of this game, we can say that it also now officially features 16-player coop, dedicated servers, new gamemodes, new characters, even more items, and even more. Not to mention that this game is still being updated. This might sound like a bold claim, but i really think this game has surpassed the first game, by a lot. 

So yeah, i really had a lot of fun with this game, i really enjoyed every second of it, so if you really are into 3d roguelikes, either to play it by yourself or with friends, you should definitely try this one, you'll love it.
i dont know how i got here

This is a damn fun game; borderlands and destiny without the fluff - even it doesn’t have the greatest introduction for new players (the starting class is dull and getting new ones can be very grindy). 

It’s a solid action rouge light with a strong visual style; an engaging game-play loop and endlessly repayable. I love its vintage toy-like aesthetic; this lore light Saturday morning cartoon vibe works well in the games design. 

The co-op is a mixed bag, but not bad. When all 4 players are playing different classes; tearing through the hordes its fantastic; however, there are some mechanics that encourage bad behaviour, like the lack of player to player revives mid-level and the loot system allowing player to hog all the good loot. Also, the community has a consistent problem with rage quitters, so many full games empty out real fast.

Overall; A good time in solo, and a sometimes amazing time in co-op.

-I've been playing this game since day one of Early Access, going through all of the amazing content patches and now (At the writing of this review) the survivors of the void DLC. Everything in this package is extremely worth it. 

-The strive to complete the extremely hard challenges and doing fun impossible god builds is always fun and laid back. From simply getting to the 3rd stage to killing an overloading worm with the commando, it's always a thrill of a time.

-It's multiplayer as well, a big highlighted feature of this game. I have some problems with it, but it's a great time still with some funny moments bound to happen.

-There are some tiny gripes with solo play as well, like how for prismatic trials the text STILL hasn't updated to at least remove the "no reward for now" text, since that's been there from day one. Minor glitches that is bound to happen when the game edges you to break and crash it if you feel like it, and very tiny things that may be specific to certain users. But, their official discord is always an amazing help for any troubleshooting, and they constantly take feedback into patches as well as fun additions to maybe weak items, like bleed and burn.

-From the small lore, to the amazing music, to the pretty atmosphere, the game was an instant buy from me when I first saw that alpha trailer, and I'm happy to see how far it's come to be one of my all time favorite games, probably ever.

(Small potential buying tip: Buy the base game first, if you like it, buy the dlc after. Buying both the dlc and the base game might be overwhelming if you haven't poured as many hours as others have.)

The game's got a lot of modes and a crapload of unlockables. Mod compatible and the mods are plentiful and awesome. New expansion adds a ton to the game and its complexity, along with a new final boss(that I haven't beaten yet). 

The main downside of the game is that the default game mode is FILLED TO THE BRIM with RNG, to the point where you could be playing damn near perfectly and just lose because you didn't get the correct items.

If you're good with tons of RNG, and you like hundreds of hours of lovingly made content, lore, and fanmade mods, you'll love Risk of Rain 2. I certainly do.

Risk of Rain 2 is a Sci-Fi Action Rogue-lite, with a side genre of 3rd-person shooter. This game had me confused, and almost made me give it a negative review. I'll get into why in just a bit, but I ultimately decided that my own feelings about the game were a little biased, and decided a positive recommendation was more fair to Hopoo Games.

I'll start by listing pros and cons (cons isn't a large list, but I feel pretty strongly about the major drawback of this game).

 [h1] [u] Pros: [/u] [/h1] 
+ Your choice of class, called a Survivor, determines how you play the game. All survivors are extremely unique, and there is a class for everyone. Each survivor also has customizable abilities, which you unlock by completing specific challenges with each survivor. Survivors also have excellent artistic design.

+ Enemies are well designed and their attacks are very clearly telegraphed. Once again, the quirky designs of enemies lends to the overall artistic design of RoR2 in a very positive way.

+ Levels are very well built, with plenty of secrets to help make consistent runs more possible. For example, [spoiler] in the fourth stage, there is always a legendary item available to collect. Look for the well-hidden legendary chest, or for a hidden boss fight [/spoiler].

+ Unlocking items is very rewarding, even if the items themselves have some pretty extreme power gaps. Challenge completion is handily listed in your logbook, so you always know the conditions for completing the challenge.

+ Pretty cool lore, which is uncovered by collecting logbook entries. Take your time uncovering the pieces, or just look up a lore video. Either way, I found the lore to be very interesting despite not finding sci-fi as immersive as fantasy. 

+ The soundtrack is absolutely GOD-TIER. Chris Christodoulou has poured his soul into the soundtrack, and it shows. "The Rain Formerly Known as Purple" has ruined several runs because of how much time I waste on stage 5 just to listen to that song on repeat.

[h1] [u] Middling: [/u] [/h1] 
+ Item power gaps leave a bad taste in your mouth if your RNG is bad. RNG is a basic part of Rogue-lites, sure, but finding 4 Bison steaks, 2 Bustling Fungus, and 3 medkits across the first three stages is pretty rough. This game could benefit from a quick restart option in the Esc. menu.
 
+ The way items interact is very convoluted, and results in only one kind of build being super viable. Look up explanations on Proc Chains for more information, but the basics are that items with on-hit effects can activate other items with different on-hit effects, and this activation can chain if you have multiple on hit effects. Items with on-hit damage effects are pretty much the only viable items for runs. Everything else is supposed to be icing on the cake. Just pray to not get screwed by RNG.

+ Artificial Time limits on stages. The timer counts up, rather than down, encouraging you to play fast since difficulty scales upwards with time. Some people enjoy having the pressure to play quickly and efficiently, but for others it could be a deal breaker. I don't like it or hate it, just part of the game.

[h1] [u] Cons: [/u] [/h1]
- Probably the biggest issue I have with this game is that it's not primarily a Rogue-lite. [b]This game is first and foremost a Bullet Hell with rogue-lite elements.[/b] It took me a lot of time and frustration to realize this, and this is the reason I almost gave this game a negative review. Bullet hells are not fun for me, and this almost ruined my experience. Taking damage is extremely punishing the longer you play, and it is VERY difficult to avoid taking damage. I kept getting more and more frustrated, without realizing why. Without the bullet hell realization, I most certainly would have given this game a negative review. No matter how much I played, I couldn't deal with certain enemies melting me due to how difficult they were to dodge. Optimizing my play by going through previous stages faster helped, but I can't beat the final boss on normal difficulty. It really frustrates me, because this game has so many strengths that I want to like it, but it's also extremely hard for me.

This game is great and I like it a lot, but you'll probably find yourself extremely frustrated if you don't like bullet hell as a genre. Solid 7/10 game.

This game was gifted to me randomly by a friend, who I still thank inside constantly and simply can't believe the luck I had in being the one receiving it.
Risk of Rain 2 is a relatively simple game. You spawn. You loot. You die. Repeat. I would call it easy to learn, but hard to master, and let me tell you it's gameplay loop is one of the most chaotic things ever.
Enemies will constantly spawn, each kill granting you money. With that money you open crates/chests that give you items, which i'm pretty sure at this point you can get an infinite amount of in your "inventory", but I haven't gotten enough in my play time to actually discern that. They give you cool stats, and the instant you die, most times that death being your own fault, you lose all of them. You start over, and there ya go, you try to get as far as possible. 
There is a final boss, but you won't reach it very quickly. Not in your first runs that's for sure, you'll be too busy dying constantly... But reaching that final boss? And more importantly beating it? That will feel very very good. In fact, most of this game is incredibly rewarding. Everything is unlocked by playing the game and getting achievements, and the character selection is very diverse and with luck not a single one of them is useless. Though there are a few... Inherently bad characters, they quickly turn very useful if you can get the right items.
This game has never really felt unfair until the much later difficulties, which, the more you survive, the harder it gets, as it usually is in these games.
All in all, I think Risk of Rain 2 is a must play. It's a comprehensive chaos that's very very fun. And if you can get friends to join you? You might never leave.

I've played this game for very few hours on Steam, but I'm over the 100 hour mark on Nintendo Switch. This game is incredibly fun, and I'll recommend it to anyone who doesn't hate 3rd-person shooters. 
This applies to very few games, but the more you play RoR2, the more fun it gets (as long as you enjoy it in the first place). You start off with an basic character and then Huntress too, and your first few runs will be you learning the controls and the enemy patterns of the ever-present life around you. Once you start getting farther and learning more and unlocking new items and characters, the game opens up to a massive scale. The fluidity of combat and the item scaling and interactions has great depth, and fine-tuning your game play is fun when the game around it is so blood-pumping and fun.
The entire asthetic is amazing too. The simple colors help to guide understanding, and under such a nice looking game is a mound of deep lore hidden in item descriptions and such. While it can be frustrating at times, RoR2 is a very fun game. It has a nice fanbase (though some characters are... valued more than others), great mechanics and lore, amazing multiplayer compatibility, and is one of the best and most replayable games I spend my time on.

Risk of Rain 2 is a lot like Borderlands 2, minus the tedious dedication to grinding for the best loot possible in this game. I make this comparison in the most positive sense, as BL2 is one of my favorite games of all time for how different and wacky the game is.
RoR2 is the first I'm hearing about the series, and already this game is hard to drop when you get into it. It's a bit off-putting to die the first few times and feeling as if the game isn't meant for you, but give it time and practice and you'll soon want to put in three-hour Easy difficulty sessions for the fun of it. The other difficulties offer their own sense of challenge and accomplishment, though I'd rather not mentally tax myself from the higher difficulties as much. Easy mode is the most fun difficulty not just because it is the easiest difficulty and lowest learning curve to master, but due to the fact that new players can experience most of the gameplay and mechanics in a single Easy-difficulty session. A playground to try out new things, or just reuse the same options that are tried and true for you, it doesn't really matter.
Regarding RoR2's unlocks and achievements, there's quite a lot going for it. Unlocks can be as simple as a new weapon choice for your character to mix up the type of gameplay you might stick with, or a whole new character with a wholly-different approach to combat. There's a lot of experimenting to what you want to try in this game, and sometimes you're rewarded for it with an achievement. In your early hours of gameplay, you'll probably come across a lot of achievements for the more menial tasks in the game which serve as a goal post for your progression on improving yourself. I think the achievements are smart in a sense that it requires you to research and experiment new mechanics whenever you can, which is great for replay value (you don't have to experiment at all either; been a Commando player since hour 1 of gameplay and I simply cannot drop this character for anything else).
Back on the Borderlands 2 comparison; both RoR2 and BL2 heavily reward the player with severe rushes of dopamine when you simply haul ass and kick ass in the most satisfying ways possible. On a great equipment load out on BL2, you'll see yourself racking up kill counts that make you feel like an unstoppable killing machine. In RoR2, you'll eventually find yourself in a great position with a lot of overpowered items that greatly increase your odds of survival and heightened sense of God status in a world of oppressive enemies. Both games also have a distinct art style that plays to this style very well, and it makes spotting certain objects and enemies relatively easy given the right circumstances (low brightness monitor warriors will have a tough time with this game). And ultimately, both of these are similar for the fact that they cater to a player's desire to be the most efficient killing machine with a great reward at the end of the killing mayhem that ensued.
Regarding music and sound; I don't play this game with the music on as I simply wish to listen to my own choice of music (3 hr playlist of Gran Turismo music; highly inappropriate for a game as fast-paced and frenzied as this one). The sound design is very intuitive, however, and you'll eventually be relying on sound to figure out what exactly is around you. It's pretty addicting getting to hear the sound of your weapons, not sure how to put that into words however. You'll just have to experience it to believe it.
I've experienced the DLC through a friend, and it's very fun with the new additions of items and stages and bosses. Clearly there's more opportunities to completely overwhelm enemies in a much more unfair manner, which is awesome to see. And this game is so much more enjoyable with friends, given you have any on Steam (if you don't, sorry about that). If you have additional teammates to join forces with, you should definitely play together on the main game.
And all of this review is just from the main gamemode; there are alternative modes that I'm too lazy to try. For a $25 retail price and a $15 DLC add on, I definitely say this game is well worth the value proposition in comparison to the replay-value that comes from it. A solid game recommendation even at full price. Give it a go, if you have the money.

I have 1500 HOURS played. I know this game. 

Before the "Survivors of the Void" DLC/Game Update, this game was fun.  Now, it's super-lagged.

Honest Performance Review :

I have a I7-11 with a 3090 RTX , my multiplayer partner has a I7-11 with a 3080.  We play across the internet, both in Texas, USA.  32 MB RAM each.

For the longest time, my buddy and I have played this game to the extreme, on voice, with Engi and Huntress.  We coordinate items to maximize and we use a mod that expands level cap. We've gotten as high as level 40,000.

In the past, before the DLC, we would scrap MASKS to cut down on possible lag issues. but really that was all we had to cut down on.  Lag was an issue until both of us had 3xxx series cards - and made sure that his 3080 had a motherboard with the full PCI v4 capacity (his 3080 with v3 lagged)

With the DLC, we're experiencing HUGE lag now, mostly once we get to the "160-ish" levels.  The main issue (besides code) seems to be all the flying projectiles added to the game, with the biggest offender being the "ICBM" missles.   With the turrents, I fire out hundreds of missles constantly and they hang in air and seek - that's a huge massive lagfest.  We scrap them to try to help.

Lots of people say the game is 'harder', but actually, with coordinated play it's much, much easier.  You ramped up the enemies, but you also really ramped up the total number of items, making us super-beast.  This exponential increase also massively creates far more game calculating/processing and thus, "lag", even with "beast PC's" like ours.  

Some of the new monsters, when they spawn in, are creating far more lag - one being XI Construct, whom is the KING of the lag-creating.  

I don't know how you fix all this, unless but you have to find a way to 'simplify' or dumb-down the math calculating. If you don't have a crazy-good PC like I do, and aren't blessed with a buddy on voice comms that's dedicated to working with you on item pickups for builds - I don't know how you play this game enjoyable with all the chaos and new lag.

The green scrap cube (a green scrap that re-generates each level) is super OP, but the executive card, which allows us to buy ALL the items from multi-shops *and* allows us to get 4-items per level from the drop-ships (2+2) as there are 2 of us playing - and we get a ton of reds this way - is super over-powered.  It's now a total item-fiesta of epic proportions.

This game could be fun in 10 years maybe when GPU/CPU hardware increases enough - but as of today, you've really over-done it code-wise.

So I played a lot of this game and after doing most of the content, I feel like I can finally review this monster of a game.

First off, let's adress the elephant in the room. 

[h1] Yeah, you should buy this game IF YOU ENJOY ROGUE-LIKES. [/h1]

This game offers so much for so little.  The content is amazing and the recent DLC added even [b] MORE [/b] of the good stuff. So yeah, go ahead.

But if you want to know [b] WHY [/b] I think you should buy it, here are the talking points.

[h1] THE MOST IMPORTANT PART OF ANY ROGUE-LIKE, REPLAYABILITY. [/h1]

This game has one of the most satisfying run/loop systems I have seen. Basically, when you complete a certain action [i] (an achievement, if you will) [/i] you will unlock some kind of new content. This is literally anything, ranging from new items available in the next run, a new modifier that can be aplied to the next run (drastically changing the game), a new character or a new alternative ability for a character. This makes every run feel very rewarding, regardles how you play at the start, you will always feel like you achieved something new and are learning. This is really hard to pull of in a game where you play from the scratch every time you start over, but it just works.

[h1] NEXT, THE CORE, THE JUICE, THE GAMEPLAY [/h1]

It never got stale. After around 150 hours, all I can say is I keep getting amazed by certain interactions with items and abilities. There are certain synergies that works extremely well with certain characters, and not so much with others, making itemization very important and makes you think on the move. Ofcourse, there are some items and equipments that are good for every occasion [i] (I'm looking at you, 57 leaf clover) [/i] these are usually pretty rare and hard to get on demand, making you think and create your strategy on the go. Each survivor has a unique playstyle and/or a mechanic that makes him stand out. But most importantly, it is just so fun to play. On the later stages, the game pretty much turns into a bullethell of doom, making you eighter the boss of this stage, or a poor critter that is about to get stepped on by an [b] Overloading Scavanger [/b]. No matter how you like to play, there is a playstyle for you that you can use and character to play that you will enjoy.

[h1] THE VISUALS [/h1]

Risk of Rain 2 is a nice game with a nice stylistic choice. That being said, this game is not made to make you awe at the sight of a stage [i] (don't get me wrong, it could, and probably will at certain maps) [/i] but to make you shit your pants from the sight of the challenge ahead. So it is pretty, but don't expect anything game changing. By the way, the simple art style is really great, because it helps the game run smoothly for as long as possible. 

[h1] DA MUSIC [/h1]

I [i] really [/i] like the music. Each map has it's special theme and I have to say, the first time I got to the final stage, I had to stop to listen to the whole song. There are tones for every situation and they change often. Are you just arriving to a stage? Most of the time, the music is slower and more relaxed. Charging a teleporter? Prepear for brutal version of the theme you listened to before, cranked into [u] overdrive [/u]. I feel as all of the tracks on the soundtrack hit the mark, because I can't think of a theme I didn't like. 

[h1] FINAL VERDICT [/h1]

I fell in love with this game. I really loved playing it before, after doing enough playing the base game, I played modded [i] (which I highly recommend, the modding community is really amazing and talented) [/i] and when that wasn't enough, a new DLC dropped and changed the whole game for me once again. It's a gift that keeps on giving no matter if you played 15 hours or 150. You always find new and interesting things, you can always try a new combinations and with challenges and modifiers, you are encouraged to play differently each time to get the most out of your time. It feels extremely fresh to find a rogue-like that doesn't feel repetetive for me, even after so much time played. 

I am looking forward to many more hours that I will spend playing the game and enjoying my time with it, as should you.

Awesome game! Super addictive and perfect roguelike experience.

The game is good. But it absolutely needs work.

I think enemies would benefit from some changes, especially fire-elites. 
They are far too powerful and absolutely annihilate you. 

I also don't agree that the game is "immensely replayable." Initially, finding items and learning how to combine them is very interesting and fun. It was very cool to discover their effects, and not simply how they function in combat but how they alter the run. Much to my disappointment however, I found that items are ... surprisingly very little. Perhaps because of how many you can acquire in a single run. I noticed that the game actually has you UNLOCK new items instead, which in my opinion is not really a good idea. I genuinely grew bored and did not feel motivated at all to unlock new items per run, after beating the game once. On that subject, I also do not like the requirements for unlocking new characters. This is more than likely personal nitpicking, but I'm still going to say it - unlocking new characters is EXTREMELY boring after you get the ones that are a bit easier to get. I'm not saying make them all available immediately, of course. I just think some of their requirements are a CHORE. 

(Reach level 50 in Simulacrum just to die from existing and not even knowing how I died. I know WHAT killed me, but the game makes it extremely hard to figure out HOW AND WHY.) 

In addition, it often feels very cheaply designed with gimmicky and unfun boss mechanics. You can do everything right, but due to the character you picked (i.e. Engineer) you'll get absolutely obliterated later on in Sky Meadows when you have to fight a Grandparent boss and their shitty nova ability, which for a character like engineer is often impossible to dodge. I've heard arguments that the game emphasizes movement in order to stay alive, but I'd honestly say it emphasizes being incredibly lucky more than anything. One could argue the fault lies in myself, but I'm of strong opinion that the game can just do much better. 

As of right now, dying is -extremely- dissatisfying in this game. I know that TIME is important, because the more of it you waste, the more powerful the enemies become, but I think enemies and boss encounters can be deadly not because they suddenly instantly kill you <REGARDLESS> of your build and even response time, but perhaps because new mechanics are introduced. Another problem I have is that sometimes it's not even the timer of the difficulty. It's just, again, very cheap gimmicks from enemies or bosses. I know balancing and game-design is complicated, but this is currently my opinion on the matter. I find it really disheartening to get instagibbed out of nowhere despite staying on my toes, being focused and having done relatively well up until That One Mob reaches enlightenment and kills my stupid ass through what I can only assume is sudden nuclear fusion.

The characters and their designs are nice and interesting, however. A very sci-fi look. The designs themselves aren't grandstanding in anyway, but they are good enough to be memorable. I think it would be cool for the characters to have access to more abilities, rather than simply four. It would spice things up. I also admit that I very much enjoyed getting new characters because it FINALLY broke up the moldy, stale feeling of dying on Commando or Huntress for the millionth time despite doing as well as I could (though I could always do better) and having nothing to show for it.  

I will revisit this review in the future, but for now I think I'll leave it as this.

The music is beautiful. There's passion in it. I also revisited Risk of Rain 1's soundtrack, which is just as good. Check it out.

This games has a bit of everything to keep fans of the genre happy. If you like using what is essentially cheats for easy wins, just chuck on artifact of command. The multiplayer is fun and the game is seemingly endlessly replay-able, with alternative game modes if you become bored of the base gameplay, as well as a rewarding progression system with skins for mastery of characters and new abilities to allow for each survivor to meet your own playstyle.
Overall i would recommend this game to anyone who is interested in a difficult challenge, and the rogue-lite genre!

this studio have made their original 2013 game to the next stage. From 2D to 3D and with a flawless execution ! it is now a masterpice. mark my words !
FIGHT ! LOOT ! RUN ! JUMP ! they are all coming for you !!! keep on moving along with this uniques and inspiring yet stranges soundtracks.
if you doesn't keep up the game will DESTROY YOU ! BREAK the game before it happen !!!

a shooting game ... it's beter when you shot ! just like that game called DOOM (which i love) Risk of rain 2 know that all too well and i love it : there is no manual reload and you have infinite ammo ! you are always in control !
and there is no loading screen in the game except at launch :D !!! you can start a game in 4 clic BAM ! PLAY NOW have fun that's what you wanted !

many ennemy types works like chess pieces they are all differents, have differents abilities and you will have to prioritize your target with your smart and quick decisions. You think while you fight and so you are engaged in the loop from start to finish.

almost every item looted have passive effects leaving you focus on the movement or the fight wile still feeling your power increasing with various effects. You can become a godlike killing machine and yet somehow the game will find a way to kill you at a moment. It would be your fault ! you were in control and you made a bad decision at some point leaving you to your death.

this game is not bound by logic or realism ! it's a barrier to the fun stuff.

go for it !

Strongly recommend for anyone looking for a fun, open-ended challenge. While this game is light on story, it's infinitely re-playable and hides LOTS of secrets. If you want to feel like a god, play this.

Developers truly understand how to scale difficulty with reward and ramping player skill. From a development perspective, this game is wonderfully conceived. It's light on graphics preventing crashing under heavy load (trust me, there will be lost of baddies!). The state of flow you achieve while playing this game is remarkable.

This game offers so many features it's hard to break them all down:
- great, varied roster of characters/survivors
- tons of unlockables (survivors, items, artefacts, log entries, etc.)
- various modes to match your skill level or desired run-time
- customizable gameplay via unlockable artefacts and alternate survivor loadouts (skills and abilities)
- concise campaign with adjustable difficulty
- space newt (you'll have to play to find out)
- IT'S COOP MULTIPLAYER!
Just sheer stupid fun. If you like not stop enemies and insane boss fights then this game ticks all those boxes.

The two I had trouble with were the grind and the story. It's a rogue like with randomness out the ass so you're supposed to play forever and never have the exact same experience twice. More so if you're going for challenges. The story isn't straight up told to you as much as it's hidden in the log book section of the main menu. You piece it together yourself to figure it out.

Sometimes I forget just how long a run has gotten. It does take a few runs to finally understand what object does what thing and how to use them properly.... even if that means to avoid them. This game is not easy. This game will steal the day from you. This game will have you enthralled and searching for new ends. This is an amazing game with lots to work towards, and plenty of challenges along the way. Even after acquiring everything there is to acquire and doing all the things to do, there is still a game to play and enjoy. You can make a run as easy or as challenging as you want, and that alone makes this game amazing. If you are looking for a new game that you want to put your money's worth into, this is a game you should bookmark for sure. The new DLC has a lot to offer and COMPLETELY changes some of the things that were originally lacking. Gotta love RoR2.

Having many different characters to choose from gives you a wide range of possibilities. Some characters are really fun long range shooters while others are melee, tank style, or others. Anyone could find a good choice. Would recommend playing with someone when you have the chance, because it makes it much more fun and prolongs the actual runs you're doing. So many items. So so many items to collect, and you'll probably go a while without seeing some items you were hoping for. Overall really fun, great for friends and a good challenge with three different starting difficulties.

I would give it a middle choice if one available.  I love me some first person shooters.  red dead, gto, borderlands....played them all all the way thru,  This one just didn't grab me.  I don't like being rushed thru a level or monsters get harder.   I don't like never clearing a level so I can explore. 15 dollar dlc ruined the game. Now instead of dying to malachites in the first maybe second loop if your rng is poor, you get to die in stage 4 with a good run due to newly buffed burn mechanics and a horrifically balanced Collapse debuff that can be inflicted by any void mob, with the only counter to it being either a legendary item that protects you from debuffs or an active item that only has use if you want to clear debuffs. Thanks Hopoo! 

All in all, Risk of Rain 2 is a phenomenal game with very very little problems. But the fact of the matter is that Survivors of The Void is a paid expansion that makes the game significantly less fun to play, even with all the super cool items. Despite my praise and unconditional love for Risk of Rain 2, i wouldn't recommend it in it's current state. Hopefully they fix a lot of the awful, awful content in this DLC.

Real disappointment.

Risk of Rain 2 manages to be really fun without sacrificing the true Roguelike ideal. 

The formula here is very different from any game ever played. It is better experienced than explained. There are a lot of hidden secrets in this game. Better avoid online guides, everything will eventually be revealed in-game.

There are tons of unique characters who all play very differently. There are varied build options for each character. This game has several different systems to circumvent possibly bad RNG runs. 

This game implements a unique idea of increasing difficulty as one plays. However it does offer a easy start for new players. Strongly recommended for anyone looking for good multiplayer vibes and adrenaline rushing combat.

+ great artstyle, it's not like it's in 4k ultra HD or something but it 'gets the point across' if you catch my drift. bright colors to compliment the distinct environments in the game
+ characters (13+1 hidden as of writing) are all very visually appealing and each have their own style. each of them have their own unique kits as well that changes the way you play
+ there are a few alternate game modes as well: prismatic trials (seeded stage every 3 days), eclipse (harder base game) and simulacrum (wave defense) to spice it up should you get tired of the regular game
+ good multiplayer experience too. i personally play this game solo, but in multiplayer, you will have to communicate and distribute the items accordingly, which creates another layer of depth to the gameplay

do note though:
- im not sure how they manage it but 2 years later and the UI still doesn't tell you the values that some items have lol. it got better with this dlc (energy drink finally tells you how much faster you are going instead of just saying "sprint faster"), but a lot of them items still gives very vague descriptions, not to mention the fact that when you hover over an item, it simply tells you the name of it, and you HAVE to pick it up to find out what they do. yeah you could say "just remember what they do lol" but new players don't have that luxury yeah? 
- on the topic of items, i know i said each playable characters have unique kits that separates them from each other, but the fact is once you learn what items are good, you tend to lean towards picking them up during your runs. and the items that are good are pretty much universally good on everyone (crits and bleeds, for example), this combines with players subconsciously picking up 'good items' leads to most runs feeling same-y, and the character you are currently playing are just bearers of all the goodies you pick up, so who you're playing kinda doesn't matter
- items again! a huge amount of your mid-late game damage are carried by your items, which means that the only time you actually would be utilizing your character's kit is during the early game grind, especially on monsoon
- final bosses (both main and alt) are absolutely tedious to get to. commencement and void locus are just unfun and worst of all you do the same thing on both maps, it's just such a chore and kills any motivation to go to those maps ever, and i find myself choosing to rather loop and then obliterate to end the run
- this isn't gameplay related, but devs decided that for their big dlc launch they will... not give us a patch note? "its too big to have a patch note" ??? brotherman that's precisely why you SHOULD have a patch note? 

i still had a great time, and it is still an amazing game despite my gripes. however, the flaws are very glaring and once i noticed them it does diminish my enjoyment ever so little. i would recommened it, because the time you spend on this game is most likely going to be very enjoyable. experiment with builds, die some times (it's fine) and maybe do it with some homies too.

If you ain't playing this game on the hardest difficulty, punching a hole in your moniter every time your 2 hour run is ended by a oneshotting hit-scan laser, you just aren't playing the game right.

Incredible game.

Risk of Rain 2 is an amazing experience for players who like games such as: Binding of Isaac, Minecraft, and the newly created hit Steam game, Muck!

RoR2 is a perfect roguelike game with stunning combat and lore that runs deep into the iceberg. Risk of Rain 2 uses classes and items, similar to League of Legends in which there are many possible combinations for when your fighting black goo encased in ceramic, holding your own against crab space police, crushing the attackers that rise from the earth itself, or triumphing over a literal god as the final boss (a recurring theme in the Risk of Rain series).

Although this game is a masterpiece, like other games it has its flaws. Some people may want a story mode rather than the main roguelike aspect, others seek extra customisation for the limited designs we have now, and some may wish for more content overall.

Whatever you see Risk of Rain 2 as, there is always something available for every type of player, speedrunner, completionist, and just general people looking for something fun. And with the recent release of the Survivors of the Void DLC, who knows what the future of this game will hold.

I loved this game a lot. The challenge it gave me made me want to get the mastery skin for every class, so I did, and I'm proud of myself for getting them.
I recommend playing Risk of Rain 2 Vanilla, but I also recommend not bothering with the DLC.
As if the game wasn't challenging enough, the void stacking damage from monsters is absolutely soul-crushing to the point of where I wish I could ask for my money back.
I get a deep itch to play one of my favorite games of all time, boot up the game, choose a character, and when I get to the 3-4th level, I bump into void monster that, if I'm not butt-clenchingly focused and avoid every single attack, I get one shot and my run is over, and all of that time is wasted.
The DLC character's have to be played in the DLC. You can't even bring them to vanilla to just enjoy them without the excessive ass-reaming.
And finally, the DLC character you have to unlock has poor character design. There were so many times on so many runs where the character turned red and got all angry, and it actually did less damage with the items I was running with. That kamahamaha beam isn't very long, so it's either run for my life and wait until the character cools off, or risk getting one shot and waste the limited time I have to enjoy games period.
The DLC left me so disappointed. I guess I'll just pretend the DLC doesn't exist when I get a craving to play it.

barely even had the chance to fully explore this game and I'm hooked! Take the physics of Halo/Destiny, mash it up with the sleek, almost minimalist style of Star Fox, or Portal (for you young'uns); mix in some of the coolest-ass sci fi ambiance and concept art, from say the comic book series PROPHET, as well as creature features from Starship Troopers, Aliens, for that matter MUTANT (an 80's B movie gem, ripping off the Aliens franchise), and the near bullet-hell of a title like ENTER THE GUNGEON or NUCLEAR THRONE; yet keeping the hack n' slash dynamics of Path of Exile or Hades, and you've got Risk of Rain 2!!! This game puts every ounce of meaning into the idiom 'run and gun' as you'll be running, jumping, and dodging A LOT, whilst going gangbusters on your guns, regardless of class; ie more long range or melee. It's not easy at first; but after two or three runs, you'll have the hang of it. And then you won't be able to stop!
This game's combat feels so rewarding when you get really good at your favorite character!
If fun were to be put into a game, this would be it. so much thought and polish to the game and the new DLC is so much fun.
Smooth animations, not many glitches, and an enjoyable gameplay loop make this game great.

I purchased this game at roughly 3 pm on Sat and by Sun afternoon I had over 16 hours played. This game is extremely entertaining; simply game to play, NOT an easy game. 
Fun, frustratingly exciting... As soon as you die, you've started the next game and are adapting the strategy.
you shoot things then you die

Core combat just isn't all that interesting. And the ultimate goal of the game seems to be "make the rest of the game a cake walk" by "abusing" designed systems. Not really my jam.

Balance felt non-existent. Either I was stomping or I was getting stomped. Very little in-between (where I find Fun). Even within the co-op group, keeping things relatively equal is left up to you and your cohort. In one of the few runs I did, one player did 80x the damage of the other players. It felt like I wasn't accomplishing much throughout the run, which the final screen confirmed in spades. I may as well have not even been there. Extremely unsatisfying.

AFAICT, the fun of the game is in trying out new whack builds that let you just melt everything (until something one-shots you in a fashion you did not know was possible. Which is SUPER fun...). But the game does very little to ensure this ends up being a fun or equal experience for everyone in the party. Instead it is a continuous mad-dash to loot for the loot goblins, and an utterly underwhelming experience if you aren't doing that (or can't, because you ended up under-powered earlier in the run, while trying to figure out what the blazes was going on).

Oh and once you're out of a round, you're just out of that round. You get to sit there and, idk, do dishes or something. While the rest of your cohort finishes the round and you fall further behind on the power curve.

I'm sure this could be fun under the right conditions, and when we stumbled into a relatively-balanced run, it was halfway enjoyable (though I still did not much enjoy the combat). But the ease with which you fall into wild co-op imbalance, or the Alpha Gamer Problem, (and about half the other design choices) make this game firmly in the Not For Me category.
Getting to funny mode and being strong enough to survive makes you feel like you own all the pizza chains in the world.

Risk of Rain is one of the few rogue likes that I really enjoy. Risk of Rain 2 somehow improved on the original game 10 fold while going from 2d game to a 3d game in a shift that somehow just works so well and feels so natural. There are so many options and play styles per character, and unlocking certain runes which changes the random item drops to a selection whenever you get a new one makes for a game that instead of random runs you can make specific builds. It's a pretty easy learning curve and even if you die a lot before reaching the boss, it's still a fun game. The music is amazing, the atmospheres are incredible, and multiplayer is a chaotic blast on later stages. Wonderful game that I will surely be coming back to for a long time.

To be honest. I love the game and ill keep playing it from  time to time. But some of the hard caps they have put on items while adding three new enemies with instant kill abilities is rediculous. Corruption should have a direct downside instead of just throwing hard limits on the player.

Got these new enemies? INCORPORATE THEM INTO A BALANCE SYSTEM. Instead of putting fucking seatbelts on your RNG based rouglike, make it so the more corrupted items you have the more likely it is that a new enemy may spawn with the waves of regular monsters.I can move so fast that i cant see sometimes but you are gonna cap my deployables or make it so i cant have more allies because i happened to have a good rng roll once every 10 runs.

Put a limit on printers maybe. Make a punishment system for corruption using the new enemies. Make it so being corrupted maybe conflicts with lunar items. Make corruption raise the difficulty scaling. JUST DONT FUCKING HARD CAP ME WHEN YOU DONT REALLY HARD CAP THE ENEMY.

Tougher times is a fantastic example of good balancing. The more you get, the less effective they are individually. Thats good balancing in this kind of game. Like god damn Captain cant even use the corrupted fusion cells! And when i get the overgrown item for that new pylon enemy, or the queens gland. They just stop functioning if i have enough bots.

My pc should be the limiter there, computer cant handle it? Well that lag will get me murdered, shoulda ended the run while you could! I choose to take on all those items and ive never been angry when dying to the lag of the game because every single time i cause the lag by pushing well balanced items and mechanics to their limits for a god run. And even when im godlike, ill accidentally run into a void bubble on occasion cause im moving so fast. Or my framerate drops and one of the new enemies manages to snipe me while im stuck because I CHOSE to keep the run going even though i knew my pc would stutter. Oh well start a new run!

Dont hold me back. It's a rouglike. If the next update also has these hard restraints on items because they dont want to do smarter balancing like they do for the happiest mask or tougher times, im just gonna stop playing and paying.

Edit: I have uninstalled the game. I know i talked about having the lag of too many enemies is a balancer. But when five guppis dying simultaneously is enough to start making a new computer with a 30 series card amonst other things chug, you know its abysmal. 
New blind pests hit way too hard, while shooting very fast and having more health and speed than wisps.
I didn't catch the name of them, but the sheep things that hop around are also insanely fast. Making it a frustrating experience at the very least to play as many characters.
No patch notes on how they have changed existing gameplay elements, leading to unknown changes in burn duration. Fire takes roughly 30 seconds to go out at the minimum. Also Days after release and still no patch for the guarenteed legendary items "glitch" from rusty chests. The reasons i put glitch in quotations is that with how blind pests and the Xi defense systems function, its almost a necessity to cheese this "broken mechanic" to actually have a run that doesnt make you angry.
Corrupted parasites are incredibly small, fairly tanky considering their size and speed, and they glitch into terrain making them impossible to kill to remove the corruption seed.
I paid for this and now i wish i didn't. Not until they fix issues, make corruption items ALL functional and viable to at least a minimal extent on ALL characters, and rebalance the new enemies so they arent hitting harder than half of the bosses do at much faster firing and movement speeds.

Risk of Rain 2 is a fun bullet hell with baubles that can make you OP or trash, luck of the draw I guess. It's a game where you need to sit down and concentrate for at least an hour. I find myself enjoying the game with friends but it's way easier to become OP with items in single player. 

Overall it's a fun game to sit down and play for a few hours while figuring things out for yourself. Shoot stuff. Pickup items. Kills stuff. Repeat.

Presentation 4.5/5: It doesn't have high production values or the most creative artwork, but the game is visually pleasing, colorful, fluid, and appropriate for the fast pace of the game as well as its genre. What makes it stand out however is the outstanding prog-rock style background music that is just so so fitting to the game aesthetic and I can't explain why. Just listen in spotify or youtube the progression of the song  'The Raindrop that Fell to the Sky'.

Story N/A? 1/2? It has some readable lore but just like many games of this genre, there is not much of a story and it is hardly needed. The game makes no sense if you attempt to understand it.

Gameplay 4.5/5: This game is extremely satisfying to play with fast character progression, short game length, but high randomness in aforementioned character progression (not to mention various characters with different playstyles to choose from). You build your character through items you receive and each game session is different. The gameplay is also of a very fast pace and the sensory input can get a bit overwhelming after half an hour or so just to warn you. It doesn't help that the game doesn't have a saving feature (baffling!) but a mod 'propersave' fixes that without removing the perma-death necessity of the genre. I'll take a half point off for the game having some serious balancing issues like bullet sponges that just won't die, being one-shot, being absolutely overpowered sometimes as well. That imbalance can be part of the fun, but I think they went waaay too far,
Good game, a lot of replayability and lots of ways to play where it can fit what you like

The key is incredibly simple. A stone crescent, with little discernable detail to the naked eye. But if one looks closer, with a sight beyond sight, they may notice the patterns inscribed on the key’s being. The patterns tell many things:

The key’s function: to unlock a lost trove of abandoned treasure.

The key’s creators: two brothers, one composed of ambition and the other compassion.

The key’s hopes: infused into the key, deep within its core, is a memory of better times, and the hope that one day, perhaps things could be better again.

The key’s reality: the bitter realization that such a reality exists only in the past.

Amazing game. Since most of the positive things have been already said about risk of rain 2 i want to note on something i have about this game for being quite unfriendly to newer players.

I think the game could use [b] at least[/b] a tutorial of some sort for newer players. When i told my friends to buy this game and in their first run I wanted to test how much would they know on what to do and they were really clueless other than the 'Charge the teleporter" objective at the top right. No indication on how to buy items or if they even need to buy items at all. 

Secondly is proper item descriptions. Im surprised this one hasn't been implemented into the game (or at least, properly). New players kind of just have to look at an item and guess if its good or not. While i get the whole concept of having new players be curious on what an item does, it would be a lot better for them to see when they hover over an item, a short sentence with a few words explaining the item. It would be a lot more user friendly. 

Also having the option to see what is the current percentage value from your stacked item. An example is the tougher times. It would be nice to have the in-game itself tell you how much block chance you have from getting a tougher time and when you get 5 or 6 more, the value updates and tells you your block chance for having multiple tougher times since its a hyperbolic type stack. (Meaning that the more you stack it, the less the items pickup value becomes less so lets say at first its 13% chance to block, then the next stack pickup is 10.1% chance to block, leading to a 23.1% chance to block instead of 26% chance). 

 But even the linear type stacked items could use it as well like sticky bombs. Sure you can count how much 7 stacks of stickies do since its linear but its a lot more user friendly to have the game to tell you automatically. 

These issues can be solved by reading the logbooks or wiki, searching up youtube guides, overtime experience, or downloading the mod that does all this UI stuff already but for new players im pretty sure they would want to play the game and not go through all this.

The game is great the steam reviews says itself. But the new player experience is terrible

Risk of Rain 2 is a fantastic game. The gameplay loop keeps things interesting with each run being different in that you will find different items and on subsequent levels past the first may be sent to different areas. Additionally, there are plenty of things to unlock and you can play at different difficulties to keep things challenging as you get better at the game. Overall a very fun and interesting game that I would highly recommend.

A funny story about the game. I bought the game for 2 reasons. It reminded me, and still reminds me of the webtoon Room of Swords. And a former friend played it.
Funilly enough, buying this game sort of directly led to me losing the vast majority of my friends. My former friend who convinced me to buy it invited me into his group of friends who played it and it was fun playing it with them at first. Eventually I invited them all into my group of friends and not everyone got along. Another person joined the first group then into the second. This new person started doing things. 8 months later they reveal they had been lying about a key piece of information the entire time which really creeped me and many other people out. a month later they were banned from my group and things spiraled. Most of my friends didn't see any issues with things they did and they left but others were grateful that she was gone having been very uncomfortable with what she was doing.
Life goes on, people come and go, if someone does something that makes you uncomfortable you don't have to let them be around you. Sometimes other people won't see issue and won't respect what makes you uncomfortable, Sometimes people won't like or respect you, but you get to choose if they get to be directly around you.

Anyway, Risk of Rain 2 is a pretty cool game and I recommend you check it out! It's highly unlikely it will lead to you losing any friends!

I don't think I could recommend this game enough to equate the amount it truly deserves. A friend of mine got me into this game and It's absolutely addicting, probably within my top 5 favorite games at this time. It has several qualities that a great roguelite game has:

 - Solid controls
 - Versatile difficulties to tailor to a multitude of players
 - Large selection of items to make every run unique and enable various strategies
 - Modifiers to affect the runs in crazy ways
 - Unlockables to entice multiple playthroughs and find every secret or complete each achievement
 - Diverse characters to play as that each have their own playstyle
 - Absolute replayability; it never feels like a run gets old.
 - Killer soundtrack
 - Stability; I've never had this game crash on vanilla, no matter how much crazy stuff I do.
 - Solid multiplayer experience; easy to set up, easy to join, and is reliable. I've never had any major MP issues thus far.
 - Modding capabilities, already full of amazing stuff on the workshop.

There's not really anything I can say bad about this game. The only minor quirks I have with it already have mods that address those concerns. The new DLC that came out just adds even more to the game, expanding the gaming experience so much more.

11/10, absolutely recommend. Even if you aren't big on roguelites, I would still recommend it.
