Fun mindless pew pew with friends.  Good music, variety of characters and unique enemies.  

But remember droning away to relax is good once in a while but don't drone away your entire life away my fellow gamers.

Good things:
Near endless replayability with procedurally generated maps, unique enemies, and a banger soundtrack.  Game devs knew what they were doing when they made this game a multiplayer experience and the new dlc is shared with the lobby(new expansion characters excluded). This game goes on sale relatively often and there is a modding community as well for that huntress booty.

Bad things: 
The matchmaking online is a little funky with a few random lag spikes here and there(not sure if this is still the same after the new update). Private matches have yet to have this problem for me. People tend to leave a lot mid run since games can average around a few hours if you're good at the game. The other mode is pretty meh but no one really plays them too much so it kinda is there for a bonus. The most fun is when you're playing with friends. I think 2 is the best number to have in a lobby but that is just my opinion. Now this isn't a bad thing necessarily but you're limited to having the "maximum amount of fun" when playing alone. If you don't have many friends who have gaming computers it will be tough to play past a few stages. This segways into the last problem, relatively hard game to run. It isn't the hardest but the game is loaded with enemies, especially when you get farther into a run with more effects coming off of elite enemies and your items. 

Don't let this large negative section convince you of not buying this game. It is mostly small issues and rants about minor gamemodes that don't affect this experience much. The main negative is not being able to play with friends with bad computers and many games have this roadblock. This game is definitely at least a 9/10 roguelike for me.
Enjoyable combat that teaches new players there is no success without suffering.
One moment you can be overconfident and shredding every enemy you come across, the next you might be staring at the defeat screen after a scavenger hits you with a preon.

Great environment and music. Lots of characters and the item list is really expansive, which can be daunting but also really interesting. Survivors of the Void adds a fun wave based game mode that reminds me of playing cod zombies. 

There are some glitches in the new modes but other than that it runs great and doesn't need high specs.

Its a shit game with terrible platforming and none of the innovations that made this level of platforming tolerable in recent years, (ie MANTLING so you don't bump your shins or head on platforms or edges you are trying to climb up. )

Your first few hours will be spent on a forest cliffside fighting to open a teleporter. The game forcefeeds you the concept of breathing but nothing actually useful like every tutorial post 2013 and certainly punishes you for exploring and taking your time by spamming ever increasing numbers of bullet sponges within the first 5-10 minutes of any run. There's also no indication of said teleporter and you have to figure it out since it spawns in a random location every time.

Timers are not fun and You will fall off cliffs and die a lot early on trying to get to the teleporter and should you manage to locate and pay the fee for the teleporter, you will have to survive a timer countdown. There's no indication of this, but if you step far enough away, you will have to do the timer countdown to turn the teleporter on all over again while being swarmed with bullet sponge OP enemies that make COD exo-zombies look like slugs.

Did I mention that timers are not fun?

I have spent many hours in this game and have enjoyed every moment of it. Each of the characters in the game have a unique feel, and there are a wide range to fill out many different playstyles. Hopoo Games are continually updating and improving the gameplay experience. The developers have an awesome relationship with the community and will ask the community to vote on which survivors they want added to the game. I would define it as the gold standard for a game companies' relationship their fanbase. Each of the characters in the game have a unique feel, and there are a wide range to fill out many different playstyles. I have never had such a great experience with a game developer, and would praise them more if I could.

This game is my absolute favorite. The skill ceiling is absolutely enormous. I have over 100 hours in this game and while yes, I do have all of the achievements, that's purely because I spent most of them specifically completing the requirements for each and every one of them. This leads me into one of the most important parts if this game, it's fun no matter what. Relaxing with friends playing on Drizzle, FUN! Going hard on a Monsoon run solo, trying your best to get those mastery skins, FUN! There is no part of this game that isn't wonderfully spectacular. I know people who have over a thousand hours on this game, and are STILL playing daily, enjoying this game. Even once you get all the base challenges done, there is still the entire logbook to fill out. Every time you kill an enemy there is a chance that it will drop a logbook entry. There are also entries hidden on every map for that map, and if you get an item that you haven't gotten yet, you get an entry as well. Even just grinding entries is fun. This is honestly the best game I've ever played, and I think everyone should try it, no matter what types of games they enjoy.

TLDR: 
Base game: 8/10. Priced well. Definitely buy if its on sale.
DLC: Tad unbalanced and overpriced. 6.5/10. Wait for sale, or buy if you really like the base game. 

Lots of good. Music, character design, level design, and player freedom are where this game shines best. You can play this game in many ways, from god-mode where the game looks more like a powerpoint presentation, to a troll your friends with friendly-fire, to an extreme challenge. 

I have a few complaints. My biggest is that I can't see how item stacking effects each item during a run, without opening the wiki and looking. A smaller complaint is a lack of pausing in multiplayer matches. After an hour and a half of a run, my fingers start to get sore and I need to stand and stretch. I can pause in a single-player run, so why not a multiplayer run?

Overall 8/10. Priced fairly well. 

DLC

As of today March 5th, the DLC is a bit unbalanced and a tad overpriced considering the amount of content you get. I imagine that the devs will sort that out with time however. The DLC itself is overall well done. It expands upon some features in the base game and creates entirely new ways to play the game.

*Rushed out a console port during early access, putting an end to hotfixes and smaller patches between large ones
*Incredibly shitty item pool with way more bad items than good
*Scrappers are just a bandaid fix to the shitty item pool
*All survivors play and build the same mid-late game, there is no unique identity between characters past the beginning of a run
*Every single main boss follows the same formula of powering up at low health
*Mithrix is an awfully designed final boss that punishes the player(s) for playing the game well, with Hopoo doubling down on its design in the face of criticism
*Unique artifact unlock requirements replaced with the same generic challenge for all of them, AKA more laziness
*Half of the artifacts aren't fun or engaging to use anyway
*Game is play-tested on Drizzle
*One-Shot Protection is another bandaid fix that doesn't even work most of the time
*Elite enemies, particularly malachites and celestines, eventually turn into damage sponges regardless of how built you are
*Locales in general feel empty and featureless when compared to the first game
*Randomly nerfing survivors and items unnecessarily
*Putting a pricetag on future content updates, despite the game still looking and feeling like an Early Access game
*Void field has become nothing more than an afterthought, it's only use is for acrid, going there for items is never worth it due to how difficulty scaling works
*Eclipse is a waste, modifiers aren't fun, not even seeded
*Some survivors STILL missing alt ability unlocks that were planned since the start
*Good chunk of the items in the PAID DLC are lifted from mods, Railgunner is basically the Sniper mod under a different coat of paint
*Fire and new collapse debuff were made OP against players to promote a self-insert red item
*Devs too lazy and incompetent to keep up with patch notes so they just stopped

Just buy Deep Rock Galactic instead

This was gifted to me. I've played some rogue-likes and rogue-lites; I do find them fun, overall. But this one? There are countless questionable design choices that all work together to give the impression that the devs do not want their game to be fun at all.

First, communication; there is minimal. Almost all important statistics are obscured, items are not given names or descriptions in places it would actually be nice to read them. Mechanics have no explanations or indications, and must be discovered only through trial, error, and chance.

Visual clarity is also lacking, with barely an indication of when damage is taken, and no indication at all from the direction of its source. Enemy projectiles have small models but large hitboxes and move at speeds too high to dodge or maneuver around. On top of all that, unless you make the decision to remove the (useless) damage numbers, your screen quickly becomes obscured by a sea of pointless digits.

Continuing from note about enemy projectiles, some attacks are effectively hitscan, leaving one to wonder what the purpose of playing a squishy character would even be, when mobility is clearly not an effective defense. And offense proves dismal as well, with enemies all being overloaded health-sponges. There is no sense of any attempt at balance whatsoever. 

When every single enemy hits harder than you, moves faster than you, is guaranteed to hit you, and is a chore to take down; when the game refuses to tell you what anything is or does until after the fact and it's too late; when you can't even tell what is happening for all the clutter in your face; when amidst all that is the fun supposed to happen?

Risk Of Rain 2 is a odd game for me. I never liked Third-Person games nor Multiplayer. I never liked games were you have to loot constantly to be powerful or games were its soundtracks weren't incredibly fast-paced either, but this game... this game caught my attention. 
When I first saw the gameplay, I thought the game was bad because of all the reasons above. One day, however, an old friend started playing it and I had money to spare, so I thought "Why not? I have a couple bucks to spare, so why not give it a try?" and bought it on 2020's Winter Sale, where I played for a bit, gave up, played a bit more, had my first "godrun" on Drizzle [a.k.a. Easy] difficulty, played about 20 minutes when I was bored during all this time and that was it. Fast forward almost 2 years, I was bored and alone at home, a bit stressed and anxious and, ironically, it was raining outside. I was scrolling towards my library until I stared a couple seconds the icon of Risk Of Rain 2. I installed it once again and I said "Fuck it." and started playing. I loved every second of it. The soundtrack was amazing, every time i looted a chest i felt powerful and it was so amazing see the boss' HP bar melt...
This game is truly a masterpiece, and if you're willing to buy it, go ahead and give it a try. The devs did an amazing job and so did Chris Christodoulou with the soundtrack. This game is challenging yet fun; repetitive, but each run has a new surprise, a new enjoyment, a new frustration and, most importantly, each run has the amazing feeling of success once you either kill the final boss or get to the next stage during a loop.
If you enjoy this amazing game just like I did, give the DLC a try. It's as amazing as the base game.

Ror2, ah yes, the game you play until everything on screen blows up at the same time and crashes the game.. Super fun especially when you start off and don't have much of an idea what items do.. Rogue like game where you run around killing things, get items then become stronger. Game on its' own is fun especially with friends to chillax and goof around without taking anything seriously! Game on its' own is fantastic, now the DLC I have a few problems with but still overall good stuff.

Now the DLC introduces 2 new survivors and a good amount of maps/items. The items seem nice but nothing insanely crazy (I was personally expecting a ton of new items with new mechanisms and was somewhat dissapointed).. Now the characters are cool, the railgunner class seems to be a class that isn't for everyone but if you enjoy snipping and doing heavy boss damage then it's very fun to play.. the void fiend dissapointed me as I feel it has some rather annoying mechanics.. For instance the meter for your corruption goes down as you heal which I heavily think is dumb as you try to make yourself Not die you kind of negate the entire point of his character.. this seems to be a problem and for one I personally hope to see changed.. also another thing worth mentioning is I wish it also was toggle to change into corrupted mode rather than automatic because this seems to be very lethal most of the time which is horrible..

Otherwise, for all those who read through my long review, in conclusion to this:

The game itself is fantastic, very fun, and super enjoyable/replay-able as you can create many diverse builds to destroy all those enemies, but the DLC seems to need a little improvement!
Its a direct upgrade from Risk of Rain.

TL;DR: It's a good game, just buy it.

As you can see, I've put 13 hours into this rogue-lite indie title. There are many like it in the genre, but none of them do it as well as Risk of Rain 2 does it. And to be honest, I think that's the average time that your typical casual gamer will put into this game. And you know what? I'm gonna say it.

That's perfectly okay.

This game doesn't demand you to commit 20 hours a week just to keep up with all of its content on top of your overly filled 40 hour work week. Imagine going to college, taking care of kids/pets/family, hanging out with friends, going shopping, or just spending time doing things that come up in every day life, and then needing to dump 20 hours a week into a video game just to consume all of its content.

Yes, I love playing video games. I've dumped 1,300 hours into Final Fantasy XIV. I've played the Destiny franchise for over 2,200 hours because I'm a Bungie fanboy. Halo 3 was my first online gaming experience and it was awesome. I've loved Call of Duty since CoD 3 and I actually thought CoD: Ghosts was pretty good and didn't deserve all the hate it got, but we can all agree Advanced Warfare and Infinite Warfare were trash.

But sometimes... I just don't want to spend 60-80 hours playing ONE video game in an age where there are just so many good ones that deserve my time. 

Risk of Rain 2 is not only something that deserves your time, it earns it by being a complete package at an incredible price especially when it's on sale. It doesn't even require 30 hours to unlock all of the characters, and it takes you about 5-8 hours to get through the final stage (there are 5 of them) and choose the option to defeat the main boss.

...or die trying (I did, many times).

Alternatively, you can choose to keep going. You can say to yourself, just a few more runs. I think I can get even stronger. I think that if I can find just a few more items, I can make a truly unique build. And then you find yourself putting 60 hours into Risk of Rain 2 because you just want to have that perfect run one more time. 

Just take a look at the reviews. Overwhelmingly positive and they have been for quite a while. 

It's a game that can be beaten in 1-2 sittings over a weekend, or you can spend a whole 2 week vacation playing it every day in 10 hour sittings, and you wouldn't even come close to all the game has to offer. It's up to you and how you want to play it. 

It's a good game, and you've spent more money on a Friday night out. 

Just buy it.

(P.S. the game just came out with a new expansion a few days ago and it's currently on sale. Definitely pick it up if you bought the main game already. Otherwise, just get the bundle which has the main game and the expansion. Totally worth it.)

(P.S.S. I'm not being paid to say any of this whatsoever, I'm just your average gamer.)

It's fun. There are plenty of long reviews out there so I'll just share what I like:

1) Lots of characters and they all feel really unique (the melee characters play differently, the long ranged ones do, etc) This adds a lot of replayability and ties in well with my 2nd point...

2) Lots of crazy builds. The items in this game are quite fun and can be combined in really diverse and fun ways. I think one great example I can think of is the fun that occurs with gas cans, wisps, knives, and lightning where one kill just starts this unstoppable chain reaction. The game has a great way of making you feel powerful while simultaneously pitting you against powerful enemies.

Risk of Rain 2 is one of the best choices in rogue-like games ever, but without a larger objective the fun may be limited by a players ability to entertain themselves. The general play style of the game revolves around spawning into a zone killing enemies while searching for the teleporter. Once the teleporter is found a player may activate it which spawns a boss. After the boss is defeated and a certain amount of time has passed, the teleporter is then activated and the player may then move on to the next zone. Perform this sequence a few times and the player will reach the final boss and a unique event which leads to the end of the game. With the general progression of the game being relatively simple. There are several elements that make the game massively more enjoyable.

The first is how difficulty is handled in the game. From the moment you start until the end of the game the difficulty is getting harder. The only way to combat this is for the players themselves to collect power-ups to constantly make themselves more powerful. This is easily the greatest element of the system which unlike many other rogue-likes in the genre, Risk of Rain 2 showers the players in power-ups frequently and each of them, especially early on, has impactful feeling on the players performance. This is where much of the fun is to be had by allowing for an endlessly stacking series of power-ups which is only matched by the games always looming difficulty timer which ensures that the player never feels too powerful for too long. 

To further enhance this experience. The player is given the opportunity to select from a reasonable number of unlock-able characters. Each of these characters has it’s own play style and attacks. What’s more is that many of these characters abilities can be changed out for alternative unlock-able attacks which adds to customization and play style opportunities. At the games price point this is a completely wonderful and worthwhile experience both as a rogue-like and as an action/shooter game. The only point where trouble may be seen is in the overall objective and longevity of the game. 

With the games direct and simple progress path. Beating the game on the normal difficulties is not hard. Increasing the difficulty often feels like it takes away from the fun by making the player feel less powerful. There are a good number of things to unlock to including a great many things not mentioned in this review. The problems are this. Characters have unlock-able abilities but if a player isn’t all that interested in the character then there is little value for the player to do the challenges to unlock them. Because of this, only part of the unlock-able content has much value to the player. Without larger and more generalized goals to strive for, regardless of the play-style, it quickly becomes up to the player to create their own goals. Because of this, the games playtime before a player gets bored feels like it is shorter than it should be but still sufficiently long. The game is still an amazing game and I highly suggest anyone remotely interested to check it out. Oh and the whole thing has four player coop so that’s also amazing.

A good game that takes all of the fun out of it due to RNG. 

I personally don't find the fun in completely ruining progression because something can spawn behind you, or completely change it's behavior at random to kill you out of nowhere. It takes what could be a consistent gameplay experience into a coin flip simulator. 

The dependence on items feels lackluster. Dodging enemies doesn't always work the same way, even after learning how each on attacks. Sometimes you'll be standing around for a minute at the beginning of the game waiting for something to spawn, other times you're constantly getting things thrown at you. 

Even when it felt like I was on a "God Run" and couldn't be touched, as I said before, an enemy changes it's behavior or I do the same things I've been doing for the past hour, then my run is entirely over with no explanation or reason other than RNG. 

I want to recommend the game, I just can't. Far too RNG dependent. I don't feel like I've gotten any better in the last 50+ hours of gameplay because of RNG. 

There simply isn't a satisfying progression system here.

As of writing this review, I've put 442 hours into it, and unlocked 111/112 achievements. [b]Damn you Prismatic Trials![/b] 

There is a massive amount of gameplay content. If you're looking for something to sink your time into, this is definitely one place to turn to, as to unlock [i]more content[/i] you have to complete challenges, which are just that; challenging. All of the challenges are in some way related to the content they unlock. Healing an exceptional amount with an item, for instance, unlocks a more rare one that improves healing. 

Secrets! Secrets galore! Theres quite a few secrets in RoR2, and its well worth it to explore and find them. Some aren't just cool and neat to find, they are just as rewarding as completing challenges; they grant you new items or new game mechanics. 

There are 13 or so characters you can play as; which means 13 vastly different playstyles. Get bored of the one you've been playing? Thats okay. [b]There is more than one way to play any given character[/b]. Each character has a specific loadout custom made for them, but you can complete challenges with that character to unlock [b]alternate skills[/b] to use with them. "On average", each character's skill has 1 counterpart that it can be swapped with. Thats a lot of ways to play the game.

Oh yeah, and its just fun. The gameplay itself is fun and satisfying. And multiplayer is pretty great, because most things are better with friends. This included. Just try not to shatter your relationships by hogging all the items.

Good, but not great rogue like. Base mechanics are fun, simple, and interesting enough for me to play as long as I have so far. I think the characters' tool sets are somewhat limiting when playing solo (i.e. some being god awful against airborne opponents), but when playing with a squad where you can cover each other's weaknesses, they shine. I do have a few significantly glaring issues with the game, however. 1.) In rogue likes, I think some items should be able to drastically change your playstyle when picked up, which i think is the appeal of rogue likes, making each run feel unique (i.e. binding of isaac's tear replacement effects or hades' varying God/Goddess rewards). I think all of the items in risk of rain (save for the lunar ones) have no drawbacks for picking them up nor do they drastically change the way you play, they just make what you're already doing better. Even with the lunar ones, the ones that make you play a different way (i.e. the one that cuts your HP in half and doubles damage) are generally just worse overall given my next point. One hit KOs/Combos. So many times in this game can you feel untouchable for the first few levels and then immediately die without even knowing what hit you. It's not like Spelunky where your deaths are usually attributable to foolishness or carelessness, rather simple sensory overload to the point where it's near impossible to keep track of all the things going on around you. And again, unlike Spelunky for example, these deaths can happen hours into a run, seemingly out of nowhere. At least in Spelunky, you've likely only been playing for a few minutes. It's very frustrating. So, with those two negatives in mind I think it's fair to recommend this game, but not glowingly.

As someone who played the first Risk of Rain and bounced off, I was hesitant when I had this game recommended to me by a friend. After a bit more peer pressure, I bought in and immediately got hooked. There's something about the Risk of Rain formula in a 3D space that makes this game infinitely more enjoyable than the first installment (to me). Roguelike games are common these days, but only a few are able to capture what makes the genre so appealing - Risk of Rain 2 is no exception. Like Binding of Isaac before it, RoR2 doesn't limit the player in what item combinations they can create, allowing for insanely game-breaking synergies that can steamroll anything that stands in the way. This game is well worth it, even at full price.

Risk of Rain 2 is an extremely fun third-person rogue-like with excellent game play, vibrant areas and a great soundtrack. The only draw back to it is there is no meta-progression beyond unlocking some characters, where is many other rogue-likes are offering some form of permanent progression which acts as a way to keep you engaged and thinking "I'll go for just one more run". But the game on it's own stands, it's really fun aside from a few issues with balance here and there that I wish they'd address. Beyond that, I can easily recommend this game.

I usually don't like games like this. Fast paced, high action shoot 'em ups have never been my thing. this one, however, is the exception. I love this game. Beautiful artwork, great music, and lots of lore to read up on every time you make progress. Each of the characters are fun to try out and play around with. The game a has a wonderful sense of humor, too! All in all, I highly recommend this game to anyone who has a group of friends looking for something to play together, or if you are just in the mood to sink a few hours into a run-through. It's worth your time!

Fast paced rougelite third person shooter/slasher/whacker with a varied cast of survivors, each with a pretty unique style of play. Odds are there's going to be at least one you like to play, if not multiple, and the 3 difficulty modes(plus the special harder mode) means most people should be able to find fun.

Unlocks are rewarding and incentivize playing and experimenting. Plenty will come naturally, and some even become mainstays, and even more require a deeper understanding of the mechanics and careful play.

Great Dungeon-like game! The classes all have their different perks and advantadges which allow for a large variety of gameplay style, not to mention that each class also has multiple abilities that can be swapped in and out to further customise your playstyle. Multiplayer connection is great if you play in closer servers and the concept is original and unique!

The way items work is great too, even without the artifact of command, getting randomised items can either ensure saftey or total chaos. And even with artifacts, the game still requires you to be able to use your class well on the harder difficulties. You'll never know what you're getting, so you have to adapt to what you have and work well with it if you want to live

As for the Survivours of the void DLC (Gifted to me by a friend, thank you!), i'm also finding that extremley fun! the new boss is very challenging, I love the railgunner class already and i can see that this game has a lot of potential

When starting the game, it may look very difficult (try playing on drizzle first) but you'll slowly get the hang of how it works and soon you'll be able to easily solo the game yourself!

It's a nice game to play with friends, it's unpredictable and You'll always experience something different.

One of my favourite games on my steam libary, I highly reccomend this!

RoR2 is a seriously addicting and fast-paced third person shooter with a wonderful graphic art style and presentation. The gameplay here is sick to boot! It starts off slowly as you build your character's strength through collecting power-ups from killing enemies, all the while searching for the boss encounter on a timer that counts down to your doom by raising the game's difficulty. 

Each character type has different inherent functions and abilities as well so there's tons of replayability in picking new faces to see who does what and how and if they suit your play-style the best.

I've only put a couple of hours into the game so far but I'm expecting to extend those hours soon. I always come back just now and then to push myself a little further, while also having turns with friends and roommates.

When I first heard Risk of Rain 2 was going to be 3D I was dubious. So many games fall flat in their sequels and being 2D is what helped the original keep it's fast pace and chaos. Risk of Rain 2 adds more chaos and mayhem than ever before at an equally fast paced. It's a Rogue Like in it's own league and instead of nerfing the most OP builds the devs decided to unleash enemies and bosses that will still challenge you when you become godlike! And I'm not talking bullet sponges (looking at you borderlands!!!) I'm talking enemies that will actually force you to pay attention and keep you on your toes.

Despite being a Rogue Like you'll find the game has a depth of hidden secrets that you'd expect from a Metroidvania. It's not a game you play for the story, it's the kind of game that has a beautifully crafted gameplay loop which you can lose yourself in for hours. It also offers mechanics to make the game more deterministic and the devs don't care which path you choose. If you want to turn on a bunch of stuff to help nail a specific challenge then the game will allow it. There's no right or wrong with RoR, play it your way and hey, if you find yourself wanting more after you 100% it... Then hit up the modding scene!

Enjoyed what I've played in the first 3 hours but have a major concern about visual clarity. I am completely unable to figure out what is happening at a given moment in a match unless I've already encountered it at least 5 times. The visual indicators as to 'this is dangerous' or 'this will be dangerous in a moment' or 'don't stand there' all wash together into a mess of flashing lights and pixels. I guess it goes away with time and memorization of what effects come from which enemies and so on, but it made every moment of the first 3 hours either 'this is tediously easy' or 'I am going to die and I don't know why'


At 20ish hrs: As expected, I've acclimated to the visual mess through exposure, but I still find it a negative. The gameplay loop is compelling and as I've started to become familiar with the equipment I find myself thinking a bit ahead in terms of possible combinations that could match well with what I have. I've tried the commando, the huntress, the engineer, and the railgunner, and while all feel unique in playstyle, they do not feel even in terms of efficacy. A 'bad' railgunner run is always better than the best of the best huntress runs I've managed, for example. Maybe that has more to do with me than with the game, but I feel that the unique strengths of each class are not always comparable. Huntress is sold as the 'fragile but fast and deadly' character, but her ability to sprint while firing is mostly nullified by the fact that sprint can only be applied in a forward direction, and her shots lack punch, leaving her as the 'fragile, weak, and also gravimetrically drawn to her death' class unless certain items are found. Railgunner is sold as the 'long range single target killer with limited mobility' but in reality is the 'all range damage dealer with crowd control ability instead of dodge who can shoot around corners and oneshot bosses with a short cooldown' character. Commando is sold as the 'reliable all arounder' but is really the 'inaccurate at long range without enough damage potential to compensate but at least you get a stun attack without needing to find stun items' character As you can see, the reality rarely matches the sales pitch. No character (except huntress) feels 100% bad to me so far, just uneven.

Since there are few tools available to eliminate randomness, this makes every run a complete crapshoot (not good, not bad, just the way it is) though having now looked at the wiki extensively to try to combat the lack of information about enemies and item specifics, there is apparently an unlockable that allows item selection. 
Level design is good, but the visual clarity rears its head again because it's often impossible to determine at a glance whether a slope is traversible or not. My character can sometimes walk up near vertical cliffs and other times cannot walk over small bumps in the terrain. Eventually, I'm sure I will memorize which paths work and which ones don't and won't notice this issue anymore, but it further exascerbates the already punishing early game arbitrariness. If I sprint past a boss towards a slope that has cover at the top, only to find the slope is impassable, that's GG for that run.

I want to start this review with a response to a review I saw a while back about this game in comparison to Binding of Isaac. The complaint was that Binding of Isaac's items change the way you play the game with new abilities, while RoR2 only changes your stats. While that's mostly true, the person reviewing forgot to mention the characters. In Isaac, you are the same dude, all the time. That's why the items inside the runs change your playstyle. In RoR2, you have an abundance of vasty different characters, all of which play the game in a completely different way. The game solves the "items don't change much" problem with the playstyle of the characters, and the different abilities to unlock. Overall after 200 hours in the game, I can say that I'll be playing even more with this new expansion coming out, and it's worth every penny!

Risk of Rain 2 is probably the best Roguelike I've ever played, it sits besides Hades in my ranking of the best games in the genre. After the first game, I didn't think it would be possible to reinvent the formula the developers created in such a way that the spirit would remain basically intact, but they did it. The game stands out mostly because it's not afraid to be a videogame, and it is a mix of tight gameplay, nice (yet simple) art design, utterly bonkers progression, and amazing music. The only bad thing I can say is that when things get really crazy on a play session, the game might stutter a bit, what with the enormous amount of enemies, projectiles, and effects on screen, but it is by no means unplayable, just a little annoying (Until it isn't I guess).
Anyone with a passing interest should buy this game, it is well worth the (frankly small amount of) money, and it comes with multiplayer too, for those who want to play with friends.  And now with the new expansion, there's even more content to enjoy.

This game is wonderful. Hours upon hours of reckless fun, combined with strategic item-building and run-crafting. While RNG is a big part in how your run will go, the game gives you many options of changing how your run will go. The game can be a laid-back experience, or an intense fight for your life - difficulty is serious. The hardest difficulties will see you suffer and the easiest will let you go for stupid ideas or use it as a background game,

The newest DLC adds in an incredible amount of new synergies and run ideas, while adding in two very fun characters and many new stages. From the amount I've played of it (about 10 hours) the DLC is definitely worth it. Heavily recommend both the game and dlc!

The base-game itself is amazing. Learning the rules, what works and what doesn't, and defeating the bosses for the first time is difficult, but very rewarding. 
After the first few hours, the initial excitment fades, but the fun doesn't. In it's place is exploring all the potential synergies items can have, and where they can be used. The many more challanging unlockables and game modifiers slowly become more appealing and completing the game with insane rules in place (both limiting you, but also opening up the way to otherwise unplayed strategies). 
And when all that is done; when you have completed all the achivements, used all the artifacts, there is one more aspect of the game left to play...

Mods. Oh lord, the mods.

Through use of Overwolf and over similar Mod Managers, you get access to well over a thousand different mods. Some are down right bad, or just not worth it, but others add fun new elements to the game that can make you play for far longer than you originally thought you would. 

Oh, and the dlc just launched. Time to play that too~~

Fun game when RNG doesn't ruin your runs. One of those games where 'difficulty' means the devs put more and more enemies on the screen, and 90% of items are worthless until you get 3, or more, of that same item. Nothing beats the feeling of playing 20, or so, minutes in a single run, just to have it end because the game decided your efforts are in vain. Not because you played poorly, but because you weren't given good items to buy. 

When everything goes your way, the game is a blast. When it doesn't, it's usually a miserable time where even the tiniest mistake is punished. If you play video games to compensate for something in life, or to get upset over something, this is your game.

It isn't often I write a review but with the most recent expansion finally dropped I felt it be a great time to do so. My conclusion best summarises my feelings about this game if you only care for opinions, with that being said this is all my opinion.

The positives:

With a heavy emphasis on the rouge-lite genre of "every runs unique", you can truly make that happen with the number of survivors now at 13, each having its own changable loadout, and the artifacts. There were many times I would wonder where all the enemies had gone during an hour long run, only to remember that they die automatically due to the abhorrent number of things going on at any one moment. However I also found myself properly struggling sometimes, especially on the harder difficulty of monsoon hiding from enemies until my life or abilities recharge, and its not often I find such a parallel in gaming unless you make it yourself.


The negative:

There are some things I can play over and over again without any true objective in mind, however Risk of Rain 2 struggles to be one, sure its fun to play and get strong much like any game, however without something to drive it forwards, the game can start to make death and victory feel all the same. Lunar coins don't truly assist that fact either, as beating the final boss doesn't sprinkle them on you, and the only way to increase them at any substantial manner is to use the prayer beads, that you have to buy with lunar coins, in a shop that unless you get extremely lucky also costs lunar coins to open, and then it doesn't even have a chance to show up initially, causing you to either spend an exponential number of lunar coins on re-rolling, or hope for next level to offer you better odds.

Conclusion:

With all said and done, I'm never going to recommend this game to everyone and that's a good thing, let this game be a masterpiece for those who enjoy it, and for the rest the perfect game exists elsewhere, but if you don't give it a go you will never find out. With all that said and done I would like to add one last thing.

 - Risk of Rain 2 is what I would consider a centre of a 'Venn diagram', with the game itself being fun to play, the company behind it offers transparency and constant updates, and lastly the community surrounding this game truly wants it to shine -

With over 200 hours in this game and most of those on Acrid, I can confidently say that every other character in the game is completely unplayable. Fuck Commando, fuck Huntress, fuck Bandit, fuck Mul-T, fuck Engineer, Fuck Artificer.
i'm so sick of seeing everyone shit on acrid, calling him trash and saying he can't melee like merc and loader If you advocate for using a visions of heresy on acrid I will fight you; acrid is the best melee character in the game and here's why: Most people use TERRIBLE abilities on him. My Acrid loadout is: Blight, Ravenous Bite, Caustic Leap. First off, Poison VS Blight. In order to understand why Blight is better, you need to understand how Acrid compares to Loader and Merc, the other melee characters. Loader specializes in dealing high damage in large punches, and mercenary specializes in invulnerability and mobility. Using poison (🤢🤢🤢) might seem better on Acrid since it just does more damage, but don't be fooled. More damage on the debuff is not as beneficial as Blight's ability to kill enemies. blight makes Acrid the best crowd control character in the game. Literally just press R with blight active and PSH PSH PSH PSH PSH! suddenly every single bitch ass wisp and beetle on the whole fucking stage is dead. Next, Neorotoxin vs Ravenous bite. People pick neurotoxin to give Acrid some range to deal with wisps and other threats because it's his only ranged ability other than Epidemic. but if you're using Blight, suddenly Epidemic (and jumping on to wisps if you have half a braincell) is enough to deal with those flying threats! Now you can use ravenous bite and FUCKING DECIMATE every single boss with ease. Pick up a backup mag and suddenly you're biting all the time, healing yourself, and dealing 240% + SLAYER + more damage to lower health enemies (HIDDEN ABILITY THAT ISNT EVEN WRITTEN ON THE ABILITY GRRRRRRR) over and over and over and over. You can literally eat grandparents for lunch. Lastly, Caustic Leap vs Frenzied Leap. Caustic is definitely better than frenzied just because frenzied's base cooldown is way too long, even though it decreases if you're hitting enemies, its not very good for looting and moving around the stage. Just use caustic and apply easy debuffs and extra crowd control. All of this and acrid is fucking fantastic, also if you pick up a single gasoline or will-o'-the-wisp or ukelele and you can just kill everything. Acrid has an extremely good base damage stat so just eat all the bosses. I normally hate dogs but Acrid is just a perfect acid dog boy who is criminally underappreciated. He's so cute and he deserves to chomp every beetle. Fuck merc, fuck rex, fuck loader, fuck captain, fuck railgunner, who tf even is void fiend.

Long story short, the game is amazing. Being a roguelike game, it is not very complicated, meaning its new player friendly. It does not require much introduction, you are introduced into a grassy plain and you have to kill swarming enemies to acquire items from locked chests in a literal race against the clock. What is meant by this is the mechanic which causes the game's difficulty to slowly rise not only as levels are completed but simply as time passes within the levels themselves! This successfully adds to the urgency of the game, forcing you to balance time and item farming for maximum efficiency. There is also an absolute abundance of unique items to collect in the game, with many unique rarities such as legendary items which are found very scarcely but give strong effects even on their own which can tip the game's balance in your favour, boss items which also give very strong effects which are different depending on which boss you defeated to gain the item, and even the risky lunar items which give a strong effect in return for a handicap of some sort. Despite the previously mentioned inevitable ever rising difficulty, the game offers lots of pre-run customisation such as which character you'll play, which abilities you'll be using for the character, which difficulty you'll play the game on and even the artifacts you'll use, which are custom settings which can be activated to add an extra effect to the game, either benefiting the player, giving an extra handicap or even both! There are many secrets to be found throughout the level, leaving not even the most veteran players without content to explore. 9/10

Precipitation Warning 2: Electric Boogaloo is a video game made for people with ADHD by people with ADHD. 
In this game you follow the protagonist, Jon Risk the 2nd in his eternal struggle against the local Australian wildlife. The virtual intercourse simulator will take you on a journey of self discovery and environmental desecration, and before you ask, yes. 

Yes.

The game is a rogue-lite which means just like the local catholic Facebook group, every time you experience this agony your gameplay and situation will differ. You acquire random items throughout unthoughtfully placed boxes and guaranteed waste of money 3D Printers which will not I guarantee you let your precious bungus fall off the stage. Outside of the funny backstage robot deciding what colour of trinket to give you, the game also constantly varies in its replay-ability with every individual survivor. Survivors are  your canvas, the blood of the innocent your paint. Survivors are crew (or purple dogs) of the UES Safe Travels, the ship's denizens definitely very concerned and mindful of the consequences of launching missile strikes at sentient beings. Being the good guys of the story, you are tasked with the herculean mission of locating and rescuing the crew of the UES Contact Grass- I mean Contact Light, whom went missing some time before you arrived. 

The playable survivors range in strengths, weaknesses and abilities with not a single character playing the same as the one you just died on Monsoon on 30 seconds ago. Want to fulfil your dreams of taking over the body of a transgender woman? Go ahead. Want to morph into an AC-130 and revoke respiratory privileges of anything that is underneath you? Be my guest. Become a plant. Become a plant I double dog goddamn dare you. 
Whichever survivor you pick delegates the flavour of terror you bring upon the civilised populous of Petrichor V. Speaking of Petrichor V, the areas you find yourself in and the untold culture of the sex, party and drugs lifestyle of fire-breathing salamanders is easily accessible to read via way too many paragraphs of  l o r e  hidden from you. Its a good thing you only learn about the complex brains and emotions these creatures feel after you slaughter them for defending their currently invaded territory. 

The standard run consists of 6 stages, or 100 if you're mentally ill. With many variants to the locales you visit you'll never be left bored unless you run out of lunar coins and can't get the fuel array to REX please just let me unlock REX please I cant dream to get abyssal depths hopoo please i just wanted rex oh my god why did you do this to me this is my 12th drizzle loader run where i dont get enough coins to get abyssal depths i just want to see how rex plays i want the plant hopoo why why did you do this to me please please please please please

After you reach stage 5 you have the option of experiencing all 5 stages again from the beginning with more tougher enemies or you can take one small step for Lumeriankind and journey to the moon where an actual blue goblin is waiting with a hammer and a lust for geometric shapes. But don't count that as the end of the game, by the time you finish it the first time you still have roughly 60 items and 4-5 characters to unlock and all of their secondary abilities. The sense of progression looms over you holding you in some sick S&M chokehold you can't get out of until you find every individual stack of pebbles that lets you wear a goats skin to run faster. Never will there not be something to do in Non-Guaranteed Downpour II. 

The most prominent feature that makes it most similar to your local catholic Facebook group is that every waking second you spend on Petrichor V means that every enemy and encounter adapts and strengthens with or without you. Survival is a race and you're amputated. If you do not kill enough enemies before the clock strikes twelve every single enemy will level up without you, meaning prioritising not spending six hours in one stage grinding and instead: running fast is your only option for keeping your own respiratory privileges intact. Ride or die, kid. 

In conclusion, this game is a fun 3rd-person shooter rogue-lite adventure for the mentally deranged, socially inept and attention deficit audience that is definitely worth your 10 fortnite vbucks you planned to purchase virtual ice-cream in the metaverse with. If you can manage to talk to another human being and convince them to play this game with you, it may just provide an unforgettable experience.

But that's just a theory. A game theory.

I've put a lot of hours into this game, and it's high time to get my review in.  

Risk of Rain 2 is an enigma for me.  It drew me in as a curiosity, but at a certain point, I was trapped.  

The lore, the style, the music, the environments -- they pull you in so deeply.  But it's by your own will -- see, some games will hold your hand, and you're tethered to it in the way that the developer intended you to be.  Here, I honestly have no clue where the developers even wanted me to start.  I loaded into the game, knowing nothing about anything, and the developers basically said "go figure it out".  

So you explore.  You explore the game, the menus, the logs, the music...it all just draws you in.  You are pulled into this alien world, and before you know it, you're invested.  You want to know more -- why are you here?  What are you fighting?  What does it all mean?

It's a story that many will eventually unfold, but everyone's individual journey will differ.  If you just want an exciting 3rd person rougelike shooter, you've got it in spades.  But there is also so much more to discover  and love about the game.

Summary
The Hog Rider is a fast ground troop with medium hitpoints, low damage, and the ability to jump over enemy Walls. He is unlocked at level 2 Dark Barracks.
The Hog Rider (person) is a bare-chested dark-skinned man holding a hammer. He has a mohawk, wears a brown leather loincloth, a red belt, and a pair of leather sandals, as well as two large golden wristbands and a gold earring.
His ride is a large hog, about half his height. It has a brown leather bridle looped around its tusks, which in turn is held by the Hog Rider.
Hog Riders prioritize defensive structures above all other targets, and will bypass all other types of enemy buildings and troops while any defenses remain on the battlefield. This is true even if they are under attack by enemy Clan Castle troops, heroes or Skeleton Trap skeletons. Note that like all troops that prioritize defenses, Hog Riders do not consider the Clan Castle to be a defense regardless of whether or not it contains enemy troops, but do consider the defending Grand Warden and the activated Town Hall weapon (if any) to be defensive buildings.
Once all defenses are destroyed, Hog Riders become like any other troop with no preferred target; they will attack the nearest building to them regardless of type, and will turn and attack enemy units if they become aware of any nearby.
Strategy
Offensive
He can be used to jump over any level Walls, rendering them ineffective against Hog Riders. Note that while this allows Hog Riders free access to what lies behind the Walls, it does not open up gaps for other troops to move through. If the Hog Riders need the support of other ground troops, you will still need to deploy Wall Breakers, a Jump Spell, or Earthquake Spells in order to assist them.
Hog Riders can be used en masse, i.e. a "Hog Rider Rush", without requiring any Wall Breakers to break Walls. However, such a strategy can be costly in terms of Dark Elixir, and sports weaknesses against defending Clan Castle troops, Heroes, Giant Bombs, and Skeleton Traps, a problem which only becomes more prominent at higher levels.
At Town Hall 10 and above, Hog Riders can be combined with Miners in a strategy known as Hog Miner or Hybrid. Both troops are able to bypass Walls innately, but Miners do not have a preferential target, allowing them to cover for Hog Riders by dealing with defending Heroes and Skeleton Traps. The combination also has weaknesses against flying Clan Castle troops, as neither are able to target air.
At lower levels, Hog Riders are quite capable of acting as distracting troops like Giants; they have nearly as much health as a similar-level Giant, move twice as fast, and do considerably more damage.
They work well with the Healing Spell when you group several of them together.
A good tactic for using Healing Spells is to place them strategically on a cluster of defenses (at least about 3 or more) and also deploy them shortly before the Hog Riders arrive in the area, i.e. deploy them ahead of the Hog Riders. This is so that the Hog Riders get the most out of the Healing Spell, and destroy the defenses without losing too much HP.
Spots where Giant Bombs or Bomb Towers are/may be should be given special attention when deploying Healing Spells. Hogs of the same level as the Giant Bomb will survive a single Giant Bomb, but they're helpless against a pair of Giant Bombs even with a Healing Spell. Heal them after they've gone through a Giant Bomb blast.
The Hog Rider is one of the best troop types for drawing out Clan Castle troops, as it can avoid Walls to penetrate deep enough to reach centrally-placed Clan Castles (and enough health to not die before it gets there). Deploy one or a few to trigger the Clan Castle troops, then lure the reinforcement troops to the corner side, and deploy multiple Archers or Wizards to slaughter them, and then deploy the remainder of your Hog Riders. This strategy is especially effective during Clan War raids. However, Skeletons from the Skeleton Trap and Heroes can also easily kill the Hog Riders, as they can only target defenses, so make sure to have some troops that target anything, such as Wizards, which can swipe out the Skeletons.
Hog Riders don't target air so flying Clan Castle troops, especially Dragons, can be a big threat. Most mass Hog Rider strategies in Clan Wars require that the Clan Castle troops be killed first by luring. Bring other troops in addition to Hog Riders, such as Wizards, to deal with enemy Clan Castle troops and clean up the base.
Poison Spells can be used to kill almost any enemy Clan Castle troop, but beware as the troops will attempt to flee the poison. If the Poison Spells are decently leveled, and you effectively keep the Clan Castle troops from escaping the Poison Spell with distracting troops, they can eliminate almost any troop. They can also be used to dispense of those pesky Skeletons risen from the Skeleton Traps.
Time is also a factor to consider. With only 3 minutes in an attack, it is essential to make sure that this whole process and the remainder of the attack is done as quickly as possible to avoid running out of time.
Defensive
Defending against Hog Riders is tricky, as their ability to bypass Walls renders them irrelevant. However, the fact that they can jump over Walls and attack defenses means that they may leave behind their ground support (such as Barbarians, etc.), as they will not be able to follow. This will allow your interior defenses to concentrate on the Hog Riders.
Another way to defend against Hog Riders is to exploit the fact that they will attack the closest defensive building. You can arrange your base in such a way so that you have high-powered defenses on the inside and lower-powered defense on the outside, with a layer of resources in between. That way, the Hogs will (in theory) complete a loop around your base before being able to attack your interior defenses (Inferno Towers, X-Bows, etc.), by which time they should have all been killed by the interior defenses.
You can place Spring Traps and Giant Bombs in between defensive buildings to take out a few Hog Riders at a time; good usage of multiple Spring Traps and Giant Bombs can severely hinder a Hog Rider rush.
Hog Riders can be easily killed using "forced pathing". Forced pathing is a strategy that manipulates the Hog Rider AI and makes them go to at least 2 defenses that cannot be prevented by surgical dropping or side clearing. Placing a set of Giant Bombs in between the two can most certainly hinder the attacker progress. They would not be able to heal the Hog Riders in time.
Clan Castle troops, Heroes, and Skeleton Traps set to Ground Mode can be an annoyance to mass Hog Rider raids, as Hog Riders will not attack them unless all defenses have been destroyed. Make sure to centralize them if you want to beat Hog Riders.
In Clan Wars, Dragons are excellent troops to place in Clan Castles against Hog Riders, especially for Town Halls 8 and 9. They have high HP, meaning they won't die easily and can kill mass quantities of Hog Riders swiftly if not properly lured. Most mass Hog Rider strategies require that the enemy Clan Castle troops be killed first, so if the attacker lures out a Dragon, but fails to kill it, then a 3-star win is next to impossible, much less a 1-star win via destroying 50% of the buildings.
Multi-target Inferno Towers can be a severe hindrance to Hog Riders, having high HP to take several hits from Hog Riders, while hitting large groups of them.
Although the Hog Rider is certainly not a liability on defense, the fact that all defensive troops are unimpeded by Walls negates the primary advantage of the Hog Rider. Still, for the space they take they are faster and more damaging compared to Giants.
Upgrade Differences
The Hog Rider undergoes significant visual changes at levels 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10.

Quick Overview:

 The graphics are somewhat simplistic, but look very good. The controls are good. Music is great. Very fast paced combat and exploration. Replayability is basically infinite. The difficulty is mostly up to you to decide, from moderately easy to completely absurd. You can also play alone or with friends. The game is played in individual runs, with each run being varying in length depending on your playstyle. If you just want to know how long it takes to rush to the final boss, a run straight for them takes between 30 and 45 minutes.  Your goal in the game is to escape the planet by finding the teleporter in each stage until you reach the final boss. You have control over the rules you give yourself in the form of sixteen artifacts and three difficulties. Artifacts allow you to add certain rules such as choosing your items or doubling enemy spawns while halving their health.

 The biggest problem I have with this game is also what I see as its biggest strength: the abundance of stuff determined by RNG (stands for random number generator, basically luck). Enemy spawns, teleporter locations, chest locations, items you get, and the levels you go to are all examples of stuff that is determined by RNG.  This gives the game its almost infinite replayability, as it will be different every time you play.  However, the abundance of RNG also means that your run can either be far more difficult or far easier than it should be.

Extra Stuff:

 As far as the items go, some are certainly better than others. Nonetheless, few, if any, are entirely useless. Depending on your situation, an item you see as a meme could either be a run saver or exactly what you expected from it. There are quite a few items that are good in any situation, but those are still better in certain situations than others. Every item has at least one strategy it fits in.

 Enemies and bosses have a lot of different variety when you aren't just one-shotting everything. Some fly, some charge at you, some shoot fireballs, some tower above you while charging at you while spitting fire. Some are slow, some are fast. Some sneak up behind you and others attack from so far away you might not be able to see them. Same as the items, you have to adapt to the enemies and bosses that are thrown at you. You have to prioritize enemies, damage them, and dodge their attacks all at the same time. This game can become extremely chaotic.

 I just realized that I've done four paragraphs and not mentioned the different characters you can play as. There are several different characters you can play as, each with a different moveset and stats. Certain enemies are easier to deal with as one character than another, and certain items work better with one character than another. It's another way that this game has so much replayability. I'm not going to say anything more about the different characters because it's best for you to figure out on your own.

 Overall, probably one my favorite games.  10/10 from me

after more than 100 hours I think I'm gonna write a review the game

Gameplay
Risk of Rain 2, abbreviated ror2, is a 3D roguelike, bullet hell game that may be played multiplayer or solo. It's impossible to explain this game into words since it's so unique, but that's what makes it so good. You start with only one character unlocked, but by playing the game properly, you rapidly unlock the rest of the cast.
The game has three levels of difficulty: Drizzle, Rainstorm, and Monsoon.
The difficulties, in my opinion, are perfectly balanced. Rainstorm provides a pleasant "normal" experience that is neither too simple nor too difficult. Drizzle is ideal for those who wish to unwind and unwind. And, if you're looking for a true challenge, Monsoon is the place to go.
The mechanics are easy to grasp, and learning the game is a breeze. That was something that stood out to me when I first started playing this game. I had no prior experience playing the first game, yet it seemed like I already understood enough to succeed after 10 minutes. The game's playability is nearly excellent for being in early access. The only thing I can think of that would immediately improve the game's experience is to solve the problems, which I'll get to later.

Multiplayer
The multiplayer impressed me with how effectively it was done. It's quite easy to jump into a game with others, and I felt that the challenge scaled very nicely. The only issue I had was one of my buddies disconnecting in the middle of the game, and they were unable to rejoin until their internet was resolved. They do, however, allow you to play with each other through mods, which I'll discuss later.

Design
Currently, there are 17 stages that can emerge during playing. Each is nicely designed and simple to navigate and understand the layout of. The design of adversaries allows you to instantly know how dangerous they are by by looking at them, while still being unique enough to understand what it is. They performed an excellent job in this regard. When things get busy, you need to be able to tell what's what, and they did just that.

Soundtrack
The current soundtrack of ror2 is around 20 or more soundtrack,However, all of the songs presently in the game match the spirit of ror2 so perfectly, and always feel like they're the right music for whatever situation I'm in. I'm excited to hear what new music they'll be introducing in the future.

Mods

Risk of Rain 2 is an absolutely fantastic game that I'd recommend to anybody who enjoys shooters, collecting achievements, or being challenged. 

The game has a rather charming art style and music is widely regarded as very well made although some songs do get a little pitchy or repetitive. I also really like that killing specific monsters or collecting specific items will allow you to inspect them in a logbook so you can truly admire the monster's design without them brutally axe-murdering you. There's a somewhat large amount of biomes that exist in the game and most have unique enemies that spawn exclusively to that area. Achievements are also fantastic (although some are ridiculous) and are very rewarding because they will always give you a new toy to play with. 

First off, I really like that achievements give you new content to mess with. It feels very rewarding to actually do them because the rewards usually involve items, alternate skills for your character, or even just a new character altogether! You're rewarded very heavily for chasing achievements and completing special tasks or wandering around and discovering cute little secrets by yourself.

Combat feels fantastic. There's a VERY large selection of enemies to vaporize and all of them need to be treated differently to be avoided. This game can get insanely crazy cus the floor will be so very littered with monsters, but if you play correctly  you'll never get hit! I really enjoy that this game rewards your personal skills at dodging and it's not always going to a dps deathmatch between every little enemy. (That being said, wisps are almost impossible to dodge but also have the lowest health pool in the game so I think it's fair considering they don't even hurt that much) Furthermore, there's tons of characters to unlock and all have special abilities you can unlock and earn through playing them. None of the characters feel recycled and all of them are interesting or have a neat gimmick. (Commando is probably the most boring in everyone else's opinion and also mine, but even he gets cool dual pistols and Dashes)

Despite this being somewhat of a luck based game, items exist in such a way that even if you don't get an item that's good for your character, you can still use your raw skill and the items you've managed to collect to dominate your games. I also really like the difficulty system in this game. It's done in such a way that you don't even need to feel bad about doing the easiest difficulty because eventually Drizzle will fuck you just about as hard as Monsoon would anyway. It tells you exactly what changes in the game from difficulty settings instead of making you play guessing games so you can decide what difficulty is most comfortable for you right out the gates.

This game has an incredible modding community and there's some funny things you can get away with in public lobbies. I have been able to join modded hosts while vanilla whom have a character that lets you play as an overloading worm which is absolutely hilarious. Do keep in mind there probably won't be completely unique characters if you join a modded lobby successfully without mods. Some mods are just able to be run with vanilla players and the game will not automatically download the mods being run if your game won't operate without them. That being said, I urge you to try mods! This game has been receiving an ever increasing amount of modders and you will be able to select between a lot of things to choose from!

There's a lot of ways to spice up your game without mods, though. Artifacts are capable of changing the rules of the game to make it more chaotic or assist you with becoming God. Just as an example, my favorite artifact is the one where an evil clone of you with your same character and items tries to kill you every ten minutes! The more popular one is the one where items can be chosen rather than randomly generated if you're just looking for a quick game and want to enjoy playing God. 

For a pretty cheap price tag, I think this game is worth trying out! If you're on the fence you can still wait for a sale, but I don't imagine anyone who likes shooters won't at least enjoy this game for a few days!

ive been playing this game since release it pog anyway this is the recipe for cupcakes

STEP 1
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and fill a 12 cupcake tray with cases.

STEP 2
Using an electric whisk beat 110g softened butter and 110g golden caster sugar together until pale and fluffy then whisk in 2 large eggs, one at a time, scraping down the sides of the bowl after each addition.

STEP 3
Add ½ tsp vanilla extract, 110g self-raising flour and a pinch of salt, whisk until just combined then spoon the mixture into the cupcake cases.

STEP 4
Bake for 15 mins until golden brown and a skewer inserted into the middle of each cake comes out clean. Leave to cool completely on a wire rack.

STEP 5
To make the buttercream, whisk 150g softened butter until super soft then add 300g icing sugar, 1 tsp vanilla extract and a pinch of salt.

STEP 6
Whisk together until smooth (start off slowly to avoid an icing sugar cloud) then beat in 3 tbsp milk.

STEP 7
If wanting to colour, stir in the food colouring now. Spoon or pipe onto the cooled cupcakes.

Strong points:
- Supports creativity and build crafting
- Surprisingly optimized for most pc's
- Unique designs and artistic style
- a fast paced roguelike with enough structure to plan builds in advance
- different experience between switch and pc
- every character is good at something and plays very differently 
- you can get good with any character even those with high skill ceilings
- some of the best mod support ive seen in years

Weak points
- Spectator simulator 9If you die in a run with a friend you'll be stuck watching them play for the entire stage which can take 5 - 20 mins)
- Endgame is almost always the same (The longer a run lasts the more you start to gravitate to a really op build just to survive)
- Requires a lot of looking up (some items are poorly explained so it will require you to visit the wiki a couple of times)
- Not endless (eventually the game gets so ridiculous that either you have to kill bosses in seconds or your game will crash trying to keep up with the ridiculous amount of enemies)

This game is a mix between a singleplayer rogue like but in a 3d world and an mmo with different roles and strength.
The graphics are a little minimalistic but have a defined art style that you don't really get tired of quickly. It's performance is surprisingly good on most computers since i can even play it with friends that play on laptops from work. 

I made a lot of friends through this game and some wonderful moments and runs that are perfect memories.
Overall this game combines the perfect balance between every item has it's use and build crafting.
The stages go in a rotation of 5 and so you can always plan if something is worth scraping or keeping a hold of.

But where this game truly shines is how good it feels both on switch and pc. They felt different and sort of have different meta's and items that are better. It gives the game a refreshing feeling. Overall there is nothing better then spending 7 hours on a run with a friend so drunk that we die to the most random stuff ever and backseat game eachother.

One of my most loved games ever.

Risk of Rain 2     One of the best roguelikes ive ever played, one of the few 3D roguelikes i own, other one being Post void, Everything about this game is perfect and addictive. right as you begin your first run you are told nothing and forced to wonder through the first level and kill monsters that spawn out of nowhere and open a few strange chests buried into the ground that give you items you barely know the purpose of, you see a black platform with horns so you approach it and use it, it spawns a large and powerful creature that kills you almost instantly. you begin another run and this time you kill more monsters and collect more chests and finally finish the first boss, Now next level, rinse and repeat, become stronger, become deadlier... and still die to stage 3 or 4 boss. learning curve in this game is insanely fun and rewarding, Everytime you reach a level you havent been to before you feel like you are exploring uncharted territory and its such an awesome feeling, the base game has so much content in it and dlcs add so much more, Lots of characters to unlock, more than 100 items that can drop and the collection grows as you play, in runs, if you get lucky it gets to a point where you become unstoppable, but that takes alot of work and scavenging which the game punishes by making the world grow stronger the more time you spend in it. 

The aesthetics of the game are one of a kind, the graphics style is very interesting blend of simple textures with beautiful effects. The OST in this game is Probably one of the best OST's ive ever heard in a roguelike, or in a game in general, the soundtracks really capture the feeling of each level, it really makes you feel like you are on a planet infested with powerful aliens, not many game ost's ive heard do that kind of stuff

if you see this review, buy this game if you love collecting alot of things and seeing yourself get stronger, if the price tag is not so pretty to you then consider going on CDkeys.com or G2A and buying the game from there, this one is a must have for all steam players

The best game that ive played in my life so far, every single mechanic feels great and the game is overall just a blast.

I can't even begin to describe the love I have for this game. I walked into this game almost a month ago, and it already feels like I've played it since launch (which I very much haven't).
Risk of Rain 2 is a fucking masterpiece. Every part of this game- every sound, every enemy, every song, every item, just reflects how much love the devs poured into it. It truly embodies the definition of a passion project, built from the ground up by 2 dudes who love what they do.

The art style is very unique in the best way possible, and when I learned that Duncan Drummond, the person who directed ALL OF THE ART, learned 3D modeling specifically for ROR2, I just fell in love with it more. Chris Christodoulou, the music director, had no business making the soundtrack like he did. The emotion put into every single track is incredible; the music for Commencement, "...con lentitud poderosa" genuinely almost had me in tears after piecing together the lore for the first time. It's unbelievable the amount of emotion that piece conveys.
Of course, the ENTIRE team over at Hopoo Games (4 people, by the way) all deserve equal credit for this stunning experience, the art and musical direction is just what immediately jumps out at the player.

The skill ceiling is incredibly high, but it never truly feels like it, as the game is just that intuitive. It really is a "get good lmao" style game, but the brutal way it teaches you its ins-and-outs is, in my opinion, the farthest thing from rage-inducing. Every death has only you to blame, and every success has only you to credit. This is one of the only games I think I have ever taken seriously and 100%'ed. Every achievement has a purpose, whether silly, lore-heavy, or useful. The unlocks and item descriptions genuinely made me care for the characters, whether I liked them or not. I was actually invested in the lore without reading someone's summary, and for a roguelike, that's really cool to me. The world you've created, Hopoo, is, for lack of better words, really fucking cool, dude.

At the time of writing, the 'Survivors Of The Void' DLC is days away from launch, and I have nothing but extremely high hopes for what's to come. I genuinely don't care how much content is in it, because I have faith that the developers put genuine love and care into their game, just as they have in the past.

Overall, 10/10 game. Hands down. That's so rare for me to type out, but DAMN does this game check every single box for me. What can I say? I fell in love with the story behind (and of) Risk of Rain 2. This is one of the only games I genuinely have nothing negative to say about, as crazy as that sounds. I am extremely excited for the direction this game, and any other Hopoo Games project, takes in the future. There's still many more hours of gameplay that I need to dump into this, there's no way in hell I can drop this game even after 100% completion.
