The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy

His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.

The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.

A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.

The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.

However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.

Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.

It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.

Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.

When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.

Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.

Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.

If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.

For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.

For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.

They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider’s landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.

The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.

A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted

A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.

This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.

The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it.

A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower.

Everything about this game is great. It's rare to have a rogue-like game where after meeting an unfortunate fate on a run you immediately want to start a new one. The one game that's given me that sort of replay value is The Binding of Isaac. All the different character load outs force you to play in different ways. You'll end up discovering certain item combinations that are absolutely busted on certain characters and absolutely horrible on others. Though your first couple of runs you'll end up dying before getting past the first stage, it won't matter, you'll try again to get further. The gameplay is fluid as can be. The art style is endearing in its own way. The music is also amazing. The community has very welcoming members, giving advice on how to get better or helping you cope after a heartbreaking defeat at a possible E8 win with Commando after realizing elite Clay Templars do way too much damage. The devs have put in a great deal of effort into this game and community and it shows. This is one the best games I've played in years, seriously. New DLC will be coming out March 1st and I'll be more than happy to buy it. These devs deserve every penny. Can't wait to see what Survivors of the Void brings to the table. Here's to another couple hundred hours on this game!

RoR2 has a phenomenal way of making you feel overpowered then robbing you of that feeling in less than a second when an elite Elder Lemurian appears in front of you and rocks your shit.
RoR2 boasts a simplistic yet highly pleasing artstyle as you traverse the many areas of Petrichor V in a frenzied fight for survival. This game is a kind of a dungeon crawler like Isaac or Gungeon, but as a third person shooter and in premade areas instead of randomly generated rooms, though loot and enemy placements are random. In fact, an AI controls enemy placements during play, meaning the game is literally trying to kill you. RoR2 has an engaging level of strategy alongside the randomness, however, as you attempt to figure out what items are worth the risk and which items you should take or share with your friends to increase your odds. And all of this is on a timer, as the game gets harder with each second you waste. Great alone and with friends, though it can get a little frustrating with randos, plus it's still being supported with updates and DLCs. 9 bustling fungi out of 10.

This is probably the most I've played a game in such a condensed time frame. Concept is simple enough - a roguelike shooter where you choose a class and pick up powerups and the enemies get increasingly harder over time with boss fights at the end of each stage. It's kind of like TF meets Dead Cells except if Dead Cells offered powerups. 

I was hooked almost immediately. I love roguelikes so it's no surprise there. The variety of classes (at least the 7 or so I have access to now) provide a decent amount of variety, though I personally think the Captain is a bit OP. I was getting frustrated with the final boss as he seemed nearly impossible to beat as a solo player - then I discovered how many areas I either missed or ignored by not exploring enough and found a few classes and the ultimate savior - Artifacts. Once I got my hands on the artifact that allows you to choose your powerups rather than getting random ones I could build my survivor the way I wanted - to the point they were ridiculously powerful enough to take down bosses in a matter of seconds. Weapons, powerups, and enemy variety and environments are well varied.

I definitely recommend this, even at full price.
Endless amounts of modding and replayability makes RoR2 one of the best rougelikes I've played. Cheers to the devs!

[u] [b]I'm going to play Devil's Advocate for this game[/b] [/u]
However I'm not saying that it's bad. It's enjoyable as a casual experience, heightened by co-op if that's accessible to you.
I merely want to remind others how Hopoo mishandled the launch, and throw in some personal takes about the new mechanics.

[u] [b]Where Hopoo disappointed[/b] [/u]

[b] Unfinished Final Level [/b]

Risk of Rain 2 released in an unfinished state. The final level was quite possibly the biggest showcase of this: there was an entire section of the level that would softlock your run if you went to it, there was little to no point in not rushing to the boss; making the entire level feel like one giant linear path with nothing worthwhile in it, enemies be damned.

The softlock was fixed a few days after, it's still unacceptable it was released in that state at all. It was simply unfinished even after the fact. And it took them half a year to rework it all.

[b] Item Logs & Skills [/b]

Many item logs didn't exist during launch. Item logs are a huge part of Risk of Rains' identity, every item had a story behind it; and it was a lot fun sitting down to read them all, especially when you wanted to see how the lore escalated from the previous game.

Skills were another thing: quite a few survivors had locked skills that were promised when they were shown to be locked in-game. Showing that, eventually, it would be added. Guess what?
Hopoo removed those skills, and anything that implied they existed.
Not even a mention about how they didn't go through with them, just gone. Content promised, removed.

[u] [b] New Mechanics: Lunar Items & Skills (Again) [/b] [/u]

Lunar Items & Coins. Cross-run progression doesn't work for this game. Coins aren't fun to obtain since they're obtained by playing the game normally as anyone would. 
Lunar Items are not fun to obtain, because there's no challenge in obtaining them outside of activating shrines; which may or may not be accessible depending on if you have mobility items in your run, what stage it is, where the shrine on the stage spawned.

Portals appearing randomly after looping to take you to the store also. Lunar buds being a rare spawn. It all feels too random.

It's awful not being able to buy a lunar item, or even access the store because you don't have enough coins. Missing out on an item pool that could improve your run sucks. All because it was out of your control to have enough coins, or even be able to go to the Lunar Bazaar.

[b] Skills [/b]

This is the worst offender. Alternate skills should have been sidegrades; but they're not. Many of them are objectively better than each other. Most of the alternate skills are better, making it feel like you're missing out on a better run since you don't have them unlocked.

Take for example: Bandit's Serrated Dagger, a melee skill on a squishy ranged unit being replaced by Serrated Shiv. A ranged attack that does the exact same thing, except with the benefit of attacking at range, out of harm's way.

[u] [b] Conclusion [/b] [/u]

There is a lot in ROR2 that misses the mark that I've come to realize after putting in the hours I did to 100% it.
I mostly wrote this to get it off my chest, and remind some people how Hopoo mishandled its launch.
If the new DLC somehow improves upon the game, or the base game receives updates, I might change this review to reflect that.

Oh and don't forget Hopoo signed a deal for a timed Stadia exclusive stage. Content exclusive to a single platform is scummy, even if it is timed. (Though I would preferred if it stayed that way since the stage is awful all around. But my point still stands)

The graphics and art direction are cohesive and pretty, the lead-up to fighting the final boss was awe-inspiring, Huntress and Bandit have fun base skill kits, the secrets are impressive and there's some enemy types I really liked going up against.

Besides that? I was waffling on whether or not to refund once I hit the 1 hour mark because I had a pretty strong idea of why I could regret purchasing Risk of Rain 2. I think the title is reasonably-priced but I'm kicking myself for not trusting my gut instinct about its initial feel.

My biggest gripe with ROR2 is repetition. Unlike other games in the genre, there's no procedural level generation, so as captivating and fun to explore as the locations can be on your first few runs, they wore out for me fast. Even with extreme grinding each class has limited kit choices compared to other ARPGs, so my potential excitement for unlocking things was low to begin with and even lower when I found out how hard I would have to try just to unlock a handful of different abilities. The multitude of ways you could build a Barbarian alone in a classic like Diablo 2 puts this title to shame. The dizzying array of loot soon switched from interesting to annoying for me as I figured out which ones I didn't want and which items I was hungry for but was denied due to RNG. I was especially bored when I didn't unlock movement speed items as I didn't want to run at a realistic pace through large levels that I was tired of traversing. The enemy variety is decent but with only so many ways to fight, even their great silhouettes and gimmicks quickly become shallow. Unlike other incredibly-repetitive games like Deep Rock Galactic, there aren't a host of different game modes or activities to do - you loot, you fight a handful of bosses, ad nauseam. I ended up just wanting to fight the final boss hundreds of times until I finally figured him out but that would have meant slogging through the rest of the game each time, which I didn't want to touch any more. 

My other key gripe is the classes. Bandit and Huntress were the only ones I liked of the ones I unlocked as the kits and base weapons of the others were boring. Even then, holding down primary fire with Huntress' bow became a slog as it deals relatively little damage without sufficient power-ups. While the rush of shotgunning things from behind, going invisible, slashing close enemies and all as Bandit felt great, the repetition of the rest of the game eventually ruined even that for me. I usually love grenade launchers like with Demoman of TF2 or Junkrat of Overwatch, but Engineer's was underwhelming. The same went for the robot's gun options, people are still making slow-travel bullets in games? On a machinegun no less? The reptile was interesting but since he was weak against fliers I didn't want to use him. The final nail in the coffin was how floaty and devoid of impact Loader felt. She was the one I was looking forward to the most as Brick was the entire reason I played Borderlands, so being stuck with stupid Skyrim-eqsue haymaker punches as primaries when I wanted rapid jabs was deeply disappointing.

Overall a mixed bag that relies too heavily on RNG to make up for mostly-shallow waters.

It feels... odd. This isn't the first rogue-like/high learning curve game i've played, in fact its not even close to the first. It is, however, the first game i think that ive ever played that punishes you for taking your time and being thorough. I absolutely hate the moving difficulty slider. It feels so incredibly unfair that difficulty scales rather quickly just because you want to enjoy the game. There would be nothing wrong if the difficulty was raised every level, or even as time passes within a level, but then move to a hardcoded difficulty once you go to the next level. Easily the worst problem i have with the game.
Still worth the money though its very enjoyable.

Edit at 217 hours played: Has now become one of my favorite games. My previous complaint about the time moving the difficulty is now something I'm fine with, it felt out of my element at first but it pushes the player and still causes the game to be very difficult to beat on harder difficulties and impossible to perfect.

At the time of writing this, the large-scale DLC for this game is only about a week and a half away, and I wanted to post this in order to convince people I know to buy this thing, because I'll tell you, it's worth it. This is the highly-acclaimed sequel to hit indie game Risk of Rain, which has improved over the original in almost every aspect. I'm going to start off by saying that this is likely my most favorite game on Steam right now, so expect about 0% bias in this review.

If you're unaware as to what the gameplay of this game is like, it's essentially a multiplayer 3D survival 3rd-person shooter (or melee even) rougelike game and, yeah, that's a beautiful mouthful of words right there. Upon picking a class to play as (more on that later), you crash onto an alien planet and it's up to you and your friends to stay alive from there while every creature in sight tries to kill you. The more you kill, the more money you get, and you use that to open loot boxes scattered around the area which provide you with a random item. Items basically give you passive buffs or abilities which make your character stronger the more you have, so the goal is to get as many as you can before the timer at the top of the screen gradually increases the difficulty. There are several types of enemies and items, but, again, I'll touch on that later on. You'll spawn into a randomly picked stage and to get to the next one, you need to locate a teleporter, activate it, fight a boss, and then proceed. You do this until you get to stage 5, where you can either head to the final boss or choose to loop through another 5 stages to get even more buffs. There are currently 3 ways to end your run, those being death, defeating the final boss, or mysteriously vanishing in a way I won't spoil.

The first thing that really stood out to me about this game was the fact that you can stack any item in the game (save for special activation items) theoretically an infinite amount of times. Examples of such include having 100 double jumps or 100% critical strike chance. Not only that, but each item is pretty fun, unique, and game-changing in its own right. There's essentially an item for anything and countless amounts of character builds and synergies are possible. Plus, the developers are continuing to add more and more of them into the game. There are different tiers of items you can find, and they are ranked by rarity. Common items are pretty basic in effect and really just change one stat or effect one happenstance, while uncommon items focus more on synergy with other items and change your playstyle a little more. Then there are legendary items which are all just kind of broken and overpowered and will synergize strongly with other items. Other tiers exist as well, which include items from bosses that give you a bit of their power, equipment items which function as a 5th skill, lunar items which are weird because they are bought from a special shop with a special currency and provide both a strong buff and debuff so I don't wanna go into all that, and more to come.

Arguably the most exciting part of this game are the survivor classes. There are a total of eleven (soon to be thirteen) classes in this game and all of them play in their own way. Each one is so very different and can range from a spaceman with guns to a robot to a lightsaber ninja to a poisonous dog. It's good to set out with several different classes at once in multiplayer so that everyone can support each other in their own unique way. Every single character is fun to play and all of them are functionally and aesthetically cool (likely objectively). You can really pick anybody to find a style for you. Even more variety can be found in unlockable alternate skills (which you only have 4 types of) that change how you can play this game even more, as well as what item build you go with.

A few other things to touch on before I wrap things up. There are loads of enemy types and bosses, which I'd say are all never really redundant, along with the possibility for stronger versions to spawn. The stages are pretty nice, especially their individual vibes, although some are simpler to navigate and fight in than others. Several secrets and easter eggs are scattered throughout levels, items, or actions you take which can add a bit of spice to your runs. If you're into lore or story in any way, the game doesn't necessarily feed it to you, however you may find a good amount of that in log entries and such which you find across playing the game. Lastly, the OST in this game is absolutely S+++ tier, my man Chris Christodoulou is making music for the wrong evolutionary stage of humans on this planet.

There are some more features in this game, and even more coming in the future, but I don't really feel the need to touch on them here. Plus, there are just several factors and things that go into runs, which make each one stand out on its own from the rest of them. This game is so damn amazing. I only want to play it more and I'm never going to grow tired of it. It gives you that high-action, adrenaline-pumping, occasionally funny, absolutely absurd, groovy, and ingenious kind of gameplay you need to make you feel like a certified god gamer, if you're into that sort of thing. Please buy it and play it with your friends, you will all have so much fun.

Very fun! While there aren't many kinds of enemies, or many unique maps, or even a massive range of characters to play as, the game has insane replayability! The RoR2 not only makes up for this, but incorperates it into the story and gameplay, making the parts that are a bit repetitive interesting. But the amazing thing is, the game doesn't even need to "make up for" repetitive bits too often. Each run is different and unique, the RNG can be frustrating but in the grand scheme of things is wonderfully well balanced, the characters don't overlap in practically any way, with each providing a different playstyle and experience, and probably the best feature: across almost every run you unlock something new or discover something new you can unlock. The game is beautifully balanced, fun to play, and will keep you engaged for a long time. I will say, each run takes a considerable amount of time once you get used to the game, with my current runs lasting anywhere from 90-270 minutes long. While the game does a wonderful job of keeping you engaged almost every second of the run, there is no way to save and quit in the middle of a run, meaning if you need to take a break beyond pausing, you're going to have to end your run. 
TL;DR: Great game that stays fun, but be prepared to pour considerable time into each sitting.

This game is awesome and I love it. I've discovered a ton of the secret stuff on my own and I love every second of this game. It's an amazing game that I recommend to anyone. I actually enjoyed it so much that the day I bought it and tried it out, I bought it for a friend of mine to try as well.

Edit: The DLC "Survivors of the Void" came out and it's a seamless, beautiful expansion to this game. I adore it even more and I can't wait to keep playing. I recommend the base game and the DLC wholeheartedly. I am getting my money's worth and more with this series.

game good, me explain

graphics: 
This game has some of the most well made design, animation and models i have ever seen in an indie game. The cell-shaded art style is amazing, the animations are really good, and the models have such a unique and fitting style for the game. 7 points for graphics.

music:
I am a massive fan of game OSTs and this one is the best ost i have ever heard since subnautica below zero's "mirage machine". This game features some absolute bangers such as "the rain formerly known as purple" (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EGXPAoyP_cg) and has made its way into my playlist. Instant 9 points for the music fuckin slapping.

gameplay: 
This game is generally the most fun roguelike since i played noita. This game is honestly an amazing experience, alone or with friends. It has many different characters and maps, items and loadouts. It is honestly, in a way, beautiful how one person can combine all these different factors into the ultimate killing machine. This game is amazing, the movement is smooth and really good, the items are (sort of) fair and balanced, and later in the game it has a sort of chaotic feel to it. I rate this 9 points, because im not a masochist.

general vibe:
This game is fuckin awesome, mainly because the feel of being on an alien planet, destroying everything in your way while gradually becoming stronger gives such an amazing feeling, and a massive dopamine rush once you get that item you've just been looking for. The song changes along with the fight, similar to how Pikmin 3's music changes all the time. General vibe is id say 8 points.

issues:
Of course, with a game of this quality it's not going to be perfect. Its a great game, but it has it's flaws. The first (and most complained about flaw) is how it is on consoles but it does not have crossplay. This is very sad, as the multiplayer aspect of the game is extremely fun. Another issue is the balancing, the class Engineer is very helpful to the squad but not much fun to play, while the Captain is fuckin orgasmic to play and is super overpowered. This isnt really a big issue tho. I think a larger issue is the secrets. You have to unlock the characters, items and modifiers. This offers a lot to do in the games, but you have to end up scouring the entire map before giving up and turning to the wiki for help. The secrets in this game are not as hard as Noita's secrets, but are very similar. -3 points for all that.

all in all:
This game is fucking amazing and i have never felt as blessed since i got factorio. I play this with my friends, and its only fuckin 4 gigabytes somehow. solid 30 points. i would buy it no matter what games you like.

The Francesinha is a Portuguese sandwich that originates from Porto. The literal translation for its name is ‘Little French Girl’, however, the only thing little about it, is the name. It’s a rather large sandwich filled with layers of beef steak, cured meat, fresh sausages, topped with cheese, covered with a beer sauce, and surrounded by French fries. It’s a meat and carb heavy meal that is believed to be a Portuguese adaptation of the French classic, the Croque-Monsieur. Multiple cafés, restaurants, and bars claim the title of having the best francesinha in Porto and it’s a hotly contested title.

Ingredients:
For the Sauce:

1tsp olive oil
1tbsp lard
1 small onion – thinly sliced
2 garlic cloves – roughly chopped
1 bay leaf
1 tin of diced tomatoes
400ml beef stock
½ cup ruby port wine
500ml blonde beer
1 piri-piri seedless
2tbsp Worcester sauce
Salt
Black pepper
For the Francesinha

2 slices of soft bread
1 thin beef steak – tenderized
1 pork sausage
1 cured pork sausage – linguiça
2 slices of ham
5 slices of cheese
1 egg
Preparation
Place a medium saucepan over low to medium heat. Once the pan is hot, add the lard, olive oil, garlic, and bay leaf. Let it cook for a minute before adding the onion. Let it simmer for about 8 minutes until the onion turns translucent.
Add the tinned tomatoes and the beef stock. Bring it to a boil and let it simmer for about 10 minutes.
Add the remaining sauce ingredients: port wine, beer, piri-piri and Worcestershire sauce, cook for another 10 minutes.
With a hand mixer, blend everything until smooth. Let the sauce simmer for 30 minutes. The texture should be similar to a gravy, but slightly more liquid.
If necessary, add some corn starch or other thickening to your taste. Make sure to dissolve it in cold water before adding to the mixture. Let it cook until it reaches your preferred texture.
Season it with salt and black pepper, set it aside.
Place a frying pan over high heat. Meanwhile, cut the sausages in half then butterfly-cut them.
Fry the sausages in their own fat, then use the remaining fat to fry the steak. Finally, lightly fry the ham slices.
Gently toast the bread slices. Start putting the Francesinha together: On a plate, place one bread slice, then a slice of cheese, ham, steak, the sausages, and the final bread slice.
Fry the egg, place it on top of the sandwich, cover it with the cheese slices, leaving the egg-yolk visible.
Bring the sauce to a boil, then spoon it on top of the sandwich. The hot sauce will melt the cheese. Serve it either with a side of French fries, or surrounded by fries if your plate is big enough!

[b] The Risk of Rain 2 experience [/b]

Good parts:
 - Learning not to die on stage 1
 - Beating the final boss for the first time
 - Playing on monsoon and feeling like a noob again
 - Replaying over and over to unlock all skins, abilities, items and lore entries
 - Finding amazing item combos that make you feel unstoppable
 - Joking with your friends about beating stage 100

Bad parts:
 - Trying not to rage while dying on stage 1
 - Failing the final boss 98 times before you beat it
 - Playing on monsoon and trying not to rage again
 - Grinding for days to unlock everything
 - Finding amazing item combos that make you feel unstoppabl- die to a lemurian
 - Actually beating stage 100

Keep an eye out for the upcoming DLC expansion pass; Survivors Of The Void!

Very enjoyable roguelike, just as good (if not better) than it's predecessor.

Good variety of classes to choose from, all with unique / distinctive playstyles. Multiple artefacts to unlock that have the capacity to make your runs different / more interesting. Large variety of items to find and unlock, along with codex entries.

Risk of Rain, both the original and the sequel are top of the pack for me, mainly due to just how strong you can become. The game doesn't go out of it's way to limit your potential in a run, items can stack like crazy and you can become a death dealing god, dancing on the graves of your enemies as you rain down even more destruction.

It's a fun ride, and the inclusion of co-op in this sequel makes for an amplified experience the original couldn't provide despite just how fantastic of a game it is / was.

My only complaint, which isn't really a complaint, is that I prefer the music of the first game more. Chris has nailed both OSTs, Risk of Rain 2 also has an amazing soundtrack, by my preference does lie with the first game as far as music goes.

This game. It was probably one of the better games I have picked up in the past few years. 

The simple gameplay loop of hopping in a stage, get items, fight boss and repeat this is just great. The base game it fun enough to keep a few hours but need a bit of mods. But even so there is a lot to diverge with it. If you arent going to get the item cheats mod the challenge of playing through to get all of the achievements adds a tone of repeatability with their game. 

The characters are a lot of fun to play but without everything unlocked does limit your use of the characters but if you don't mind cheating it in it makes use of the characters feel refreshing. Even modded characters are great to play that well have quality. That is one of the main issues with modded characters but they are not obviously needed. Now with the two new characters coming out soon it will make it even more refreshing.

Now the items are really annoying. Some are great and useful to many characters or some items are just bad on some character or are just bad in general. Most of the greens are not useful for most situations, bandoleers, stealth kit, squid turrets, and tome are some items you want to avoid. I am glad printers and scrappers are a thing because I will never want to keep these items for long and will find a scrapper. Now whites vary from the only real bad items I would say is Bison Stake an Warbanner. Thats it but even then some items are only great of some characters and bad on others. But white items are more versatile. But my point is that i hate how there are bad items where I think there should be good items rather then conditional items. 

Now the DLC could help with some of the items can help the good items and make the bad ones irrelavent or really replace them but who knows. 

Mods all be it not needed but mods that add new items or characters can make it refreshing. Item mods can make builds cool and add verity to base game characters. Then the modded characters ad more verity to it and the ones that are actually good and not the anime ones or other game characters, the paladin, miner, and the two enforcers the normal and the nemesis enforcer both being unique. Here is to hope that older characters and new characters to the game in the future.

Awesome roguelike looter shooter. Lots of characters and items and artifacts to unlock through unique circumstances. All the characters play differently and none feel bad, just less to your playstyle. You go through each level finding a teleporter than spawns the boss and lets you pass to the next level, at the 5th level you can loop back to the start or go to the final level. Enemies get stronger and more numerous with time. Absolutely enormous replayability with the possible builds, secrets, and it's one of the best multiplayer experiences I've had in years. All the unlocks are really challenging and yet not so challenging as to feel unobtainable without seriously grinding to get better. One thing I thought would take a long toime for me to do (get to a certain level at a certain speed) I ended up just getting by chance on my next run. Recommend at full price, if you see this on sale do not skip it.

The gameplay loop is amazing. If you're into lore like me, this game does so much with so little. Somehow this game pulls off insane amounts of depth with small bits and pieces of story scattered around here and there. Granted this game is not story based what so ever, or at least it can ignored entirely if that's what you're all about. Either way I would describe the atmosphere is "Etheral", and "highly addicting" is how I would describe the gameplay. Lastly, the audio track is so incredibly good. The game doesn't revolve around the soundtrack but when you do notice the songs in the background you can't help but admire the sound design. This game has given me so many memories and I suggest you definitely get this game if you are considering it or it goes on sale.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The original Risk of Rain was one of my first experiences in PC Indie Gaming, and it left quite an impression on me. From its stylistic character design, to the 2d side-scrolling ability spam fest, and an ending with music so beautifully appropriate it ended up permanently etched into my mind. So, when Hopoo Games, a studio of 4!!!! Individuals announced they were making a 2nd game and it would be 3d, I was all for it. I haven't written a review for this game yet, but I've owned it since it was first available in early access and with its first DLC on the horizon I think its time. Theirs a lot of reasons why I think this game is one of my favorites, and why it succeeds so much over its predecessor, which in its own right is fantastic:

The transition from 2d to 3d while keeping its style is incredible. From the ability usage, to the items, it all feels amazing as your character transcends into a beast until you either beat the game or loop until you die.
With the items you can feel that rush of getting a red on stage 1, or simply feeling happy at finally getting those damn crit glasses for when you desperately need one. Every item serves a purpose that benefits you in a very direct, observable way.
Plenty of secrets to unlock and explore, from hidden stages, characters, and items, it can keep you busy for a long time.
A wide variety of characters that all allow for a distinct play-style while also having switchable abilities that changes elements of their kit. 
It is one of the best soundtracks that I've ever heard. From the active teleporter boss jams, to the quiet serenity of the earlier stages, to the absolutely fantastic finale of [i] ...con lentitud poderosa [/i] it's an incredible listening experience, every time.
Easily accessible coop through steam, alongside the new addition of challenge modes for people who want that extra difficulty or variety in their runs, 

So, should YOU buy this game? 100%. Play a few rounds on your own to get the hang of it, then once you inevitably get hooked, tell all your friends to buy it, and jam out with them. Your music will be electric.

TL:DR/ 
Risk of Rain 2 is an excellent 3rd person rogue-like game with immense amounts of replay value and overall variety, and I enjoy both solo and multiplayer experiences.  What sets it apart from other rogue-likes is the risk/reward of spending time gearing up; the clock is always running and the difficulty constantly increases.  When nearing endgame difficulty there is some chaos on-screen including drones, ally creatures, item effects, enemy mobs, and a lot of explosions.  Your Survivor will eventually amass item combos so busted that elite boss mobs vaporize when an effect procs just once.  Story takes a backseat to gameplay (the game's lore is tied to Logbook entries) with an interesting focus on player agency; if you don't die there are different ways to end a run, but you can also keep a run going potentially forever.  Create personalized runs with different modifiers and adjust your character ability loadouts.  This game has several secrets to discover as well.  

If you're looking for a curated, complete package of gameplay and story then I would recommend Hades first.  That being said, Risk of Rain 2 does so many things right.  Honestly even if story is an important feature this game is still a must-play.  Highly, highly recommended.


\\\\\\\\\\\\\\

Premise and Overview/  

Pick a Survivor, set your ability loadout, and then start the run.  Your escape pod lands on a mysterious planet where everything wants to murder you.  You begin with only a base set of abilities that have cooldowns.  Each Survivor has unique abilities, passive perks, starting items, and different play styles.    Kill enemies to earn money and gain experience levels, open capsules to get cash, and use your accrued funds to open chests littered around each stage.  Each chest can drop an item of variable rarity that gives minor bonuses to movement/sprint speed, extra jumps, extra health, additional ability charges, extra boss damage, and lots more.  Legendary items grant unique effects such as: electrocuting any nearby enemies, reduce ability cooldowns by X%, revive your character on death, and many other benefits well worth chasing.  Almost every bonus/effect stacks and many items synergize extremely well.  There are also stations with 3 item choices and a 3D printer that produces item X if you feed it scrap or randomly sacrifice your own items.  
Move quickly to gear up and clear each stage by charging the local teleporter.  Kill the boss that appears, go through the portal, rinse and repeat.  As you spend time roaming around each stage you will notice an in-game timer with a difficulty slider that is constantly going higher (Easy >> Medium >> Hard >> .... ).  Clearing individual stages also advances the difficulty slider further.  Harder enemies have increased experience levels, higher damage and health, can become elites with additional elemental modifiers (think 'Cold-Enchanted' or 'Stone Skin' mobs in D2), and then they spawn almost constantly around you.  Spend too long in each stage without an equalizing set of items and you can die really fast.  

Each run is a shifting balance of your priorities and time management.  Should you spend the extra 5 minutes to farm enough money for a Legendary chest?  Legendary (red) items are very worthwhile but 5 minutes on Monsoon difficulty can make a big difference in the early game.  Keep in mind that money converts to XP when you go through a portal; there is no way to stockpile funds between stages.  There is no currency to spend outside a run, and there are no permanent leveling systems to grind through.  Collect logbooks from enemies, items, and from each stage.  There is one persistent currency you can use but only during an active run; Lunar Coins randomly drop from enemies and can be earned by clearing the game.  
Otherwise, everything resets at the next run.  Stage routes, chest/altar locations, teleporter bosses, and minor stage topography are randomized every time.  Several stages have a very consistent layout, though.

\\\\\\\\\\\\\\

Points of Interest/ 

High]

- Insanely fun gameplay loop and core mechanics; most of my runs have been a blast even when I failed miserably.  Discovering new item and ability synergies is always fantastic.
- Stellar replay value; there are many in-game items and Survivor abilities which are locked behind challenges.  Unlocked Survivor abilities allow for alternate loadouts, and unlocked items will start appearing in the world drop pool.  The challenges are attainable and fun to pursue for the most part.  You can also end your run in specific ways aside from dying.  There are secret stages and Artifacts to collect if you want to modify the game in substantial ways (ex: making all enemies elite; fall damage becomes fatal).
- Good music overall (if you enjoy moody, dense synth).
- RoR2 runs don't have to be huge time investment; expect to spend at least 20 minutes for a successful run but it can extend way beyond that amount if you want.


Neutral]

- Multiplayer is very fun and easy to join, but if you die during a run then you have to wait until your group enters the next stage.  In the meantime you miss all XP and item drops because you are stuck in a spectator mode limbo.  It was common for me to revive on the next stage several levels behind my friends, and with only a fraction of their inventory.  I don't love it but I can understand why this mechanic is in place.
- Story is very minimal (whether this is a pro or con will depend on your preference).  As I stated before, there is a Logbook in the main menu where you can view any of the entries that you've collected throughout your runs.  The lore is interesting but limited if you're looking for extensive world-building.  I didn't play Risk of Rain 1 so I can't compare the two games here or judge how well they connect with each other.  Risk of Rain 2 sacrifices narrative for crazy action and a customized experience.  


Low]

- Fall damage; only one Survivor is immune to it otherwise you will need a specific Legendary item.  I don't have a problem with fall damage as a mechanic but some enemies have abilities that rocket you into the air with little time to react.  On several occasions I was knocked so high up that I popped up through the ground and I lost most of my health.  Nothing major just annoying.  The game's physics are bit wonky too; if you have heavily boosted movement and sprint speed then you might just bump into random level geometry and then careen into space.  (Can be exploited to traverse stages without stacking your jump count.)
- Insufficient character control while descending from a jump.  Jumping itself feels floaty, not always precise at times.  The total jump count and speed of forward motion are both boosted by items, as usual, but there's a point in-between jumps (and when you're launched into the air) where your character falls slowly.  Too slowly, in my opinion.  One boss will capitalize on this; you can get juggled if their Captain Corridors don't kill you instantly.  Another issue that's mostly countered with a Legendary item but I wish the fall speed was faster overall.

\\\\\\\\\\\\\\

Bugs and game performance/


No bugs encountered so far.  Physics/collision can be goofy at times but nothing that completely negates a run.
The game has not crashed once in 150+ hours. 

I have a low-mid range PC that's several years old but it has no problems running this game at 1080p 60FPS.  When you ascend to nuking elite lv99 mobs there will be a lot of visual effects; I noted a few instances where my frame rates dropped below 5FPS because of that chaos.  Not frequent.

 I have to keep my graphic settings pretty low however that's not a deal-breaker for me because of the game's visual style.  Your mileage may vary.


\\\\\\\\\\\\\\
\\\\\\\\\\\\\\


Thank you for reading this review.  Hopefully it helps you make a decision one way or another.

Risk of Rain 2 is video game crack. It is a slow start much like many roguelikes but you'll soon find yourself becoming a fiend finding out the tiniest details of how to optimize your run and making your character as broken as humanly possible. This game also has the most fun grappling hook character in any game, Loader. Who knew combining the mechanics of Doomfist and Wrecking Ball from Overwatch could result in something so fun. RoR2 just does not pull any punches both with the enemy's power as well as yours. You can infinitely stack almost any item in the game resulting in runs where your character can shoot across the entire map with a single press of the W key. This game is just pure fun and I love every decision made for RoR2. Very excited for the DLC.

+ There's a lotta secrets to find and exploring is usually rewarded.

It's a really fun game. Depending on which survivor you choose, and many other things (such as if you use artifacts, what kind of items you get, how much time you spend collecting items), the style of gameplay can really vary and you can sink a lot of hours into the game just exploring the different possibilities. Around half of my playtime was spent trying to unlock various things and the other half was me just wanting to play the game and starting runs just for the fun of it. 

That being said, I would say that if I'm picking between this game and some other games with a similar idea, I often end up playing some other games just because in them, if I need to quit in the middle of the run, my "current" run gets saved and I can just get back into it whenever I find time. This is especially true for whenever I have a very limited time to play. Sadly there have been really epic runs that I had to end because I had other things to do and in Risk of Rain 2 leaving the run/going back to main menu means not being able to continue that run. The same has happened while playing with other people too. Usually we just wait to sacrifice ourselves as soon as possible, but one time we just tried to get ourselves killed by standing completely still because we were in a hurry (it did not work because we were too OP and we ended up just quitting instead)

But provided you have a few hours to play, and you want to have fun, this game is probably one of the best choices. It also has three difficulties to choose from, and as someone who's not very good at the game and who's stuck somewhere between easy and normal mode, I can say that no matter your skill level, you will be able to enjoy it.

Also the game having multiplayer is pretty cool and playing with friends can make it extra fun.

I'm still new to this game, but I have this much to say:

I think it's a rather slow rogue-like game. you hold down m1 most of the time for the first 3 initial basic classes and then click your other abilities a few times. not a particularly high skill ceiling given that you can't do headshots or little tricks like that. Most good runs heavily depend on RNG. It's not nearly as reactive as some other games that i've played.

Big cons for me: no story (which is common to this genre but doesn't help it), terrible difficulty curve (hard early and everything is super easy afterwards), and enemies are linear and boring/simplistic AI

However, the later classes do spice up the game a lot and make it more fun. The game developers also seem to be passionate and update the game quite a bit.

This game is genuinely one of the best games I have ever played. I was obsessed with the first one came out when I was a kid, and when this one came out I made my friends buy it so we could play together. I play some many games and get bored of them quickly, but this one never seems to lose my interest. There is so much to unlock, explore, and experience that it really is just mind blowing. Not to mention that if you complete the game and want more content, you can download a modloader to add a bunch more variety to the game. It makes it fun while waiting for the devs to come up with new and exciting content. 10/10 is too low of a score for this absolute MASTERPIECE of a game.

One of the rare games that actually feels like gamers made it. The game feels so good to play as any character and each ability suits a purpose without making it only useful in one situation. All unlocks are based on your skill to play the character so if you want to look snazzy, you're gonna need to put a few hours in. Addicting to get started with, but not so overwhelming to the point of the inability to turn it off. It's an amazing game and I could not recommend it more.

I love a game that isn't afraid to let you break it and this game not only allows it, but promotes.

If you like a game where no two runs really are the same, or just want a game to fool around in: you've found it.

I will say though, I dislike when a game doesn't tell you what the items actually do and just give you a "funny" description. Lucky for us this game has mod support, and oh boy do the mods enhance it ten fold. I mainly download QOL mods, but you can straight up add new unique characters and items with some of the mods available. 

In summary: great game, infinite replayability, mod support, and a wide selection of characters, abilities, and items to play around with.

Old Fashioned Pumpkin Pie

2 large eggs
1 large egg yolk
1/2 cup packed dark brown sugar
1/3 cup white sugar
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 teaspoons cinnamon
1 teaspoon ground ginger
1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
1/4 teaspoon ground cloves
1/8 teaspoon cardamom
1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest
2 cups pumpkin purée from a sugar pumpkin (see Recipe Note) OR 1 (15-ounce can) pumpkin purée (can also use puréed cooked butternut squash)
1 1/2 cups heavy cream or 1 (12-ounce) can evaporated milk
1 homemade pie crust, chilled or frozen (see pâte brisée recipe or our no-fail flaky pie crust recipe), or 2 pre-made pie shells

Preheat the oven:
Preheat your oven to 425°F.
Make the filling:
Beat the eggs in a large bowl. Mix in the brown sugar, white sugar, salt, spices — cinnamon, ground ginger, nutmeg, ground cloves, cardamom, and lemon zest.
Mix in the pumpkin purée. Stir in the cream. Beat together until everything is well mixed.
mixing pumpkin pie ingredients
pumpkin pie ingredients mixed well
adding cream to pumpkin pie puree
pumpkin pie filling ready to add to pie
Fill the pie shell and bake:
Pour the filling into an uncooked chilled or frozen pie shell. Bake at a high temperature of 425°F for 15 minutes.
Then after 15 minutes, lower the temperature to 350°F. Bake for 45 to 55 minutes more. The pie is done when a knife tip inserted in the center comes out wet but relatively clean. The center should be just barely jiggly.
(About half-way through the baking, you may want to put foil around the edges or use a pie protector to keep the crust from getting too browned.)
Note that the pumpkin pie will come out of the oven all puffed up (from the leavening of the eggs), and will deflate as it cools.
pumpkin pie in dish ready for baking
Baked Pumpkin Pie From Scratch
Cool the pie on a rack, then serve:
Cool the pumpkin pie on a wire rack for 2 hours.
Serve with whipped cream.

Honestly, I'm going to cut the overly long review stuff I usually do and keep this one short and sweet, because whether or not I recommend you play Risk of Rain 2 heavily depends on if you enjoy roguelikes in the first place.

You do? Play it. It's my favorite roguelike.
You don't? Play it anyway.

You have a variety of difficulty options both for accessibility and a nice challenge, a solid foundation, developers that engage with the community shockingly often, a whole list of items, survivors, artifacts and skills to unlock to keep you playing, heaps of content on the horizon, and one hell of a soundtrack to boot.
Not to mention the fact that the game has a thriving modding community, adding anything from an implementation of expanded lobby numbers to a VR mod complete with implementation of motion controls. It ain't quite Skyrim, but I'm sure you've seen people joke about how Goku is a survivor in Risk of Rain 2. And... yeah, he is.

Risk of Rain was a little difficult for me to recommend to friends, but I have no problem at all telling people to play Risk of Rain 2.

A really great rogue-like that makes you say "one more round". The premise is simple enough, find the teleporter and advance the stages. The catch is there is a time-bound difficulty increase, the longer you spend in a stage, the harder it becomes. Spend your time wisely to loot and gear up, while advancing the stages as quickly as possible. There are 11 playable characters as of right now and they have different mechanics/playstyle. Having fun with friends is the way to go but you can still enjoy it solo. To enhance the replay value, the game has tons of mods that adds new content or tweak the mechanics. No wonder it's so highly praised.

So customizable it puts tears to my eyes sometimes. It was already an amazing fun game that is infinitely playable, meaning that every run is VERY different from any other run. Plus the base game ALSO has amazing levels of customization. Plus Hopoo actually cares about the game.

There hasn't been a single game in my library that has made me so obsessed with than Risk of Rain 2. It's the only game I've actually been compelled to get all the achievements for. It's highly addicting and re-playable gameplay with a lot of possibilities for challenge always bring me back to it. Not only it's incredibly fun to play with friends, but also to play solo as well. And unlike other games, there's a lack of competitive sense to it, and I feel like that's what makes this game so great. Because it's community isn't about getting the highest rank or whatever but play together and see if together the best run can be achieved. It promotes teamwork and a sense of comradery not only with friends but with people online as well. Definitely recommending it if you want to play it with your friends.

First of all, I played Risk of Rain 1 before Risk of Rain 2 was even teased. I was huge into that game, it was so unique and interesting and I still don't think I've really played anything like that.

That being said, when Risk of Rain 2 was first released... I wasn't excited.
You see, I'm one of those weird hipsters that likes pixel indie games. I'm not very good at third or first-person shooters and (at the time, before I studied it in university) I didn't care for 3D graphics.

But Jesus, man. This game is just GOOD.

It's weird, it feels like it is simultaneously Risk of Rain 1 with just more content- but at the same time, it feels like it completely reinvented the idea.

This game has very charming graphics. It has a nice style that doesn't care about realism and instead leans into the cartoony feeling that gives it such a nice hold against many modern shooters. The lore of this game keeps you thinking and wanting to know more.

But ultimately, it's just fun. It's really, really fun. If you're a rogue-like fan like me consider putting down Binding of Isaac for just a bit and give this game one run.

You won't regret it.

So this game essentially feels like that time in school where that one kid reminded the teacher that the homework was due that day riiiight before the bell rang, so you had the whole class chasing after you.

Except, you're that kid, and the critters that are after you are the rest of the class. As you traverse each level, you find yourself being chased by other classes, as the news starts spreading. Eventually, the seniors come after you too for being such a frickin nerd. Mithrix is basically that other buff kid that steals your lunch money, and he is NOT happy. In fact, he is asking you for an extra $1.55 to afford a delicious apple juice instead of those cruddy milk boxes that have those corny cow jokes on the side.

My point? This game is awesome, and you get to beat the heck out of that kid trying to steal your lunch money, or not (skill issue).

This is one of the most fun games I have played in while. If you played risk of rain 1, this is pretty much the same game but as a 3rd person shooter and let me tell you it is only to the benefit of the series. The game offers a superb combination of casual and challenging runs (mostly challenging). And a very unique and fun way of powering up your character as you find more seemingly random items to affix to your character. 

Not necessarily a complaint with the game but there are a relatively small number of levels they have (currently), and they are not procedurally generated (but does randomly close off sections), this of course does reward players for exploring and memorizing where high value loot is hiding. Just unusual for a roguelike.  The price is on point, you get a very well made game for ~$20 and it supports a small developer that is set on making more content in the future. 
I cannot wait to see what this game and others Hopoo games plans to make in the future. (check out Deadbolt, by them as well)

A surprisingly fun yet simple game, Risk of Rain 2 is an action-packed game that I can't stop coming back to. Risk of Rain 2 is a somewhat simple game with a short story, you play through the game on short "runs" that you can take on alone or with up to three friends. Gameplay involves fighting off hordes of enemies and bosses, and collecting items to help you survive. However, you are always on the clock though, literally, there is a timer on the screen at all times that is linked with the difficulty. The longer you play, the harder it gets. The game length on an average run is typically 30 minutes to an hour. Nevertheless, this game is surprisingly dense and packed with content and secrets to make it feel almost infinitely replayable. There are many ways to customize your gameplay, such as changing a few of the game's rules using "Artifacts", or with many unlockable items and characters / loadouts that you can unlock via progressing through the game and collecting achievements by completing challenges, you can utilize these to easily make an infinitely long run. There are plenty of things to keep you busy in this game. This game can be surprisingly unforgiving towards newer players, however this game made me feel strongly accomplished as I got better. 

Not for everyone, but definitely for me.

8.5/10

I played the first game for a bit and it loved it. The sequel is just as strong and I have been both games a lot recently. I wouldnt say its a game where if your on fence I would say just take the plunge, but more than likley if you are on the fence you will like it. All the characters are unique and diverse so although the starting commando may not be your cup of tea, you will find someone in the roster that fits with you, mine is artificer.

Time does not seem to play as much of a role in 2 compared to the first, still very important, but does seem a little less important with side events and realms to explore that freeze time and drop loot. Not a bad thing, but something I noticed I will point out.

Both games are great and where most rougelikes can barely keep me playing after 10 or so hours, I still come back to the first and dont even feel close to done with the second as of rn.

Fine game. Many characters to choose from, amazing visual style, great soundtrack. BUT, despite having a lot of items most builds on every character end up being crit+speed+proc chains. Some enemies have ridiculous spawn rate and spawn in swarms making killing them a chore. Others (elite enemies) are just bullet sponges and force you to pick some particular items to make killing them less boring and tedious. At the very beggining of the game you are at mercy of RNG to give you items, yet you can do some unlocks to be able to pick whatever item you want for your build. Some characters are very underperforming on higher difficulties, it doesn't matter what items you pick, you can't counter balance all their flaws and it's not fun to play them. Game suffers from severe fps drops when you play longer than 1 hour because there is just so much happening on screen it turns game into a slideshow.  Otherwise, it's a great game to play coop with friends for a couple of times. Some might say gameplay gets boring and formulaic the more you play and I agree. But I just like to get numb and click on targets and watch fancy visuals.

It started off as a relaxing, slow-paced dungeon crawl, but by the end it was hell. It took nearly 50 hours to beat. Despite each time I failed, and each run I lost, I knew I needed to go another round. 2 am? I can sleep at 3. Work starts in an hour? I can squeeze in one more game. The enemies scale rather well, and I never found an obstacle I could never overcome. The items are all fun, and unique, and you often won't have two runs that are the same. The combat is pretty fluid, and every enemy has it's own niche ability, that keeps things fair, but always makes you feel like you're fighting against overwhelming odds. The end boss is challenging, and if you can even make it there, you're either extremely lucky, or you have everything you need to beat it. And for me, I've finally beaten it, and without a doubt I feel like I know enough now to say that, you should buy it. Don't wait for a sale, don't wait for risk of rain 3. Buy it now, and at the very least try a few runs before you refund, and trust me you won't get far, but you'll have a blast.

Everyone I've talked to seems to love this game, it may very well be a good game.
However there is very little to no assistance for new players.
It is very beginner unfriendly.
Additionally, if motion sickness is a problem for you, beware.
Also if you're starting out, play solo.

So, you play for about the first two-three hours, not really sure of how you're gonna do it. You've seen how the difficulty can go, but also you've seen how fun it could be. Eventually, you get your friends in and you just vibe, and get exponentially better at the game. It's fun as hell, and both surprisingly immersive and lore-filled. Buy it, or nut in a sock; do what you want.

This game is quite literally perfect in every way. I could just leave it that but that would be just touching the surface of this games perfection, feeling around the labias if you will. In this review I wont just be corrosing the labia, I will be going full fist in. This video game has no flaws and you will never find another like it. Its unique game play and art style are just the first layer of its perfection. The deeper layers of this sacred onion are all the different game play techinques and strategies, the challenges you'll have to overcome. At some points of the game you will be completely overwhelmed with the variety of enemies and will just have to click keys and hope to not get beamed by a giant stone titan, but thats the beauty of it. This game will make you feel like you took 27 percs and decided to down a quart of lean. The vibrant colors and lightshows will provide you a euphoria that your discord kitten cant even provide you.

I have not played a game this much in a long time. Over the past 2 years I've been struggling to get into a new game and Risk of Rain 2 does just that for me. Its fun to play solo but its also really fun to play with friends. I really love the mysterious aesthetic where you don't completely know whats going on with the story but you go along with it and find out more. I would highly recommend this game to anyone and everyone. You can get a lot out of this game no matter what your preferences are. If you do struggle to get into playing it consistently it might be because you havent found your character yet. All the characters offer drastically different playstyles and finding the one you like is a fun journey.

I'm really not sure what the devs did to this one, it was amazing when it released but has somehow gone backward in progress. For starters, spawn rates are really, really messed up. (waiting 3+ minutes for enemies to spawn, only 1 or 2 enemies spawning per wave, etc.) My last run I had killed less than 50 enemies by the 15 minute mark at stage 3 and was bored out of my mind literally standing around for 2-3 minutes after every few kills to wait for enemies to spawn. On top of that, there are game breaking bugs including your teleporter (the thing that allows you to progress further) spawning inside of objects. And don't even get me started on the waste of development resources that is Mithrix (the "final boss"). Sadly at this late stage in the game's life I don't think we will see it ever returned to its former glory (it really was amazing in early access) so we are kind of stuck with what we've got which I would most definitely not recommend to anyone interested in this genre of game.

INDUSTRIAL SOCIETY AND ITS FUTURE
Introduction

1. The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race. They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in “advanced” countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human beings to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in “advanced” countries.

2. The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine. Furthermore, if the system survives, the consequences will be inevitable: There is no way of reforming or modifying the system so as to prevent it from depriving people of dignity and autonomy.

3. If the system breaks down the consequences will still be very painful. But the bigger the system grows the more disastrous the results of its breakdown will be, so if it is to break down it had best break down sooner rather than later.

4. We therefore advocate a revolution against the industrial system. This revolution may or may not make use of violence; it may be sudden or it may be a relatively gradual process spanning a few decades. We can’t predict any of that. But we do outline in a very general way the measures that those who hate the industrial system should take in order to prepare the way for a revolution against that form of society. This is not to be a POLITICAL revolution. Its object will be to overthrow not governments but the economic and technological basis of the present society.

5. In this article we give attention to only some of the negative developments that have grown out of the industrial-technological system. Other such developments we mention only briefly or ignore altogether. This does not mean that we regard these other developments as unimportant. For practical reasons we have to confine our discussion to areas that have received insufficient public attention or in which we have something new to say. For example, since there are well-developed environmental and wilderness movements, we have written very little about environmental degradation or the destruction of wild nature, even though we consider these to be highly important.

THE PSYCHOLOGY OF MODERN LEFTISM

6. Almost everyone will agree that we live in a deeply troubled society. One of the most widespread manifestations of the craziness of our world is leftism, so a discussion of the psychology of leftism can serve as an introduction to the discussion of the problems of modern society in general.

7. But what is leftism? During the first half of the 20th century leftism could have been practically identified with socialism. Today the movement is fragmented and it is not clear who can properly be called a leftist. When we speak of leftists in this article we have in mind mainly socialists, collectivists, “politically correct” types, feminists, gay and disability activists, animal rights activists and the like. But not everyone who is associated with one of these movements is a leftist. What we are trying to get at in discussing leftism is not so much movement or an ideology as a psychological type, or rather a collection of related types. Thus, what we mean by “leftism” will emerge more clearly in the course of our discussion of leftist psychology. (Also, see paragraphs 227-230.)

8. Even so, our conception of leftism will remain a good deal less clear than we would wish, but there doesn’t seem to be any remedy for this. All we are trying to do here is indicate in a rough and approximate way the two psychological tendencies that we believe are the main driving force of modern leftism. We by no means claim to be telling the WHOLE truth about leftist psychology. Also, our discussion is meant to apply to modern leftism only. We leave open the question of the extent to which our discussion could be applied to the leftists of the 19th and early 20th centuries.

9. The two psychological tendencies that underlie modern leftism we call “feelings of inferiority” and “oversocialization.” Feelings of inferiority are characteristic of modern leftism as a whole, while oversocialization is characteristic only of a certain segment of modern leftism; but this segment is highly influential.

FEELINGS OF INFERIORITY

10. By “feelings of inferiority” we mean not only inferiority feelings in the strict sense but a whole spectrum of related traits; low self-esteem, feelings of powerlessness, depressive tendencies, defeatism, guilt, self- hatred, etc. We argue that modern leftists tend to have some such feelings (possibly more or less repressed) and that these feelings are decisive in determining the direction of modern leftism.

11. When someone interprets as derogatory almost anything that is said about him (or about groups with whom he identifies) we conclude that he has inferiority feelings or low self-esteem. This tendency is pronounced among minority rights activists, whether or not they belong to the minority groups whose rights they defend. They are hypersensitive about the words used to designate minorities and about anything that is said concerning minorities. The terms “negro,” “oriental,” “handicapped” or “chick” for an African, an Asian, a disabled person or a woman originally had no derogatory connotation. “Broad” and “chick” were merely the feminine equivalents of “guy,” “dude” or “fellow.” The negative connotations have been attached to these terms by the activists themselves. Some animal rights activists have gone so far as to reject the word “pet” and insist on its replacement by “animal companion.” Leftish anthropologists go to great lengths to avoid saying anything about primitive peoples that could conceivably be interpreted as negative. They want to replace the world “primitive” by “nonliterate.” They seem almost paranoid about anything that might suggest that any primitive culture is inferior to our own. (We do not mean to imply that primitive cultures ARE inferior to ours. We merely point out the hypersensitivity of leftish anthropologists.)

12. Those who are most sensitive about “politically incorrect” terminology are not the average black ghetto- dweller, Asian immigrant, abused woman or disabled person, but a minority of activists, many of whom do not even belong to any “oppressed” group but come from privileged strata of society. Political correctness has its stronghold among university professors, who have secure employment with comfortable salaries, and the majority of whom are heterosexual white males from middle- to upper-middle-class families.

This game is really fun and well executed on very many levels

Combat: each character in this game feels totally unique and has a fun and devastating move set, and each boss and enemy in the game is equally as unique and fun to fight against, especially the final boss

Exploration: each stage is grand and epic to explore with beautiful scenery and graphics all around, even on low settings like mine. Finding every hidden thing is a super fun part of the game and will take dozens or hundreds of hours

Design: the whole design of the game encourages risk taking for reward. Go fast and have less items, of go slow and have more items, while the enemy's are getting stronger by time. It's a very fun mechanic that puts a ton of pressure on the player while still totally allowing for freedom to play how you want

Unlockables: this game has toooons of unlockables that will take many hours to unlock, but they are all fun and completing the challenges to unlock them is fun as well. Highly recommend for people who lov to unlock abilities and items

Music and sound: both the music and sound design in this game is phenomenal. Despite the variety of dozens of monsters, you will always know what monsters are near just by the sounds they make. And the music is outstanding. I have played the game for hundreds of hours without getting bored of the soundtrack. The ambience of each stage music, the intense battle music, and the beautiful guitar solos make this one of my favorite video game soundtracks

Fun with friends: this game is so much fun with friends. Obviously that's not for everyone, but if you have a group of friends you love to game with, introduce them to this. The games scales very well with groups of players and using your different members abilities to team up and survive is very fun

Variety: there is soo much variety in the gameplay. Not only do you have different classes, but each class has tons of unlockable abilities and powers to use. Additionally, with hundreds of items, you can make tons of different powerful and unique loadouts to wreak havoc and become an unstoppable killing force

In summary, this game is just very fun for people who love combat, abilities, unlockables, exploration, goofing off with friends, or even music. Even some interesting lore to boot, if you're into that, however it's not necessary to enjoy the gameplay. Overall it's just a very fun game and very much worth the price. I recommend just about everyone should give it a try! :steamthumbsup:
