Ror2 isn't immersive, it doesn't have much of a story if you don't go out of your way to read logs and can be extremely unforgiving even when compared to games such as dead cells, hollow knight, Hades etc. But what it does do is provide very good graphics and art style paired with gameplay that just feels great from the time you get out of the escape pod to the time you stand as a god being barraged by 100 monsters attacking you all at once. I very rarely find any issue with framerate on my nividia 3060 and ryzen 3600 and only once has the game ever crashed in over 80 hours of gameplay. I recommend this game to anyone looking for an affordable game assembled by a crew that really put passion and effort into making a game with huge amounts of content that feels like is made for enjoyment and not a cash grab.

Despite the look of the game, I found victory coming down a lot to luck, and less so with skill. Depending on how many items you find, and how quickly you find them. If you take too long, you've got no chance at the end of the game as enemies health, damage and numbers quickly outpace you and you find yourself swarmed without many tools to avoid damage. I did have some fun with this game, but after 25 hours, and unlocking most of the characters and some of the items I feel the desire to keep playing very quickly disappearing, as it feels as though my actions during the game have little to do with my success.

The game is a lot better in multiplayer, as then it can become more casual, and a decently fun romp with friends. But solo, aiming to beat the game and unlock everything feels like its up to the game as to how well you do, as long as you keep playing eventually you'll find success once the game decides to give you a decent run.

This game is like everything I want Warframe to be, it's an Endless looter/shooter that starts off pretty slow, and before you know it, you've sunk in 2 hours and you're really done with your run but you decide to keep going because you just want to see just what limits you can push, how much faster you can zoom through the maps, if you can start one-shotting bosses, if you can beat your previously loop's time, if you can reach something absurd like 9999% attack speed. The plains that felt like they took forever to cross are now a cakewalk.

This game is for anyone who wants to turn their brain off while simultaneously keeping the difficulty up so that you have to pay attention, that's not to mention that you can add modifiers to your game to tailor it more to whatever difficulty you like. Personally, I enable enemy drops, choose the ability to pick your items,  double enemy spawn rates and then try to create the perfect Zenith Build/Run.

I recommend this game to anyone who wants a true Looter/shooter experience

I was a bit adverse to a third-person, rouge-like shooter, but the game grew on me (like the Bungus). 

First off, the game has tons of very completable achievements. If you like achievement hunting, this game is phenomenal for that, as every achievement also unlocks some bit of game content. 

Secondly, multiplayer? This game excels in that as well. It is just as easy to play alone as it is to play with your friends. Everything scales with your party, but it still feels great to play.

Third, tons of unique experiences. The distinct characters and their interactions with items and enemies provide so much variety to gameplay that I have come back to play this game for hundreds of hours, and I still want more. As of the writing of this, Hoopoo is planning on releasing an expansion. I will most certainly acquire this as it will absolutely add a multitude of quality new experiences which will be another bundle of hours from me.

I would absolutely recommend this to anyone.

One of the best games I've ever played. Tons of replayability and super fun.

The good:
- Artistic style. This is subjective, but I think they've really pulled of a simple look as it's so clean, yet still provides enough interest.
- Challenge level. The fact that easy really trains you up well and then spanks you later on if you're foolish is great. This is influenced by drops somewhat however. Some runs you're so unlucky you can be dead by 4th boss.
- Sick guitar riffs in music \m/ Wandering around an alien landscape with prog rock solos ringing in your ears is bliss in the late hours.
- Unlockable classes to suit all playstyles

Bad:
- Not having the friends to play co-op with :( Some classes appear intended with co-op in mind, so you may never use them in a solo run.
- Replay value. Once you've completed it a few times solo, you might find yourself not wishing to sink another hour into a run on your own again.

On balance, I definitely would recommend this game.

Risk of Rain 2 is a gem of a game. If you are even remotely into roguelikes get this game you will not regret it. This is one of my favorite games of 2020 and 2021, maybe even 2022.

Been told to try ROR2 by many peoples, time and time again people would simply tell me "It's just a good game" and give me no real reason to play the game. This put me off initially.
However, bored a couple of days ago I couldn't find anything to play and decided to buy the game.
I went in with a negative mindset due to the reviews mostly being memes and "Good game" and nothing more, and initially I was ready to refund the game. HOWEVER, I decided to keep playing and give the game a proper chance, and my am I happy I did. 

This game ticks every single box for me personally when we're talking good game.

- Easy to get into.
- Tons of replayability.
- Co-op.
- Good filler game for when you have nothing else to do.
- Relaxing.
- Tons of modsupport.

Having played the game for a few days I can now see why many reviews are simply "Good game, just play it". But I will say this. 
If you are looking for a good and relaxing game to play with friends, then Risk Of Rain 2 has you and your friends covered. There is tons and tons of mods to make the game even better to top it.

TL;DR - Good game, just play it.

Fortunately for me I had the luxury of a friend who was willing to explain the ins and outs of the game as we played, which allowed me to find the fun in it. If I had just played by myself, I would've only spent a few hours trying to figure out what I can do, what I need to do to beat the game, what I need to do to unlock the content of the game, and then eventually get frustrated and stop playing. Sure, I could've spent time looking up guides, but it shouldn't be unreasonable to expect a game to be able to explain what the goals are and how to achieve them. There were so many times where my friend was like "oh yeah there's no other way to get this achievement/character besides jumping off a random cliff and going through these hidden platforms to turn this dial and complete this secret level to unlock the switch that you can activate if you get to the last level" and I'm wondering how the hell I would've figured this out on my own when the game doesn't tell me jack.

Multiplayer was fun, but it commonly created a situation where someone died early at the start of the level, and had to wait 10-20 minutes to get another chance to play. Plus, if you die early you miss out on loot, making it exponentially more like that you die early in the next level, snowballing until the game becomes impossible to play for more than a couple minutes in between periods of almost half an hour of waiting. I started having a second game open on my second monitor to play if I died early, which I dont think is ever a good thing to have happen for people playing your game. The soundtrack can alleviate some of the boredom, and during tense boss fights it can be fun to watch your friends, but there's only so much you can do to make waiting interesting.

I wouldn't really call this a roguelite because it doesn't offer those hard CHOICES, that allow you to craft a vastly unique and different character build in each run.  What keeps the game feeling fresh is the different character choices you make at the starting screen.  Same choices at the starting screen, SAME RUN for the most part.  That said, it is a fun game and finding rare items to make your character OP is a blast.  Co-op mode is also fun when it works properly, which is about 50% of the time. This game is a triumph.  Ever since I played Hades, I've had a serious rogue-like/lite itch, and Risk of Rain 2 scratches it damn goodly.  Hopoo knows EXACTLY what they're doing.  I seriously can't think of a franchise that has made a better transition from 2D to 3D aside from maybe Mario games.  The character variety is broad and deep, and so the build variety is VAST, usually hilarious, and sometimes straight up broken.  The way that progress between runs is tied to achievements and secrets discovered in game which unlock new items, abilities, and modifiers that alter the rules of play is both charmingly retro and an innovative stroke of genius.  All of this combined with continuous developer support since launch and an active and talented mod community make this the game that just keeps on giving.  It is, without a doubt, unbalanced, but, where in most games this might come across as lazy, it is arguably one of the best parts of this gem.  The difficulty infinitely scales the longer your run lasts, challenging you to break the game before it breaks you. Every time you reach stage 5, you can choose to advance to the final boss, or loop back around to stage 1 to begin again, ratcheting up the insanity even further.  Being able to play with up to 3 friends at once has made it an infinitely amusing staple in me and friends weekend rotation when we want to play something with instead of against each other.  It is basically the only game that when somebody new to my discord says "What is that?" I say "Here, I'll buy you a copy."  I can't wait for the DLC!

I just can't get behind this game.  I've given it a fair chance and ever since early access I walk away from my runs frustrated, annoyed, and unsatisfied.  It has everything I would want from a game on a surface level:  Third person, action, roguelite, great flowing combat, and a decent soundtrack.  The issues for me, however, seem to be apparent once I play long enough and dig a bit deeper to its systems.

Here are my issues with the game:

Pretty lame powerups.  They're all mostly basic passive bonuses minus a few of the big powerups, overall they don't feel like they have much impact between them other than "be stronger" which feels boring.

Very little control over lame powerups.  I know there are ways to get items outside of just picking up what the game gives you, but it can be a risky strategy where you dump the powerup you wanted for one that isn't as good.

Too much running around scrambling to find lame powerups.  This is where the game gets frustrating for me, it's really hard to tell if you've missed items and where they are so you can waste a lot of time just running around helplessly looking for items only to walk away with nothing.  Add to this the maps are massive and this really becomes the main aspect of the game, which is not an aspect I'm particularly fond of.  I'd rather have solid reliable combat as the focus than running around playing map slot machine.

Fighting gets buried under a mountain of strobey effects and attack animations that make it pretty impossible to counter after a while.  Once the game picks up to the HAHAHA phase you're just mostly doing what you can to avoid damage but overall there's too many enemies and attacks to reliably avoid damage.  Most the time you're okay but every now and then the game cheap shot blasts you into the dirt.  Great, now the 50 minute run you did is over.  "Start over" says the game, "no thanks" says a burnt out me.

I was hopeful that the game would have cleaned up a lot of its messiness during its development through early access, but really it didn't.  I thought the game had potential, and I get that a lot of people like it, but this just is something I think is a pretty shallow experience in a very pretty and appealing shell.

Risk of Rain 2 is the much-awaited sequel to Indie Dev Hopoo Games Risk of Rain. Returning with its signature Roguelite gameplay and Co-Op capability except now in 3D and more entertaining than ever.

The game has almost unlimited replayability with its multiplayer mode,  Roguelike features, expansive unlockable system, and in-game collectibles such as achievements. Risk of Rain 2 gives you plenty of reasons to keep playing.

The game also continues to get better as Hopoo games strives for excellence with major updates released in the past year and more set to come. 

Bottomline: The game is worth far more than its asking price. Pick it up and give it a try.
Masterpiece of a game. Buy it!

I've been in a gaming drought for a really long time and no game has been able to peak my interest quite like this one, something about the massive simplicity this game provides is so different yet so original, I could go on and on but really you just have to try it for yourself.
I like roguelikes and I love well-balanced survival (endless or otherwise) games. I have zero idea of why RoR has such a high rating.

Tl;Dr Pretty good, really fun with co op and even more fun with co op and mods. Super fluid in game and tons of little things you can add to make every run drastically different than the last. Only downside is the stages are kinda stale and you may get sick of them pretty quick. If it is ever on sale pick it up if its not on sale just know you'll probably get 50-100 hours off rip.

Also the music is phenomenal it sets the mood like perfectly. 

The Real Review : 

You actually learn the game pretty quick. Like all the stages, mobs, bosses and what not. Your items are where the most time learning will be spent. In RoR2 there is a lot of items and a ton of synergies to go with those items. But for the most part you can pick up almost everything you see and be fine. Drizzle (Easy) is a nice entry difficulty to teach you fundamentals. When you jump up in difficulty the game gets exponentially harder. Just know that there becomes a time where Hard (Monsoon) is to hard and the Normal (Rainstorm, I think its called) is far to easy. and you'll kinda have to sit and learn a lot to do the harder runs but its all in good fun. The Content is at a drought currently, (Jan 2022) but a DLC is coming out so hopefully there are regular updates again. 

As for how it plays as a roguelike, I would personally say it is like 60% luck and 40% skill. This doesn't really matter on anything below Monsoon but if you want to do the Big Boy runs (Eclipse 1-8) your luck can actually screw you, and for the most part you can't comeback. Very Rarely you can recover from a horrible run but if you're reading this and you get bad runs a lot, just become the [spoiler] Heretic [/spoiler] and all your issues will probably be resolved. 

As for the characters. They are all super fun and all have a pretty different play-style than one another. Then you can also have modded characters too and those basically make monsoon drizzle mode.

Lastly, the music is really really good. Chris Christodoulou kileld this soundtrack. Every single time the last stage sends chills down my spine when the guitar riff hits. Every song is a banger but if you're not into long 80's styled guitar riffs then it may not be for you.

Good game, I think the best part about it is the range in difficulty. You can play for hours and not notice that its been 3 hours. The more you play, the more you have to play with as you unlock new items. This gives you different builds to make and build as you go.

You have to play the game and collect the items as you play, so its easy to learn how to play. It also keeps it interesting as new items like artefacts change the and how you would play it. It also gives a layer of difficulty.

This game is seriously addicting with a great gameplay loop and fun, if not sometimes frustrating, gameplay. It has a great artstyle and good character design that you get to appreciate for about 2 stages before your characters starts looking like a sentient garage sale which I find pretty funny. My favorite thing is probably how different characters wear sunglasses which are an item in the game. Captain wears them on his hat, whereas commando literally wears them over his bubble helmet, and huntress wears them on their side because her helmet has 2 vertical lenses.

In general it's a great game that's a lot of fun to play with friends or alone. Very challenging and the achievements you earn actually feel like achievements because they unlock different items and character abilities. There are also artifacts to unlock which change game mechanics like making enemies drop items on death instead of chests, amplify damage to 500% but reduce health to 10%, make enemies only spawn as elites, or make all enemies spawn as the same type per stage.

I feel like I'm might be a little addicted to this game tbh. Hasn't even been two weeks since I got it and I've already logged 96 hours of game time.

There are very few games that I would actually rate on a critique level as a 10/10, and maybe plenty that I would rate on a personal level to me at a 10/10. What I mean is, if I had anything bad to technically say about the game, neither my personal opinion nor my critique would feel like it is necessary to rate this game any lower than a 10/10. This might quite frankly be the best roguelike title I've played to date, and has officially set the standards for all roguelike games to come after.

[b] Okay! with the Survivors of the Void out, it's time to give this game a proper review. [/b]
I don't think I can express my appreciation for this game the way it deserves it, but I will give it a shot. 

[i] "Their Security Chests? Full of overrides and backdoors..." [/i]

The clock has started and the stage is set. Your fate is in your hands. Why did the ship crash? What are you doing on Petrichor? All the things that do not matter right now. For now, you should survive the hoards of creatures and machines that come at you with no remorse. You're an outsider after all, an invader, a mere threat to the peace of all the creatures that The Hero saved and brought to Petrichor. Those shipments are property of UES...to hell with them, you need to survive first. You better fight back with everything you find; crowbars, bullets, heck even firecrackers. Two strange curved metal bars stand-out in the distance, almost like horns, around it full of fireflies. You touch the leaver and a signal comes from the sky and takes you with it. Are you still on the same planet? There are still boxes around, but how does it look so different? No matter, you must survive. Rinse and repeat [spoiler] until finally, you receive a message from Safe Travels. An escape pod is waiting for you at the moon. You can escape, but not before one last obstacle...[/spoiler]
[i] "...A brief spark of hope – the survivor had some medical supplies in his shelter. If he could only make it back, he may be able to treat his leg and remove the tar…" [/i]

Well, with my headcanon out of the way, let the actual review begin. To be honest, I found RoR2 overwhelming at first. So many things to take note of, so many mechanics and items to learn, and so little time to do so before you die. I was sure it was a bit more than luck of the draw, it had to be. After being carried to the end by a friend once or twice, I was sold on the game. I realized how much every item augmented the experienced massively, how every enemy was enjoyably annoying in its own way, and how intricately each map and track was made. I still don't get how every stage theme resonates with my heart while the sheer thought of dying is still lingering. After every run, you're always left with "what if I did this instead?" And if at any point your felt like you have done everything, pick one of the 16 Artifacts that overhauls the game. 

If I say this game has brought a smile to my face more than any other game I have played, it would hardly be an overstatement. 

[i] "It looks like starseed, tanning in dirt.
It smells like hot stone, and tall grass.
It tastes like spiced fruit, sweet and hot.
It feels like solar winds, and solar chimes.
It sounds like two brothers, chasing glass frogs in the sun." [/i]
Pretty cool. Plus it's really re-playable!

To start off, I would recommend this game to anyone if it weren't for one MAJOR issue. 

The game will spontaneously crash at random times; sometimes at the menu, sometimes 3 hours into a run. 

Graphics drivers are up to date, tried running as admin, tried running in compatibility for every windows version known to man, tried windowed mode, tried unplugging misc devices, tried verifying game files, tried resetting caches, tried running the game in a VM with nothing that could possibly cause a software conflict, and yet...

None of these fixes, alone or in any combination with one another, have had any impact on the random Unity crashes.

This issue does not affect everyone, so, if you want to roll the dice on the crashing, get the game. If the odds are in your favor, you'll love it.

Since i bought this game i basically cant put it down. Of all the rogue-likes that i have played this one brings the fast pace of Hades, the shooter and item aspect of Enter the Gungeon plus the cherry on top, online multiplayer with friends. 

Now obviously this isn't the first time multiplayer has been added to a rogue-like but i think Hopoo Games really improved on the multiplayer aspect of this game. Compared to Gungeon, as far as i know its only local in person multiplayer that caps at 2 players, while Ror2 can have 4 players which can get pretty chaotic at times. Honestly all of the features they added even before booting up a run is pretty cool with artefacts which can completely change the way you play the game. 

The Survivors feel wicked to play and not clunky, the survivors feels smooth to play if that makes sense. This game also is really challenging at times, especially with the artefacts one example is a artefact that doubles enemies but halves their HP, which crate huge swarms of enemies that if your wave clear is not good can really tank your run at times. 

The items are fantastic, compared to other rogue-likes I've played the fact where there is a limited amount of unique times that can stack infinitely is hilarious and convenient at the same time where i can try and build towards a suitable build for my survivor or just run a artefact that i can choose what item to go and stack 20 of one item and just troll around. 

I'll stop here and say try it yourself, honestly its worth the 25+ dollars plus it can go on sale for roughly 17$ which is a steal in my opinion, i would pick it up soon especially with DLC coming really soon (supposed to release in the first quarter of 2022). All in all a amazing game would rate a 10/10.

Risk of Rain 2 is what you play when you want a good time. It feels the just right of amount of challenging without being overly frustrating and yet still inviting you push yourself further to overcome the challenges it presents. 

Another selling point of this game is the achievements. Now that I've started actively hunting down achievements and trying to deliberately go after them, Risk of Rain 2 actively rewards and incentives you to go after them. By unlocking achievements you can get new abilities, potential item drops and entirely new characters. It no holds bar, punches the insidious practice of gate-keeping new content behind a paywall right in the teeth and makes you earn it. You actually feel like there's some accomplishment involved when you finally ace that level or manage to clock your firerate beyond 200%. 

I highly recommend this game and especially if you plan to play with friends.

Id say this game is a solid 9 or 10. You start off confused and lost, not knowing the benefits and powers that each little item can give you, and the power and control you gain, to memorizing 85 or 90% of all items, the downsides to them, the upsides, and still even then, the game is hard, and challenging. Good graphics, good controls, satisfying blowing up all the enemies with one shot, etc. Overall EPIC game. 
Also the music is godly. Though, every game has its ups and downs. The perfect game, doesn't exist, and won't ever factually exist. Some of the reasons this game isn't a 10 out of 10 baller fuckin game, its a 9, it's due to the tediousness of it. You get and want the same items that are overpowered, you loop 5 times getting to stage 45, making your weapons one shot every single godamn enemy you see, infinite health, range, etc. The game has been recently updated by a far amount, though there is still a problem; item variety. There was 18 items added, and 5 new equipments, and some others added with the void dlc, and i yet have to see about 16 of the commons, and all of the oranges. I think the game has a fuck ton of items, and it isn't really the item VARIETY per say, its really the knowing whats good and whats horrible. once you are good enough to understand and execute the things you need for a god run, the game gets dull. For example, if you are wanting a god run to beat mythrix without looping once, you will need a few simple items, nothing more. here is a list of things you need to beat him in less than an hour, and quickly: sheild regenerators, teddy bears, daggers, glasses, solder syringes, focus crystals, will-o the wisps, ukulele, crowbars, and ONE brilliant behemoth. If you have all those items, a wealthy amount of them, you win, if your a mediocre player at the least. Yes, of course, without a doubt there are millions, no BILLIONS of combinations to beat the game as quick as possible and as easy as possible, but those items that are listed are easily S-tier items, and will get you dubs back to back. The picture here is, the items never change, its the same basic strat and want in a match; the OP items. BUT, like I said before, I edited this today, the day the DLC came out, and realized this game is phenomenal, and it holds a special place in my heart. Despite the powerful con to this game, it is truly legendary, extrodanary, unique, beautiful, satisfying, encouraging, funny, glorious, rewarding, and, bone chilling in the best way possible. The feeling you get while ending it all, fighting the final boss, the music, the rush, the drones shooting bullet hell towards it, you, using your strength, speed, durability, knowledge you've gained during this long hard fought journey, it is a truly fucking amazing feeling. This game, is something else. -A fan

Definitely recommended for anyone that enjoys games that include semi-rogue likes, first-person shooters, a diverse cast of characters with unique abilities, and a lot of hidden material that you will not get to see through many of your playthroughs.

There are multiple characters to be unlocked and a multitude of paths to be taken when playing through ROR2. Many of these paths may take a while to find (if you're not using a guide) but definitely adds some excitement to the game and boosts replayability. Many of these paths can lead you to a dead end but some can lead you down a loop, which in my opinion, adds so much more to the game. These loops aren't just the same things you've seen over and over; they include newer, stronger enemies and bosses, secrets, and even new items to unlock but all contained in the maps you know like the back of your hand after a few hours of play.

Multiplayer is its own beast unto itself. With most common servers being up to a max of 4 players and some custom servers which I've seen up to 32 players, the ability to drop into a started game, and a custom set of game rules (items which you can obtain through one of the previously mentioned paths that alter what effects are given throughout the run).

The only cons I can think of off hand are that when playing in multiplayer, it is possible for anyone to steal items (boons) that you unlock, through chests, item stands, etc..., with your in-game currency. If an item that you've bought goes to another online player, it can get very frustrating, especially if it's not a one-time occurrence. This can cause your abilities to fall behind and not long after, basically will be unable to compete with any of the mobs that appear on the maps, which in turn will make it so you can't really afford to unlock items, or even stay alive long enough to catch up.

Some players will deliberately hold up progress in multiplayer games to either benefit themselves or to just sabotage a run. This can become increasingly frustrating when you've made it further into the game than you had hoped for. The icing on the cake for these situations are that you are unable to vote someone out of the game, if they've taken the previously mentioned actions.

Please don't let this deter you from trying the game. It is, in my opinion, one of the best FPS Rogue-likes out there that bring so much to the table.

There are very few games that allow you to potentially COMPLETELY break the game through ability scaling. You're meant to absolutely suck at this game until you figure out the rhythm and balance of how much time to spend on a stage vs. how much to farm. And then you'll be cruising through runs where killing one enemy creates an insane proc chain reaction that kills every enemy on screen except one that you didn't realize snuck up behind you and now you're dead. 

9/10

Though I'm a huge fan of rogue-lite/likes, I find some to be terribly boring, frustrating, or disrespectful to one's limited time. Unfortunately, RoR2 falls into this category.

Items and luck are far and away more important to progression than skill. This is made all the more tedious by the armfuls of completely worthless items in the pool. Certain items/combinations of items are all but required to not get overwhelmed and oneshot by enemies later in the run. 

I'm too old and decrepit to play with the speed required to keep the difficulty manageable, leading myself to be left behind by teammates, hitting a brick wall of difficulty, or feeling unsatisfied progressing to the next level. 

Oftentimes, dying in a party results in you dying every. single. level. as you're placed so far behind by a lack of items and levels. This, compounded by other problems with the game, lead the game, even (or possibly, especially) in coop, to be comparable to grinding my skin with a cheese grater.

Risk of Rain 2 is a an shooter action roguelike, where runs consist of fighting through a 3d environments looking for the portal to the next world while collecting items to make yourself stronger. Like all roguelikes, it is permadeath but with meta progression where you unlock and find more things even on failed runs.

I think I just have to admit that this game is not for me. I tried picking it up several times, but I found it just too frustrating to get into. 

My core complaint is about communication: the game tells you next to nothing and expects you to figure it out yourself. This is all well and good, until the act of exploration and experimentation dooms your run. For example, you gain items throughout a run, some much better than others. You will also find many stations throughout the game where you can trade a random item for a different one. The problem is that you don't know what an item does until you pick it up and sometimes not even then (looking at you ukelele). I have on more than one occasion traded one or more items for a borderline useless item. I never know how much effort or how much I should pay for the various items I find, because I literally don't know what they are. All I know is that I need SOME of them and have to get lucky. 

Also there is a clock constantly ticking, the game getting harder as time goes on, so you don't want to take your time and figure stuff out. The various maps range in size with plenty of dead ends around. I have been unable to find the portal on many runs, wasting precious time retreading old ground. I assume I would get better at spotting it after more runs, but its just one more example of the game punishing you for not knowing how its constructed. 

Other examples of the game actively punishing you for things you had no chance of knowing is the various instakill boss moves. Great example is the Wandering Vagrant boss that has an explosion attack that goes all around it, that you either need to seek cover for or be far enough away from to tank. Now the boss uses exclusively ranged attacks that you dodge, so an undogeable super nova comes out of nowhere and kills you. I had something like this happen every other boss, where there was something critical I needed to know that I felt the game just did not tell me about.

A few learning curves that you need to retry and experience is fine, but the sheer quantity of stuff that will just end your run because you didn't know put me right off. Other games also punish you for not knowing things as a way of teaching the players, but rarely will it be this much and rarely will it kill you in a permadeath scenario. It is just too much. Worst part is, I tried several months later to give the game another shot but I had already forgotten the few things I had learned the first time around making my experience even worse. 

Bottom line, I am sure there is a great game on the other side of the learning curve. I am sure if I took the time to memorize the various items, learn the ins and outs of the bosses, and develop a sense for the layout of the maps, I could have a good time. But 6 hours in I am still not having a good time, so I don't think I'll ever make it to the other side of the curve.

This "game" (Risk of Rain 2) sucks, I recently discovered that there is not actually any rain (the condensed moisture of the atmosphere falling visibly in separate drops) in the "game" (Risk of Rain 2). This is absolutely unacceptable considering they put the word "Rain" (the condensed moisture of the atmosphere falling visibly in separate drops) in the "game"'s title (Risk of Rain 2). This "game" (Risk of Rain 2) is actively STEALING from dev teams who pour blood, sweat and tears into putting actual rain (the condensed moisture of the atmosphere falling visibly in separate drops) into their games! (like Mojang did with their hit game Minecraft!) This sort of clickbait should not be tolerated on the Steam platform!

This game is one of my favorite games ever made. Never have I come across a game so addictive, so, consistently challenging and enjoyable, so ingeniously well put together. Every enemy, every item, every stage layout in the game has a specialized purpose that you can take advantage of. There are so many deep layers to the combat, so much so that even I who has played a great many games, can confidently say that this game has one of the most fantastic combat systems in any game in history. The soundtrack is also simply phenomenal. I don't usually mind a games' soundtrack but this game absolutely murders you with its divine music. This is a fun, interesting, endlessly playable, challenging, diverse, lovingly made masterpiece. If you are thinking of buying this but are also wondering if it would be worth the price, please get it. I know that I'm not really a source anyone knows, and this game certainly isn't for the faint of heart, but trust me. It's worth the Risk.

In all honesty, this game was not what I was expecting it to be. I was expecting a game with stages, sort of like Mario. It's more of a "survive the waves" type of game, but I think It's done pretty well. I will say, when I first started, I was really confused on how exactly some mechanics worked, and I still don't know how a few do, but It's still fun nonetheless, even if you play just solo. Overall solid 8/10, highly addictive, though I wonder for how much longer the game will have my interest.
when you first load in it feels kinda slow but once you collect your first few items the game is just so much fun.

Most of my playtime in [i]Risk Of Rain 2[/i] was spent with friends, on Discord voice chat. Having a strategy for which class (or player) gets which upgrades can have great results - coordinated play will give you plenty of time to enjoy the level designs, loot and spawn mechanics, and the gameplay differences between the characters. Solo play - or last-player-alive play - is a completely different experience, and feels sparse or incomplete compared to the full group multiplayer experience. Highly recommended if you'll be playing with a friend or in a group!

Risk of Rain 2 is a fantastic game. 

In comparison to Risk of Rain 1 which was set on a 2D plane, Risk 2 is 3D and continues the story of Risk 1 in a stunning indie visual way. You can clearly tell how much the devs love their creation, and all the hard work they have put into this game to make it a great experience both in single-player, and multi-player settings. 

The gameplay feels great honestly and when playing with friends and co-ordinating together on each level, it feels like you all have your individual skill set when working as a team. The game feels well balanced and frequently reminds you of the need to keep moving (via sudden and brutal death from hostiles).  

In summary, It is a charming game to play and frequently gift this game to friends. - Well worth the price!

Easy to get into. A shooty rougelite that you can play without a lot of mental effort. It's very replayable which I think is the mark of a good roguelite.

You shoot things to get money and you spend money to open chests and get items that empower your character of choice. There's only so many chests per stage so you have to beat a boss challenge to go to new more difficult stages with more items. The game ramps up the difficulty based on how long you are alive so you need to get items quickly to keep up with the advancing difficulty.

There's multiplayer but the public servers are kinda boring, probably a blast with friends. 

When you're close to finishing the game you can unlock artifacts which are mutators that change game rules. Most artifacts make the game harder but a few can make it much easier or just broken. One artifact in particular, Command, allows one to choose the items one gets and that's very interesting but takes away from replayability so don't overuse it.

There's lots of characters and they all play differently at first but sort of become less different as you gain more items since the items begin to define your character more than your non-upgradable skills. Still, it's fun to unlock and play all the different characters.

I've been told to buy this at least 100 times over the last 2 years.
 It took me drinking an entire bottle of vodka on New Years eve for my friends to con me into actually doing it. Thanks to that I'm down $15 for a game that's worth maybe $3. To be fair it's nowhere near as bad as I thought it would be.

[b] Pros [/b]

-Semi random generated worlds make it somewhat interesting to replay.
-The graphics are bad but don't hurt to look at. Very fitting.
-There are a lot of classes I think
-it runs well

[b] Cons [/b] 
-The combat feels very bad, It's nothing more than holding down primary fire and spamming all of your ability buttons.
-Significantly overpriced.
-Ugly until you get used to it.
-3rd person ONLY.
-The whole game can be played in about an hour and the story appears to be nonsense.
-The name is nonsense, there isn't even any rain in the game.
-The soundtrack made me want to fire a shotgun into my forehead.

RoR2 falls short in the amount of chaos that you could create in the original by stacking absurd amounts of items, but the shift to 3D adds more tactics and vertical thought to the combat. Cover is now actually a thing. Line of sight actually matters in a firefight. The higher ground can and will save your life. Aiming is far more than just spraying down a 2D avenue. And there's still enough explosive item stacks to ruin your framerate if you want to. 
It even comes with a dedicated girlfriend class (The engineer) for when you're tired of playing the game and would like the AI to do it for you. Always a positive.

It's a platform 3d collectathon third person shooter with so much character and charm, it's infectious. It's an extremely difficult game, even on easy if you are new, but I have rarely felt cheated. My opinions on items and characters have changed immensely over my time playing it, and every character, map, and item gives you such a unique experience (except the chronobauble...)

This is a game where you get attached to everything. Every aspect of Risk of Rain feels personalized despite the fact that there's barely any customization for loadouts. Each character feels like they are from an entirely different genre with incredibly diverse playstyles (ex. There's a call of duty basic commando, a spellcaster with high damage and flight but lots of cooldown management like Diablo or something, A plant that heals itself and uses health as an alternate resource to manage like it's from an RTS, A grappling hooked tank like from bionic commando, and an engineer like from TF2 just to name a few of the wildly different playstyles). Characters I thought I'd love, I hated to play as, and characters I had no interest in became my favourites. This is definitely a game that requires a lot of experimentation and play time to really get the hang of, but you'll have no trouble feeling motivated to play it.

Speed and skill is the name of the game, and getting your personal and team strategies down is half the fun. I mostly play one character, and I still find tons of interesting combinations to keep me invested and creative as I play. As much as I hate to say it, you almost have no time to think or plan, but the experience of playing this game, and getting just that much better at thinking quick is a remarkable feeling.

If you are on the fence about this game, get it. You won't be disappointed.
its cool game and there is spider man aka loader!

It's an extremely well produced version of the original, to the point that you have to play a lot to see the original inside it. Your first fifty or so hours are going to be really, really fun. Running around, unlocking stuff, finding new builds and new items. Cool. 

It gives you a meaningful choice how you spend your time. And the big plus for me is that there was so much variety in the stuff to unlock and see. 

But then it runs into the same problem as the original where you end up feeling the loop and you see it for the grind it is. Kiting away and dealing tons of damage, repeat. It's the kind of problem you run into where you really only have one or two metrics your leveling up effectively. Crit damage, crit chance, base damage, bleed. These are all the same stats effectively and based on who you are playing/ how, one is going to be objectively better. 

I don't think it's one of those rouge lights you can squeeze hundreds of hours out of, but the time it does work for you is going to be a blast. And the co-op function is amazing if you have friends. 

It's definitely worth playing and the devs keep supporting it. 7/10. A low 7/10.

If you love figuring out ways to become overpowered or "cheese" the game, this is the game for you. This is easily the best gift I received this season.

Absolutely perfect sequel to a fantastic game. Incredible transition from 2D to 3D with fantastic music and artstyle while still maintaining the incredible roguelike gameplay from the first game.
As a huge fan of roguelikes, I'd have to say Risk of Rain 2 is one of my favorite rougelikes on steam as of writing this and easily one of the best coop roguelikes by far.
The devs have done a fantastic job listening to the community and supporting the game over the last 2 years and I'm eager to see how the expansions might add to the game going forward.
Additionally, the modding community is quite extensive and it's very simple to mod the game to better fit your preferences or even add additional content for more replayability.
If you like roguelikes, especially if you have friends who would play with you, this game is well worth $25 USD not including sales. Easiest recommend of my life.

I haven't played to much Risk of Rain 2 and have only beaten the game one time.  I got the game on sale back in early November, and didn't like it at first.  I would always die at the teleporter boss, and if I didn't die there I would die on the next stage.  But then, when I figured out that items were the way to go, I got farther.  Eventually, around hour 18, I beat the game as Huntress.  I haven't really tried again since then mainly becuase runs can take anywhere from 40 to 70 minutes on the easiest mode.  This can be hard, especially because you can't save.  It can be hard to just play a run because you don't get anything, even if you end the run.  And typically I don't have the time to just sit down for an hour or more on any normal day and play Risk of Rain 2.  That is really all I have against it.  It is fun, lot's of content, and diverse characters.  I think that if I had more time to play games on a given day, I would be putting RoR higher on the list.

Risk of Rain returns with a diferent perspective....and that's about all. The 3rd person perspective greatly damages the gamemplay. The game retains all the mechanics from the previous title, but said mechanics were never thought for a 3rd person shooter, and they don't work.

Despite having a lot of flaws, the game is very addictive and its a good cooperative game.

The good:
+The game looks nice
+The characters have interesting skill sets
+Lots of items
+A new printer system that allows you to customize the build
+Very addictive gameplay
+Fun if played in coop

The bad:
-The variety of enemies and bosses is low enought your will feel like you are always fighting the same stuff
-The ammount of maps is also very low
-The teleporter is really hard to find in a 3rd person perspective, making runs strongly luck-based
-The dificulty escalates very abruptly. Some runs may be really easy while others are impossible, depending on random elements.
-The item system makes for a very unforgiving multiplayer
-The ammount of emenies in screen makes it nearly impossible to see what is hitting you some times
-This game is VERY heavy on CPU (particularly on the more advanced dificulties). So avoid it if you are worried about heat.`
-Very weak game to play solo

This is a polished masterpiece of a game. I had no clue a 3-D rogue-like could be so good. There are diverse characters and playstyles and a myriad of items and perks to buff and build your character as you wish while synergizing them all together! Characters encourage a specific style for each of them, without making them feel too linear. Want consistency and balance? Play commando. Want mobility and speed? Play loader! Want to not have to think about hurting enemies, and instead let mechanics do it for you? Play Acrid or Engineer! There's such good viability for each character (Not saying there is no meta) that you don't ever feel worried about going in at a real disadvantage. Controls/Movement are tight and tactile, and scaling is gradual enough to let you process the change without feeling overwhelmed. There are tons of secrets in the game to explore and plenty of progression to keep you enthralled for one of my favorite roguelikes to date (but it will never defeat gungeon).

Special Note: The music is RIDICULOUS. Polyrythyms, metal power ballads, eletcronic bangers and thrashers... Its ridiculous...

Got this game for Christmas and it is really fun. Only thing is there isn't too many people online for multiplayer but you there are enough that you can usually get into a lobby.

At it's best, Risk of Rain 2 will have you engaged in hectic but satisfying swarm combat with unique playable characters, interesting abilities, buffs, and the occasional synergy.

At it's worst, the game is a sadistic slog where you simply hope that you won't get screwed over by RNG, and that you'll be given enough healing items to survive the constant unavoidable damage. If you're new to the game, there's a very good chance you will die to one of the instant-death effects right at the end.

It can be very fun, but in my experience fun has been the rare exception, not the rule. For example, I once got stuck on a level for over 20 minutes because the teleporter was clipped into the terrain and other objects. 
By the time I finally found and activated it, the boss immediately two-shot me because the difficulty had scaled up too far. I've done about a dozen runs, and almost every single time I have walked away from the game pissed off.
This game does not respect your time, and is all too eager to instantly end a run. 

Maybe pick it up when there's a good discount. Hopefully your experience will be better than mine.

Deeper Detail:
Very fun game to burn some time in, several classes and play styles to choose from allowing you to mix and match your builds to your hearts desire in medium to lower difficulties.
However, on "Monson" difficulty (the hardest) you are going to be forced to min max specific builds in order to finish anything. In addition, if you're a completionist this is going to be a huge disappointment and the funs going to be completely sucked out of the game within a few hours.

this is a rewrite of my original. risk of rain 2 is a fast paced action roguelike, and is a time sponge, you pic it up for about 10 mins and you are instantly hooked. that art style is beautiful, the music is stellar, the games play is fast snappy and intuitive, and pretty much reinvented the wheel when it came to the repetitive gameplay loops that plague most roguelikes. the base game can get boring however, runs can slog, and some just fail outright. but throw in the dlc, and it pretty much erases those problems from existing in the first place. by adding a handfull of brand new consepts, maps, enemies, bosses and more. i hole heartedly recommend this game, as it is one of my favorite roguelike, and seems to be one of the majorities as well.

Stage 5's track especially is just so damn good that I'm convinced that the composer is the reincarnation of jesus himself, it's that good. Only ever really heard good things about the game for the longest time and now that I've played it I can see why.

Upon really getting to grips with the games basic systems, that baseline understanding blows the game wide open and everything becomes that much more enjoyable. 

Each character [that I've played] feels wholly distinct while still fitting well within the games scaling and itemization. You can immediately tell which characters suit which play style with the informative descriptions before dropping in. The challenges for each are nicely themed and range in varying difficulties and with the ones I've done they are well worth doing.

The game's itemization and scaling feel good on the whole, you can certainly make do without any big pulls for a good while before you start to feel lacking though sometimes you can fall prey to some bad rng but you wouldn't be playing the game if you didn't want that risk. Items are simple in nature and very effective, anything you don't want to hold on to can be exchanged later (with a bit of luck) and the distribution between the item tiers seems very fair.

The enemies/bosses and their elite variants provide an engaging challenge and a good bit of variety throughout and the final boss is fittingly unlike everything else before it. It's usually pretty simple to figure out what's done you in and thus easier to know what to improve upon last time.

Levels are generally nice to look at and throw their own sets of challenges at the players alongside some tricky areas to get to as well. The game does a good job of letting players identify where the next objective is (or isn't).

The game's art style proves itself immediately recognizable and easy on the eyes. The game is very lightweight and runs well as a result, very handy for when things start to get crazy and you need everything to go smoothly. Visual and audio cues are plenty and very easy to read to know what's happening and serve as an essential part of the whole 'not dying' thing.  

On the whole, a very complete package for fans of the roguelike genre. Plenty of room for player growth with each character. Several engaging challenges and secrets to discover. Special modifiers to be optionally applied to every run. A killer soundtrack and pretty a game. And that's not to mention the extensive modding community either.

The game is designed to be a time waster. Frankly, none of the enemies except the bosses are difficult at all, and depending on the character you play they are either target practice or bullet sponges. The entire game seems to be designed to artificially inflate game time, with long intervals between enemy spawns and sometimes difficult to find teleporters with mostly meaningless interactions.
Just the right amount of frustrating and satisfying.

You can make insanely busted builds and stomp every enemy in your path, loop through the levels multiple times to rack up an arsenal to face the final boss or you can just hunt for unlocks. An excellent roguelike with just enough variety to feel accessible without ever getting stale.

Characters are excellent - they each play in completely different way with high skill ceilings and tricky challenges to progress their skillsets.

Items are wacky, fun, and still good - no item is truly useless and there is a good balance of simple status effects and buffs with gameplay-shifting build-breakers.

Level design is very well thought out - some play to certain characters strengths, while others may dramatically hurt your run depending on your items and character. They feel familiar, overwhelming, challenging, and complimentary to the flow of gameplay all at once.

The story is barebones, but it does well enough to serve why we're here and what's going on. At the end of the day, it helps define a great, minimalistic art style that is informative, distinct, and charming all in one.

Enemy design is great - it never over-complicates itself like many 3D roguelikes do, but instead streamlines your expectations with similar status effects to those you can apply, creating familiarity without forgetting challenge.

Risk of Rain 2 is a very well made game that is a ton of fun to play, especially with friends. I will tell you what you are getting yourself into if you decide to buy this game. Risk of Rain 2 is a roguelike game where you progress through stages via teleporters and level up, gain items, and fight stronger and more unique enemies as you go with a starting character (there are 11) you chose in the lobby. Every teleporter there is a boss that will be REQUIRED to kill before entering to the next stage. Once you reach stage 5, you can choose to loop (go back to the first stage and continue but the enemies as well as you keep items/levels) or fight a final boss after defeating some pillars. You can also add artifacts in the lobby to spice up the experience.

Upsides of RoR2
- Very fun leveling up faster than the enemies and feeling a sense of progress
- A lot of ways to customize your experience (artifacts, 11 different characters, even mods, etc)
- Very fun with friends
- Plenty of secrets and lore added into the game
- Bungus

Downsides of RoR2
- Kinda annoying if you die to a lagspike in a god run that took several hours
- Without friends if you have already beat the game several times, it loses replayibility value

That is my summary of RoR2. Of course thats not all, theres still plenty to see for yourself. I would rate this game a 9.5/10. I have 108 hours and it still is a lot of fun. That is all, have a great day!

[h1] Genuinely blown away by this experience so far [/h1]

It's extremely rare these days that you stumble across a game that really gets a grip on you, that kind of grip where you refuse to put it down and it remains in the back of your mind. This game hooked me very quickly with the chaotic gameplay coupled nicely with roguelike elements that gives it extra replayability. 

Main pros:

- This game isn't afraid of you becoming ridiculously powerful to the point of godlike abilities, and that's as fun as it sounds
- Brilliantly intense combat that goes from 0-100 within a second
- Multiple different characters (many of which you can unlock after completing certain objectives) that each have a fun and unique place
- Expansive maps that (for the most part) look great and apparently hide secrets
- Time-pressure mechanic (which I didn't originally think I'd be fond of) actually works really well
- Almost every time I die, it's because of a clear mistake I made or something I need to learn from, which lessens tilt and creates a more enjoyable experience overall
- The devs appear to be transparent and communicative with the community

Main cons:

- Potentially controversial opinion, but artifacts kind of ruin the game for me to some degree. Having the option available to switch up your game is great, but providing no downside for doing so (or alternatively, an obvious benefit to playing vanilla) means there is no good reason not to pick up strong artifacts that feel like cheat codes. Yes, you could just say "dont use them" but I'm in the camp that would rather not have this option in the first place,or have a significant reason not to use them, rather than rely on self restraint.
- Dramatically fluctuating FPS can be a bit jarring at points
- This may be personal preference, but imo the colours are a little washed out
- Enemy variety is on the lower side (why are those rock monsters and lesser wisps everywhere?)
- (Minor final boss spoiler) [spoiler] The final level + boss kinda sucks imo. It's either a cakewalk or you're underpowered and gameplay slows to a crawl [/spoiler]

Follow these two simple questions to see if you should buy this game or not! 

1. Do you like third person action games? 
2. Do you like roguelikes? 

If your answer is yes to either of these two questions; BUY THIS GAME RIGHT FUCKING NOW!

I first played this game with no familiarity or context about what I was getting into, and after 47.6 hours as of this review, I believe this is the best way to enjoy the game. Do NOT, if you haven't already, spoil yourself for what this game is and what lies within it. It is a magical experience that must be enjoyed by yourself or with friends with a blind eye. Anyways, I digress.

[b] The Basics [/b]

   The game starts you with just two unique survivors and dumps you into an unrelenting world of challenge, filled with aliens, loot, secrets, and many, many, run killers. This game is by far the most unique yet challenging roguelike I have ever touched, while also being one of the easiest to learn. Just as a roguelike should be, you start each game with nothing but the survivor you have chosen. You will go around killing enemies and collecting loot, making yourself more powerful, to make it to the next stage and to continue battling the increasing challenge of enemies. You can play by yourself or tag along with friends. Your goal for each run might not be the same, as you may want to go for a boss, particular stage, certain character or ability unlock, or build to end it on. No run-through of the game will ever feel the same because of the dynamic enemies that you will be finding and fighting, the different varieties of loot drops you may come across, and of course, the challenges that await being discovered.

 [b] The Challenge [/b]
   
    This game will kick your fucking teeth in. It's so hard and sometimes demoralizing to think you're doing so well in your skills as a survivor and luck in your loot drops to then be instantly killed by a tough enemy you may have never even seen before. Yet, you start another run. That's something this game forces on you somewhat early on, learning from your mistakes. Don't take any run for granted, it could turn sour in a heartbeat. That's why, when you do have that one "god-run," it feels so satisfying to achieve and to wanna pursue again in another run-through. Skill and luck do play a factor in achieving such a run; however, for those who are not to fond of the RNG, Scrappers and 3D-Printers exist within stages to help mitigate the risks that come with luck based RNG. These two mechanics, to me anyways, are so important to successful runs that beginner players will come to realize, giving a lot of depth to the game. Speaking of...

[b] The Depth [/b]

    The Scrappers and 3D-Printers give players the option to get rid of loot they don't want in exchange for a guaranteed drop of your choice; essentially, allowing for players to have choice in the builds they want to make for their survivor within a particular run. Because the contents of these printers will never be the same, the choices in a custom build will never be the same every run. There are both silly funny and stupid busted builds that players will come to realize are possible with their survivors when experimenting with these two mechanics, once more increasing the replay value because of what can be possible. 

    I previously mentioned the secrets that this game has; many of them are purposefully withheld from players to further increase the surprise and reward factor when they are eventually discovered. These secrets can range from new item drops, surprise character unlocks, stage easter eggs, new enemies/bosses, new secret stages/realms, and even new gameplay mechanics. Some of these secrets you may come across super early and some far later into your playtime than you'd realize. It ranges for each player. For example, it took me and a friend 23 hours into the game to come across the visually horrifying and equally as powerful [spoiler] Grandparent [/spoiler] enemy and about 40 hours to discover the [spoiler] A Moment, Whole [/spoiler] hidden realm that allowed us to fight a new boss we had never seen before. Most of these secrets are not just for show and tell either, as some may have a huge impact on your future runs once discovered. For example, after the discovery of the [spoiler] Void Fields [/spoiler] hidden realm, I never miss a chance to stop by there to try my chances at better early-game loot for a run. And on Siren's Call, my party [spoiler] always destroys all of the bird eggs to spawn the secret Alloy Worship boss fight [/spoiler] to guarantee our chances at an extra Red Legendary loot drop. With the hours that I have, you'd be surprised to hear that there are still at least two enemies I have yet to encounter. There are plenty more secrets not mentioned above that leave players to discover and utilize them on their own. I highly encourage discovering them yourself and not through other means, as the natural progression of the game will allow you to discover everything in a satisfying and rewarding manner. The game's natural progression and depth will keep you coming back and playing for far longer than you'd imagine. 

    In terms of natural progression, their are also unlockable characters and items you will be earning as you play. In the beginning, you'll really just be playing to play and will occasionally unlock something. But once you explore the game more, you'll start to figure out how to unlock certain things you want to earn and will shoot for runs that fulfill the requirements in unlocking it. Each character plays differently and feels unique to the rest of the cast, breathing new life into a run once you begin mastering them. 

[b] Final Thoughts [/b]

    This review is getting long so I'm going to wrap it up here. The final two things I would like to mention is the soundtrack and the mod support. The soundtrack is a BANGER, and shouldn't go as hard as it does. Just get to Stage 5 or search up "The Rain Formerly Known As Purple," on Youtube or Spotify to hear what I mean, the guitar solo is orgasmic. And the mod support adds infinite replayability to this already replayable game. My friends and I play with the ROR1 Survivors, ROR1 Classic Items, ROR2 Unused Enemies, and Starstorm 2 mod to retain much of the original first game while also making the second game feel different from vanilla but still ROR2. 

    I'm sure I forgot something I love about this game to mention, but I'm sure you can hear it from another person's positive review. Hell this game is full of them. It's worth more money than it already is. I never write reviews, but this game is a masterpiece. I haven't enjoyed a video game this much in years. You can tell that so much love was put into it and everyone in the community should thank the devs for continuing to support it. I am going to continue increasing my hours in the hopes of another god run.

    [b] 11/10. [/b]

I'll do some pros and cons. 

Pros:
Interesting map layout and design.
Really good gunplay.
Interesting enemies and bosses.
Its difficulty levels are good and accurate.
It's fun to progress and go through teleporters.
Good controls.
Cool powerups and abilities.
Good selection of characters.
If you fall off of the map you don't die.
Very easy to learn.
(One thing I personally think is cool, as the levels go on, the difficulty scale goes up, the thing I like about it is
the contents of the difficulties, the last 3 are, "I see you", "I'm coming for you" and and endless series of 'HAHAHA').

CONS:
If you quit the game, it ends your run.
If you open a chest that swaps out one of your powerups for another, you don't get to choose which powerup it takes, and you can't get it back (it doesn't even tell you that you can't choose).

All in all, I give it a 9/10.

Fun fact: while I was thinking of cons, I realized even more pros.

As someone who isn't a huge fan of rogue likes Risk of Rain is perfect for me.
There's lots of variety, unlocks are common and it's not hard to finish a run in some form.
Meaning you constantly feel like you're making progress.

On top of that the characters are really fun to play and the game has great game feel as a result.
The massive variety in play styles stops you getting bored to quick as you can just try something else out.

My one complaint is that runs tend to play out quite similar.
You'll use your combat abilities until you've picked up a huge amount of passive damage and healing then you'll keep killing til you can't no more.
Sometimes it's harder, sometimes it's easier depending on RNG.
But you won't really have big pick ups that change your run massively like some other roguelikes.
Since most of the damage buffs are entirely passive and usually apply to all of your abilities you'll probably play your max level character the same as the first level, you'll just move a bit faster and have shorter cooldowns.

You don't know real happiness until you have 2 clovers, 5 atg's, a meat hook, a few predatory instincts, and a shatterspleen on dual nailgun MUL-T because...
wow

Risk of Rain 2 is a masterfully crafted, well made gaming experience that's right up the alley of any rouge-like fan or anyone who's looking for a good challenge.

The scenery goes absolutely perfect with it's polygon aesthetic. The soundtrack is an absolute banger and goes very well with your gameplay as you traverse flaming deserts to illusive void fields. The art direction always beats a game's graphics in terms of what ages better in my opinion, and I think that this will be a prime example when someone looks back at it some years later.

Choose your own playstyle with a handful of unique characters, each with their own unique weapons and utilities. Fight off hordes of creatures ranging from fireball lizards to phasing shadow demons. Loot from a selection of useful (some useless) tools and upgrades to help to fight your way to the finish line. Play how you want, but if you've come looking for victory, play fast! Difficulty rises the longer you aren't aren't progressing, rising from "This Is Difficult, But Fun!" to "Dear God Why Did I Buy This $22 Piece Of Steaming Hot Trash In The First Place." I can see how the difficulty can shoo some players off. I understand that some people are looking for a casual game to play and I totally understand, but if you like a good challenge and something that needs some speed, try this, you might like it! 
And if this game scared you off in the past, I suggest that you try it again if you're not sure, you might like it this time!

I've come to the realization that the rain implied in the title doesn't translate to in-game rain, but more of a metaphor, something like, in your point of view, a really enjoyable and nice run, good items and overall performance in battle, and then, a big fire lizard dude slaps you in the back of the head and the next thing you see is your character's rag doll flying all over the map while your health bar is in negative.

There, right there, that's the moment the so mentioned "rain" comes into play, it wasn't referring to some meteorological phenomenon at all, it was talking about you, more specific, your feelings, it's not the sky that is raining, your eyes are, tears of pure disappointment and anger, yet . . . I want to start a new run, how strange. . . maybe i'm a masochist.

You managed to create the perfect combination of items. 
Once you kill one enemy and you set off a rube goldberg chain of debuffs, that makes bodies explode, slows enemies and burns them to ash, feeding a growing snowstorm that freezes and damages your foes, leeching health for every tick of damage, giving you a shield that stacks with every kill, making your graphics card beg for mercy. Enemies and bosses alike melt in front of you. You're invincible, you're going to beat the game. Who's going to stop you? You have the power of god and anime on your side!

Out of nowhere you hear a guitar. Almost inaudible at first, it plays a few notes, barely a melody. Your brain refuses to recognise the pattern.

The guitar repeats the notes.

A cold shiver creeps up your spine. Everything is going perfectly, your health and shield bar is full, your 17 health drones swarm around you like cleaner fish a great white, you see enemies get atomised in cinematic 12 fps and yet.... 
something is off.

Suddenly, the guitar plays a quick melody, not very loud, but it hits you like a freight train. 
Something from behind attacks you, dealing 4 trillion damage instantly. 

Before you can even make sense of what happened, the screen tints yellow and freezes.

[b] Roundabout [/b] by [b] Yes [/b] echoes through your head, while you read the final message:


 [h1] [spoiler] ur dead LOL get rekt [/spoiler]  [/h1]

I recently hit the 1k hours mark. That's time played not sitting idle. So i've played about 1,000 matches. Typically one match can last around an hour, sometimes half an hour, and i've had both games reaching stage 40+ for over 5 hours and i've stayed on the first stage for 4hrs (with sacrifice). 

I've had all achievements since 2019 and i still play the game almost everyday. This game is bloody addictive. The culmination of a fresh start, with vanilla or various artifacts, possibly mods, new people to play with, game get's more players every sale, and an expansion is set to come out in 2022.

I STRONGLY recommend this game to anyone and everyone. HOWEVER, be warned, the community for this game can get very toxic. I try to steer clear of the forums as there are a few trolls and negative people on there.

That being said, i have enjoyed at least 80% of my time in this game, because you have to rely on the RNG gods for their favor in the items and rarity your going to receive and the types of monsters that may spawn up your arse as soon as you begin looting something.

Roguelike game played in third-person. Runs generally can last up to an hour, if you make it far and don't die. Expect the following things from this game:

+ stylized graphics
+ a healthy variation of environments, enemies, and artifacts (game modifiers you enable before a run) to mix things up
+ Lunar Items also add interesting ways of mixing things up
+ each character has their own rhythms that make them feel distinct and...well, their own characters, rather than classes.
+ though the game can feature characters with very fast movement speeds, you generally move a lot faster than enemies, and enemies in this game are generally easy to outrun or maneuver unless you specifically move near them to attack. This aspect of the gameplay loop means that you can always try running back so you have time to plan your next attack, if things get tricky. This makes the game less reliant on twitch reflexes.
+ a solid gameplay loop
- both final bosses (the default and the Beads of Fealty routes) have abilities that can decide the fight before it even begins if you do something wrong with your inventory.
- RNG for item drops on this game can be very unforgiving, and on some characters such as the Commando, this is almost to the point of deciding your entire run. However, if you really do not like the RNG, an option exists; enabling the Artifact of Command before your run starts will allow you to choose item drops, removing a huge part of RNG.

One of my favorites.

Risk of Rain, the first one, was a fun little game. Deceivingly simple it really built up after 20 or 30 hours. It had a good recipe at its core. And when Risk of Rain 2 was announced... In 3D... It just felt right. It felt like it was going to work. Maybe that wasn't the consensus at the time given that kind of leap rarely works for a series, but I was onboard. I bought it right away and dove in once I could. It works. Spectacularly. The change allowed the game to blossom. 120 some odd hours later of blindly blasting about and I finally beat the game on "Monsoon" (hard) difficulty. Solo, with the commando (base character). Yup, solo. This game is billed as a game to be played with others. It is indeed at its best co-op (up to 4players). But you can go it alone. There's a huge community around the game and I'm sure if I poked my nose in I could've learned some tips or game meta stuff that would've made my journey a little easier. But I was too stubborn. I had to conquer that moon myself. 

After a year of playing it in bursts on and off I beat it the way it felt right to me. And so it was finally time to review. 

I hesitate to break details down or talk too much about character variety, difficulty arcs, powerups because all I'll do is gush. This game is an all timer for me. Simple as that. I have a million things to say about it and they're all redundantly good and positive. As of the writing of this; 100k reviews "overwhelmingly" agree that it's a good one! All I can really hope to add to the consensus is that; It's perfectly fun, and a heck of a challenge, solo too. That doesn't get mentioned much. I'm pretty sure the review website I read even explicitly said it wasn't fun solo when they reviewed it back on release. But it is. The mountain is harder to conquer alone, a Sherpa (or three) makes for an even more spectacular time, but just have it any way you can. Play this game! If you're reading a review and still haven't tried it; do it. You can get everything out of Risk of Rain 2 that you are willing to put in. It rewards effort. It rewards your time. It rewards your grind. And it takes an awful lot to plateau. Even then, there's usually an update (or a DLC!) looming. More more more. 

Your weather forecast should always be rain. Strongly recommended. An all time classic that is still being developed really isn't something to be ignored or skipped.

This is an amazing game that intimidated the crap out of me at first! There's great depth and if you put in a little time and brainpower to learning the ropes and finding a main (or few) you will be greatly rewarded with the thrill of ridiculous power. Don't be put-off if you play with friends at first and are overwhelmed as they carry you; just give yourself time for the concepts to sink-in.

Just know that when people say "you can play it on a potato," you [i]technically can[/i] but your runs will always be short because at some point your frames will slow dramatically. It's still [i]possible[/i] to clear levels when spawns chunk you down to like 8fps, but don't expect reliably epic god-runs if you aren't on a decent PC.
So, on a 2.4 GHz CPU with 7GB RAM and a 1050 ti and lowest settings it was [i]possible[/i] to complete 20 levels and [i]possible[/i] to grind-out runs longer than 6 real-life hours, but it was [b]not reliable and not recommended.[/b]
