Do you like fun? Well then, Risk of Rain 2 is for you! This game incorporates many of my favorite aspects from other games like Mass Effect 3 Multiplayer, the Borderlands franchise and Overwatch with a Rogue-light flavor that will keep you coming back for more. 

Slaughter wave after wave of their own men with your favorite character builds along side your best buds! Explore beautiful maps to find hidden secrets! Unlock new characters through your in-game merits! Small file size, but delivers huge fun! My SO and I have been playing together and rekindling our gaming bond. :) There are other benefits to this game too.

Spoilers (?). Just beware.

Game is good - for me. I love mindless RNG-based shooting after tense working days.

I play only singleplayer runs. I bought RoR2 after release and didn't play it in early access.

For 90% of time I run as Commando, Mercenary, Huntress or Artificer. I find other characters boring for now: Artificer also felt like a sack of potato but then it became sooo good and satisfying to play. Those four chars have higher mobility and can deal some dmg.

Most of the time I play on Drizzle or Rainstorm. Monsoon feels tense and I don't want that kind of challenge. But it is certainly welcomed.

Drizzle is quite easy after 1 loop. Do you know what the loop is? Reach Sky Meadow, find a challenge teleporter, put a code (any code will do) and go through. Or use other routes. Enemies will become stronger, bosses will spawn randomly as regular enemies, teleporter bosses will be doubled with each loop.

It's more complicated on higher difficulty. This requires some skill and some amount of luck. 
RNG gods may give blessing and you will get red items during 1st stage, or they won't bless you. So you will play around with what's available. Later there are chests/bosses which drops good loot. Whatever, it's not that unfair - after all, this is roguelike. If RNG isn't what you want - why even bother?

Obtain more and more items and you may prevail during the run.

Still, RoR2 will try to play itself if you gathered enough items. Leeching HP and building shield while dealing DMG, also almost all that DMG leads to crits, bleeding, curse, chain lightning, explosions and so on... 
Sometimes I didn't even understand what killed enemies. I mean... Some of them died out of my sight -- maybe I sprinted or jumped too fast for them to deal with it. You can become so thick and threatening after being very fragile. I like it - some may not.

How to make runs different or challenging? Use artifacts. There are a lot of them. Become a glass canon, make all enemies elites (and eff them with some specific item), etc. It's cool, I appreciate the effort.

And after long 200-300 minutes of a run you will come to Mithrix, the last boss.
Most of enemies are slow, really slow, they can be spongy and deal good DMG. He is fast and can deal high DMG, easily one-shooting.
This guy is boring and lacks variety. It usually takes minutes to kick him to the death even when mobs/bosses vaporize in seconds or during spawn.
He has three or four phases:
- running-smashing-dodging
- (can't say this is a TRUE phase) call for mobs... ew
- running-smashing-dodging + calling for mobs + do some DMG with magick :)
- stealing your items and walking slowly (maybe something else but he dies quickly, losing items when getting DMG)
That's why I would rather loop around 5-6 times then going straight to Mithrix. To have my mindless fun with this game. Nevertheless, it's more satisfying to obliterate in the Void then beating that sack of moonflash.

Therefore, I kinda recommend this game. 
Nothing too deep. Bang-bang. Some skill or luck till you become a death machine are required.

My first game I did NOT know how to play, the difficulty kept increasing! Is this winnable??? Died before I even understood that money was lost between teleports... lol

Then I played with some friends who knew how the system worked, all of a sudden the game made sense and I could walk around casually at the final timer difficulty, incredible! Being carried by some OP teammates gave me the time to actually read item descriptions and ask questions, far better than any video tutorial.

It's such a break from the stereotypical FPS genre and it's so much more fun. The whole progression isn't "beat each level in order and get better gear" it's "run because every second you waste makes it harder and pile on everything you can grab".

The amount of replayability is also insane, not even having unlocked any new characters, every run was something entirely different and I had to learn new mechanics and strategy every time, forcing me to think fast while always in motion, it keeps the pace of the game enjoyable and leaves no chance to settle into a single play style for the whole run.

You're going to die repeatedly. Whether you just started playing or have played for a long time now. You are going to die again, again, and again by either a lack of skill, bad item rng, or because the game says you should.

And because it's a great roguelite. You're going to come back to die more.
Risk of Rain 2 is almost perfect. Besides some lame stage design, the lore of the characters, 3D modeling, enemies, and everything else are on point.

I've yet to learn all the mechanics of this game, but I highly recommend this game if you want something that you never get tired of.

Rouge-likes have always been a very interesting genre of game, but no rouge-like has ever come close to RoR2. The game flows really well, and it's very easy to get hooked on the game and saying "one more" constantly through day or night until your boss calls you asking why you weren't at work for the past week. Besides some unlocks, every run you start in RoR2 has you start over from ground zero; no items, no exp, stage 1, adding a fresh feeling at the start of every run. The longer the game goes on, the harder it gets, and it's always a grueling feeling watching the dificulty tick over from "I'M COMING FOR YOU" to "HAHAHAHA." With that being said, the game does require a lot of time to actually play, as each run typically lasts around an hour if you don't loop around, and an extra half an hour for each loop after that. Still, this is easily the best game I've ever played. 13/10.

My only criticism with this game is there is lack of "builds" so to speak. You're always looking for the same key items - AtG, Runald's/Kjaro's band, ukelele and so on. I suppose its only natural that in a rogue like you'd wanna stack as many bonus damage items as possible, but once you get 1.5-2 ish hours in, all games are basically the same.

This game is like home for sweaty try hards. The more you play and progress through the levels the difficulty increases until you cannot handle it anymore, it gets pretty intense but is super fun. One thing I don't/can't recommend though is playing on 64 player slot servers as doing so with max settings turned up my game had a very bad crash/freeze on one of the higher difficulties/levels. Hundreds of bosses/enemies spawning constantly and only 30 some players were on the servers I played in on. Having that many players on a server with all that going on at the same time was causing the game to lag very badly and eventually ended up in a freeze/crash and had to restart my pc. My PC Specs below.

CPU: Ryzen 9 3600x
GPU: Nvidia GeForce 2060 Super SC Ultra
Ram: 32gb Trident Royal Z
Storage: 1TB SSD

So yeah if there's one bad thing about this game it would be the 64 slot playable servers.  Other than that, the game is solid and has a highly addictive and interesting gameplay loop. To put it simply...

Stumbling around through ugly, monotonous environments isn't "spooky". It's just boring. There isn't anything to do in the world but stare at the same few creatures you're hacking and slashing your way through. Endless. Sprawling. Grey and brown.

And then there's the lack of video settings options. And the abject failure of the button mapping to update the HUD's tips and labels. So after you remap your keys you better remember what they are when you come back after a month because the game absolutely will not tell you. This is basic UI design issues and it's profoundly embarrassing to be seeing this in the 21st century. And then there's the awkward translations which end up misdirecting you or even just flat-out lying to you about what things do. No, you actually can't This critique has been repeating a theme a lot, but it's fitting for this specific game. It's not actually a game. It's just a tedium simulator. It's not difficult, it's anti-designed. It's not dark and depressing, it's just boring and ugly.

Is it the absolute worst I've ever played? No. But it's among the worst ten, in the last twenty five years of gaming.

One of the best games I have ever played. 
10/10
Pros
-The games design and pacing is phenomenal, the game is built around the player's ability to come up with combinations 
 of items, abilities, equipment's and characters. The choice to allow items to stack infinitely allows for the unlimited 
 empowerment of the player to a point when you almost always feel overpowered, while making each run very unique. Yet 
 despite this (when playing on the highest difficulty especially) the player never feels complacent. Even when you can kill 
 an entire stage by being afk 5 times in a row, there is a good chance you will be one shot next stage, keeping the game 
 always fresh.
-Each of the characters is unique and plays different, while some do feel more powerful than others every character feels 
 balanced and on a level playing field and each synchronises with different items much better making each run feel unique 
 and keeping any item from being wholly redundant.
-Music and visuals are awesome, though it is subjective I doubt its controversial to say that the music slaps. The visuals are  
 vibrant and well designed giving each enemy distinctive features, types and abilities so they feel fresh.
-Game has full modding support and a very active modding community.
-The devs are absolute legends.

Cons
-If you have epilepsy or light sensitivity, I would advise to avoid the game.
-It is extremely fast paced and at times somewhat overwhelming.
-There is a disturbing amount of porn mods (this may be a positive for some)

I just want to thank Hopoo for this masterpiece in action/rogue-like gaming. 
I played the first game a lot with my friends back when it came out in 2013/14, and after a while we had sussed out how to overcome the difficulty curve and play until we would nearly crashed our computers. 
The original game was great, and seeing this game announced left me with high expectations for the sequel, and when the pre-release version was made public I, and my friends bought it as soon as possible. We were blown away to see the game in 3D: the characters, enemies and bosses all making an almost seamless transition into the new 3D environment. Even with just 3 maps it was just like going back to 2013: we just threw ourselves into the game and all the challenges, with improving with each run.
The game is a bit of a challenge for my ageing computer, but even with low graphics settings selected, I think the game is great to look at, the sound design and music (just like in the first game) really round off the gaming experience, and the difficulty always keeps you on your toes. 
So if you like a frantic action game where you feel like you are in constant danger, then I really recommend Risk of Rain 2.

I give this game a thumbs up! First of all, Risk Of Rain 2 is by far the best rouge-like game that I have, I'd say it would even be one of my favorite games! Also, this game is built like a tank, it takes a lot to make this game lag. Lastly, this game has 11 different characters to choose from and earn, making you able to spend hundreds of hours with always action packed game play! In conclusion, I would rate this game a solid 9 out of 10! 
              P.S. A couple downsides about this game is, one, you can just set a timer and expect to be done right around that time, and two, this game does get very repetitive and grindy so beware. Still after all that, Risk Of Rain 2 is well worth the price!

Absolute banger of a game. Every run is different and each character is unique and fun to play. The game is also extremely mod-friendly and there are tons of quality of life and content mods available which just enhance the experience. The upcoming DLC looks amazing so far as well and will only add more content to the game, as well as a new game mode. 

There are modifiers called "artifacts" which you can enable to change up the gameplay, but in my opinion the absolute best way to play this game is with no artifacts on, which keeps the replayability high by keeping your items random and having you adapt to what the game deals you. 

There's a little bit of a learning curve, you will die a lot, but that's all part of the game. Don't get discouraged if you're having a tough time at the start, you'll learn quickly how to avoid different enemies and how to navigate each stage. It's much less daunting than it may originally appear.

Where do I begin with Risk of Rain 2...

There's a lot of positive things to say about it, so here goes.

[h1] Starting off with my personal thoughts on the characters: [/h1]

- Commando: Your beginning class and the designated Dark Souls class (because y'know, rolling around?)
Pretty strong yet underrated honestly, mainly because some builds like dps + bleed can really get him in a good DPS spot alongside other classes like Mercenary. He's also built (at least to me) to be a Jack of all Trades class, so any item will work on him just fine. Well, mostly. 

My only complaints about him are about his basic kit. They'll quickly lose use without mods or builds as you unlock the Tactical Slide and Shotgun secondary. However, you can play him as you like. 

- Huntress: Previously the class you got from an achievement (Warrior) but now another starting character, she's the designated kiting class, ignoring [i] other ideals. [/i] She's good at dodging past attacks and dealing damage of her own, though her low health pool makes her not so ideal for head-on attacks, though Crowbars work wonders.

My only complaint is how weak Arrow Rain feels compared to Ballista, but Arrow Rain still has it's uses in vanilla or modded, so it's not entirely useless!

- Bandit: Returning from Risk of Rain 1 and taking Huntress's spot in the Warrior achievement, he's a classic favourite of mine so seeing him return was a welcome surprise. I don't have any real complaints about him seeing as his kit is fluid, works well, and is fun to use. 

- MUL-T: Another good DPS class with extremely strong Crowbar synergy with his rebar railguns (like with Huntress), he's your main damage dealer in the classes in terms of range. He also has good mobility and works wonders with both ranged and melee builds. No real complaints here, but feel free to share any of your own!

- Engineer: The classic "sit and wait" class for some, but for others, not so much. His bungus turret strat is probably one of the most well known and the most broken builds on him, but I'll let you in on a secret. [spoiler] Try a bleed crit build on his laser turrets, it's super fun. [/spoiler] 

My only complaint is kinda how crap his primary is, but mods or getting good with it can alleviate the problem. 

- Artificer: Honestly - at least for me - one of the hardest yet most rewarding classes to play. She's not terrible by any means, but you'll have to learn quite a bit with her to play her good. I personally like using the crowbar ice spear tactic over the ball but any build works, [i] even the Purity flamethrower strat. [/i]

No complaints here besides how... lacklustre her alternate primary feels, but it might have some uses. 

- Mercenary: One of two overpowered melee characters, his Purity Eviscerate build tests the endurance of both the enemy and your index finger as you spam R to save your ever so risky life. Other builds however - like Slicing Winds builds - are super fun too! 

No complaints here.

- REX: One of two that I main personally, and also an absolute powerhouse with the right red items. With a fast enough attack speed, Rejuvenation Rack and Aegis, you can come [i] nearly [/i] invincible. Even though his unlock requirement can be tedious, I'd say it's worth it. 

My only complaint is how tedious the requirement is, but it's by far worth the trouble. 

- Loader: The other overpowered melee class next to Mercenary, Loader is a wrecking ball of a class capable of destroying bosses with the right setups. Thunderslam and Charged Gauntlet alongside Spiked Fist are a good build for those who unlock them, though even her basic kit is extremely good. 

No complaints here. 

- Acrid: The other that I main, and a sad mess of a class. He's a good melee class... but not on Monsoon. You can make him [b] work [/b] on Monsoon, but eventually you'll have to ditch his melee. Ranged Acrid however is a good setup. 

My complaints are that his melee builds don't really work without mods or luck, but he's still good either way. 

- Captain: The oldie but goldie that obliterates enemies with care packages like it's Call of Duty all over again. He's a reliable class and his bleed builds work amazingly on almost anything. His nuke may be impractical but it's fun once in a while. 

No complaints here. 

There are all my personal opinions, so they're short, not really informative, nor may they be true for y'all, so feel free to share your own opinions. 

[h1] On the game itself. [/h1] 

It's a roguelike shooter that pits you against enemies in various environments. Some are strong, some are weak, some are small, some are big. It all tests your patience, reaction time, and luck with loot. Most items work well or terribly with some characters while some completely break characters and turn them into absolute killing machines. You can loop as much as you want or go to (spoiler content ahead:) [spoiler] defeat Mithrix, the King of Nothing, atop Commencement. [/spoiler] 

Items are unlocked from achievements, so are Artifacts, which alter the game in certain ways. You'll naturally get item unlocks from playing the game, but you'll have to seek out the artifact boards and do their respective Trial for those achievements. Same goes with classes. 

I don't have much else to say here, so I recommend looking at Spades' beginner guide video on this game 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m7hqQ21Zs9k

And generally just have fun at your own pace; don't rush through it, find your footing and your preferred character, and have fun blazing through stages, either alone or with friends!

Risk of Rain 2 is a fine game in concept, and I'm sure a lot of people will love it and have fun with it, but I persoanlly have too many bones to pick with this game to give it a great recommendation, and would rather advise thinking carefully before picking it up.

A game of Risk of Rain 2 is a massive time commitment, and that's my main gripe with it. A normal game will take between 45m-1h30m. You can't save midway, and the entire game is based on a timer where the longer it takes, the harder the game gets. The only way to pause that timer is to go to a market place, where there's a secret minigame that takes another 10-15 minutes to get more upgrades, and you have no reason NOT to take it since it's upgrades with no penalties. After one game and failing to finish a run that you thought you had good stuff going on, my brain never goes "ONE MORE!", but rather "I'd rather play anything else".

By the time you reach the final levels and boss, the stacks of perks and items are so insane player skill is practically a second thought. Either you can annihilate almost everything in an instant, are almost or completely invincible, or you're going to die. When you die, you're out for an entire level, so you won't get all of the perks your friends gets on the rest of the map, you have to sit your ass and do nothing for 5+ minutes while they finish the level, and by the time you join in the next level, you'll be under-geared, under-perked, and you'll likely die again and have to wait and be carried to the end game.

Maybe I'm just bad at the game, or maybe I just don't get it, but for me, these massive stacking of abilities means everything gets incredibly blurred by the end and I don't find that particularly fun.

Never stops being fun and satisfying, the game is replayable af because there is always something to unlock and some of those unlockables are pretty hard to get but since the game is actually fun you ACTUALLY want to unlock the game's achievements or on the other hand you just forget you wanted to unlock some shit because you are too focused on having fun playing the game. 

It's not even just the unlockables, you just get to know your character and what makes it tick which items to go for or how to better play them so you always have something new to look for in the game.

Another thing is CHOICE, surprising for a game with a lot of RNG, but the game gives you a lot of it, you can change the game's difficulty, you can use artifacts which will either make the game harder or easier, you can destroy items to make other ones you prefer, you can use different skills for you character which completely change the way you play, you can accept optional challenges during your run which are risky but rewarding or optional difficulty modifiers that sometimes spawn around the map each level, you can either loop indefinitely or go to a final boss stage, etc.

The art is extremely good, this is coming from someone who actually makes a living making art for games, specially knowing that the guy in charge of the art was not an artist before the creation of ROR1 so its remarkable how he has grown the quality of the in game art with time. I mean I bought the game day one and I can literally tell how they have been polishing those assets little by little.

Music. I don't know man I'm not a musician but that shit slaps.

This game honestly caught me by surprise from how well it delivers in ways most games fail to do. The game itself has such a wide roster of survivors that provide every player with the playstyle that suits them, whether it be fast paced hacking and slashing enemies or just nuking enemies with one attack. The replay value of this game is so high due to how many different builds the items allow you to create and the modifiers you can add to the game to change the way you approach the game. The only small issue with the game is how multiplayer can be troublesome with too many people hoarding the limited items present and how your game can easily crash if your computer is not capable to handle the large amount of enemies and particles that can occur in the game. To sum up, this is definitely worth your time and money to play this game as it just takes all the good aspects of the rougelite genre and combine it into this masterpiece.

Risk of Rain 2 is such a blast. I've been playing it with three other friends regularly since I bought it about a month ago. The rogue like elements add variety to each run as you try to make the perfect build for your survivor each time. It's challenging in a good way, there's always that "one more run" feeling and it's kept me up late into the night. 

The gameplay is smooth and action packed. Each survivor is distinct and has a different style. Glass cannons, tanks, support, and melee characters are all present. I have my favorites, such as Mul-T with dual wielding nail guns but each survivor is fun and I switch often for the variety. Unlocking loadouts, survivors, and artifacts gives you something else to strive for other than just seeing how long you can last. There are alternate game modes as well but I haven't tried them yet, the standard mode has been a blast. 

It's fun solo but it really shines in co-op. I regularly play with 3 friends and it's so much fun. Another aspect that needs to mentioned is the soundtrack. Chris Christodoulou did an amazing job creating a killer soundtrack that really adds character to the game. It's not often I listen to a game soundtrack outside of playing the game but I do with this one. it's one of my favorites up there with Persona 5. 

I highly recommend Risk of Rain 2 especially if you have friends to play with. Gameplay is smooth, survivors are unique, it's challenging, and addicting in the best possible way.
very big fan of this game, but not a very big fan of the fact in the void fields, if they get crowbars, your run is over if you get hit, but this has quickly become one of my favorite games so far.

It is kinda hard to get going (like most rougelikes) but once you do it is VERY addictive. It is very replayable because of all the different modifiers, like artifacts, characters, and difficulties allowing most runs to never feel the same, and they all feel unique. Sometimes when a run goes bad, it really sucks because RNGesus isnt on your side and you get bad items and die fast, but when you get a good run, it feels amazing. Each character has pros and cons further adding to how good this game is, and there is lots of balance between most things.

I really wouldn't say I do or don't recommend this game. It's just ok.
Pretty shallow gameplay. 
It seems like there are a lot of items to choose from, but most of them are pretty worthless. You can do a crit build or you can be weaker than you would be if you had done a crit build. That's pretty much it, since the crit build literally has everything in it, including healing.
There are a decent number of monster affixes in actuality, but you're gonna see like 80% just the frost explosion and the burny fire affix, so it really feels like there's no variety at all.
There are melee characters, but like all of the monster affixes seem to exist simply to screw over melee characters, so why would you?
There are characters with attacks that are ground effects, but pretty much half of everything in the game is airborne making those attacks useless. Honestly, though, it doesn't matter too dang much, because once you get past like the second zone you're usually way too strong to die unless you majorly screw up.
It's fun to play together, but it just has head-scratchingly confusing gameplay design choices and is ultimately a shallow experience. It could be really great though, with some changes to the aforementioned things.

Risk of Rain 2 is an awesome third-person shooter action roguelike. There is a ton to do and unlock in this game. As of this review there are 11 playable characters, each of which have multiple abilites and a skin that you can unlock through achievements. There are a ton of different items to pick up that will change how each run is played. 2 maps to go to for each stage with an option to loop back around instead of finishing your run. This game is insanely fun and I highly recommend it

Overall top tier game, easily in my top 5 of all time. Super re-playable with tons of modifiers. Giant modding community and a well optimized mod loader that doesn't look like a Russian hacking playground. Soundtrack is amazing and very diverse.

I had originally left a review for this game when I had 46 hours in it. It's time I come back to it, now that I've sixtupled the amount of time I have in the game.

I still do not recommend this game as a solo player. Sure, in multiplayer it's a great experience. If your friends are loot goblins, there are ways to fix that with mods like ShareSuite. The characters complement each other  extremely well. I was running a challenge to complete all achievements as SinglePlayer. Although I almost got it done, it's time I give up. The melee characters are quite frankly trash. Loader is very strong, but in my humble opinion, very boring. Mercenary is just trash, period. Maybe I don't get how to play it, but I'd rather not put myself through the pain of having to play that character for no reason. Sadly, a lot of achievements are tied to these guys, notably their mastery and the prismatic trial.

This is most certainly my extreme schizophrenia when it comes to RNG, but this game is [b]hella[/b] rigged. You will have games where some items are simply absent entirely, and for some reason it tends to be the ones your character needs to prosper. I'm talking about bustling fungus on engineer, crit glasses on volley huntress, etc. And yet, you'll play another game right after as another character and get a printer of that exact item!... except you only get printers of that specific item, 5 maps in a row. It's rigged, I tell you.

[h3]Original review[/h3]
Even after this much time in the game, [strike]I despise the fact that you have to get out of levels after "about 5 minutes" because otherwise you fall behind. Even though I understand the reasoning behind it, I think it's a dumb mechanic and honestly, ruins the game for me.[/strike] Dumb friend told me dumb rule, doesn't apply.

It's important to note that I'm a solo player. It is beyond me that someone could so poorly balance a game for solo play yet so perfectly balance it for coop. Do not buy this if you're going to play it solo, it's a waste of time.

I've tried so hard to like this game, but a "winnable" run takes such specific item RNG that it just isn't fun. An average run for me lasts about 30 minutes before getting randomly 1 shot by some obnoxious elite that I didn't see spawn directly behind me while fighting 400 other monsters in my field of view.

This game severely needs a balancing mechanic for upper end monster damage. There are very few (if any) other Rogue-likes where you can be nearing the end of a run and a regular ass enemy takes you out in 1 hit. Life? Hah, doesn't matter, because if you didn't get one-shot you'll surely just die momentarily afterwards. The unlocks are just plain boring to interact with too and seemingly pure RNG whether you can complete them in any given run. In the end, nothing matters about this game because you will surely spend 80% of all your runs dying in one hit to something you didn't notice within the first 3s it was spawned.

Risk of Rain 2 is a game made by devs that care, and the gameplay shows that. You rarely, if ever feel cheated when you fail. It is by no means an easy game, but it presents a very fun and unique challenge, while also allowing you to play it in a variety of different ways that can all be effective if done right. The art style is fantastic, the visuals never get old, and don't even get me started on the god tier soundtrack. One of the few games that I have songs in the soundtrack saved and will listen to them when in my free time.

The game has a great mod community, but the vanilla game is still a fun and entertaining experience. The more you play, you unlock a variety of new items, new characters with different sets of skills and abilities, discover new areas, each with their own secrets. Those secrets could unlock new characters, an alternate stage, secret boss fights, among many other things. The only catch to this game is it has you do it all on your own. No tutorial, no hints, no guide, you're just dropped into the game and left to figure it out on your own. If you have friends with previous experience, and that have made some progression, you can play with them to much more quickly unlock new items and discover the secrets of the game. The multiplayer is loads of fun with friends, I've never actually tried playing with random players so i can't really say much about that. But the game is fun to play solo as well.

Risk of Rain 2 is a massive step up from its predecessor, Risk of Rain, in almost every way. New stages, new survivors, new items, new bosses... the game add so much more of what players already loved. Not just that, but it also delivers all this content in an entirely new format, going from a 2D side scroller to a 3rd person shooter. 

If you're someone who enjoys roguelikes, then I can say wholeheartedly that this is more than likely the game for you.

You were killed in one shot and you can't deny it. I don't even need to be there to see it. I know that is how you died. You could not have died in any other way. It will always be a one-shot kill death. There is no other death. You can only die that way. There is no other way of dying after all. Massive damage in an extremely short period of time is what will kill you and there is no escaping. It doesn't matter how much health you have it'll all be gone and there is no escape either. You'll be back to do it again. You will never stop. You'll keep getting one shot for all eternity, til all stars burn out and there is nothing but darkness left in the universe and then longer still until all of eternity ceases to be and there is just nothingness. All memories will cease to exist, all of reality is gone. Except one thing. One singular thing. A feeling. A sensation. This will continue to persist and you recognize it. This is the feeling of being killed in one shot.

All three modes are overall fun with hazard zone being surprisingly enjoyable. The only lacking content is the amount of sidearms (3) but the variety of all other weapon types and gadgets covers the majority of playstyles. Only additions i would like are a nearby medic menu when downed and crouch sprinting.”

I'm kind of enjoying it, but it ran out of steam for me... The mechanics are pretty darn slick, but the game is missing two big things for me: the ability to acquire a truly god-like game-breaking build, and pacing. The game slams on the breaks as soon as you enter the last level to fight the final boss and never picks back up. So here I am now, finally getting pretty good with one of the classes, and I just don't want to play another round because the possibility of an incredibly fun and exciting round just isn't there like it is for other rogue-lites (Hades, Nuclear Throne, FTL, Noita, just to name a few!). In all of those, the game is exciting the entire way through, never loses momentum, and there's always the possibility of a game-breaking build. Here, it's mediocrity all the way through. It feels like the devs for this game rushed it out too quickly, and that's a terrible shame because this game could have been so much better.

ROR 1 was a 2D masterpiece, the 2 is a 3D one. 

A casual/hardcore experience with up to 4 (or more modded) people, with a frenetic combat and cool progression. You can play with full rng on items, or unlock artifacts that remove randomization or even make even your character randomize every game.

And even when you finish the game, mods expand the experience as no other game. With new characters well balanced (most of), stunning  new items e tons of quality of life.
Btw the mod manager of ROR 2, R2modman has the feature of "exporting" your modlist and mod configs as a code, so all your friends who don't know a thing about modding can just paste a code a play together.
Very fun with friends, needs more progression but overall veri nise

I highly recommend to play this game if you like Roguelike games. It's one of the best ones I've played, and I've played quite a bit of them, most of them being indies.

This one might not have "a lot" of enemies, "a lot" of worlds, but it just feels so good to play.

The atmosphere is superb, a lot of object combos, very distinct characters with very distinct skills.

There are some flaws, the biggest one being bosses do not make their attack obvious, so you might have to search how to dodge this or that. Another one is some bosses have insanely powerful attacks even at the first level, which is annoying since it's not about dodging but just running away, basically no skill required, it's just a loss of time.

Those flaws are small though, and the game has so many great things as mentioned before. Do not get overshadowed by those flaws, you have to try it and decide by yourself. I am fucking terrible at games, so it might just be that too, I am almost at IGN "critics" level.

If you have seen reviews, watched others play, I highly recommend trying it out for yourself. Wait for a sale or buy at full price? In my opinion, it's worth the full asking price, but if you can get it on sale, absolutely do so.

====================================

-Graphics 4.5/5 [They  could have done a bit better with the environments, but that's about it.]

-Sound 4/5 [Explosions get a bit loud at times, and can easily overpower all other volume, this needs to be turned down]

-Music 10/5 [I can't believe how good the sound track to the game is.]

-Fun Factor replayability 5/5 [So many characters, so many different playstyles, so many bosses, so many secrets.]

Value 5/5 [There are mods, multiplayer, you can add characters and so on...]

====================================

Risk of rain 2 is one of those games that even after fully completing I still find myself returning to it. 

The game is visually exciting and the sound design is good but it's the core gameplay that I always return for, the ability to loop and play for ages if you want to is amazing and with a wide cast of characters it's very rare to get bored. 

With thousands of different playstyles made possible by the large roster of characters and items this game is enjoyable for nearly everyone. An example of one of my favorite builds in this game is an infinite missle build which allows you to just infinity fire off missles that auto target enemies and proc all your other items and abilities.

Now one issue that I find my self and friends getting annoyed at with the game is joining in progress games or saving games in general. Unless you play the game modded you cannot save your runs and that can be frustrating when you have a good run going and if you want a friend to join a mutiplayer game you have to end your run and start a new one for them to load in.

Now there is some other smaller issues but overall this game is truly amazing and the less you know about it going into it the more fun and fascinating it is. Would reccomend to anyone at any price but get ready to spend hours playing this without even noticing!

Game is both simple and surprisingly deep.  You can romp around and shoot at monsters without much thought in colorful, interesting environments,  or you can lose your mind try to perfect the perfect build for a character while dealing with increasingly brutal enemies.
I hate Rougelikes and I love this. Beautiful visuals, wonderful soundtrack, and a refreshing lack of developer sadism.

Overall it is a good game, not great, but good. Gameplay and mechanics of the game are good. I like the concept. Here is my problems with the game:

1. The first time you play it, they just drop you into the thick of it without anything to go off of. As someone who didn't play the first installment and knew nothing coming into playing the second, felt like they just dropped me into the middle of something and told me to figure it out.

2. The replayability of this game stems from making better runs and finding secrets in levels. I've spent  over 50 hours playing the game with maybe 4 survivor unlocks and no artifacts. I feel like each run gets me nowhere and doesn't make me much better at the game if at all. There is no reward after a run unless you get really far. There is no currency you can earn each run to save up for anything. You can spend 30+ minutes on a run and almost always have nothing to show for it after.

My experience is based off of playing it single player. I have played only one online game and there was just massive connection issues and wasn't fun.

[b]+[/b] While the most fun part of the game - multiplayer - kinda sucks singleplayer runs are smooth.

[b]-[/b] The netcode sucks.
[b]-[/b] The content is very limited unless you call these bizzare unlock runs content.
[b]-[/b] There are very few survivors (i unlocked most of them in 10h).
[b]-[/b] Almost no build variety or fun RNG finds, even if you get the best quality items it doesnt seem to affect gameplay that much.
[b]-[/b] Three previous issues wont get fixed unless you want to pay for the upcomming DLC.
[b]-[/b] DLC to the game this lacking in content so early after 1.0 is a crime.
I still enjoyed this game but be aware it sucks.

Just barely was able to refund this game. Here are the problems:
- Not really much direction
    - Sure you are supposed to learn the game through trial and error but there isn't even a tutorial for controls
    - The text is too tiny and too spread out
- Gameplay
    - Gameplay was fine and I would have liked it if it wasn't for the boring items and characters.
    - Items are just little stat boosts that stack. Yay. Why no items that have a major impact (like the feather which is practically essential for a winning run).
    - The characters all feel super underpowered. 
    - The most you can do to survive is just run and jump around but even then you will get sniped by a (s)hitscan enemy.
- Enemies:
    - The enemies are just the worst. You have easy to dodge enemies that can only melee, ones who have hitscan lasers, and ones who can just one tap you if you stand still for even a second.

That is just a short review of what I thought would be my next Binding of Isaac like addiction. This game was such a letdown and I won't be picking it up again.

Risk of Rain 2 is a 3D roguelike third person shooter, based around a difficulty timer ushering players through successive worlds while acquiring items to advance their combat abilities.  The sequel acts as an excellent followup to the original,  having made the leap from 2D to 3D beautifully, and coming out better for it.  

Players should anticipate high paced gameplay, with a difficult learning curve, but intentionally exploitable difficulty.  Depending on the settings you utilize, you can modulate to your current skill level.  Expect standard roguelike shenanigans, with two hit KOs, and RNG deciding you just aren't going to have a good time.  

When a build clicks, the game's difficulty inverts on itself in that perfect way that leaves you feeling like a living god as you smite the enemies that would ruin you any other run.  

And the soundtrack is great.
my favorite roguelike, very fun and super satisfying to play

Among Us is a 2018 online multiplayer social deduction game developed and published by American game studio Innersloth. The game was inspired by the party game Mafia and the science fiction horror film The Thing. The game allows for cross-platform play, first released on iOS and Android devices in June 2018 and on Windows later that year in November. The game was then ported to the Nintendo Switch in December 2020, and on the PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One and Xbox Series X/S in December 2021. While the game was initially released in 2018 to little mainstream attention, it received a massive influx of popularity in 2020 due to many well-known Twitch streamers and YouTubers playing it. A separate VR version of the game, Among Us VR, will be released for Meta Quest 2, SteamVR, and PlayStation VR, developed by Schell Games.

Among Us takes place in a space-themed setting where players look like colorful armless cartoon astronauts; however, since the release of "The Skeld" spaceship, three other maps have been added in later years: the skyscraper "MIRA HQ", the "Polus" planetary station, and "The Airship" (based on Infiltrating the Airship from the Henry Stickmin series, also developed by Innersloth). Each player takes on one of two roles—most are Crewmates, but a small number play Impostors—which does not alter their appearance. The goal of the Crewmates is to either identify and vote out the Impostors, or to complete all the tasks around the map; the goal of the Impostors is to covertly sabotage the mission either by killing the Crewmates before they complete all their tasks or by triggering a disaster that is not resolved in time.

Probably the best roguelike I've ever played. Tons of fun alone and with friends. Seemingly infinite replay-ability. Great soundtrack. Great visual style. Lots of different ways to play with character variety, multiple abilities per character, difficulty settings and run-modifiers. Couldn't recommend this game enough. For this price, it's an absolute steal. Developers still support the game with content updates and there's a paid expansion coming adding more bosses, items, zones, playable characters, etc. A must have for fans of roguelikes!

Now I can see why people like this game so much. Not quite what I expected but very fun and addictive. Very hard at first and has a steep learning curve. Another game that makes me forget what time it is but not quite enough to become one of my top favorites of all time (definitely honorable mention worthy). I can tell I have only scratched the surface of what this game has to offer and even though the levels are a combo of handmade and randomly generated the playthroughs are different enough to not make me get bored easily. Thankfully each new character brings a whole new dynamic to the game or this would've been boring after 100-200 hours. Luckily there are many characters and each so far are like a whole new game in themselves. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes arcade style 3rd person combat and permadeath games. Honestly anyone who likes a bit of an adrenaline ride with no breaks (unless you pause) will probably love this game and it could easily become an instant favorite. The most annoying thing I can think about it is that there is very little explanation of the underlying bits and although it's probably on purpose it forces the person to either look up a guide and risk major spoilers or play completely blind (which I would recommend for any game like this). Hope you like it as much as I do and I will try to update the review once I get to 1k hours if I do (which I bet will happen in a year or more).

The best rogue like game of all time

Positive:

Gameplay 10/10: As simple as shooting, slashing, or bashing a variety of aliens that get gradually stronger and more numerous with time. Also, with unlockable characters, loadouts, skins, and endless stages, this game has a ton of replayability. 

graphics 10/10: This game has such a unique artstyle where it isn't throwing the good textures in your face like most games do.

Soundtrack 10/10: This games music might be more hardcore than Doom's, and this is DOOM we are talking about here. It is a great mix of epic and melancholy that just sort of blasts in the background while you commit genocide.

Humor 9/10: It may be few and far inbetween, but this game does have some pretty funny bits. especially some of the logbook entries.

Negative:

some of the sound effects can get a bit repetative. That is literally the only complaint.

Other notes:

Before the anniversary update, Mithrix was way too easy to exploit.

I don't care what kind of giant lizard-lava-bug-robot monsters this game wants to throw at me, the lesser wisps are the most annoying little pests in this entire game (This was written before sotv was released... did I just predict the blind pests???)

The one thing this game is missing is voice acting. that would be epic.

All of the logbook entries are great. ALL OF THEM. They range from goofy references to poetic lore paragraphs. The shurikens are canonically shipped to "Sensai Dareth's Mojo dojo". Wait... isn't that the guy from ninjago?? NINJAGO IS CANON IN ROR2 LETS GO!1!!!!!1!1!

Final score: 10/10

This game is my favorite rougelike, it has that brutally difficult feeling that comes with the genre but allows you to really go ham if you're good enough. In most rougelikes you can just kinda die due to bad luck, but this game gives you more than enough ways to build a kit the way you want it, without just letting you choose what items. The great thing about it is you can just get as many upgrades as possible, there is no inventory space, and no stack limit, but it's not as easy as just get everything you see because some upgrades are pretty much useless to some characters, and the lunar items give you an insane, game changing buff that changes a playstyle completely, but they are the only type of item that has a downside, so they are a really big risk (pun intended). and to top it off it has multiplayer, so get the game already.

This game deserves every praise it has and more. My first roguelite/like was Dead Cells. While I thoroughly enjoyed the game, I played it sporadically, jumping in for a run every now and then between other games. With RoR2, it took over and I ended up completing it in a few days. 

The gameplay is incredibly fun, it makes you want to have one more run after the last. Every character I've unlocked so far has been unique and none have felt underwhelming, although it does take a run or two to adjust your playstyle. Art, music, enemy design, levels, and any other metric you can think of to judge the game is top notch. 

And that final boss...

Well I refunded this game once! Back at the time when there wasn't much in there and almost all you had to do was running and shooting and picking up some occasional random drops that happened to be mostly useless! Don't want to be rude, but that's how it looked like about 2 years ago. So i decided to pick it up again and give it another go, but this time I stayed! Game not only kept calling to me "you need to break through all the way to the end", but also the taste of doing achievements took me all the way into another level.
Got to admit tho, when I picked it up I thought it was a procedural generation based dungeon crawler, but I was a bit put off when I reached the border of a zone and died to hazard! But the concept is still neat in my opinion and deserves attention.

This game is one of my absolute favorites, and is definitely my favorite Roguelite (or is it Roguelike?). There is so much to praise with this game; gameplay, replayability, challenge, soundtrack, visual style, et cetera.

I often play this game just to listen to the OST it is so good. The composer, Chris Christodoulou created what I consider a masterpiece OST. Combined with the game's visual style, Risk of Rain 2 can be a very relaxing and chill game to play, depending on what difficulty and Artifacts you play. 

Artifacts are game modifiers that you can permanently unlock by doing a certain challenge in a run, that can greatly differ gameplay. For example, there is one Artifact that makes you deal 500% more damage, but your health is capped at 10%. That Artifact is quite tame compared to some others, like one that makes your character change from level to level. With the game's three difficulties and plethora of Artifacts, and alternate gamemodes, the game can be tailored to your desired difficulty, and makes almost limitless replayability. 

All of these points are just about the game itself, but then there is also co-op multiplayer. You can play with random people online, though I never have, if that's your speed. You can also play with some buddies and bond over this amazing game. It can be fun to compete with friends over who gets the better build, who gets the best score in the end, or even who can afford that chest first to gain another item.

This game is worth every penny, and then some!

Great game. Haven't finished it yet, but it's just everything I want from a game like this. Every run will give you the opportunity to become overpowered in some way. It's Coop and moddable with friends. Great game.

I originally didn't see myself liking this game as I wasn't interested in typical rogue-likes where you die over and over with randomized levels and all that jazz. However, after playing it and experiencing it firsthand, my mind has totally been changed. Risk of Rain 2 has super satisfying controls, items, levels, music, they really went the distance. I can't really even point at a part of the game I don't like. Sometimes things happen in game that feel unfair, but that's just the experience and it still manages to feel fun even when insane things happen.

200 hours later, it's in the top 3 games I've ever played and I'm even considering doing cosplay for characters in the game. Even if you're the kind of person who dislikes this type of game, get Risk of Rain 2 anyway, I doubt you'll be disappointed.

Risk of Rain 2 is probably one of the most enjoyable and re-playable shooters on the market today. Each character feels incredibly unique and no two characters play exactly the same, making it almost impossible to not find a character you like.  and don't even get me started on the beautiful environments, great graphics and the truly phenomenal soundtrack to make sitting there playing it over and over again until your brain is just a puddle of rain water just that much more fun. and once you grab some friends (or just find a nice public server) and jump into multiplayer it adds a whole new feel to the gameplay, synergy and teamwork goes a long way especially when on the higher difficulties. all in all I'd give it a solid 10/10 since I haven't encountered any bugs and all the gameplay feels polished and crisp.

This game truly stands a cut above the rest. There's nothing quite like it that evokes the same feeling of exhilarating gameplay while also keeping you glued to your chair for hours. The gameplay is highly addictive, and although it can be stressful, it is very easy to slip into "the zone" and spend 3 hours in the blink of an eye. The soundtrack is simply phenomenal and worth the price of admission alone. The technical feat of getting a game like this to perform well even in the later stages when the screen is littered with mobs is pretty incredible. The developers should be very proud of this gem.

IM NEVER GOING TO STOP PLAYING ROR2 THIS GAME IS SO AWESOME

You ever been asked the question “which game could you play the rest of your life without getting bored?” Well, this is that game, at least for me. This game’s constant cycle of fear, struggle, overcoming odds and death always keeps me engaged. Gameplay is fast paced with constant engagement between searching and fighting. The items you get can make or break a run and you are always trying to balance your time buying and fighting. I wasn’t feeling the music at first, but over time it has grown on me, especially the Sky Meadows theme. I highly reccomend playing this on a call with friends. The absolute chaos that erupts from this game’s multiplayer is unlike anything I have ever experienced. At the time of writing the first DLC has been announced but not released, and it shows so much promise for the future. I will look forward to trying it out once it comes out. Thank you Hopoo for creating this, and please continue to support this indescribable experience.

If you liked Risk of Rain, getting Risk of Rain 2 should be a no-brainer. This is just more Risk of Rain for us to enjoy, polishing some details that were present on the first one, like not having to scour the entire map looking for the remaining enemies in order to proceed to the next stage, for example.

If you haven't played the original, this is a solo/coop rogue-lite arena kind of game, where you play as one of the available Survivors, each one with their own set of abilities, going from stage to stage defeating enemies to earn money in order to buy items that provide boosts and additional bonuses to your Survivor. The game works around time: as time passes, the enemies become stronger. The longer you play, the more fierce your enemies, and hopefully you, will be.

There's a lot to collect, including Survivors, Monster Logs, Stages' lore, items and artifacts, giving the game a lot of replayability. 

And of course, a soundtrack by Chris Christodoulou is always a blessing.

I will always recommend this game to anyone who asks me, and if you can gather up some friends to play it with, that's just an assured good time.
